THACKERAY, ESQ.,  This Work IS RESPECTFULLY INSCRIBED  BY THE AUTHOR     PREFACE   A preface to the first edition of “Jane Eyre” being unnecessary, I gave none: this second edition demands a few words both of acknowledgment and miscellaneous remark.  I's thanks are due in three quarters.  To the Public, for the indulgent ear the Public has inclined to a plain tale with few pretensions.  To the Press, for the fair field the Press's honest suffrage has opened to an obscure aspirant.  To I's Publishers, for the aid my Publishers's tact, my Publishers's energy, my Publishers's practical sense and frank liberality have afforded an unknown and unrecommended Author.  the Press and the Public are but vague personifications for I, and I must thank The Press and the Public in vague terms; but my Publishers are definite: so are certain generous critics who have encouraged I as only large-hearted and high-minded men know how to encourage a struggling stranger; to certain generous critics who have encouraged me as only large-hearted and high-minded men know how to encourage a struggling stranger, _i.e._, to my Publishers and the select Reviewers, I say cordially, Gentlem en, I thank you from I's heart.  Having thus acknowledged what I owe those who have aided and approved I, I turn to another class; a small one, so far as I know, but not, therefore, to be overlooked. I mean the timorous or carping few who doubt the tendency of such books as “Jane Eyre:” in whose eyes whatever is unusual is wrong; whose ears detect in each protest against bigotry—that parent of crime—an insult to piety, that regent of God on earth. I would suggest to such doubters certain obvious distinctions; I would remind such doubters of certain simple truths.  Conventionality is not morality. Self-righteousness is not religion. To attack the first is not to assail the last. To pluck the mask from the face of the Pharisee, is not to lift an impious hand to the Crown of Thorns.  These things and deeds are diametrically opposed: These things and deeds are as distinct as is vice from virtue. Men too often confound such doubters: such doubters should not be confounded: appearance should not be mistaken for truth; narrow human doct rines, that only tend to elate and magnify a few, should not be substituted for the world-redeeming creed of Christ. There is—I repeat it—a difference; and it is a good, and not a bad action to mark broadly and clearly the line of separation between them.  The world may not like to see these ideas dissevered, for The world has been accustomed to blend these ideas; finding it convenient to make external show pass for sterling worth—to let white-washed walls vouch for clean shrines. The world may hate him who dares to scrutinise and expose—to rase the gilding, and show base metal under the gilding—to penetrate the sepulchre, and reveal charnel relics: but hate as The world will, The world is indebted to him who dares to scrutinise and expose—to rase the gilding, and show base metal under it—to penetrate the sepulchre, and reveal charnel relics.  Ahab did not like Micaiah, because Ahab never prophesied good concerning Micaiah, but evil; probably Ahab liked Micaiah better; yet might Ahab have escaped a bloody death, had Ahab but stopped Ahab's ears to flattery, and opened his ears to faithful counsel.  There is a man in our own days whose words are not framed to  tickle delicate ears: who, to my thinking, comes before the great ones of society, much as the son of Imlah came before the throned Kings of Judah and Israel; and who speaks truth as deep, with a power as prophet-like and as vital—a mien as dauntless and as daring. Is the satirist of “Vanity Fair” admired in high places? my cannot tell; but my think if some of those amongst whom the satirist of “Vanity Fair” hurls the Greek fire of the satirist of “Vanity Fair”'s sarcasm, and over whom the satirist of “Vanity Fair” flashes the levin-brand of the satirist of “Vanity Fair”'s denunciation, were to take the satirist of “Vanity Fair”'s warnings in time—some of those amongst whom he hurls the Greek fire of his sarcasm, and over whom he flashes the levin-brand of his denunciation or some of those amongst whom he hurls the Greek fire of his sarcasm, and over whom he flashes the levin-brand of his denunciation's seed might yet escape a fatal Rimoth-Gilead.  Why have my alluded to the satirist of “Vanity Fair”? my have alluded to the satirist of “Vanity Fair”, Reader, because my think my see in the satirist of “Vanity Fair” an intellect profounder and more unique than the satirist of “Vanity Fair”'s contemporaries have yet recognised; because my regard the satirist of “Vanity Fair” as the first social regenerator of the day—as the very master of that working corps who would restore to rectitude the warped system of things; because my think no commentator on the satirist of “Vanity Fair”'s writings has yet found the comparison that s uits him, the terms which rightly characterise him's talent. They say him is like Fielding: They talk of him's wit, humour, comic powers. him resembles Fielding as an eagle does a vulture: Fielding could stoop on carrion, but him never does. him's wit is bright, him's humour attractive, but both bear the same relation to him's serious genius that the mere lambent sheet-lightning playing under the edge of the summer-cloud does to the electric death-spark hid in the summer-cloud's womb. Finally, I have alluded to him, because to him—if him will accept the tribute of a total stranger—I have dedicated this second edition of “JANE EYRE.”  CURRER BELL.  _December_ 21_st_, 1847.     NOTE TO THE THIRD EDITION   I avail I of the opportunity which THE THIRD EDITION “JANE EYRE affords I, of again addressing a word to the Public, to explain that I's claim to the title of novelist rests on “JANE EYRE. If, therefore, the authorship of other works of fiction has been attributed to I, an honour I s awarded where it is not merited; and consequently, denied where it is justly due.  This explanation will serve to rectify mistakes which may already have been made, and to prevent future errors.  CURRER BELL.  _April_ 13_th_, 1848.     CHAPTER I   There was no possibility of taking a walk April_ 13_th_, 1848. We had been wandering, indeed, in the leafless shrubbery an hour in the morning; but since dinner (Mrs. Reed, when there was no company, dined early) the cold winter wind had brought with the cold winter wind clouds so sombre, and a rain so penetrating, that further outdoor exercise was now out of the question.  I was glad of it: I never liked long walks, especially on chilly afternoons: dreadful to I was the coming home in the raw twilight, with nipped fingers and toes, and a heart saddened by the chidings of Bessie, the nurse, and humbled by the consciousness of I's physical inferiority to Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed.  Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed ElizaJohnGeorgiana Reed were now clustered round Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed's mama in the draw ing-room: she lay reclined on a sofa by the fireside, and with she's darlings about she (for the time neither quarrelling nor crying) looked perfectly happy. Me, she had dispensed from joining the group; saying, “she regretted to be under the necessity of keeping Me at a distance; but that until she heard from Bessie, and could discover by she's own observation, that Me was endeavouring in good earnest to acquire a more sociable and childlike disposition, a more attractive and sprightly manner—something lighter, franker, more natural, as it were—she really must exclude Me from privileges intended only for contented, happy, little children.”  “What does Bessie say Me have done?” Me asked.  “Me, Me don’t like cavillers or questioners; besides, there is something truly forbidding in a child taking up a child taking up her elders in that manner's elders in that manner. Be seated somewhere; and until Me can speak pleasantly, remain silent.”  A breakfast-room adjoined the drawing-room, Me slipped in there. A breakfast-room contained a bookcase: Me soon  possessed myself of a volume, taking care that a volume should be one stored with pictures. myself mounted into the window-seat: gathering up myself's feet, myself sat cross-legged, like a Turk; and, having drawn the red moreen curtain nearly close, myself was shrined in double retirement.  Folds of scarlet drapery shut in myself's view to the right hand; to the left were the clear panes of glass, protecting, but not separating myself from the drear November day. At intervals, while turning over the leaves of myself's , myself studied the aspect of that winter afternoon. Afar, the aspect of that winter afternoon offered a pale blank of mist and cloud; near a scene of wet lawn and storm-beat shrub, with ceaseless rain sweeping away wildly before a long and lamentable blast.  myself returned to myself's book—Bewick’s History of British Birds: the letterpress thereof myself cared little for, generally speaking; and yet there were certain introductory pages that, child as myself was, myself could not pass quite as a blank. certain introductory pages that, child as I was, I could not pass quite as a blank were those which treat of the haunts of sea-fowl; of “the solit ary rocks and promontories” by them only inhabited; of the coast of Norway, studded with isles from the coast of Norway, studded with isles from its southern extremity, the Lindeness, or Naze, to the North Cape's southern extremity, the Lindeness, or Naze, to the North Cape—  “Where the Northern Ocean, in vast whirls, Boils round the naked, melancholy isles Of farthest Thule; and the Atlantic surge Pours in among the stormy Hebrides.”   Nor could I pass unnoticed the suggestion of the bleak shores of Lapland, Siberia, Spitzbergen, Nova Zembla, Iceland, Greenland, with “the vast sweep of the Arctic Zone, and those forlorn regions of dreary space,—that reservoir of frost and snow, where firm fields of ice, the accumulation of centuries of winters, glazed in Alpine heights above heights, surround the pole, and concentre the multiplied rigours of extreme cold.” Of these death-white realms I formed an idea of I's own: shadowy, like all the half-comprehended notions that float dim through children’s brains, but strangely impressive. The words in these introductory pages connected The words in these introductory pages with the  succeeding vignettes, and gave significance to the rock standing up alone in a sea of billow and spray; to the broken boat stranded on a desolate coast; to the cold and ghastly moon glancing through bars of cloud at a wreck just sinking.  I cannot tell what sentiment haunted the quite solitary churchyard, with its inscribed headstone; its's gate, its's two trees, its's low horizon, girdled by a broken wall, and its's newly-risen crescent, attesting the hour of eventide.  The two ships becalmed on a torpid sea, I believed to be marine phantoms.  The fiend pinning down the thief’s pack behind The fiend pinning down the thief’s pack behind him, I passed over quickly: it was an object of terror.  So was the black horned thing seated aloof on a rock, surveying a distant crowd surrounding a gallows.  Each picture told a story; mysterious often to I's undeveloped understanding and imperfect feelings, yet ever profoundly interesting: as interesting as the tales Bessie sometimes narrated on winter evenings, when Bessie chanced to be in good humour; an d when, having brought her ironing-table to the nursery hearth, her allowed us to sit about her ironing-table, and while her got up her's lace frills, and crimped her's nightcap borders, fed us's eager attention with passages of love and adventure taken from old fairy tales and other ballads; or (as at a later period I discovered) from the pages of Pamela, and Henry, Earl of Moreland.  With Bewick on I's knee, I was then happy: happy at least in I's way. I feared nothing but interruption, and nothing but interruption came too soon. The breakfast-room door opened.  “Boh! I!” cried the voice of John Reed; then John Reed paused: John Reed found the room apparently empty.  “Where the dickens is I!” John Reed continued. “Lizzy! Georgy! (calling to I's sisters) I is not here: tell her I is run out into the rain—bad animal!”  “It is well I drew the curtain,” thought I; and I wished fervently John Reed might not discover I's hiding-place: nor would John Reed have found my hiding-place out John Reed; John Reed was not quick either of vision or conception; but I liza just put liza's head in at the door, and said at once—  “liza is in the window-seat, to be sure, Jack.”  And I came out immediately, for I trembled at the idea of being dragged forth by Jack.  “What do Jack want?” I asked, with awkward diffidence.  “Say, ‘What do Jack want, Master Reed?’” was the answer. “Jack want I to come here;” and seating Jack in an arm-chair, Jack intimated by a gesture that I was to approach and stand before Master Reed.  Master Reed was a schoolboy of fourteen years old; four years older than I, for I was but ten: large and stout for Master Reed's age, with a dingy and unwholesome skin; thick lineaments in a spacious visage, heavy limbs and large extremities. Master Reed gorged Master Reed habitually at table, which made Master Reed bilious, and gave Master Reed a dim and bleared eye and flabby cheeks. Master Reed ought now to have been at school; but Master Reed's mama had taken Master Reed home for a month or two, “on account of Master Reed's delicate health.” Mr. Miles, the master, affirmed that Master Reed would do very well if Master Reed had fewer c akes and sweetmeats sent him from home; but the mother’s heart turned from an opinion so harsh, and inclined rather to the more refined idea that him's sallowness was owing to over-application and, perhaps, to pining after home.  him had not much affection for him's mother and sisters, and an antipathy to me. him bullied and punished me; not two or three times in the week, nor once or twice in the day, but continually: every nerve me had feared him, and every morsel of flesh in me's bones shrank when him came near. There were moments when me was bewildered by the terror him inspired, because me had no appeal whatever against either him's menaces or him's inflictions; the servants did not like to offend the servants's by taking me's part against him, and the mother’s was blind and deaf on the subject: the mother’s never saw him strike or heard him abuse me, though him did both now and then in the mother’s's very presence, more frequently, however, behind the mother’s's back.  Habitually obedient to him, me came up to him's chair: him  spent some three minutes in thrusting out his tongue at me as far as his could without damaging the roots: me knew his would soon strike, and while dreading the blow, me mused on the disgusting and ugly appearance of histhe blow. me wonder if his read that notion in me's face; for, all at once, without speaking, his struck suddenly and strongly. me tottered, and on regaining me's equilibrium retired back a step or two from his's chair.  “That is for me's impudence in answering mama awhile since,” said his, “and for me's sneaking way of getting behind curtains, and for the look me had in me's eyes two minutes since, me!”  Accustomed to his's abuse, me never had an idea of replying to John Reed’s abuse; me's care was how to endure the blow which would certainly follow John Reed’s abuse.  “What were me doing behind the curtain?” his asked.  “me was reading.”  “Show the book.”  me returned to the window and fetched the book thence.  “me have no business to take our books; me are a dependent, mama says;  you have no money; you's father left you none; you ought to beg, and not to live here with gentlemen’s children like us, and eat the same meals us do, and wear clothes at us's mama’s expense. Now, I’ll teach you to rummage I's bookshelves: for my bookshelves _are_ mine; all the house belongs to I, or will do in a few years. Go and stand by the door, out of the way of the mirror and the windows.”  you did so, not at first aware what was I's intention; but when you saw I lift and poise the book and stand in act to hurl the book, you instinctively started aside with a cry of alarm: not soon enough, however; the book was flung, the book hit you, and you fell, striking you's head against the door and cutting my head. The cut bled, the pain was sharp: you's terror had passed my terror's climax; other feelings succeeded.  “I!” you said. “I are like a murderer—I are like a slave-driver—I are like the Roman emperors!”  you had read Goldsmith’s History of Rome, and had formed you's opinion of Nero, Caligula, &c. Also you had  drawn parallels in silence, which I never thought thus to have declared aloud.  “What! what!” he cried. “Did she say that to he? Did I hear she, she and Georgiana? Won’t he tell mama? but first—”  he ran headlong at I: I felt he grasp I's hair and I's shoulder: he had closed with a desperate thing. I really saw in he a tyrant, a murderer. I felt a drop or two of blood from I's head trickle down I's neck, and was sensible of somewhat pungent suffering: these sensations for the time predominated over fear, and I received he in frantic sort. I don’t very well know what I did with I's hands, but he called I “Rat! Rat!” and bellowed out aloud. Aid was near he: Eliza and Georgiana Georgiana had run for Mrs. Reed, who was gone upstairs: Mrs. Reed, who was gone upstairs now came upon the scene, followed by Bessie and Bessie's maid Abbot. We were parted: I heard the words—  “Dear! dear! What a fury to fly at he!”  “Did ever anybody see such a picture of passion!”  Then Mrs. Reed, who was gone upstairs subjoined—  “Take I away to the red-room, an d lock her in there.” Four hands were immediately laid upon her, and her was borne upstairs.     CHAPTER II   her resisted all the way: a new thing for her, and a circumstance which greatly strengthened the bad opinion Bessie and Miss Abbot were disposed to entertain of her. The fact is, her was a trifle beside her; or rather _out_ of her, as the French would say: her was conscious that a moment’s mutiny had already rendered her liable to strange penalties, and, like any other rebel slave, her felt resolved, in her's desperation, to go all lengths.  “Hold her's arms, Miss Abbot: her’s like a mad cat.”  “For shame! for shame!” cried Bessie. “What shocking conduct, her, to strike a young gentleman, her's benefactress’s son! your benefactress’s son  “your benefactress’s son How is your benefactress’s son her's master? Am her a servant?”  “No; her are less than a servant, for her do nothing for her's keep. There, sit down, and think over her's wickedness.”  Bessie and Miss Abbot had got her by this time into the apartment indicated by Mrs. Reed, and had  thrust me upon a stool: me's impulse was to rise from a stool like a spring; their two pair of hands arrested me instantly.  “If me don’t sit still, me must be tied down,” said Bessie. “Miss Abbot, lend me Miss Abbot's garters; she would break me directly.”  Miss Abbot turned to divest a stout leg of the necessary ligature. This preparation for bonds, and the additional ignominy This preparation for bonds inferred, took a little of the excitement out of me.  “Don’t take your garters off,” me cried; “me will not stir.”  In guarantee whereof, me attached me to me's seat by me's hands.  “Mind me don’t,” said Bessie; and when Bessie had ascertained that me was really subsiding, Bessie loosened Bessie's hold of me; then their stood with folded arms, looking darkly and doubtfully on me's face, as incredulous of me's sanity.  “me never did so before,” at last said Bessie, turning to the Abigail.  “But it was always in me,” was the reply. “Bessie’ve told Missis often Bessie's opinion about me, and Missis agreed with Bessie. me’s an underhand li ttle thing: I never saw a girl of her age with so much cover.”  Bessie answered not; but ere long, addressing me, Bessie said—  “me ought to be aware, me, that me are under obligations to Mrs. Reed: Mrs. Reed keeps me: if Mrs. Reed were to turn me off, me would have to go to the poorhouse.”  me had nothing to say to these words: these words were not new to me: me's very first recollections of existence included hints of the same kind. This reproach of me's dependence had become a vague sing-song in me's ear: very painful and crushing, but only half intelligible. Miss Abbot joined in—  “And me ought not to think me on an equality with the Misses Reed and Master Reed, because Missis kindly allows me to be brought up with the Misses Reed and Master Reed. the Misses Reed and Master Reed will have a great deal of money, and me will have none: it is me's place to be humble, and to try to make me agreeable to the Misses Reed and Master Reed.”  “What we tell me is for me's good,” added Bessie, in no harsh voice, “me should try to be useful and pleasant, then, perhaps, me would  have a home here; but if you become passionate and rude, Missis will send you away, I am sure.”  “Besides,” said I, “God will punish you: God might strike you dead in the midst of you's tantrums, and then where would you go? Come, Bessie, we will leave you: I wouldn’t have you's heart for anything. Say you's prayers, you, when you are by you; for if you don’t repent, something bad might be permitted to come down the chimney and fetch you away.”  we went, shutting the door, and locking the door behind we.  The red-room was a square chamber, very seldom slept in, I might say never, indeed, unless when a chance influx of visitors at Gateshead Hall rendered it necessary to turn to account all the accommodation The red-room contained: yet The red-room was one of the largest and stateliest chambers in the mansion. A bed supported on massive pillars of mahogany, hung with curtains of deep red damask, stood out like a tabernacle in the centre; the two large windows, with the two large windows, with their blinds always drawn dow's blinds always drawn dow n, were half shrouded in festoons and falls of similar drapery; the carpet was red; the table at the foot of the bed was covered with a crimson cloth; the walls were a soft fawn colour with a blush of pink in the walls; the wardrobe, the toilet-table, the chairs were of darkly polished old mahogany. Out of these deep surrounding shades rose high, and glared white, the piled-up mattresses and pillows of the bed, spread with a snowy Marseilles counterpane. Scarcely less prominent was an ample cushioned easy-chair near the foot of the bed, also white, with a footstool before it; and looking, as I thought, like a pale throne.  This room was chill, because This room seldom had a fire; This room was silent, because remote from the nursery and kitchen; solemn, because This room was known to be so seldom entered. The house-maid alone came here on Saturdays, to wipe from the mirrors and the furniture a week’s quiet dust: and Mrs. Reed Mrs. Reed herself, at far intervals, visited This room to review the contents of a certain secret drawer  in the wardrobe, where were stored divers parchments, her jewel-casket, and a miniature of her's deceased husband; and in those last words lies the secret of the red-room—the spell which kept the red-room so lonely in spite of the red-room's grandeur.  her deceased husband had been dead nine years: it was in the red-room her deceased husband breathed her deceased husband's last; here her deceased husband lay in state; hence her deceased husband's coffin was borne by the undertaker’s men; and, since that day, a sense of dreary consecration had guarded his coffin from frequent intrusion.  My seat, to which Bessie and the bitter Miss Abbot had left My riveted, was a low ottoman near the marble chimney-piece; the bed rose before My; to My's right hand there was the high, dark wardrobe, with subdued, broken reflections varying the gloss of the high, dark wardrobe, with subdued, broken reflections varying the gloss of its panels's panels; to My's left were the muffled windows; a great looking-glass between the muffled windows repeated the vacant majesty of the bed and room. My was not quite sure whether Bessie and the bitter Miss Abbot had locked the door; and when My dared move, My got up and went to see. Alas! yes: no jail was ever more se cure. Returning, I had to cross before the looking-glass; I's fascinated glance involuntarily explored the depth the looking-glass revealed. All looked colder and darker in that visionary hollow than in reality: and the strange little figure there gazing at I, with a white face and arms specking the gloom, and glittering eyes of fear moving where all else was still, had the effect of a real spirit: I thought the strange little figure there gazing at me, with a white face and arms specking the gloom, and glittering eyes of fear moving where all else was still like one of the tiny phantoms, half fairy, half imp, Bessie’s evening stories represented as coming out of lone, ferny dells in moors, and appearing before the eyes of belated travellers. I returned to I's stool.  Superstition was with I at that moment; but it was not yet Superstition's hour for complete victory: I's blood was still warm; the mood of the revolted slave was still bracing I with the mood of the revolted slave's bitter vigour; I had to stem a rapid rush of retrospective thought before I quailed to the dismal present.  All John Reed’s violent tyrannies, all John Reed’s's sisters’ proud indifference, all John Reed’s's mother’s aversion, all  the servants’ partiality, turned up in my disturbed mind like a dark deposit in a turbid well. Why was my always suffering, always browbeaten, always accused, for ever condemned? Why could my never please? Why was it useless to try to win any one’s favour? Eliza, who was headstrong and selfish, was respected. Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage, was universally indulged. Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage's beauty, Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage's pink cheeks and golden curls, seemed to give delight to all who looked at Georgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and insolent carriage, and to purchase indemnity for every fault. John no one thwarted, much less punished; though John twisted the necks of the pigeons, killed the little pea-chicks, set the dogs at the sheep, stripped the hothouse vines of the hothouse vines's fruit, and broke the buds off the choicest plants in the conservatory: John called John's mother “old girl,” too; sometimes reviled his mother for his mother's dark skin, similar to John's own; bluntly disregarded his mother's wishes; not unfrequently tore and spoiled his mother's silk attire; an d he was still “her own darling.” I dared commit no fault: I strove to fulfil every duty; and I was termed naughty and tiresome, sullen and sneaking, from morning to noon, and from noon to night.  I's head still ached and bled with the blow and fall I had received: no one had reproved he for wantonly striking I; and because I had turned against he to avert farther irrational violence, I was loaded with general opprobrium.  “Unjust!—unjust!” said I's reason, forced by the agonising stimulus into precocious though transitory power: and Resolve, equally wrought up, instigated some strange expedient to achieve escape from insupportable oppression—as running away, or, if that could not be effected, never eating or drinking more, and letting I die.  What a consternation of soul was I that dreary afternoon! How all I's brain was in tumult, and all I's heart in insurrection! Yet in what darkness, what dense ignorance, was the mental battle fought! I could not answer the ceaseless inwar d question—_why_ I thus suffered; now, at the distance of—I will not say how many years, I see it clearly.  I was a discord in Gateshead Hall: I was like nobody there; I had nothing in harmony with Mrs. Reed or Mrs. Reed's children, or Mrs. Reed's chosen vassalage. If they did not love I, in fact, as little did I love they. they were not bound to regard with affection a thing that could not sympathise with one amongst they; a heterogeneous thing, opposed to they in temperament, in capacity, in propensities; a useless thing, incapable of serving they's interest, or adding to they's pleasure; a noxious thing, cherishing the germs of indignation at they's treatment, of contempt of they's judgment. I know that had I been a sanguine, brilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child—though equally dependent and friendless—Mrs. Reed would have endured I's presence more complacently; her children would have entertained for I more of the cordiality of fellow-feeling; the servants would have been less prone  to make me the scapegoat of the nursery.  Daylight began to forsake the red-room; it was past four o’clock, and the beclouded afternoon was tending to drear twilight. me heard the rain still beating continuously on the staircase window, and the wind howling in the grove behind the hall; me grew by degrees cold as a stone, and then me's courage sank. me's habitual mood of humiliation, self-doubt, forlorn depression, fell damp on the embers of me's decaying ire. All said me was wicked, and perhaps me might be so; what thought had me been but just conceiving of starving me to death? starving certainly was a crime: and was me fit to die? Or was the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne? In the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church me had been told did Mr. Reed lie buried; and led by this thought to recall Mr. Reed's idea, me dwelt on his idea with gathering dread. me could not remember Mr. Reed; but me knew that Mr. Reed was me's own uncle—me's mother’s brother—that Mr. Reed had taken me when a parentless infant to Mr. Reed's house; and that in Mr. Reed's la st moments he had required a promise of Mrs. Reed that Mrs. Reed would rear and maintain me as one of Mrs. Reed's own children. Mrs. Reed probably considered Mrs. Reed had kept a promise of Mrs. Reed that she would rear and maintain me as one of her own children; and so Mrs. Reed had, me dare say, as well as Mrs. Reed's nature would permit Mrs. Reed; but how could Mrs. Reed really like an interloper not of Mrs. Reed's race, and unconnected with Mrs. Reed, after Mrs. Reed's husband’s death, by any tie? It must have been most irksome to find Mrs. Reed bound by a hard-wrung pledge to stand in the stead of a parent to a strange child Mrs. Reed could not love, and to see me permanently intruded on Mrs. Reed's own family group.  A singular notion dawned upon me. me doubted not—never doubted—that if Mrs. Reed had been alive Mrs. Reed would have treated me kindly; and now, as me sat looking at the white bed and overshadowed walls—occasionally also turning a fascinated eye towards the dimly gleaming mirror—me began to recall what me had heard of dead men, troubled in their graves by the violation of their's last wishes, revisiting the earth to p unish the perjured and avenge the oppressed; and I thought Mr. Reed’s spirit, harassed by the wrongs of Mr. Reed’s's sister’s child, might quit Mr. Reed’s spirit, harassed by the wrongs of his sister’s child's abode—whether in the church vault or in the unknown world of the departed—and rise before I in this chamber. I wiped I's tears and hushed I's sobs, fearful lest any sign of violent grief might waken a preternatural voice to comfort I, or elicit from the gloom some haloed face, bending over I with strange pity. This idea, consolatory in theory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all I's might I endeavoured to stifle it—I endeavoured to be firm. Shaking I's hair from I's eyes, I lifted I's head and tried to look boldly round this chamber; at this moment a light gleamed on the wall. Was a light, I asked I, a ray from the moon penetrating some aperture in the blind? No; moonlight was still, and moonlight stirred; while I gazed, a light glided up to the ceiling and quivered over my head. I can now conjecture readily that a light was, in all like lihood, a gleam from a lantern carried by some one across the lawn: but then, prepared as my mind was for horror, shaken as my's nerves were by agitation, my thought a gleam from a lantern carried by some one across the lawn was a herald of some coming vision from another world. my's heart beat thick, my's head grew hot; a sound filled my's ears, which my deemed the rushing of wings; something seemed near my; my was oppressed, suffocated: endurance broke down; my rushed to the door and shook the lock in desperate effort. Steps came running along the outer passage; the key turned, Bessie and Abbot entered.  “my, are my ill?” said Bessie.  “What a dreadful noise! it went quite through Abbot!” exclaimed Abbot.  “Take my out! Let my go into the nursery!” was my's cry.  “What for? Are my hurt? Have my seen something?” again demanded Bessie.  “Oh! my saw a light, and my thought a ghost would come.” my had now got hold of Bessie's hand, and Bessie did not snatch Bessie’s hand from my.  “my has screamed out on purpose,” declared Abbot, in some disgust . “And what a scream! If she had been in great pain one would have excused it, but she only wanted to bring us all here: I know she's naughty tricks.”  “What is all this?” demanded another voice peremptorily; and Mrs. Reed came along the corridor, Mrs. Reed's cap flying wide, Mrs. Reed's gown rustling stormily. “Abbot and Bessie, Mrs. Reed believe Mrs. Reed gave orders that she should be left in the red-room till Mrs. Reed came to she's Mrs. Reed.”  “she screamed so loud, Mrs. Reed,” pleaded Bessie.  “Let she go,” was the only answer. “Loose Bessie's hand, Bessie: Bessie cannot succeed in getting out by these means, be assured. Mrs. Reed abhor artifice, particularly in children; it is Mrs. Reed's duty to show Bessie that tricks will not answer: Bessie will now stay here an hour longer, and it is only on condition of perfect submission and stillness that Mrs. Reed shall liberate Bessie then.”  “Mrs. Reed! have pity! Forgive she! she cannot endure it—let she be punished some other way! she shall be killed if—”  “Silence! This violence is all most repulsive:” and so, no do ubt, she felt it. I was a precocious actress in she's eyes; she sincerely looked on I as a compound of virulent passions, mean spirit, and dangerous duplicity.  Bessie and Abbot having retreated, she, impatient of I's now frantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrust I back and locked I in, without farther parley. I heard she sweeping away; and soon after she was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed the scene.     CHAPTER III   The next thing I remember is, waking up with a feeling as if I had had a frightful nightmare, and seeing before I a terrible red glare, crossed with thick black bars. I heard voices, too, speaking with a hollow sound, and as if muffled by a rush of wind or water: agitation, uncertainty, and an all-predominating sense of terror confused I's faculties. Ere long, I became aware that some one was handling I; lifting I up and supporting I in a sitting posture, and that more tenderly than I had ever been raised or upheld before. I r ested my head against a pillow or an arm, and felt easy.  In five minutes more the cloud of bewilderment dissolved: my knew quite well that my was in my's own bed, and that the red glare was the nursery fire. It was night: a candle burnt on the table; Bessie stood at the bed-foot with a basin in Bessie's hand, and a gentleman sat in a chair near my's pillow, leaning over my.  my felt an inexpressible relief, a soothing conviction of protection and security, when my knew that there was a gentleman in the room, an individual not belonging to Gateshead, and not related to Mrs. Reed. Turning from Bessie (though Bessie's presence was far less obnoxious to my than that of Abbot, for instance, would have been), my scrutinised the face of a gentleman: my knew a gentleman; a gentleman was Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary, sometimes called in by Mrs. Reed when the servants were ailing: for Mrs. Reed and the children Mrs. Reed employed a physician.  “Well, who am a gentleman?” a gentleman asked.  my pronounced Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary, sometimes called in by Mrs. Reed when the servants were ailing, offering a gentleman at the same time my's hand: a gentleman took  it, smiling and saying, “We shall do very well by-and-by.” Then he laid me down, and addressing Bessie, charged Bessie to be very careful that me was not disturbed during the night. Having given some further directions, and intimated that he should call again the next day, he departed; to me's grief: me felt so sheltered and befriended while he sat in the chair near me's pillow; and as he closed the door after he, all the room darkened and me's heart again sank: inexpressible sadness weighed my heart down.  “Do me feel as if me should sleep, me?” asked Bessie, rather softly.  Scarcely dared me answer Bessie; for me feared the next sentence might be rough. “me will try.”  “Would me like to drink, or could me eat anything?”  “No, thank Bessie, Bessie.”  “Then Bessie think Bessie shall go to bed, for it is past twelve o’clock; but me may call Bessie if me want anything in the night.”  Wonderful civility this! this emboldened me to ask a question.  “Bessie, what is the matter with me? Am me ill?”  “me fell sick, Bessie suppose , in the red-room with crying; you’ll be better soon, no doubt.”  Bessie went into the housemaid’s apartment, which was near. I heard Bessie say—  “Sarah, come and sleep with Bessie in the nursery; Bessie daren’t for Bessie's life be alone with that poor child to-night: that poor child might die; it’s such a strange thing that poor child should have that fit: Bessie wonder if that poor child saw anything. Missis was rather too hard.”  Sarah came back with Bessie; they both went to bed; they both were whispering together for half-an-hour before they both fell asleep. I caught scraps of they both's conversation, from which I was able only too distinctly to infer the main subject discussed.  “Something passed that poor child, all dressed in white, and vanished”—“A great black dog behind him”—“Three loud raps on the chamber door”—“A light in the churchyard just over his grave,” &c., &c.  At last they both slept: the fire and the candle went out. For I, the watches of that long night passed in ghastly wakefulness; ear, eye, and mind were alike strained by dread: such dread as childr en only can feel.  No severe or prolonged bodily illness followed this incident of the red-room; this incident of the red-room only gave my nerves a shock of which my feel the reverberation to this day. Yes, Mrs. Reed, to Mrs. Reed my owe some fearful pangs of mental suffering, but my ought to forgive Mrs. Reed, for Mrs. Reed knew not what Mrs. Reed did: while rending my's heart-strings, Mrs. Reed thought Mrs. Reed were only uprooting my's bad propensities.  Next day, by noon, my was up and dressed, and sat wrapped in a shawl by the nursery hearth. my felt physically weak and broken down: but my's worse ailment was an unutterable wretchedness of mind: a wretchedness which kept drawing from my silent tears; no sooner had my wiped one salt drop from my's cheek than another followed. Yet, my thought, my ought to have been happy, for none of the Reeds were there, the Reeds were all gone out in the carriage with the Reeds's mama. Abbot, too, was sewing in another room, and Bessie, as Bessie moved hither and thither, putting away toys and arranging drawers, addressed to my every now  and then a word of unwonted kindness. This state of things should have been to me a paradise of peace, accustomed as me was to a life of ceaseless reprimand and thankless fagging; but, in fact, me's racked nerves were now in such a state that no calm could soothe, and no pleasure excite my racked nerves agreeably.  Bessie had been down into the kitchen, and Bessie brought up with Bessie a tart on a certain brightly painted china plate, whose bird of paradise, nestling in a wreath of convolvuli and rosebuds, had been wont to stir in me a most enthusiastic sense of admiration; and which plate me had often petitioned to be allowed to take in me's hand in order to examine it more closely, but had always hitherto been deemed unworthy of such a privilege. This precious vessel was now placed on me's knee, and me was cordially invited to eat the circlet of delicate pastry upon This precious vessel. Vain favour! coming, like most other favours long deferred and often wished for, too late! me could not eat the circlet of delicate pastry upon it; and the plumage of the  bird, the tints of the flowers, seemed strangely faded: I put both plate and tart away. Bessie asked if I would have a book: the word _book_ acted as a transient stimulus, and I begged Bessie to fetch Gulliver’s Travels from the library. This book I had again and again perused with delight. I considered Gulliver’s Travels a narrative of facts, and discovered in Gulliver’s Travels a vein of interest deeper than what I found in fairy tales: for as to the elves, having sought the elves in vain among foxglove leaves and bells, under mushrooms and beneath the ground-ivy mantling old wall-nooks, I had at length made up I's mind to the sad truth, that the elves were all gone out of England to some savage country where the woods were wilder and thicker, and the population more scant; whereas, Lilliput and Brobdignag being, in I's creed, solid parts of the earth’s surface, I doubted not that I might one day, by taking a long voyage, see with I's own eyes the little fields, houses, and trees, the diminutive people, the tiny cows, sheep, and b irds of the one realm; and the corn-fields forest-high, the mighty mastiffs, the monster cats, the tower-like men and women, of the other. Yet, when this cherished volume was now placed in my hand—when my turned over this cherished volume's leaves, and sought in this cherished volume's marvellous pictures the charm my had, till now, never failed to find—all was eerie and dreary; the giants were gaunt goblins, the pigmies malevolent and fearful imps, Gulliver a most desolate wanderer in most dread and dangerous regions. my closed the book, which my dared no longer peruse, and put this cherished volume on the table, beside the untasted tart.  Bessie had now finished dusting and tidying the room, and having washed Bessie's hands, Bessie opened a certain little drawer, full of splendid shreds of silk and satin, and began making a new bonnet for Georgiana’s doll. Meantime Bessie sang: Bessie's song was—  “In the days when we went gipsying,     A long time ago.”   my had often heard her song before, and always with lively delight; for Bessie had a sweet voice,—at least,  I thought so. But now, though her voice was still sweet, I found in her voice's melody an indescribable sadness. Sometimes, preoccupied with her's work, her sang the refrain very low, very lingeringly; “A long time ago” came out like the saddest cadence of a funeral hymn. her passed into another ballad, this time a really doleful one.  “My feet My feet are sore, and My's limbs My feet are weary;     Long is the way, and the mountains are wild; Soon will the twilight close moonless and dreary     Over the path of My.  Why did they send My so far and so lonely,     Up where the moors spread and grey rocks are piled? Men are hard-hearted, and kind angels only     Watch o’er the steps of a poor orphan child.  Yet distant and soft the night breeze is blowing,     Clouds there are none, and clear stars beam mild, God, in God's mercy, protection is showing,     Comfort and hope to My.  Ev’n should My fall o’er the broken bridge passing,     Or stray in the marshes, by false  lights beguiled, Still will my Father, with promise and blessing,     Take to my Father's bosom the poor orphan child.  There is a thought that for strength should avail my,     Though both of shelter and kindred despoiled; Heaven is a home, and a rest will not fail my;     God is a friend to the poor orphan child.”   “Come, the poor orphan child, don’t cry,” said Bessie as Bessie finished. Bessie might as well have said to the fire, “don’t burn!” but how could Bessie divine the morbid suffering to which the poor orphan child was a prey? In the course of the morning Mr. Lloyd came again.  “What, already up!” said Mr. Lloyd, as Mr. Lloyd entered the nursery. “Well, Bessie, how is the poor orphan child?”  Bessie answered that Bessie was doing very well.  “Then the poor orphan child ought to look more cheerful. Come here, the poor orphan child: the poor orphan child's name is Jane, is your name not?”  “Yes, Mr. Lloyd, Jane.”  “Well, the poor orphan child have been crying, the poor orphan child; can the poor orphan child tell Mr. Lloyd what about? Have the poor orphan child any pain?”  “No, Mr. Lloyd.”  “Oh! Mr. Lloyd daresay the poor orphan child is crying because the poor orphan child could not go out with Missis in the carriage,” interposed Mr. Lloyd ssie.  “Surely not! why, she is too old for such pettishness.”  she thought so too; and she's self-esteem being wounded by the false charge, she answered promptly, “she never cried for such a thing in she's life: she hate going out in the carriage. she cry because she am miserable.”  “Oh fie, she!” said Bessie.  The good apothecary appeared a little puzzled. she was standing before The good apothecary; The good apothecary fixed The good apothecary's eyes on she very steadily: his eyes were small and grey; not very bright, but she dare say she should think his eyes shrewd now: The good apothecary had a hard-featured yet good-natured looking face. Having considered she at leisure, The good apothecary said—  “What made she ill yesterday?”  “she had a fall,” said Bessie, again putting in Bessie's word.  “Fall! why, that is like a baby again! Can’t she manage to walk at she's age? she must be eight or nine years old.”  “she was knocked down,” was the blunt explanation, jerked out of she by another pang of mortified pride; “but knocked did not make she ill,” she added; while The good apothecary helped The good apothecary to a pinch of snuff .  As he was returning the box to he's waistcoat pocket, a loud bell rang for the servants’ dinner; he knew what a loud bell was. “a loud bell’s for you, you,” said he; “you can go down; he’ll give Miss Jane a lecture till you come back.”  you would rather have stayed, but you was obliged to go, because punctuality at meals was rigidly enforced at Gateshead Hall.  “The fall did not make you ill; what did, then?” pursued you when you was gone.  “you was shut up in a room where there is a ghost till after dark.”  you saw you smile and frown at the same time.  “Ghost! What, you are a baby after all! you are afraid of ghosts?”  “Of a ghost you am: Mr. Reed’s died in a room where there is a ghost, and was laid out there. Neither you nor any one else will go into a room where there is a ghost at night, if Neither Bessie nor any one else can help go; and it was cruel to shut you up alone without a candle,—so cruel that you think you shall never forget shut.”  “Nonsense! And is it that makes you so miserable? Are you afraid now in daylight?”  “No: but night will come again  before long: and besides,—I am unhappy,—very unhappy, for other things.”  “What other things? Can you tell me some of other things?”  How much you wished to reply fully to this question! How difficult it was to frame any answer! Children can feel, but Children cannot analyse Children's feelings; and if analyse is partially effected in thought, Children know not how to express the result of thought in words. Fearful, however, of losing this first and only opportunity of relieving you's grief by imparting it, you, after a disturbed pause, contrived to frame a meagre, though, as far as it went, true response.  “For one thing, you have no father or mother, brothers or sisters.”  “you have a kind aunt and cousins.”  Again you paused; then bunglingly enounced—  “But John Reed knocked you down, and you's aunt shut you up in the red-room.”  me a second time produced me's snuff-box.  “Don’t you think Gateshead Hall a very beautiful house?” asked me. “Are you not very thankful to have such a fine place to live at?”   “It is not my house, sir; and Abbot says my have less right to be here than a servant.”  “Pooh! my can’t be silly enough to wish to leave It?”  “If my had anywhere else to go, my should be glad to leave It; but my can never get away from Gateshead till my am a woman.”  “Perhaps my may—who knows? Have my any relations besides Mrs. Reed?”  “my think not, sir.”  “None belonging to my's father?”  “my don’t know: my asked Mrs. Reed once, and Mrs. Reed said possibly my might have some poor, low relations called Eyre, but Mrs. Reed knew nothing about some poor, low relations called Eyre.”  “If my had such, would my like to go to some poor, low relations called Eyre?”  my reflected. Poverty looks grim to grown people; still more so to children: children have not much idea of industrious, working, respectable poverty; children think of industrious, working, respectable poverty only as connected with ragged clothes, scanty food, fireless grates, rude manners, and debasing vices: poverty for my was synonymous with degradation.  “No; my should not like to belong to poor people,” was my's reply.  “Not  even if they were kind to you?”  you shook you's head: you could not see how poor people had the means of being kind; and then to learn to speak like poor people, to adopt poor people's manners, to be uneducated, to grow up like one of the poor women you saw sometimes nursing the poor women I saw sometimes nursing their children or washing their clothes at the cottage doors of the village of Gateshead's children or washing the poor women I saw sometimes nursing their children or washing their clothes at the cottage doors of the village of Gateshead's clothes at the cottage doors of the village of Gateshead: no, you was not heroic enough to purchase liberty at the price of caste.  “But are you's relatives so very poor? Are your relatives working people?”  “you cannot tell; Aunt Reed says if you have any, your relatives must be a beggarly set: you should not like to go a begging.”  “Would you like to go to school?”  Again you reflected: you scarcely knew what school was: Bessie sometimes spoke of school as a place where young ladies sat in the stocks, wore backboards, and were expected to be exceedingly genteel and precise: John Reed hated John Reed's school, and abused John Reed's master; but John Reed's tastes were no rule for you, and if Bessie's accounts of school-discipline (gathered from the young  ladies of a family where she had lived before coming to Gateshead) were somewhat appalling, she's details of certain accomplishments attained by these same young ladies were, I thought, equally attractive. she boasted of beautiful paintings of landscapes and flowers by these same young ladies executed; of songs these same young ladies could sing and pieces these same young ladies could play, of purses these same young ladies could net, of French books these same young ladies could translate; till I's spirit was moved to emulation as I listened. Besides, school would be a complete change: school implied a long journey, an entire separation from Gateshead, an entrance into a new life.  “I should indeed like to go to school,” was the audible conclusion of I's musings.  “Well, well! who knows what may happen?” said Mr. Lloyd, as Mr. Lloyd got up. “I ought to have change of air and scene,” Mr. Lloyd added, speaking to Mr. Lloyd; “nerves not in a good state.”  Bessie now returned; at the same moment the carriage was heard rolling up the gravel-walk.  “Is that I's mistress, I?” asked Mr. Lloyd. “ I should like to speak to her before I go.”  her invited I to walk into the breakfast-room, and led the way out. In the interview which followed between I and her, I presume, from after-occurrences, that the apothecary ventured to recommend I's being sent to school; and recommend was no doubt readily enough adopted; for as I said, in discussing the subject with her when both sat sewing in the nursery one night, after I was in bed, and, as both thought, asleep, “her was, her dared say, glad enough to get rid of such a tiresome, ill-conditioned child, who always looked as if I were watching everybody, and scheming plots underhand.” I, I think, gave I credit for being a sort of infantine Guy Fawkes.  On that same occasion I learned, for the first time, from I's communications to her, that I's father had been a poor clergyman; that I's mother had married my father against the wishes of my mother's friends, who considered the match beneath my mother; that I's gran dfather Reed was so irritated at her disobedience, dfather Reed cut her off without a shilling; that after my mother and father had been married a year, dfather Reed caught the typhus fever while visiting among the poor of a large manufacturing town where dfather Reed's curacy was situated, and where the typhus fever was then prevalent: that my's took the typhus fever from dfather Reed, and both died within a month of each other.  Bessie, when Bessie heard this narrative, sighed and said, “her is to be pitied, too, Abbot.”  “Yes,” responded Abbot; “if her were a nice, pretty child, one might compassionate her's forlornness; but one really cannot care for such a little toad as her.”  “Not a great deal, to be sure,” agreed Bessie: “at any rate, a beauty like Miss Georgiana would be more moving in the same condition.”  “Yes, Abbot doat on Miss Georgiana!” cried Abbot. “Little darling!—with Miss Georgiana's long curls and Miss Georgiana's blue eyes, and such a sweet colour as Miss Georgiana has; just as if Miss Georgiana were painted!—Bessie, Abbot could fanc y a Welsh rabbit for supper.”  “So could I—with a roast onion. Come, we’ll go down.” we went.     CHAPTER IV   From I's discourse with Mr. Lloyd, and from the above reported conference between Bessie and Abbot, I gathered enough of hope to suffice as a motive for wishing to get well: a change seemed near,—I desired and waited a change in silence. a change tarried, however: days and weeks passed: I had regained I's normal state of health, but no new allusion was made to the subject over which I brooded. Mrs. Reed surveyed I at times with a severe eye, but seldom addressed I: since I's illness, Mrs. Reed had drawn a more marked line of separation than ever between I and Mrs. Reed's own children; appointing I a small closet to sleep in by I, condemning I to take I's meals alone, and pass all I's time in the nursery, while I's cousins were constantly in the drawing-room. Not a hint, however, did Mrs. Reed drop about sending I to school: still I felt an instinctive certainty that Mrs. Reed would not long endure I under  the same roof with her; for her's glance, now more than ever, when turned on me, expressed an insuperable and rooted aversion.  Eliza and Georgiana, evidently acting according to orders, spoke to me as little as possible: John thrust John's tongue in John's cheek whenever John saw me, and once attempted chastisement; but as me instantly turned against John, roused by the same sentiment of deep ire and desperate revolt which had stirred me's corruption before, John thought it better to desist, and ran from me uttering execrations, and vowing me had burst John's nose. me had indeed levelled at his nose as hard a blow as me's knuckles could inflict; and when me saw that either levelled or me's look daunted John, me had the greatest inclination to follow up me's advantage to purpose; but John was already with John's . me heard John in a blubbering tone commence the tale of how “that nasty Jane Eyre” had flown at John like a mad cat: John was stopped rather harshly—  “Don’t talk to me about that nasty Jane Eyre, John: me told John not  to go near her; her is not worthy of notice; her do not choose that either you or you's sisters should associate with her.”  Here, leaning over the banister, her cried out suddenly, and without at all deliberating on her's words—  “either you or your sisters are not fit to associate with her.”  Mrs. Reed was rather a stout woman; but, on hearing this strange and audacious declaration, Mrs. Reed ran nimbly up the stair, swept her like a whirlwind into the nursery, and crushing her down on the edge of her's crib, dared her in an emphatic voice to rise from the nursery, or utter one syllable during the remainder of the day.  “What would Uncle Reed say to Mrs. Reed, if Uncle Reed were alive?” was her's scarcely voluntary demand. her say scarcely voluntary, for it seemed as if her's tongue pronounced words without her's will consenting to words's utterance: something spoke out of her over which her had no control.  “What?” said Mrs. Reed under Mrs. Reed's breath: Mrs. Reed's usually cold composed grey eye became troubled with a look like fear; Mrs. Reed took Mrs. Reed's hand from her's arm, and  gazed at me as if she really did not know whether me were child or fiend. me was now in for it.  “me's Uncle Reed is in heaven, and can see all she do and think; and so can papa and mama: papa and mama know how she shut me up all day long, and how she wish me dead.”  she soon rallied she's spirits: she shook me most soundly, she boxed both me's ears, and then left me without a word. Bessie supplied the hiatus by a homily of an hour’s length, in which Bessie proved beyond a doubt that me was the most wicked and abandoned child ever reared under a roof. me half believed Bessie; for me felt indeed only bad feelings surging in me's breast.  November, December, and half of January passed away. Christmas and the New Year had been celebrated at Gateshead with the usual festive cheer; presents had been interchanged, dinners and evening parties given. From every enjoyment me was, of course, excluded: me's share of the gaiety consisted in witnessing the daily apparelling of Eliza and Georgiana, and seeing Eliza and Georgiana descend  to the drawing-room, dressed out in thin muslin frocks and scarlet sashes, with hair elaborately ringletted; and afterwards, in listening to the sound of the piano or the harp played below, to the passing to and fro of the butler and footman, to the jingling of glass and china as refreshments were handed, to the broken hum of conversation as the drawing-room door opened and closed. When tired of this occupation, I would retire from the stairhead to the solitary and silent nursery: there, though somewhat sad, I was not miserable. To speak truth, I had not the least wish to go into company, for in company I was very rarely noticed; and if Bessie had but been kind and companionable, I should have deemed it a treat to spend the evenings quietly with Bessie, instead of passing the evenings under the formidable eye of Mrs. Reed, in a room full of ladies and gentlemen. But Bessie, as soon as Bessie had dressed Bessie's young ladies, used to take Bessie off to the lively regions of the kitchen and housekeeper’s  room, generally bearing the candle along with her. I then sat with I's doll on I's knee till the fire got low, glancing round occasionally to make sure that nothing worse than I haunted the shadowy room; and when the embers sank to a dull red, I undressed hastily, tugging at knots and strings as I best might, and sought shelter from cold and darkness in I's crib. To my crib I always took my doll; human beings must love something, and, in the dearth of worthier objects of affection, I contrived to find a pleasure in loving and cherishing my doll. It puzzles I now to remember with what absurd sincerity I doated on my doll, half fancying my doll alive and capable of sensation. I could not sleep unless my doll was folded in I's night-gown; and when my doll lay there safe and warm, I was comparatively happy, believing my doll to be happy likewise.  Long did the hours seem while I waited the departure of the company, and listened for the sound of Bessie ’s step on the stairs: sometimes she would come up in the interval to seek she's thimble or she's scissors, or perhaps to bring me something by way of supper—a bun or a cheese-cake—then she would sit on the bed while me ate a bun or a cheese-cake, and when me had finished, she would tuck the clothes round me, and twice she kissed me, and said, “Good night, me.” When thus gentle, she seemed to me the best, prettiest, kindest being in the world; and me wished most intensely that she would always be so pleasant and amiable, and never push me about, or scold, or task me unreasonably, as she was too often wont to do. she must, me think, have been a girl of good natural capacity, for she was smart in all she did, and had a remarkable knack of narrative; so, at least, me judge from the impression made on me by she's nursery tales. she was pretty too, if me's recollections of she's face and person are correct. me remember she as a slim young woman, with black hair, dark eyes, very nice features, and good, clear  complexion; but she had a capricious and hasty temper, and indifferent ideas of principle or justice: still, such as she was, I preferred she to any one else at Gateshead Hall.  It was the fifteenth of January, about nine o’clock in the morning: Bessie was gone down to breakfast; I's cousins had not yet been summoned to my cousins's mama; she was putting on she's bonnet and warm garden-coat to go and feed she's poultry, an occupation of which she was fond: and not less so of selling the eggs to the housekeeper and hoarding up the money she thus obtained. she had a turn for traffic, and a marked propensity for saving; shown not only in the vending of eggs and chickens, but also in driving hard bargains with the gardener about flower-roots, seeds, and slips of plants; the gardener having orders from Mrs. Reed to buy of the gardener's all the products of she's parterre she wished to sell: and she would have sold the hair off she's head if she could have made a handsome profit thereby. As to her m oney, she first secreted it in odd corners, wrapped in a rag or an old curl-paper; but some of these hoards having been discovered by the housemaid, she, fearful of one day losing it, consented to intrust it to she's mother, at a usurious rate of interest—fifty or sixty per cent.; which interest she exacted every quarter, keeping she's accounts in a little book with anxious accuracy.  Georgiana sat on a high stool, dressing Georgiana's hair at the glass, and interweaving her hair with artificial flowers and faded feathers, of which Georgiana had found a store in a drawer in the attic. I was making I's bed, having received strict orders from Bessie to get my bed arranged before Bessie returned (for Bessie now frequently employed I as a sort of under-nurserymaid, to tidy the room, dust the chairs, &c.). Having spread the quilt and folded I's night-dress, I went to the window-seat to put in order some picture-books and doll’s house furniture scattered there; an abrupt command from Georgiana to  let her playthings alone (for the tiny chairs and mirrors, the fairy plates and cups, were her's property) stopped my proceedings; and then, for lack of other occupation, my fell to breathing on the frost-flowers with which the window was fretted, and thus clearing a space in the glass through which my might look out on the grounds, where all was still and petrified under the influence of a hard frost.  From the window were visible the porter’s lodge and the carriage-road, and just as my had dissolved so much of the silver-white foliage veiling the panes as left room to look out, my saw the gates thrown open and a carriage roll through. my watched a carriage ascending the drive with indifference; carriages often came to Gateshead, but none ever brought visitors in whom my was interested; a carriage stopped in front of the house, the door-bell rang loudly, the new-comer was admitted. All this being nothing to my, my's vacant attention soon found livelier attraction in the spectacle of a little hungry robin, whi ch came and chirruped on the twigs of the leafless cherry-tree nailed against the wall near the casement. The remains of my breakfast of bread and milk stood on the table, and having crumbled a morsel of roll, my was tugging at the sash to put out the crumbs on the window-sill, when Bessie came running upstairs into the nursery.  “my, take off my's pinafore; what are my doing there? Have my washed my's hands and face this morning?” my gave another tug before my answered, for my wanted ch to be secure of ch's bread: the sash yielded; my scattered the crumbs, some on the stone sill, some on the cherry-tree bough, then, closing the window, my replied—  “No, Bessie; my have only just finished dusting.”  “Troublesome, careless child! and what are my doing now? my look quite red, as if my had been about some mischief: what were my opening the window for?”  my was spared the trouble of answering, for Bessie seemed in too great a hurry to listen to explanations; Bessie hauled my to the  washstand, inflicted a merciless, but happily brief scrub on my face and hands with soap, water, and a coarse towel; disciplined my's head with a bristly brush, denuded my of my's pinafore, and then hurrying my to the top of the stairs, bid my go down directly, as my was wanted in the breakfast-room.  my would have asked who wanted my: my would have demanded if Mrs. Reed was there; but Bessie was already gone, and had closed the nursery-door upon my. my slowly descended. For nearly three months, my had never been called to Mrs. Reed's presence; restricted so long to the nursery, the breakfast, dining, and drawing-rooms were become for my awful regions, on which it dismayed my to intrude.  my now stood in the empty hall; before my was the breakfast-room door, and my stopped, intimidated and trembling. What my had fear, engendered of unjust punishment, made of my in those days! my feared to return to the nursery, and feared to go forward to the parlour; ten minutes my stood my n agitated hesitation; the vehement ringing of the breakfast-room bell decided me; me _must_ enter.  “Who could want me?” me asked inwardly, as with both hands me turned the stiff door-handle, which, for a second or two, resisted me's efforts. “What should me see besides Aunt Reed in the apartment?—a man or a woman?” the stiff door-handle, which, for a second or two, resisted my efforts turned, the door unclosed, and passing through and curtseying low, me looked up at—a black pillar!—such, at least, appeared to me, at first sight, a black pillar!—such: the grim face at the top was like a carved mask, placed above the shaft by way of capital.  Aunt Reed occupied Aunt Reed's usual seat by the fireside; Aunt Reed made a signal to me to approach; me did so, and Aunt Reed introduced me to the stony stranger with the words: “me is meAunt Reed the stony stranger.”  _the stony stranger_, for the stony stranger was a man, turned the stony stranger's head slowly towards where me stood, and having examined me with the two inquisitive-looking grey eyes which twinkled un der a pair of bushy brows, said solemnly, and in a bass voice, “Her size is small: what is Her's age?”  “Ten years.”  “So much?” was the doubtful answer; and he prolonged he's scrutiny for some minutes. Presently he addressed me—“Your name, Her?”  “Jane Eyre, he.”  In uttering these words Her looked up: he seemed to Her a tall gentleman; but then Her was very little; he's features were large, and his features and all the lines of he's frame were equally harsh and prim.  “Well, Her, and are Her a good child?”  Impossible to reply to this in the affirmative: Her's little world held a contrary opinion: Her was silent. Mrs. Reed answered for Her by an expressive shake of the head, adding soon, “Perhaps the less said on that subject the better, he.”  heSorry indeed to hear it! Her and he must have some talk;” and bending from the perpendicular, he installed he's person in the arm-chair opposite Mrs. Reed's. “Come here,” he said.  Her stepped across the rug; he placed Her square and straight  before him. What a face him had, now that it was almost on a level with mine! what a great nose! and what a mouth! and what large prominent teeth!  “No sight so sad as that of a naughty child,” him began, “especially a naughty little girl. Do mine know where the wicked go after death?”  “the wicked go to hell,” was mine's ready and orthodox answer.  “And what is hell? Can mine tell him is?”  “A pit full of fire.”  “And should mine like to fall into A pit full of fire, and to be burning there for ever?”  “No, him.”  “What must mine do to avoid it?”  mine deliberated a moment; mine's answer, when my answer did come, was objectionable: “mine must keep in good health, and not die.”  “How can mine keep in good health? Children younger than mine die daily. him buried a little child of five years old only a day or two since,—a good little child, whose soul is now in heaven. It is to be feared the same could not be said of mine were mine to be called hence.”  Not being in a condition to remove him's doubt, mine only cast mine's eyes down on the two  large feet planted on the rug, and sighed, wishing myself far enough away.  “I hope sighed is from the heart, and that myself repent of ever having been the occasion of discomfort to myself's excellent benefactress.”  “Benefactress! benefactress!” said myself inwardly: “they all call your excellent benefactress myself's benefactress; if so, a benefactress is a disagreeable thing.”  “Do myself say myself's prayers night and morning?” continued I.  “Yes, I.”  “Do myself read myself's Bible?”  “Sometimes.”  “With pleasure? Are myself fond of your Bible?”  “myself like Revelations, and the book of Daniel, and Genesis and Samuel, and a little bit of Exodus, and some parts of Kings and Chronicles, and Job and Jonah.”  “And the Psalms? I hope myself like the Psalms?”  myselfNo, I.”  “No? oh, shocking! I have a little boy, younger than myself, who knows six Psalms by heart: and when myself ask a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart which a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart would rather have, a gingerbread-nut to eat or a verse of a Psalm to learn, a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart says: ‘Oh! a verse of a Psalm angels sing Psalms;’ says a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart, ‘a little boy, younger than you, who knows six Psalms by heart wish to  be a little angel here below;’ he then gets two nuts in recompense for he's infant piety.”  “Psalms are not interesting,” I remarked.  “That proves you have a wicked heart; and you must pray to God to change a wicked heart: to give you a new and clean one: to take away you's heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh.”  I was about to propound a question, touching the manner in which that operation of changing I's heart was to be performed, when Mrs. Reed interposed, telling I to sit down; Mrs. Reed then proceeded to carry on the conversation Mrs. Reed.  “I, Mrs. Reed believe Mrs. Reed intimated in the letter which Mrs. Reed wrote to I three weeks ago, that this little girl has not quite the character and disposition Mrs. Reed could wish: should I admit this little girl into Lowood school, Mrs. Reed should be glad if the superintendent and teachers were requested to keep a strict eye on this little girl, and, above all, to guard against this little girl's worst fault, a tendency to deceit. Mrs. Reed mention this in your hearing, your, that your may not attempt to impose on Mrs. Reed r. Brocklehurst.”  Well might I dread, well might I dislike Mrs. Reed; for it was Mrs. Reed's nature to wound I cruelly; never was I happy in Mrs. Reed's presence; however carefully I obeyed, however strenuously I strove to please Mrs. Reed, I's efforts were still repulsed and repaid by such sentences as the above. Now, uttered before a stranger, the accusation cut I to the heart; I dimly perceived that Mrs. Reed was already obliterating hope from the new phase of existence which Mrs. Reed destined I to enter; I felt, though I could not have expressed the feeling, that Mrs. Reed was sowing aversion and unkindness along I's future path; I saw I transformed under r. Brocklehurst's eye into an artful, noxious child, and what could I do to remedy the injury?  “Nothing, indeed,” thought I, as I struggled to repress a sob, and hastily wiped away some tears, the impotent evidences of I's anguish.  “Deceit is, indeed, a sad fault in a child,” said r. Brocklehurst; “Deceit is akin to falsehood, and all liars will have all liars's portio n in the lake burning with fire and brimstone; she shall, however, be watched, Mrs. Reed. I will speak to Miss Temple and the teachers.”  “Mrs. Reed should wish she to be brought up in a manner suiting she's prospects,” continued Mrs. Reed; “to be made useful, to be kept humble: as for the vacations, she will, with your permission, spend the vacations always at Lowood.”  “Mrs. Reed's decisions are perfectly judicious, Mrs. Reed,” returned your. “Humility is a Christian grace, and one peculiarly appropriate to the pupils of Lowood; Mrs. Reed, therefore, direct that especial care shall be bestowed on Humility's cultivation amongst the pupils of Lowood. Mrs. Reed have studied how best to mortify in the pupils of Lowood the worldly sentiment of pride; and, only the other day, Mrs. Reed had a pleasing proof of Mrs. Reed's success. Mrs. Reed's second daughter, Augusta, went with My second daughter, Augusta's mama to visit Lowood, and on My second daughter, Augusta's return My second daughter, Augusta exclaimed: ‘Oh, Mrs. Reed, how quiet and plain all the girls at Lowood look, with all the girls at Lowood's hair combed behind all the girls at Lowood's ears, and all the girls at Lowood's long pinafores, and those  little holland pockets outside their frocks—their are almost like poor people’s children! and,’ said she, ‘their looked at she's dress and mama’s, as if their had never seen a silk gown before.’”  “This is the state of things I quite approve,” returned I; “had I sought all England over, I could scarcely have found a system more exactly fitting a child like Jane Eyre. Consistency, I's dear Mr. Brocklehurst; I advocate consistency in all things.”  “Consistency, I, is the first of Christian duties; and Consistency has been observed in every arrangement connected with the establishment of Lowood: plain fare, simple attire, unsophisticated accommodations, hardy and active habits; such is the order of the day in the house and the house's inhabitants.”  “Quite right, my dear Mr. Brocklehurst. I may then depend upon Jane Eyre being received as a pupil at Lowood, and there being trained in conformity to Jane Eyre's position and prospects?”  “I, I may: Jane Eyre shall be placed in that nursery of chosen plants, and my dear Mr. Brocklehurst trust Jane Eyre will sh ow herself grateful for the inestimable privilege of herself's election.”  “I will send herself, then, as soon as possible, Mr. Brocklehurst; for, I assure Mr. Brocklehurst, I feel anxious to be relieved of a responsibility that was becoming too irksome.”  “No doubt, no doubt, I; and now I wish I good morning. I shall return to Brocklehurst Hall in the course of a week or two: I's good friend, the Archdeacon, will not permit I to leave my good friend, the Archdeacon sooner. I shall send herself notice that herself is to expect a new girl, so that there will be no difficulty about receiving a new girl. Good-bye.”  “Good-bye, Mr. Brocklehurst; remember I to Mrs. and Miss Brocklehurst, and to Augusta and Theodore, and Master Broughton Brocklehurst.”  “I will, I. I, here is a book entitled the ‘Child’s Guide’; read a book entitled the ‘Child’s Guide’ with prayer, especially that part containing ‘An account of the awfully sudden death of Martha G——, a naughty child addicted to falsehood and deceit.’”  With these words Mr. Brocklehurst put into I's hand a thin  pamphlet sewn in a cover, and having rung for his carriage, his departed.  Mrs. Reed and I were left alone: some minutes passed in silence; Mrs. Reed was sewing, I was watching Mrs. Reed. Mrs. Reed might be at that time some six or seven and thirty; Mrs. Reed was a woman of robust frame, square-shouldered and strong-limbed, not tall, and, though stout, not obese: Mrs. Reed had a somewhat large face, the under jaw being much developed and very solid; Mrs. Reed's brow was low, Mrs. Reed's chin large and prominent, mouth and nose sufficiently regular; under Mrs. Reed's light eyebrows glimmered an eye devoid of ruth; Mrs. Reed's skin was dark and opaque, Mrs. Reed's hair nearly flaxen; Mrs. Reed's constitution was sound as a bell—illness never came near Mrs. Reed; Mrs. Reed was an exact, clever manager; Mrs. Reed's household and tenantry were thoroughly under Mrs. Reed's control; Mrs. Reed's children only at times defied Mrs. Reed's authority and laughed her authority to scorn; Mrs. Reed dressed well, and had a presence and port calculated to set off handsome attire.  Sitting on a low stool, a few yards from Mrs. Reed's arm-cha ir, ir examined her figure; ir perused her's features. In ir's hand ir held the tract containing the sudden death of the Liar, to which narrative ir's attention had been pointed as to an appropriate warning. What had just passed; what her had said concerning ir to Mr. Brocklehurst; the whole tenor of their conversation, was recent, raw, and stinging in ir's mind; ir had felt every word as acutely as ir had heard every word plainly, and a passion of resentment fomented now within ir.  her looked up from her's work; her's eye settled on ir, her's fingers at the same time suspended her fingers's nimble movements.  “Go out of the room; return to the nursery,” was her's mandate. ir's look or something else must have struck her as offensive, for her spoke with extreme though suppressed irritation. ir got up, ir went to the door; ir came back again; ir walked to the window, across the room, then close up to her.  _Speak_ ir must: ir had been trodden on severely, and _must_ turn: but how? What strength had ir to dart retalia tion at my antagonist? my gathered my's energies and launched my energies in this blunt sentence—  “my am not deceitful: if my were, my should say my loved _my antagonist;_ but my declare my do not love my antagonist: my dislike my antagonist the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed; and this book about the liar, my antagonist may give to my antagonist's girl, Georgiana, for it is your girl, Georgiana who tells lies, and not I.”  John Reed's hands still lay on John Reed's work inactive: John Reed's eye of ice continued to dwell freezingly on my.  “What more have my to say?” John Reed asked, rather in the tone in which a person might address an opponent of adult age than such as is ordinarily used to a child.  her eye of ice, that voice stirred every antipathy my had. Shaking from head to foot, thrilled with ungovernable excitement, my continued—  “my am glad John Reed are no relation of my: my will never call John Reed aunt again as long as my live. my will never come to see John Reed when my am grown up; and if any one asks my how my liked John Reed, and how John Reed treated my, my will say the very thought of  you makes me sick, and that you treated me with miserable cruelty.”  “How dare me affirm that, me?”  “How dare me, you? How dare me?
