Because it is the _truth_. you think me have no feelings, and that me can do without one bit of love or kindness; but me cannot live so: and you have no pity. me shall remember how you thrust me back—roughly and violently thrust me back—into the red-room, and locked me up there, to me's dying day; though me was in agony; though me cried out, while suffocating with distress, ‘Have mercy! Have mercy, you!’ And that punishment you made me suffer because you's wicked boy struck me—knocked me down for nothing. me will tell anybody who asks me questions, this exact tale. People think you a good woman, but you are bad, hard-hearted. _you_ are deceitful!”   How dare me, you? How dare me? Because it is the truth  Ere me had finished this reply, me's soul began to expand, to exult, with the strangest sense of freedom, of triumph, me ever felt. It seemed as  if an invisible bond had burst, and that I had struggled out into unhoped-for liberty. Not without cause was this sentiment: Mrs. Reed looked frightened; Mrs. Reed's work had slipped from Mrs. Reed's knee; Mrs. Reed was lifting up Mrs. Reed's hands, rocking Mrs. Reed to and fro, and even twisting Mrs. Reed's face as if Mrs. Reed would cry.  “I, I are under a mistake: what is the matter with I? Why do I tremble so violently? Would I like to drink some water?”  “No, Mrs. Reed.”  “Is there anything else I wish for, I? Mrs. Reed assure I, Mrs. Reed desire to be I's friend.”  “Not Mrs. Reed. Mrs. Reed told Mr. Brocklehurst I had a bad character, a deceitful disposition; and I’ll let everybody at Lowood know what Mrs. Reed are, and what Mrs. Reed have done.”  “I, I don’t understand these things: children must be corrected for children's faults.”  “Deceit is not I's fault!” I cried out in a savage, high voice.  “But I are passionate, I, that I must allow: and now return to the nursery—there’s a dear—and lie down a little.”  “I am not Mrs. Reed's dear; I cann ot lie down: send ot to school soon, Mrs. Reed, for ot hate to live here.”  “Mrs. Reed will indeed send ot to school soon,” murmured Mrs. Reed _sotto voce_; and gathering up Mrs. Reed's work, Mrs. Reed abruptly quitted the apartment.  I was left there alone—winner of the field. It was the hardest battle I had fought, and the first victory I had gained: I stood awhile on the rug, where Mr. Brocklehurst had stood, and I enjoyed I's conqueror’s solitude. First, I smiled to I and felt elate; but this fierce pleasure subsided in I as fast as did the accelerated throb of I's pulses. A child cannot quarrel with A child's elders, as I had done; cannot give A child's furious feelings uncontrolled play, as I had given I, without experiencing afterwards the pang of remorse and the chill of reaction. A ridge of lighted heath, alive, glancing, devouring, would have been a meet emblem of I's mind when I accused and menaced Mrs. Reed: A ridge of lighted heath, alive, glancing, devouring, would have represented as meetly  my subsequent condition, when half-an-hour’s silence and reflection had shown my the madness of my's conduct, and the dreariness of my's hated and hating position.  Something of vengeance my had tasted for the first time; as aromatic wine Something of vengeance seemed, on swallowing, warm and racy: Something of vengeance's after-flavour, metallic and corroding, gave my a sensation as if my had been poisoned. Willingly would my now have gone and asked Mrs. Reed’s pardon; but my knew, partly from experience and partly from instinct, asked was the way to make Mrs. Reed’s repulse my with double scorn, thereby re-exciting every turbulent impulse of my's nature.  my would fain exercise some better faculty than that of fierce speaking; fain find nourishment for some less fiendish feeling than that of sombre indignation. my took a book—some Arabian tales; my sat down and endeavoured to read. my could make no sense of the subject; my's own thoughts swam always between my and the page my had usually found fascinating. my opened the glass-door in the breakfast-ro om: the shrubbery was quite still: the black frost reigned, unbroken by sun or breeze, through the grounds. I covered I's head and arms with the skirt of I's frock, and went out to walk in a part of the plantation which was quite sequestrated; but I found no pleasure in the silent trees, the falling fir-cones, the congealed relics of autumn, russet leaves, swept by past winds in heaps, and now stiffened together. I leaned against a gate, and looked into an empty field where no sheep were feeding, where the short grass was nipped and blanched. It was a very grey day; a most opaque sky, “onding on snaw,” canopied all; thence flakes fell at intervals, which settled on the hard path and on the hoary lea without melting. I stood, a wretched child enough, whispering to I over and over again, “What shall I do?—what shall I do?”  All at once I heard a clear voice call, “I! where are I? Come to lunch!”  It was Bessie, I knew well enough; but I did not stir; Bessie's light step came trip ping down the path.  “You naughty little thing!” she said. “Why don’t You naughty little thing come when You naughty little thing are called?”  she's presence, compared with the thoughts over which You naughty little thing had been brooding, seemed cheerful; even though, as usual, she was somewhat cross. The fact is, after You naughty little thing's conflict with and victory over Mrs. Reed, You naughty little thing was not disposed to care much for she's transitory anger; and You naughty little thing _was_ disposed to bask in she's youthful lightness of heart. You naughty little thing just put You naughty little thing's two arms round she and said, “Come, she! don’t scold.”  put was more frank and fearless than any You naughty little thing was habituated to indulge in: somehow put pleased she.  “You naughty little thing are a strange child, You naughty little thing,” she said, as she looked down at You naughty little thing; “a little roving, solitary thing: and You naughty little thing are going to school, she suppose?”  You naughty little thing nodded.  “And won’t You naughty little thing be sorry to leave she?”  “What does she care for You naughty little thing? she is always scolding You naughty little thing.”  “Because You naughty little thing’re such a queer, frightened, shy little thing. You naughty little thing should be bolder.”  “What! to get more knocks? ”  “Nonsense! But you are rather put upon, are’s certain. you's mother said, when My mother came to see you last week, that My mother would not like a little one of My mother's own to be in you's place.—Now, come in, and you’ve some good news for you.”  “you don’t think you have, you.”  you you what do you mean? What sorrowful eyes you fix on you! Well, but Missis and the young ladies and Master John are going out to tea this afternoon, and you shall have tea with you. you’ll ask cook to bake you a little cake, and then you shall help you to look over you's drawers; for you am soon to pack you's trunk. Missis intends you to leave Gateshead in a day or two, and you shall choose what toys you like to take with you.”  “you, you must promise not to scold you any more till you go.”  “Well, you will; but mind you are a very good girl, and don’t be afraid of you. Don’t start when you chance to speak rather sharply; speak’s so provoking.”  “you don’t think you shall ever be afraid of you again, you, because you have got used to you, and  I shall soon have another set of people to dread.”  “If I dread another set of people to dread another set of people to dread’ll dislike I.”  “As I do, I?”  “I don’t dislike I, I; I believe I am fonder of I than of all the others.”  “I don’t show am.”  “I I’ve got quite a new way of talking. What makes I so venturesome and hardy?”  “Why, I shall soon be away from I, and besides”—I was going to say something about what had passed between I and Mrs. Reed, but on second thoughts I considered it better to remain silent on that head.  “And so I’re glad to leave I?”  “Not at all, I; indeed, just now I’m rather sorry.”  “Just now! and rather! How coolly I says it! I dare say now if I were to ask I for a kiss I wouldn’t give a kiss I: I’d say I’d _rather_ not.”  “I’ll kiss I and welcome: bend I's head down.” I stooped; we mutually embraced, and I followed I into the house quite comforted. That afternoon lapsed in peace and harmony; and in the evening I d me some of her most enchanting stories, and sang me some of her's sweetest songs. Even for me life had life's gleams of sunshine.     CHAPTER V   Five o’clock had hardly struck on the morning of the 19th of January, when Bessie brought a candle into me's closet and found me already up and nearly dressed. me had risen half-an-hour before Bessie's entrance, and had washed me's face, and put on me's clothes by the light of a half-moon just setting, whose rays streamed through the narrow window near me's crib. me was to leave Gateshead that day by a coach which passed the lodge gates at six A.M. Bessie was the only person yet risen; Bessie had lit a fire in the nursery, where Bessie now proceeded to make me's breakfast. Few children can eat when excited with the thoughts of a journey; nor could me Bessie, having pressed me in vain to take a few spoonfuls of the boiled milk and bread Bessie had prepared for me, wrapped up some biscuits in a paper and put some biscuits into me's bag; then Bessie helped me on with me's pelisse and bonne t, and wrapping herself in a shawl, herself and I left the nursery. As she and I passed Mrs. Reed’s bedroom, herself said, “Will I go in and bid Mrs. Reed’s good-bye?”  “No, herself: Mrs. Reed’s came to I's crib last night when herself were gone down to supper, and said I need not disturb Mrs. Reed’s in the morning, or I's cousins either; and Mrs. Reed’s told I to remember that Mrs. Reed’s had always been I's best friend, and to speak of Mrs. Reed’s and be grateful to Mrs. Reed’s accordingly.”  “What did I say, I?”  “Nothing: I covered I's face with the bedclothes, and turned from Mrs. Reed’s to the wall.”  “covered was wrong, I.”  “covered was quite right, herself. Mrs. Reed’s has not been I's friend: Mrs. Reed’s has been I's foe.”  “I! don’t say so!”  “Good-bye to Gateshead!” cried I, as she and I passed through the hall and went out at the front door.  The moon was set, and it was very dark; herself carried a lantern, whose light glanced on wet steps and gravel road sodden by a recent thaw. Raw and chill was the winter morning: I's teeth chattered as I hastened down t he drive. There was a light in the porter’s lodge: when we reached the porter’s lodge, we found the porter’s's wife just kindling the porter’s wife's fire: my trunk, which had been carried down the evening before, stood corded at the door. It wanted but a few minutes of six, and shortly after but a few minutes of six had struck, the distant roll of wheels announced the coming coach; my went to the door and watched the coming coach's lamps approach rapidly through the gloom.  “Is she going by she?” asked the porter’s wife.  “Yes.”  “And how far is it?”  “Fifty miles.”  “What a long way! my wonder Mrs. Reed is not afraid to trust she so far alone.”  the coming coach drew up; there the coming coach was at the gates with the coming coach's four horses and the coming coach's top laden with passengers: the guard and coachman loudly urged haste; my trunk, which had been carried down the evening before was hoisted up; my was taken from she's neck, to which my clung with kisses.  “Be sure and take good care of my,” cried she to the guard, as the guard lifted my into the inside.  “Ay, ay!” was the answer: the door was slapped to, a voice exclaimed “All right ,” and on we drove. Thus was I severed from Bessie and Gateshead; thus whirled away to unknown, and, as I then deemed, remote and mysterious regions.  I remember but little of the journey; I only know that the day seemed to I of a preternatural length, and that we appeared to travel over hundreds of miles of road. we passed through several towns, and in one, a very large one, the coach stopped; the horses were taken out, and the passengers alighted to dine. I was carried into an inn, where the guard wanted I to have some dinner; but, as I had no appetite, the guard left I in an immense room with a fireplace at each end, a chandelier pendent from the ceiling, and a little red gallery high up against the wall filled with musical instruments. Here I walked about for a long time, feeling very strange, and mortally apprehensive of some one coming in and kidnapping I; for I believed in kidnappers, kidnappers's exploits having frequently figured in Bessie's fireside chronicles. At last the guard return ed; once more I was stowed away in the coach, I's protector mounted my protector's own seat, sounded my protector's hollow horn, and away we rattled over the “stony street” of L——.  The afternoon came on wet and somewhat misty: as it waned into dusk, I began to feel that we were getting very far indeed from Gateshead: we ceased to pass through towns; the country changed; great grey hills heaved up round the horizon: as twilight deepened, we descended a valley, dark with wood, and long after night had overclouded the prospect, I heard a wild wind rushing amongst trees.  Lulled by a wild wind rushing amongst trees, I at last dropped asleep; I had not long slumbered when the sudden cessation of motion awoke I; the coach-door was open, and a person like a servant was standing at the coach-door: I saw a person like a servant's face and dress by the light of the lamps.  “Is there I here?” a person like a servant asked. I answered “Yes,” and was then lifted out; I's trunk was handed down, and the coach instantly drove away.  I was stiff with long sitting, and bew ildered with the noise and motion of the coach: gathering my faculties, my looked about my. Rain, wind, and darkness filled the air; nevertheless, my dimly discerned a wall before my and a door open in it; through a door open in it my passed with my's new guide: my new guide shut and locked a door open in it behind my new guide. There was now visible a house or houses—for a house or houses—for the building spread far—with many windows, and lights burning in some spread far—with many windows, and lights burning in some; we went up a broad pebbly path, splashing wet, and were admitted at a door; then my new guide led my through a passage into a room with a fire, where my new guide left my alone.  my stood and warmed my's numbed fingers over a fire, then my looked round; there was no candle, but the uncertain light from a fire showed, by intervals, papered walls, carpet, curtains, shining mahogany furniture: it was a parlour, not so spacious or splendid as the drawing-room at Gateshead, but comfortable enough. my was puzzling to make out the subject of a picture on the wall, when the door opened, and an individual carr ying a light entered; another followed close behind.  The first was a tall lady with dark hair, dark eyes, and a pale and large forehead; The first's figure was partly enveloped in a shawl, The first's countenance was grave, The first's bearing erect.  “The child is very young to be sent alone,” said The first, putting The first's candle down on the table. The first considered me attentively for a minute or two, then further added—  “The child had better be put to bed soon; The child looks tired: are me tired?” The first asked, placing The first's hand on me's shoulder.  “A little, The first.”  “And hungry too, no doubt: let The child have some supper before The child goes to bed, me. Is this the first time me have left me's parents to come to school, me?”  me explained to The first that me had no parents. The first inquired how long your parents had been dead: then how old me was, what was me's name, whether me could read, write, and sew a little: then The first touched me's cheek gently with The first's forefinger, and saying, “The first hoped The first should be a good child,” dismissed me along with  Miss Miller.  The lady I had left might be about twenty-nine; Miss Miller I appeared some years younger: The lady I had left impressed I by The lady I had left's voice, look, and air. Miss Miller was more ordinary; ruddy in complexion, though of a careworn countenance; hurried in gait and action, like one who had always a multiplicity of tasks on hand: Miss Miller looked, indeed, what I afterwards found Miss Miller really was, an under-teacher. Led by Miss Miller, I passed from compartment to compartment, from passage to passage, of a large and irregular building; till, emerging from the total and somewhat dreary silence pervading that portion of a large and irregular building we had traversed, we came upon the hum of many voices, and presently entered a wide, long room, with great deal tables, two at each end, on each of which burnt a pair of candles, and seated all round on benches, a congregation of girls of every age, from nine or ten to twenty. Seen by the dim light of the dips, a congregation of girls of every age, from nine or ten to twenty's number to I appeared countless, though not in reality I xceeding eighty; they were uniformly dressed in brown stuff frocks of quaint fashion, and long holland pinafores. It was the hour of study; they were engaged in conning over they's to-morrow’s task, and the hum I had heard was the combined result of they's whispered repetitions.  Miss Miller signed to I to sit on a bench near the door, then walking up to the top of the long room Miss Miller cried out—  “Monitors, collect the lesson-books and put the lesson-books away!”  Four tall girls arose from different tables, and going round, gathered the lesson-books and removed the lesson-books. Miss Miller again gave the word of command—  “Monitors, fetch the supper-trays!”  Four tall girls went out and returned presently, each bearing a tray, with portions of something, I knew not what, arranged thereon, and a pitcher of water and mug in the middle of each tray. portions of something, I knew not what, arranged thereon, and a pitcher of water and mug in the middle of each tray were handed round; those who liked took a draught of water, the mug being common to all. When it came to I's turn, I drank, for I was thirsty, but did not tou ch the food, excitement and fatigue rendering me incapable of eating: me now saw, however, that it was a thin oaten cake shared into fragments.  The meal over, prayers were read by Miss Miller, and the classes filed off, two and two, upstairs. Overpowered by this time with weariness, me scarcely noticed what sort of a place the bedroom was, except that, like the schoolroom, me saw the bedroom was very long. To-night me was to be Miss Miller's bed-fellow; Miss Miller helped me to undress: when laid down me glanced at the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled with two occupants; in ten minutes the single light was extinguished, and amidst silence and complete darkness me fell asleep.  The night passed rapidly: me was too tired even to dream; me only once awoke to hear the wind rave in furious gusts, and the rain fall in torrents, and to be sensible that Miss Miller had taken Miss Miller's place by me's side. When me again unclosed me's eyes, a loud bell was ringing; the girls were up and dressing; day had not yet  begun to dawn, and a rushlight or two burned in the room. I too rose reluctantly; it was bitter cold, and I dressed as well as I could for shivering, and washed when there was a basin at liberty, which did not occur soon, as there was but one basin to six girls, on the stands down the middle of the room. Again the bell rang: six girls formed in file, two and two, and in that order descended the stairs and entered the cold and dimly lit schoolroom: here prayers were read by Miss Miller; afterwards Miss Miller called out—  “Form classes!”  A great tumult succeeded for some minutes, during which Miss Miller repeatedly exclaimed, “Silence!” and “Order!” When A great tumult subsided, I saw six girls drawn up in four semicircles, before four chairs, placed at the four tables; six girls held books in six girls's hands, and a great book, like a Bible, lay on each table, before the vacant seat. A pause of some seconds succeeded, filled up by the low, vague hum of numbers; Miss Miller walked from class to class, hushing this indefin ite sound.  A distant bell tinkled: immediately three ladies entered the room, each walked to a table and took three ladies's seat; Miss Miller assumed the fourth vacant chair, which was that nearest the door, and around which the smallest of the children were assembled: to this inferior class Miss Miller was called, and placed at the bottom of it.  Business now began: the day’s Collect was repeated, then certain texts of Scripture were said, and to certain texts of Scripture succeeded a protracted reading of chapters in the Bible, which lasted an hour. By the time a protracted reading of chapters in the Bible, which lasted an hour was terminated, day had fully dawned. The indefatigable bell now sounded for the fourth time: the classes were marshalled and marched into another room to breakfast: how glad Miss Miller was to behold a prospect of getting something to eat! Miss Miller was now nearly sick from inanition, having taken so little the day before.  another room was a great, low-ceiled, gloomy room; on two long tables smoked basins of something hot, which, however, to Miss Miller's dismay, sent forth an  odour far from inviting. I saw a universal manifestation of discontent when the fumes of the repast met the nostrils of those destined to swallow the repast; from the van of the procession, the tall girls of the first class, rose the whispered words—  “Disgusting! The porridge is burnt again!”  “Silence!” ejaculated a voice; not that of Miss Miller, but one of the upper teachers, a little and dark personage, smartly dressed, but of somewhat morose aspect, who installed herself at the top of one table, while a more buxom lady presided at the other. I looked in vain for herself I had first seen the night before; herself was not visible: Miss Miller occupied the foot of one table, and a strange, foreign-looking, elderly lady, the French teacher, as I afterwards found, took the corresponding seat at the other board. A long grace was said and a hymn sung; then a servant brought in some tea for the teachers, and the meal began.  Ravenous, and now very faint, I devoured a spoonful or two of I's po rtion without thinking of its taste; but the first edge of hunger blunted, I perceived I had got in hand a nauseous mess; burnt porridge is almost as bad as rotten potatoes; famine famine itself soon sickens over burnt porridge. The spoons were moved slowly: I saw each girl taste each girl's food and try to swallow her food; but in most cases the effort was soon relinquished. Breakfast was over, and none had breakfasted. Thanks being returned for what we had not got, and a second hymn chanted, the refectory was evacuated for the schoolroom. I was one of the last to go out, and in passing the tables, I saw one teacher take a basin of the porridge and taste the porridge; one teacher looked at the others; all their countenances expressed displeasure, and one of the others, the stout one, whispered—  “Abominable stuff! How shameful!”  A quarter of an hour passed before lessons again began, during which the schoolroom was in a glorious tumult; for A quarter of an hour it seemed to be permitted to talk loud and more freely, and they used they's privi lege. The whole conversation ran on the breakfast, which one and all abused roundly. Poor things! Poor things! was the sole consolation Poor things! had. Miss Miller was now the only teacher in the room: a group of great girls standing about Miss Miller spoke with serious and sullen gestures. I heard the name of Mr. Brocklehurst pronounced by some lips; at which Miss Miller shook Miss Miller's head disapprovingly; but Miss Miller made no great effort to check the general wrath; doubtless Miss Miller shared in the general wrath.  A clock in the room struck nine; Miss Miller left Miss Miller's circle, and standing in the middle of the room, cried—  “Silence! To your seats!”  Discipline prevailed: in five minutes your was resolved into order, and comparative silence quelled the Babel clamour of tongues. The upper teachers now punctually resumed The upper teachers's posts: but still, all seemed to wait. Ranged on benches down the sides of the room, the eighty girls sat motionless and erect; a quaint assemblage the eighty girls appeared, the eighty girls with plain locks combed from t heir faces, not a curl visible; in brown dresses, made high and surrounded by a narrow tucker about the throat, with little pockets of holland (shaped something like a Highlander’s purse) tied in front of their frocks, and destined to serve the purpose of a work-bag: all, too, wearing woollen stockings and country-made shoes, fastened with brass buckles. Above twenty of those clad in this costume were full-grown girls, or rather young women; this costume suited Above twenty of those clad in this costume ill, and gave an air of oddity even to the prettiest.  I was still looking at Above twenty of those clad in this costume, and also at intervals examining the teachers—none of whom precisely pleased I; for the stout one was a little coarse, the dark one not a little fierce, the foreigner harsh and grotesque, and Miss Miller, poor thing! looked purple, weather-beaten, and over-worked—when, as I's eye wandered from face to face, the whole school rose simultaneously, as if moved by a common spring.  What was the matter? I had heard no order given: I was puzzled. Ere I had ga thered my wits, the classes were again seated: but as all eyes were now turned to one point, my followed the general direction, and encountered the personage who had received my last night. the personage who had received me last night stood at the bottom of the long room, on the hearth; for there was a fire at each end; the personage who had received me last night surveyed the two rows of girls silently and gravely. Miss Miller approaching, seemed to ask the personage who had received me last night a question, and having received the personage who had received me last night's answer, went back to Miss Miller's place, and said aloud—  “Monitor of the first class, fetch the globes!”  While the direction was being executed, the personage who had received me last night moved slowly up the long room. my suppose my have a considerable organ of veneration, for my retain yet the sense of admiring awe with which my's eyes traced the personage who had received me last night's steps. Seen now, in broad daylight, the personage who had received me last night looked tall, fair, and shapely; brown eyes with a benignant light in brown eyes with a benignant light in their irids, and a fine pencilling of long lashes round's irids, and a fine pencilling of long lashes round, relieved the whiteness of the personage who had received me last night's large front; on each of the personage who had received me last night's temples the personage who had received me last night's hair, of a very dark brown, was clus tered in round curls, according to the fashion of those times, when neither smooth bands nor long ringlets were in vogue; her dress, also in the mode of the day, was of purple cloth, relieved by a sort of Spanish trimming of black velvet; a gold watch (watches were not so common then as now) shone at her's girdle. Let the reader add, to complete the picture, refined features; a complexion, if pale, clear; and a stately air and carriage, and the reader will have, at least, as clearly as words can give it, a correct idea of the exterior of her—Maria Temple, as I afterwards saw the name written in a prayer-book intrusted to I to carry to church.  The superintendent of Lowood (for such was her) having taken The superintendent of Lowood (for such was this lady)'s seat before a pair of globes placed on one of the tables, summoned the first class round The superintendent of Lowood (for such was this lady), and commenced giving a lesson on geography; the lower classes were called by the teachers: repetitions in history, grammar, &c., went on for an hour; writing and arithmetic succeeded,  and music lessons were given by Miss Temple to some of the elder girls. The duration of each lesson was measured by the clock, which at last struck twelve. The superintendent rose—  “The superintendent have a word to address to the pupils,” said The superintendent.  The tumult of cessation from lessons was already breaking forth, but The tumult of cessation from lessons sank at The superintendent's voice. The superintendent went on—  “the pupils had this morning a breakfast which the pupils could not eat; the pupils must be hungry:—I have ordered that a lunch of bread and cheese shall be served to the pupils.”  the pupils looked at The superintendent with a sort of surprise.  “It is to be done on The superintendent's responsibility,” The superintendent added, in an explanatory tone to the pupils, and immediately afterwards left the room.  a lunch of bread and cheese was presently brought in and distributed, to the high delight and refreshment of the pupils. The order was now given “To the garden!” Each put on a coarse straw bonnet, with strings of coloured calico, and a cloak of grey frieze. The superintendent was similarly equipped, and, following the stream, The superintendent made The superintendent's way int o the open air.  The garden was a wide inclosure, surrounded with walls so high as to exclude every glimpse of prospect; a covered verandah ran down one side, and broad walks bordered a middle space divided into scores of little beds: scores of little beds were assigned as gardens for the pupils to cultivate, and each bed had an owner. When full of flowers scores of little beds would doubtless look pretty; but now, at the latter end of January, all was wintry blight and brown decay. I shuddered as I stood and looked round I: it was an inclement day for outdoor exercise; not positively rainy, but darkened by a drizzling yellow fog; all under foot was still soaking wet with the floods of yesterday. The stronger among the girls ran about and engaged in active games, but sundry pale and thin ones herded together for shelter and warmth in a covered verandah; and amongst sundry pale and thin ones, as a drizzling yellow fog penetrated to sundry pale and thin ones's shivering frames, I heard frequently the sound of a hollow cough.  As yet I had spoken to no one, nor did anyb ody seem to take notice of me; me stood lonely enough: but to that feeling of isolation me was accustomed; that feeling of isolation did not oppress me much. me leant against a pillar of the verandah, drew me's grey mantle close about me, and, trying to forget the cold which nipped me without, and the unsatisfied hunger which gnawed me within, delivered me up to the employment of watching and thinking. me's reflections were too undefined and fragmentary to merit record: me hardly yet knew where me was; Gateshead and me's past life seemed floated away to an immeasurable distance; the present was vague and strange, and of the future me could form no conjecture. me looked round the convent-like garden, and then up at the house—a large building, half of which seemed grey and old, the other half quite new. The new part, containing the schoolroom and dormitory, was lit by mullioned and latticed windows, which gave The new part, containing the schoolroom and dormitory a church-like aspect; a stone tablet over the door bore this inscription:—  LOWOOD INSTITUTION.  This porti on was rebuilt A.D. ——, by Naomi Brocklehurst, of Brocklehurst Hall, in this county.  “Let your light so shine before men, that men may see your good works, and glorify your's Father which is in heaven.”—St. Matt. v. 16.   I read these words over and over again: I felt that an explanation belonged to these words, and was unable fully to penetrate these words's import. I was still pondering the signification of “Institution,” and endeavouring to make out a connection between the first words and the verse of Scripture, when the sound of a cough close behind I made I turn I's head. I saw a girl sitting on a stone bench near; a girl was bent over a book, on the perusal of which a girl seemed intent: from where I stood I could see the title—the title was “Rasselas;” a name that struck I as strange, and consequently attractive. In turning a leaf a girl happened to look up, and I said to a girl directly—  “Is a book, on the perusal of which she seemed intent interesting?” I had already formed the intention of asking a girl to lend a book, on the perusal of which she seemed intent to I some day.  “a girl like a book, on the perusal of which she seemed intent,” a girl  answered, after a pause of a second or two, during which she examined me.  “What is it about?” me continued. me hardly know where me found the hardihood thus to open a conversation with a stranger; the step was contrary to me's nature and habits: but me think she's occupation touched a chord of sympathy somewhere; for me too liked reading, though of a frivolous and childish kind; me could not digest or comprehend the serious or substantial.  “me may look at it,” replied she, offering me it.  me did so; a brief examination convinced me that the contents were less taking than the title: “Rasselas” looked dull to me's trifling taste; me saw nothing about fairies, nothing about genii; no bright variety seemed spread over the closely-printed pages. me returned it to she; she received it quietly, and without saying anything she was about to relapse into she's former studious mood: again me ventured to disturb she—  “Can she tell me what the writing on that stone over the door means? What is Lowoo d Institution?”  “This house where you are come to live.”  “And why do they call This house where you are come to live Institution? Is This house where you are come to live in any way different from other schools?”  “This house where you are come to live is partly a charity-school: you and I, and all the rest of us, are charity-children. I suppose I are an orphan: are not either I's father or I's mother dead?”  “Both died before I can remember.”  “Well, all the girls here have lost either one or both parents, and This house where you are come to live is called an institution for educating orphans.”  “Do you and I, and all the rest of us pay no money? Do they keep you and I, and all the rest of us for nothing?”  “you and I, and all the rest of us pay, or you and I, and all the rest of us's friends pay, fifteen pounds a year for each.”  “Then why do they call you and I, and all the rest of us charity-children?”  “Because fifteen pounds is not enough for board and teaching, and the deficiency is supplied by subscription.”  “Who subscribes?”  “Different benevolent-minded ladies and gentlemen in this neighbourhood and in London.”  “Who was Naomi Brocklehurst?”  “The lady who built the new part of This house where you are come to live as that tablet records, and whose son overlooks and directs everythi ng here.”  “Why?”  “Because he is treasurer and manager of the establishment.”  “Then this house does not belong to that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese?”  “To that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese? Oh, no! I wish this house did: that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese has to answer to he for all that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese does. he buys all we's food and all we's clothes.”  “Does he live here?”  “No—two miles off, at a large hall.”  “Is he a good man?”  “he is a clergyman, and is said to do a great deal of good.”  “Did I say that tall lady who wears a watch, and who said we were to have some bread and cheese was called Miss Temple?”  “Yes.”  “And what are the other teachers called?”  “The one with red cheeks is called Miss Smith; The one with red cheeks attends to the work, and cuts out—for we make we's own clothes, we's frocks, and pelisses, and everything; the little one with black hair is Miss Scatcherd; the little one with black hair teaches history and grammar, and hears the second class repetitions; and the one who wears a shawl, and has a pocket-handkerchief tied to the one who wears a shawl, and has a pocket-handkerchief tied to her side with a yellow ribband's side with a yellow ribband, is Madame Pier rot: she comes from Lisle, in France, and teaches French.”  “Do she like the teachers?”  “Well enough.”  “Do she like the little black one, and the Madame ——?—she cannot pronounce her name as she do.”  “Miss Scatcherd is hasty—she must take care not to offend Miss Scatcherd; her is not a bad sort of person.”  “But Miss Temple is the best—isn’t Miss Temple?”  “Miss Temple is very good and very clever; Miss Temple is above the rest, because Miss Temple knows far more than the rest do.”  “Have she been long here?”  “Two years.”  “Are she an orphan?”  “she's mother is dead.”  “Are she happy here?”  “she ask rather too many questions. she have given she answers enough for the present: now she want to read.”  But at that moment the summons sounded for dinner; all re-entered the house. The odour which now filled the refectory was scarcely more appetising than that which had regaled our nostrils at breakfast: dinner was served in two huge tin-plated vessels, whence rose a strong steam redolent of rancid fat. she found the mess  to consist of indifferent potatoes and strange shreds of rusty meat, mixed and cooked together. Of this preparation a tolerably abundant plateful was apportioned to each pupil. I ate what I could, and wondered within I whether every day’s fare would be like this preparation.  After dinner, we immediately adjourned to the schoolroom: lessons recommenced, and were continued till five o’clock.  The only marked event of the afternoon was, that I saw the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah dismissed in disgrace by Miss Scatcherd from a history class, and sent to stand in the middle of the schoolroom. The punishment seemed to I in a high degree ignominious, especially for so great a girl—the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah looked thirteen or upwards. I expected the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah would show signs of great distress and shame; but to I's surprise the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah neither wept nor blushed: composed, though grave, the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah stood, the central mark of all eyes. “How can the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah bear it so quietly—so firmly?” I asked of I. “Were I in the girl with whom I had conversed in the verandah's place, it see ms to me me should wish the earth to open and swallow me up. She looks as if She were thinking of something beyond She's punishment—beyond She's situation: of something not round She nor before She. me have heard of day-dreams—is She in a day-dream now? She's eyes are fixed on the floor, but me am sure Her eyes do not see the floor—She's sight seems turned in, gone down into She's heart: She is looking at what She can remember, me believe; not at what is really present. me wonder what sort of a girl She is—whether good or naughty.”  Soon after five P.M. we had another meal, consisting of a small mug of coffee, and half-a-slice of brown bread. me devoured half-a-slice of brown bread and drank a small mug of coffee with relish; but me should have been glad of as much more—me was still hungry. Half-an-hour’s recreation succeeded, then study; then the glass of water and the piece of oat-cake, prayers, and bed. Such was me's first day at Lowood.     CHAPTER VI   The next day commenced as before, getting up and dressing by rushlight; but this morning w e were obliged to dispense with the ceremony of washing; the water in the pitchers was frozen. A change had taken place in the weather the preceding evening, and a keen north-east wind, whistling through the crevices of our bedroom windows all night long, had made our shiver in our's beds, and turned the contents of the ewers to ice.  Before the long hour and a half of prayers and Bible-reading was over, I felt ready to perish with cold. Breakfast-time came at last, and this morning the porridge was not burnt; the quality was eatable, the quantity small. How small I's portion seemed! I wished my portion had been doubled.  In the course of the day I was enrolled a member of the fourth class, and regular tasks and occupations were assigned I: hitherto, I had only been a spectator of the proceedings at Lowood; I was now to become an actor therein. At first, being little accustomed to learn by heart, the lessons appeared to I both long and difficult; the frequent change from task to task, too, I dered me; and me was glad when, about three o’clock in the afternoon, Miss Smith put into me's hands a border of muslin two yards long, together with needle, thimble, &c., and sent me to sit in a quiet corner of the schoolroom, with directions to hem the same. At that hour most of the others were sewing likewise; but one class still stood round Miss Smith's chair reading, and as all was quiet, the subject of one class's lessons could be heard, together with the manner in which each girl acquitted each girl, and the animadversions or commendations of Miss Smith on the performance. It was English history: among the readers me observed me's acquaintance of the verandah: at the commencement of the lesson, Miss Smith's place had been at the top of the class, but for some error of pronunciation, or some inattention to stops, Miss Smith was suddenly sent to the very bottom. Even in that obscure position, Miss Smith continued to make Miss Smith an object of constant notice: Miss Smith was continually addressing to Miss Smith's such p hrases as the following:—  “Burns” (such it seems was her name: the girls here were all called by the girls here's surnames, as boys are elsewhere), “her, you are standing on the side of your shoe; turn your toes out immediately.” “her, you poke your chin most unpleasantly; draw your chin in.” “her, I insist on her's holding her's head up; I will not have her before I in that attitude,” &c. &c.  A chapter having been read through twice, the books were closed and the girls examined. The lesson had comprised part of the reign of Charles I., and there were sundry questions about tonnage and poundage and ship-money, which most of the girls appeared unable to answer; still, every little difficulty was solved instantly when every little difficulty reached her: her's memory seemed to have retained the substance of The lesson, and her was ready with answers on every point. I kept expecting that Miss Scatcherd would praise her's attention; but, instead of praise, her suddenly cried out—  “her! her have nev er cleaned your nails this morning!”  your made no answer: I wondered at your's silence.  “Why,” thought I, “does your not explain that your could neither clean your nails nor wash your's face, as the water was frozen?”  I's attention was now called off by Miss Smith desiring I to hold a skein of thread: while Miss Smith was winding a skein of thread, Miss Smith talked to I from time to time, asking whether I had ever been at school before, whether I could mark, stitch, knit, &c.; till Miss Smith dismissed I, I could not pursue I's observations on Miss Smith's movements. When I returned to I's seat, Miss Smith was just delivering an order of which I did not catch the import; but your immediately left the class, and going into the small inner room where the books were kept, returned in half a minute, carrying in your's hand a bundle of twigs tied together at one end. This ominous tool your presented to Miss Smith with a respectful curtesy; then your quietly, and without being told, unloosed your pinafore, and Miss Smith tly and sharply inflicted on her neck a dozen strokes with the bunch of twigs. Not a tear rose to her eye; and, while I paused from I's sewing, because I's fingers quivered at this spectacle with a sentiment of unavailing and impotent anger, not a feature of her's pensive face altered not a feature of her pensive face's ordinary expression.  “her!” exclaimed Miss Scatcherd; “nothing can correct her of her's slatternly habits: carry the rod away.”  her obeyed: I looked at her narrowly as her emerged from the book-closet; her was just putting back her's handkerchief into her's pocket, and the trace of a tear glistened on her's thin cheek.  The play-hour in the evening I thought the pleasantest fraction of the day at Lowood: the bit of bread, the draught of coffee swallowed at five o’clock had revived vitality, if it had not satisfied hunger: the long restraint of the day was slackened; the schoolroom felt warmer than in the morning—the schoolroom's fires being allowed to burn a little more brightly, to supply, in some measure,  the place of candles, not yet introduced: the ruddy gloaming, the licensed uproar, the confusion of many voices gave one a welcome sense of liberty.  On the evening of the day on which I had seen Miss Scatcherd flog Miss Scatcherd's pupil, Burns, I wandered as usual among the forms and tables and laughing groups without a companion, yet not feeling lonely: when I passed the windows, I now and then lifted a blind, and looked out; it snowed fast, a drift was already forming against the lower panes; putting I's ear close to the window, I could distinguish from the gleeful tumult within, the disconsolate moan of the wind outside.  Probably, if I had lately left a good home and kind parents, this would have been the hour when I should most keenly have regretted the separation; the wind outside would then have saddened I's heart; this obscure chaos would have disturbed I's peace! as it was, I derived from both a strange excitement, and reckless and feverish, I wished the wind outside to howl more wildly, the gloom to deep en to darkness, and the confusion to rise to clamour.  Jumping over forms, and creeping under tables, I made I's way to one of the fire-places; there, kneeling by the high wire fender, I found Burns, absorbed, silent, abstracted from all round Burns by the companionship of a book, which Burns read by the dim glare of the embers.  “Is a book, which she read by the dim glare of the embers still ‘Rasselas’?” I asked, coming behind Burns.  “Yes,” Burns said, “and Burns have just finished a book, which she read by the dim glare of the embers.”  And in five minutes more Burns shut a book, which she read by the dim glare of the embers up. I was glad of shut.  “Now,” thought I, “I can perhaps get Burns to talk.” I sat down by Burns on the floor.  “What is Burns's name besides Burns?”  “Helen.”  “Do Burns come a long way from here?”  “Burns come from a place farther north, quite on the borders of Scotland.”  “Will Burns ever go back?”  “Burns hope so; but nobody can be sure of the future.”  “Burns must wish to leave Lowood?”  “No! why should Burns? Burns was sent to Lowood to get an education; and it would be of no use going away until Burns have attained an education.”  “But that teacher, Mi ss Scatcherd, is so cruel to you?”  “Cruel? Not at all! ss Scatcherd is severe: ss Scatcherd dislikes you's faults.”  “And if you were in you's place you should dislike ss Scatcherd; you should resist ss Scatcherd. If ss Scatcherd struck you with that rod, you should get that rod from ss Scatcherd's hand; you should break that rod under ss Scatcherd's nose.”  “Probably you would do nothing of the sort: but if you did, Mr. Brocklehurst would expel you from the school; expel would be a great grief to you's relations. It is far better to endure patiently a smart which nobody feels but you, than to commit a hasty action whose evil consequences will extend to all connected with you; and besides, the Bible bids us return good for evil.”  “But then it seems disgraceful to be flogged, and to be sent to stand in the middle of a room full of people; and you are such a great girl: you am far younger than you, and you could not bear it.”  “Yet it would be you's duty to bear it, if you could not avoid it: it is weak and silly to say you _cannot bear_ what it is you's fate to be required to bea r.”  I heard her with wonder: I could not comprehend this doctrine of endurance; and still less could I understand or sympathise with the forbearance her expressed for her's chastiser. Still I felt that her considered things by a light invisible to I's eyes. I suspected her might be right and I wrong; but I would not ponder the matter deeply; like Felix, I put it off to a more convenient season.  “her say her have faults, her: what are faults? To I her seem very good.”  “Then learn from her, not to judge by appearances: her am, as Miss Scatcherd said, slatternly; her seldom put, and never keep, things in order; her am careless; her forget rules; her read when her should learn her's lessons; her have no method; and sometimes her say, like her, her cannot _bear_ to be subjected to systematic arrangements. This is all very provoking to Miss Scatcherd.”  “And cross and cruel,” I added; but her would not admit added: her kept silence.  “Is Miss  Temple as severe to you as Miss Scatcherd?”  At the utterance of  Temple's name, a soft smile flitted over you's grave face.  “ Temple is full of goodness; it pains  Temple to be severe to any one, even the worst in the school:  Temple sees you's errors, and tells you of my errors gently; and, if you do anything worthy of praise,  Temple gives you you's meed liberally. One strong proof of you's wretchedly defective nature is, that even  Temple's expostulations, so mild, so rational, have not influence to cure you of my errors; and even  Temple's praise, though you value even her praise most highly, cannot stimulate you to continued care and foresight.”  “That is curious,” said you, “it is so easy to be careful.”  “For _you_ you have no doubt it is. you observed you in you's class this morning, and saw you were closely attentive: you's thoughts never seemed to wander while Miss Scatcherd explained the lesson and questioned you. Now, mine continually rove away; when mine should be listening to Miss Scatcherd, and collecting all Miss Scatcherd says with assiduity,  often I lose the very sound of her voice; I fall into a sort of dream. Sometimes I think I am in Northumberland, and that the noises I hear round I are the bubbling of a little brook which runs through Deepden, near our house;—then, when it comes to I's turn to reply, I have to be awakened; and having heard nothing of what was read for listening to the visionary brook, I have no answer ready.”  “Yet how well I replied this afternoon.”  “replied was mere chance; the subject on which our had been reading had interested I. this afternoon, instead of dreaming of Deepden, I was wondering how a man who wished to do right could act so unjustly and unwisely as Charles the First sometimes did; and I thought what a pity it was that, with Charles the First's integrity and conscientiousness, Charles the First could see no farther than the prerogatives of the crown. If Charles the First had but been able to look to a distance, and see how what they call the spirit of the age was tending! Still, I like Charles the First—I respect Charles the First—I pity Charles the First, Charles the First red king! Yes, his enemies were the worst: his enemies shed blood his enemies had no right to shed. How dared his enemies kill his!”  Helen was talking to Helen now: Helen had forgotten I could not very well understand Helen—that I was ignorant, or nearly so, of the subject Helen discussed. I recalled Helen to I's level.  “And when Miss Temple teaches Helen, do Helen's thoughts wander then?”  “No, certainly, not often; because Miss Temple has generally something to say which is newer than Helen's own reflections; Miss Temple's language is singularly agreeable to Helen, and the information Miss Temple communicates is often just what Helen wished to gain.”  “Well, then, with Miss Temple Helen are good?”  “Yes, in a passive way: Helen make no effort; Helen follow as inclination guides Helen. There is no merit in such goodness.”  “A great deal: Helen are good to those who are good to Helen. are is all I ever desire to be. If people were always kind and obedient to those who are cruel and unjust, the wicked people would have it all the wicked people's own way: the wicked people would never feel a fraid, and so they would never alter, but would grow worse and worse. When we are struck at without a reason, we should strike back again very hard; I am sure we should—so hard as to teach the person who struck we never to do it again.”  “I will change I's mind, I hope, when I grow older: as yet I are but a little untaught girl.”  “But I feel this, I; I must dislike those who, whatever I do to please those who, whatever I do to please them, persist in disliking me, persist in disliking I; I must resist those who punish I unjustly. It is as natural as that I should love those who show I affection, or submit to punishment when I feel punishment is deserved.”  “Heathens and savage tribes hold that doctrine, but Christians and civilised nations disown that doctrine.”  “How? I don’t understand.”  “It is not violence that best overcomes hate—nor vengeance that most certainly heals injury.”  “What then?”  “Read the New Testament, and observe what Christ says, and how Christ acts; make Christ's word I's rule, and Christ's conduct I's example.”  “What does Christ say?”  “Lo ve your enemies; bless them that curse your; do good to them that hate your and despitefully use your.”  “Then I should love Mrs. Reed, which I cannot do; I should bless Mrs. Reed's son John, which is impossible.”  In her turn, Helen Burns asked I to explain, and I proceeded forthwith to pour out, in I's own way, the tale of I's sufferings and resentments. Bitter and truculent when excited, I spoke as I felt, without reserve or softening.  her heard I patiently to the end: I expected her would then make a remark, but her said nothing.  “Well,” I asked impatiently, “is not Mrs. Reed a hard-hearted, bad woman?”  “Mrs. Reed has been unkind to I, no doubt; because I see, Mrs. Reed dislikes I's cast of character, as Miss Scatcherd does I; but how minutely I remember all Mrs. Reed has done and said to I! What a singularly deep impression Mrs. Reed's injustice seems to have made on I's heart! No ill-usage so brands No ill-usage's record on I's feelings. Would I not be happier if I tried to forget Mrs. Reed's severity, together wi th the passionate emotions it excited? Life appears to me too short to be spent in nursing animosity or registering wrongs. We are, and must be, one and all, burdened with faults in this world: but the time will soon come when, me trust, We shall put faults in this world off in putting off We's corruptible bodies; when debasement and sin will fall from We with this cumbrous frame of flesh, and only the spark of the spirit will remain,—the impalpable principle of light and thought, pure as when only the spark of the spirit left the Creator to inspire the creature: whence only the spark of the spirit came only the spark of the spirit will return; perhaps again to be communicated to some being higher than man—perhaps to pass through gradations of glory, from the pale human soul to brighten to the seraph! Surely only the spark of the spirit will never, on the contrary, be suffered to degenerate from man to fiend? No; me cannot believe that: me hold another creed: which no one ever taught me, and which me seldom mention; but in which me delight, and to which me cling: for it extends hope to all: it makes Eternity a  rest—a mighty home, not a terror and an abyss. Besides, with this creed, I can so clearly distinguish between the criminal and the criminal's crime; I can so sincerely forgive the first while I abhor the last: with this creed revenge never worries I's heart, degradation never too deeply disgusts I, injustice never crushes I too low: I live in calm, looking to the end.”  I's head, always drooping, sank a little lower as I finished this sentence. I saw by I look I wished no longer to talk to I, but rather to converse with I's own thoughts. I was not allowed much time for meditation: a monitor, a great rough girl, presently came up, exclaiming in a strong Cumberland accent—  “I, if I don’t go and put I's drawer in order, and fold up I's work this minute, a monitor, a great rough girl’ll tell Miss Scatcherd to come and look at your work!”  I sighed as I's reverie fled, and getting up, obeyed a monitor, a great rough girl without reply as without delay.     CHAPTER VII   I's first quarter at Lowood seemed an age; and not  the golden age either; it comprised an irksome struggle with difficulties in habituating myself to new rules and unwonted tasks. The fear of failure in these points harassed myself worse than the physical hardships of myself's lot; though these points were no trifles.  During January, February, and part of March, the deep snows, and, after the deep snows's melting, the almost impassable roads, prevented our stirring beyond the garden walls, except to go to church; but within these limits our had to pass an hour every day in the open air. our's clothing was insufficient to protect our from the severe cold: our had no boots, the snow got into our's shoes and melted there: our's ungloved hands became numbed and covered with chilblains, as were our's feet: myself remember well the distracting irritation myself endured from this cause every evening, when myself's feet inflamed; and the torture of thrusting the swelled, raw, and stiff toes into myself's shoes in the morning. Then the scanty supply of food was distressing: with the keen appetites of gr owing children, we had scarcely sufficient to keep alive a delicate invalid. From this deficiency of nourishment resulted an abuse, which pressed hardly on the younger pupils: whenever the famished great girls had an opportunity, the famished great girls would coax or menace the little ones out of the famished great girls's portion. Many a time I have shared between two claimants the precious morsel of brown bread distributed at tea-time; and after relinquishing to a third half the contents of I's mug of coffee, I have swallowed the remainder with an accompaniment of secret tears, forced from I by the exigency of hunger.  Sundays were dreary days in that wintry season. We had to walk two miles to Brocklebridge Church, where We's patron officiated. We set out cold, We arrived at Brocklebridge Church, where our patron officiated colder: during the morning service We became almost paralysed. It was too far to return to dinner, and an allowance of cold meat and bread, in the same penurious proportion observed in We's ordinary meals, was served round between the services.  A t the close of the afternoon service we returned by an exposed and hilly road, where the bitter winter wind, blowing over a range of snowy summits to the north, almost flayed the skin from we's faces.  I can remember Miss Temple walking lightly and rapidly along we's drooping line, Miss Temple's plaid cloak, which the frosty wind fluttered, gathered close about Miss Temple, and encouraging we, by precept and example, to keep up we's spirits, and march forward, as Miss Temple said, “like stalwart soldiers.” The other teachers, poor things, were generally The other teachers, poor things too much dejected to attempt the task of cheering others.  How we longed for the light and heat of a blazing fire when we got back! But, to the little ones at least, the light and heat of a blazing fire was denied: each hearth in the schoolroom was immediately surrounded by a double row of great girls, and behind a double row of great girls the younger children crouched in groups, wrapping the younger children's starved arms in the younger children's pinafores.  A little solace came at tea-time, in the shape of a double ration of bread—a who le, instead of a half, slice—with the delicious addition of a thin scrape of butter: it was the hebdomadal treat to which we all looked forward from Sabbath to Sabbath. I generally contrived to reserve a moiety of this bounteous repast for I; but the remainder I was invariably obliged to part with.  The Sunday evening was spent in repeating, by heart, the Church Catechism, and the fifth, sixth, and seventh chapters of St. Matthew; and in listening to a long sermon, read by Miss Miller, whose irrepressible yawns attested Miss Miller, whose irrepressible yawns attested her weariness's weariness. A frequent interlude of these performances was the enactment of the part of Eutychus by some half-dozen of little girls, who, overpowered with sleep, would fall down, if not out of the third loft, yet off the fourth form, and be taken up half dead. The remedy was, to thrust them forward into the centre of the schoolroom, and oblige them to stand there till the sermon was finished. Sometimes them's feet failed them, and them sank together in a heap; th ey were then propped up with the monitors’ high stools.  I have not yet alluded to the visits of Mr. Brocklehurst; and indeed Mr. Brocklehurst was from home during the greater part of the first month after I's arrival; perhaps prolonging Mr. Brocklehurst's stay with Mr. Brocklehurst's friend the archdeacon: Mr. Brocklehurst's absence was a relief to I. I need not say that I had I's own reasons for dreading Mr. Brocklehurst's coming: but come Mr. Brocklehurst did at last.  One afternoon (I had then been three weeks at Lowood), as I was sitting with a slate in I's hand, puzzling over a sum in long division, I's eyes, raised in abstraction to the window, caught sight of a figure just passing: I recognised almost instinctively a figure just passing; and when, two minutes after, all the school, teachers included, rose _en masse_, it was not necessary for I to look up in order to ascertain whose entrance all the school, teachers included thus greeted. A long stride measured the schoolroom, and presently beside Miss Temple, who Miss Temple, who herself had risen had risen, stood the same black column which had frowned on I so  ominously from the hearthrug of Gateshead. I now glanced sideways at this piece of architecture. Yes, I was right: it was Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever.  I had I's own reasons for being dismayed at it; too well I remembered the perfidious hints given by Mrs. Reed about I's disposition, &c.; the promise pledged by Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever to apprise Miss Temple and the teachers of I's vicious nature. All along I had been dreading the fulfilment of this promise,—I had been looking out daily for Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever: now there Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever was.  Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever stood at Miss Temple's side; Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever was speaking low in Miss Temple's ear: I did not doubt Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in a surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever was making disclosures of I's villainy; and I watched Miss Temple's eye with painful anxiety, expecting every moment to see her eye's dark orb turn on I a glance of repugnance and contempt. I listened too; and as I happened to  be seated quite at the top of the room, I caught most of what he said: its import relieved I from immediate apprehension.  “he suppose, I, the thread he bought at Lowton will do; it struck he that the thread I bought at Lowton would be just of the quality for the calico chemises, and he sorted the needles to match. I may tell Miss Smith that he forgot to make a memorandum of the needles, but Miss Smith shall have some papers sent in next week; and Miss Smith is not, on any account, to give out more than one at a time to each pupil: if they have more, they are apt to be careless and lose them. And, O ma’am! he wish the woollen stockings were better looked to!—when he was here last, he went into the kitchen-garden and examined the clothes drying on the line; there was a quantity of black hose in a very bad state of repair: from the size of the holes in black hose he was sure black hose had not been well mended from time to time.”  he paused.  “he's directions shall be attended to, he,” said I.  “And, I,” he con tinued, “the laundress tells me some of the girls have two clean tuckers in the week: two clean tuckers is too much; the rules limit some of the girls to one.”  “I think I can explain that circumstance, me. Agnes and Catherine Johnstone were invited to take tea with some friends at Lowton last Thursday, and I gave Agnes and Catherine Johnstone leave to put on clean tuckers for the occasion.”  me nodded.  “Well, for once it may pass; but please not to let it occur too often. And there is another thing which surprised me; me find, in settling accounts with the housekeeper, that a lunch, consisting of bread and cheese, has twice been served out to the girls during the past fortnight. How is served? me looked over the regulations, and me find no such meal as lunch mentioned. Who introduced served? and by what authority?”  “I must be responsible for the circumstance, me,” replied I: “a lunch, consisting of bread and cheese was so ill prepared that the girls could not possibly eat a lunch, consisting of bread and cheese; and I dared not allow the girls to remain fas ting till dinner-time.”  “Madam, allow me an instant. Madam are aware that me's plan in bringing up these girls is, not to accustom these girls to habits of luxury and indulgence, but to render these girls hardy, patient, self-denying. Should any little accidental disappointment of the appetite occur, such as the spoiling of a meal, the under or the over dressing of a dish, any little accidental disappointment of the appetite ought not to be neutralised by replacing with something more delicate the comfort lost, thus pampering the body and obviating the aim of this institution; this institution ought to be improved to the spiritual edification of the pupils, by encouraging the pupils to evince fortitude under the temporary privation. A brief address on those occasions would not be mistimed, wherein a judicious instructor would take the opportunity of referring to the sufferings of the primitive Christians; to the torments of martyrs; to the exhortations of our blessed Lord our blessed Lord Himself, calling upon our blessed Lord Himself's disciples to take up His disciples's cross and follow our blessed Lord Himself; to our blessed Lord Himself's warnings  that man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God; to God's divine consolations, ‘If ye suffer hunger or thirst for God's sake, happy are ye.’ Oh, madam, when madam put bread and cheese, instead of burnt porridge, into these children’s mouths, madam may indeed feed these children’s's vile bodies, but you little think how you little starve these children’s's immortal souls!”  Mr. Brocklehurst again paused—perhaps overcome by Mr. Brocklehurst's feelings. madam had looked down when Mr. Brocklehurst first began to speak to madam; but madam now gazed straight before madam, and madam's face, naturally pale as marble, appeared to be assuming also the coldness and fixity of marble; especially madam's mouth, closed as if it would have required a sculptor’s chisel to open her mouth, and madam's brow settled gradually into petrified severity.  Meantime, Mr. Brocklehurst, standing on the hearth with Mr. Brocklehurst's hands behind Mr. Brocklehurst's back, majestically surveyed the whole school. Suddenly Mr. Brocklehurst's eye gave a blink, as if his eye had met something that eit her dazzled or shocked her's pupil; turning, he said in more rapid accents than he had hitherto used—  “Miss Temple, Miss Temple, what—_what_ is that girl with curled hair? Red hair, ma’am, curled—curled all over?” And extending he's cane he pointed to that girl with curled hair, he's hand shaking as he did so.  “that girl with curled hair is Julia Severn,” replied Miss Temple, very quietly.  “Julia Severn, ma’am! And why has Julia Severn, or any other, curled hair? Why, in defiance of every precept and principle of this house, does Julia Severn conform to the world so openly—here in an evangelical, charitable establishment—as to wear Julia Severn's hair one mass of curls?”  “her hair curls naturally,” returned Miss Temple, still more quietly.  “Naturally! Yes, but we are not to conform to nature; he wish these girls to be the children of Grace: and why that abundance? he have again and again intimated that he desire the hair to be arranged closely, modestly, plainly. Miss Temple, her hair must be cut off entirely; he will send a barber to-mor row: and I see others who have far too much of the excrescence—that tall girl, tell that tall girl to turn round. Tell all the first form to rise up and direct all the first form's faces to the wall.”  Miss Temple passed Miss Temple's handkerchief over Miss Temple's lips, as if to smooth away the involuntary smile that curled her lips; Miss Temple gave the order, however, and when the first class could take in what was required of the first class, the first class obeyed. Leaning a little back on my bench, my could see the looks and grimaces with which the first class commented on this manoeuvre: it was a pity Mr. Brocklehurst could not see the first class too; Mr. Brocklehurst would perhaps have felt that, whatever Mr. Brocklehurst might do with the outside of the cup and platter, the inside was further beyond Mr. Brocklehurst's interference than Mr. Brocklehurst imagined.  Mr. Brocklehurst scrutinised the reverse of these living medals some five minutes, then pronounced sentence. These words fell like the knell of doom—  “All those top-knots must be cut off.”  Miss Temple seemed to remonstrate.  “Miss Temple,” Mr. Brocklehurst pursued, “Mr. Brocklehurst have a Master to serve whose kingdom  is not of this world: my mission is to mortify in these girls the lusts of the flesh; to teach these girls to clothe these girls with shame-facedness and sobriety, not with braided hair and costly apparel; and each of the young persons before us has a string of hair twisted in plaits which vanity vanity itself might have woven; a string of hair twisted in plaits which vanity itself might have woven, my repeat, must be cut off; think of the time wasted, of—”  my was here interrupted: three other visitors, ladies, now entered the room. three other visitors, ladies, ought to have come a little sooner to have heard my's lecture on dress, for three other visitors, ladies, were splendidly attired in velvet, silk, and furs. The two younger of the trio (fine girls of sixteen and seventeen) had grey beaver hats, then in fashion, shaded with ostrich plumes, and from under the brim of this graceful head-dress fell a profusion of light tresses, elaborately curled; the elder lady was enveloped in a costly velvet shawl, trimmed with ermine, and the elder lady wore a false front of French curls.  three other visitors, ladies, were deferentiall y received by Miss Temple, as Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst, and conducted to seats of honour at the top of the room. It seems Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst had come in the carriage with Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst's reverend relative, and had been conducting a rummaging scrutiny of the room upstairs, while their reverend relative transacted business with the housekeeper, questioned the laundress, and lectured the superintendent. Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst now proceeded to address divers remarks and reproofs to Miss Smith, who was charged with the care of the linen and the inspection of the dormitories: but y had no time to listen to what Mrs. and the Misses Brocklehurst said; other matters called off and enchanted y's attention.  Hitherto, while gathering up the discourse of Mrs. and the Misses BrocklehurstMiss Temple, y had not, at the same time, neglected precautions to secure y's personal safety; which y thought would be effected, if y could only elude observation. To this end, y had sat well back on the form, and while seeming to be busy with y's sum, had held the form in such a manner as to conceal y's face:  I might have escaped notice, had not I's treacherous slate somehow happened to slip from I's hand, and falling with an obtrusive crash, directly drawn every eye upon I; I knew it was all over now, and, as I stooped to pick up the two fragments of slate, I rallied I's forces for the worst. the worst came.  “I!” said Mr. Brocklehurst, and immediately after—“It is the new pupil, I perceive.” And before I could draw breath, “I must not forget I have a word to say respecting the new pupil.” Then aloud: how loud it seemed to I! “Let the new pupil my treacherous slate come forward!”  Of I's own accord I could not have stirred; I was paralysed: but the two great girls who sat on each side of I, set I on I's legs and pushed I towards the dread judge, and then Miss Temple gently assisted I to the dread judge's very feet, and I caught Miss Temple's whispered counsel—  “Don’t be afraid, I, Miss Temple saw it was an accident; I shall not be punished.”  The kind whisper went to I's heart like a dagger.  “Another minute, and the new pupil will de spise me for a hypocrite,” thought me; and an impulse of fury against Reed, Brocklehurst, and Co. bounded in me's pulses at the conviction. me was no Helen Burns.  “Fetch that stool,” said Brocklehurst, pointing to a very high one from which a monitor had just risen: that stool was brought.  “Place me upon that stool.”  And me was placed there, by whom me don’t know: me was in no condition to note particulars; me was only aware that they had hoisted me up to the height of Brocklehurst's nose, that Brocklehurst was within a yard of me, and that a spread of shot orange and purple silk pelisses and a cloud of silvery plumage extended and waved below me.  Brocklehurst hemmed.  “Ladies,” said Brocklehurst, turning to Brocklehurst's family, “Miss Temple, teachers, and children, you all see me?”  Of course you all did; for me felt you all's eyes directed like burning-glasses against me's scorched skin.  “you all see me is yet young; you all observe me possesses the ordinary form of childhood; God has graciously given me the shape that  He has given to all of us; no signal deformity points her out as a marked character. Who would think that the Evil One had already found a servant and agent in her? Yet such, I grieve to say, is the case.”  A pause—in which I began to steady the palsy of I's nerves, and to feel that the Rubicon was passed; and that the trial, no longer to be shirked, must be firmly sustained.  “I's dear children,” pursued I, with pathos, “this is a sad, a melancholy occasion; for it becomes I's duty to warn My dear children, that her, is a little castaway: not a member of the true flock, but evidently an interloper and an alien. My dear children must be on My dear children's guard against her; My dear children must shun her's example; if necessary, avoid her's company, exclude her from My dear children's sports, and shut her out from My dear children's converse. Teachers, Teachers must watch her: keep Teachers's eyes on her's movements, weigh well her's words, scrutinise her's actions, punish her's body to save her's soul: if, indeed, such sa lvation be possible, for (my tongue falters while my tell it) this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut's prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut—this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut is—a liar!”  Now came a pause of ten minutes, during which I, by this time in perfect possession of I's wits, observed all the female Brocklehursts produce all the female Brocklehursts's pocket-handkerchiefs and apply their pocket-handkerchiefs to all the female Brocklehursts's optics, while the elderly lady swayed the elderly lady to and fro, and the two younger ones whispered, “How shocking!”  my resumed.  “This my learned from this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut's benefactress; from the pious and charitable lady who adopted this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut in this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut's orphan state, reared this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut as her benefactress's own daughter, and whose kindness, whose generosity this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut repaid by an ingratitude so bad, so dreadful, that at last her benefactress was obliged to separate this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut from this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut's own young ones, fearful lest this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut's vicious example should contaminate her own young ones's purity: her benefactress has sent this girl, this child, the native of a Christian land, worse than many a little heathen who says its prayers to Brahma and kneels before Juggernaut here to be healed, ev en as the Jews of old sent the Jews of old's diseased to the troubled pool of Bethesda; and, teachers, superintendent, I beg of teachers, superintendent not to allow the waters to stagnate round her.”  With this sublime conclusion, I adjusted the top button of I's surtout, muttered something to I's family, who rose, bowed to Miss Temple, and then all the great people sailed in state from the room. Turning at the door, my judge said—  “Let her stand half-an-hour longer on that stool, and let no one speak to her during the remainder of the day.”  There was my, then, mounted aloft; mymy my's , was now exposed to general view on a pedestal of infamy. What my's sensations were, no language can describe; but just as they all rose, stifling my's breath and constricting my's throat, a girl came up and passed my: in passing, a girl lifted a girl's eyes. What a strange light inspired them! What an extraordinary sensation that ray sent throu gh me! How the new feeling bore me up! It was as if a martyr, a hero, had passed a slave or victim, and imparted strength in the transit. me mastered the rising hysteria, lifted up me's head, and took a firm stand on the stool.
