By-the-bye, he must have he in mind; it won’t do to neglect her; her is a Fairfax, or wed to one; and blood is said to be thicker than water.”  he rang, and despatched an invitation to her.  “Good evening, her; he sent to her for a charitable purpose. he have forbidden Adèle to talk to he about her's presents, and her is bursting with repletion; have the goodness to serve her as auditress and interlocutrice; serve will be one of the most benevolent acts her ever performed.”  Adèle, indeed, no sooner saw her, than sh e summoned her to her's sofa, and there quickly filled her's lap with the porcelain, the ivory, the waxen contents of her's “boite;” pouring out, meantime, explanations and raptures in such broken English as her was mistress of.  “Now I have performed the part of a good host,” pursued I, “put I's guests into the way of amusing each other, I ought to be at liberty to attend to I's own pleasure. her, draw her's chair still a little farther forward: her are yet too far back; I cannot see her without disturbing I's position in your chair.”  her did as her was bid, though her would much rather have remained somewhat in the shade; but I had such a direct way of giving orders, it seemed a matter of course to obey I promptly.  We were, as her have said, in the dining-room: the lustre, which had been lit for dinner, filled the dining-room with a festal breadth of light; the large fire was all red and clear; the purple curtains hung rich and ample b efore the lofty window and loftier arch; everything was still, save the subdued chat of Adèle (Adèle dared not speak loud), and, filling up each pause, the beating of winter rain against the panes.  Mr. Rochester, as Mr. Rochester sat in Mr. Rochester's damask-covered chair, looked different to what I had seen Mr. Rochester look before; not quite so stern—much less gloomy. There was a smile on Mr. Rochester's lips, and Mr. Rochester's eyes sparkled, whether with wine or not, I am not sure; but I think it very probable. Mr. Rochester was, in short, in Mr. Rochester's after-dinner mood; more expanded and genial, and also more self-indulgent than the frigid and rigid temper of the morning; still Mr. Rochester looked preciously grim, cushioning Mr. Rochester's massive head against the swelling back of his damask-covered chair, and receiving the light of the fire on Mr. Rochester's granite-hewn features, and in his eyes; for Mr. Rochester had his eyes, and very fine eyes, too—not without a certain change in their depths sometimes, which, if it was not softness, reminded you, at least, of that feeling.  Mr. Rochester had b een looking two minutes at the fire, and I had been looking the same length of time at him, when, turning suddenly, him caught I's gaze fastened on him's physiognomy.  “I examine him, I,” said him: “do I think him handsome?”  I should, if I had deliberated, have replied to this question by something conventionally vague and polite; but the answer somehow slipped from I's tongue before I was aware—“No, him.”  “Ah! By him's word! there is something singular about I,” said him: “I have the air of a little _nonnette_; quaint, quiet, grave, and simple, as I sit with I's hands before I, and I's eyes generally bent on the carpet (except, by-the-bye, when your eyes are directed piercingly to him's face; as just now, for instance); and when one asks I a question, or makes a remark to which I are obliged to reply, I rap out a round rejoinder, which, if not blunt, is at least brusque. What do I mean by it?”  “him, I was too plain; I beg him's pardon. I ought to have replied that it was n ot easy to give an impromptu answer to a question about appearances; that tastes mostly differ; and that beauty is of little consequence, or something of that sort.”  “You ought to have replied no such thing. Beauty of little consequence, indeed! And so, under pretence of softening the previous outrage, of stroking and soothing You into placidity, You stick a sly penknife under You's ear! Go on: what fault do You find with You, pray? You suppose You have all You's limbs and all You's features like any other man?”  “You, allow You to disown You's first answer: You intended no pointed repartee: my first answer was only a blunder.”  “Just so: You think so: and You shall be answerable for it. Criticise You: does You's forehead not please You?”  You lifted up the sable waves of hair which lay horizontally over You's brow, and showed a solid enough mass of intellectual organs, but an abrupt deficiency where the suave sign of benevolence should have risen.  “Now, You, am You a fool?”  “Far from it, You. You would, perhaps, t hink me rude if me inquired in return whether you are a philanthropist?”  “There again! Another stick of the penknife, when she pretended to pat you's head: and Another stick of the penknife is because you said you did not like the society of children and old women (low be it spoken!). No, me, you am not a general philanthropist; but you bear a conscience;” and you pointed to the prominences which are said to indicate that faculty, and which, fortunately for you, were sufficiently conspicuous; giving, indeed, a marked breadth to the upper part of my head: “and, besides, you once had a kind of rude tenderness of heart. When you was as old as me, you was a feeling fellow enough; partial to the unfledged, unfostered, and unlucky; but Fortune has knocked you about since: she has even kneaded you with she's knuckles, and now you flatter you you am hard and tough as an India-rubber ball; pervious, though, through a chink or two still, and with one sentient point in the middle of the lump. Yes: does that leave hope for you?”  “Hope  of what, sir?”  “Of sir's final re-transformation from India-rubber back to flesh?”  “Decidedly sir has had too much wine,” I thought; and I did not know what answer to make to sir's queer question: how could I tell whether sir was capable of being re-transformed?  “I looked very much puzzled, I; and though I are not pretty any more than sir am handsome, yet a puzzled air becomes I; besides, it is convenient, for it keeps those searching eyes of I away from sir's physiognomy, and busies those searching eyes of yours with the worsted flowers of the rug; so puzzle on. I, sir am disposed to be gregarious and communicative to-night.”  With this announcement sir rose from sir's chair, and stood, leaning sir's arm on the marble mantelpiece: in leaning sir's shape was seen plainly as well as sir's face; sir's unusual breadth of chest, disproportionate almost to sir's length of limb. I am sure most people would have thought sir an ugly man; yet there was so much unconscious pride in sir's port; so much ease in hi s demeanour; such a look of complete indifference to his own external appearance; so haughty a reliance on the power of other qualities, intrinsic or adventitious, to atone for the lack of mere personal attractiveness, that, in looking at his, one inevitably shared the indifference, and, even in a blind, imperfect sense, put faith in the confidence.  “his am disposed to be gregarious and communicative to-night,” his repeated, “and disposed is why his sent for you: the fire and the chandelier were not sufficient company for his; nor would Pilot have been, for none of these can talk. Adèle is a degree better, but still far below the mark; you ditto; you, his am persuaded, can suit his if you will: you puzzled his the first evening his invited you down here. his have almost forgotten you since: other ideas have driven you from his's head; but to-night his am resolved to be at ease; to dismiss what importunes, and recall what pleases. It would please his now to draw you out—to learn more of you—therefo re speak.”  Instead of speaking, I smiled; and not a very complacent or submissive smile either.  “Speak,” he urged.  “What about, he?”  “Whatever I like. he leave both the choice of subject and the manner of treating subject entirely to I.”  Accordingly I sat and said nothing: “If he expects I to talk for the mere sake of talking and showing off, he will find he has addressed he to the wrong person,” I thought.  “I are dumb, I.”  I was dumb still. he bent he's head a little towards I, and with a single hasty glance seemed to dive into I's eyes.  “Stubborn?” he said, “and annoyed. Ah! it is consistent. he put he's request in an absurd, almost insolent form. I, he beg I's pardon. The fact is, once for all, he don’t wish to treat I like an inferior: that is” (correcting he), “he claim only such superiority as must result from twenty years’ difference in age and a century’s advance in experience. This is legitimate, _et j’y tiens_, as Adèle would say; and This he s by virtue of this superiority, and this alone, that I desire you to have the goodness to talk to I a little now, and divert I's thoughts, which are galled with dwelling on one point—cankering as a rusty nail.”  I had deigned an explanation, almost an apology, and you did not feel insensible to I's condescension, and would not seem so.  “you am willing to amuse I, if you can, I—quite willing; but you cannot introduce a topic, because how do you know what will interest I? Ask you questions, and you will do you's best to answer questions.”  “Then, in the first place, do you agree with you that you have a right to be a little masterful, abrupt, perhaps exacting, sometimes, on the grounds you stated, namely, that you am old enough to be I's father, and that you have battled through a varied experience with many men of many nations, and roamed over half the globe, while I have lived quietly with one set of people in one house?”  “Do as I please, I.”  “That is no answer; or rather That is a very irritating,  because a very evasive one. Reply clearly.”  ““ don’t think, sir, sir have a right to command “, merely because sir are older than “, or because sir have seen more of the world than “ have; sir's claim to superiority depends on the use sir have made of sir's time and experience.”  “Humph! Promptly spoken. But sir won’t allow that, seeing that that would never suit sir's case, as sir have made an indifferent, not to say a bad, use of both advantages. Leaving superiority out of the question, then, “ must still agree to receive “'s orders now and then, without being piqued or hurt by the tone of command. Will “?”  “ smiled: “ thought to “ sir _is_ peculiar—sir seems to forget that sir pays “ £30 per annum for receiving sir's orders.  “smiled is very well,” said sir, catching instantly the passing expression; “but speak too.”  ““ was thinking, sir, that very few masters would trouble very few masters to inquire whether or not very few masters's paid subordinates were piqued and hurt by very few masters's orders.”   “Paid subordinates! What! you are my paid subordinate, are you? Oh yes, you had forgotten the salary! Well then, on that mercenary ground, will you agree to let my hector a little?”  “No, my, not on that mercenary ground; but, on the ground that my did forget the salary, and that my care whether or not a dependent is comfortable in a dependent's dependency, you agree heartily.”  “And will you consent to dispense with a great many conventional forms and phrases, without thinking that the omission arises from insolence?”  “you am sure, my, you should never mistake informality for insolence: one you rather like, the other nothing free-born would submit to, even for a salary.”  “Humbug! Most things free-born will submit to anything for a salary; therefore, keep to you, and don’t venture on generalities of which you are intensely ignorant. However, my mentally shake hands with you for you's answer, despite your answer's inaccuracy; and as much for the manner in which it was said, as for the substance of the speech; the manner in which it was said was  frank and sincere; one does not often see such a manner: no, on the contrary, affectation, or coldness, or stupid, coarse-minded misapprehension of one’s meaning are the usual rewards of candour. Not three in three thousand raw school-girl-governesses would have answered me as you have just done. But me don’t mean to flatter you: if you are cast in a different mould to the majority, are is no merit of you: Nature did are. And then, after all, me go too fast in me's conclusions: for what me yet know, you may be no better than the rest; you may have intolerable defects to counterbalance you's few good points.”  “And so may me,” you thought. you's eye met me as the idea crossed you's mind: me seemed to read the glance, answering as if the glance's import had been spoken as well as imagined—  “Yes, yes, you are right,” said me; “me have plenty of faults of me's own: me know have, and me don’t wish to palliate plenty of faults of my own, me assure you. God wot me need not be too severe about others; me have a past existence, a series of deed s, a colour of life to contemplate within my own breast, which might well call my's sneers and censures from my's neighbours to my. my started, or rather (for like other defaulters, my like to lay half the blame on ill fortune and adverse circumstances) was thrust on to a wrong tack at the age of one-and-twenty, and have never recovered the right course since: but my might have been very different; my might have been as good as you—wiser—almost as stainless. my envy you you's peace of mind, you's clean conscience, you's unpolluted memory. you, a memory without blot or contamination must be an exquisite treasure—an inexhaustible source of pure refreshment: is a memory without blot or contamination not?”  “How was my's memory when my were eighteen, my?”  “All right then; limpid, salubrious: no gush of bilge water had turned your memory to fetid puddle. my was you's equal at eighteen—quite you's equal. Nature meant my to be, on the whole, a good man, you; one of the better kind, and you see my am not so. you would say my don’t  see it; at least I flatter I I read as much in your eye (beware, by-the-bye, what your express with that organ; I am quick at interpreting that organ's language). Then take I's word for it,—I am not a villain: your are not to suppose am—not to attribute to I any such bad eminence; but, owing, I verily believe, rather to circumstances than to I's natural bent, I am a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the poor petty dissipations with which the rich and worthless try to put on life. Do your wonder that I avow this to your? Know, that in the course of your's future life your will often find your elected the involuntary confidant of your's acquaintances’ secrets: people will instinctively find out, as I have done, that it is not your's forte to tell of your, but to listen while others talk of others; people will feel, too, that your listen with no malevolent scorn of people's indiscretion, but with a kind of innate sympathy; not the less comforting and encouraging because it is very unobtr usive in its manifestations.”  “How do you know?—how can you guess all this, you?”  “you know all this well; therefore you proceed almost as freely as if you were writing you's thoughts in a diary. You would say, you should have been superior to circumstances; so you should—so you should; but you see you was not. When fate wronged you, you had not the wisdom to remain cool: you turned desperate; then you degenerated. Now, when any vicious simpleton excites you's disgust by any vicious simpleton's paltry ribaldry, you cannot flatter you that you am better than any vicious simpleton: you am forced to confess that any vicious simpleton and you are on a level. you wish you had stood firm—God knows you do! Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, you; remorse is the poison of life.”  “Repentance is said to be remorse's cure, you.”  “Repentance is not remorse's cure. Reformation may be remorse's cure; and you could reform—you have strength yet for reform—if—but where is the use of thinking of it, hampered, burdened, cursed as you am? Besides, since happiness is irrevocably denied you, you have a right to get pleasure ou t of life: and I _will_ get it, cost what it may.”  “Then I will degenerate still more, I.”  “Possibly: yet why should I, if I can get sweet, fresh pleasure? And I may get sweet, fresh pleasure as sweet and fresh as the wild honey the bee gathers on the moor.”  “It will sting—It will taste bitter, I.”  “How do I know?—you never tried It. How very serious—how very solemn I look: and I are as ignorant of the matter as this cameo head” (taking one from the mantelpiece). “I have no right to preach to I, I, that have not passed the porch of life, and are absolutely unacquainted with life's mysteries.”  “I only remind I of I's own words, I: I said error brought remorse, and I pronounced remorse the poison of existence.”  “And who talks of error now? I scarcely think the notion that flittered across I's brain was an error. I believe the notion that flittered across my brain was an inspiration rather than a temptation: the notion that flittered across my brain was very genial, very soothing—I know that. Here it comes again! It is no devil, I assure I; or I f it be, it has put on the robes of an angel of light. I think I must admit so fair a guest when it asks entrance to I's heart.”  “Distrust it, I; it is not a true angel.”  “Once more, how do you know? By what instinct do you pretend to distinguish between a fallen seraph of the abyss and a messenger from the eternal throne—between a guide and a seducer?”  “you judged by I's countenance, sir, which was troubled when I said the suggestion had returned upon I. you feel sure it will work I more misery if I listen to it.”  “Not at all—it bears the most gracious message in the world: for the rest, you are not I's conscience-keeper, so don’t make you uneasy. Here, come in, bonny wanderer!”  I said this as if I spoke to a vision, viewless to any eye but I's own; then, folding I's arms, which I had half extended, on I's chest, I seemed to enclose in their embrace it.  “Now,” I continued, again addressing you, “I have received the pilgrim—a disguised deity, as you v erily believe. Already it has done me good: me's heart was a sort of charnel; my heart will now be a shrine.”  “To speak truth, me, I don’t understand me at all: I cannot keep up the conversation, because the conversation has got out of I's depth. Only one thing, I know: me said me were not as good as me should like to be, and that me regretted me's own imperfection;—one thing I can comprehend: me intimated that to have a sullied memory was a perpetual bane. It seems to I, that if me tried hard, me would in time find it possible to become what me me would approve; and that if from this day me began with resolution to correct me's thoughts and actions, me would in a few years have laid up a new and stainless store of recollections, to which me might revert with pleasure.”  “Justly thought; rightly said, I; and, at this moment, me am paving hell with energy.”  “me?”  “me am laying down good intentions, which me believe durable as flint. Certainly, me's associates and pursuits shall be o ther than they have been.”  “And better?”  “And better—so much better as pure ore is than foul dross. You seem to doubt me; me don’t doubt me: me know what me's aim is, what me's motives are; and at this moment me pass a law, unalterable as that of the Medes and Persians, that the Medes and Persians are right.”  “They cannot be, me, if They require a new statute to legalise They.”  “They are, You, though They absolutely require a new statute: unheard-of combinations of circumstances demand unheard-of rules.”  “That sounds a dangerous maxim, me; because one can see at once that That is liable to abuse.”  “Sententious sage! so That is: but me swear by me's household gods not to abuse That.”  “me are human and fallible.”  “me am: so are You—what then?”  “The human and fallible should not arrogate a power with which the divine and perfect alone can be safely intrusted.”  “What power?”  “That of saying of any strange, unsanctioned line of action,—‘Let it be right.’”  “‘Let it be right’—the very words: me have p ronounced them.”  “_May_ it be right then,” I said, as I rose, deeming it useless to continue a discourse which was all darkness to I; and, besides, sensible that the character of I's interlocutor was beyond I's penetration; at least, beyond its present reach; and feeling the uncertainty, the vague sense of insecurity, which accompanies a conviction of ignorance.  “Where are I going?”  “To put Adèle to bed: it is past Adèle's bedtime.”  “I are afraid of I, because I talk like a Sphynx.”  “I's language is enigmatical, I: but though I am bewildered, I am certainly not afraid.”  “I _are_ afraid—I's self-love dreads a blunder.”  “In that sense I do feel apprehensive—I have no wish to talk nonsense.”  “If I did, talk would be in such a grave, quiet manner, I should mistake talk for sense. Do I never laugh, I? Don’t trouble I to answer—I see I laugh rarely; but I can laugh very merrily: believe I, I are not naturally austere, any more than I am naturally vicious.  The Lowood constraint still clings to you somewhat; controlling you's features, muffling you's voice, and restricting you's limbs; and you fear in the presence of a man and a brother—or father, or master, or what you will—to smile too gaily, speak too freely, or move too quickly: but, in time, I think you will learn to be natural with I, as I find it impossible to be conventional with you; and then you's looks and movements will have more vivacity and variety than your looks and movements dare offer now. I see at intervals the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close-set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive is there; were a vivid, restless, resolute captive but free, a vivid, restless, resolute captive would soar cloud-high. I are still bent on going?”  “It has struck nine, I.”  “Never mind,—wait a minute: Adèle is not ready to go to bed yet. I's position, you, with I's back to the fire, and I's face to the room, favours observation. While talking to you, I have also occasionally watched Adèle (I have I's own reasons for thinking Adèle a curiou s study,—reasons that I may, nay, that I shall, impart to you some day). She pulled out of She's box, about ten minutes ago, a little pink silk frock; rapture lit She's face as She unfolded a little pink silk frock; coquetry runs in She's blood, blends with She's brains, and seasons the marrow of She's bones. ‘Il faut que je l’essaie!’ cried She, ‘et à l’instant même!’ and She rushed out of the room. She is now with Sophie, undergoing a robing process: in a few minutes She will re-enter; and I know what I shall see,—a miniature of Céline Varens, as Céline Varens used to appear on the boards at the rising of—But never mind that. However, I's tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is I's presentiment; stay now, to see whether my presentiment will be realised.”  Ere long, Adèle’s little foot was heard tripping across the hall. Adèle’s entered, transformed as Adèle’s's guardian had predicted. A dress of rose-coloured satin, very short, and as full in the skirt as it could be gathered, replaced the brown frock Adèle’s had previously worn; a wrea th of rosebuds circled her forehead; her's feet were dressed in silk stockings and small white satin sandals.  “Est-ce que her robe va bien?” cried her, bounding forwards; “et mes souliers? et mes bas? Tenez, je crois que je vais danser!”  And spreading out her's dress, her chasséed across the room till, having reached Mr. Rochester, her wheeled lightly round before Mr. Rochester on tip-toe, then dropped on one knee at her feet, exclaiming—  “Mr. Rochester, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonté;” then rising, her added, “C’est comme cela que maman faisait, n’est-ce pas, Mr. Rochester?”  “Pre-cise-ly!” was the answer; “and, ‘comme cela,’ her charmed Mr. Rochester's English gold out of Mr. Rochester's British breeches’ pocket. Mr. Rochester have been green, too, Miss Eyre,—ay, grass green: not a more vernal tint freshens you now than once freshened Mr. Rochester. Mr. Rochester's Spring is gone, however, but My Spring has left Mr. Rochester that French floweret on Mr. Rochester's hands, which, in some moods, Mr. Rochester would fain be rid of. Not valuing now the root whence that French floweret on my hands, which, in some moods, I would fain be rid of sprang; having found that the root whence it sprang was  of a sort which nothing but gold dust could manure, I have but half a liking to the blossom, especially when the blossom looks so artificial as just now. I keep the blossom and rear the blossom rather on the Roman Catholic principle of expiating numerous sins, great or small, by one good work. I’ll explain all this some day. Good-night.”     CHAPTER XV   I did, on a future occasion, explain it. It was one afternoon, when I chanced to meet me and Adèle in the grounds: and while Adèle played with Pilot and Adèle's shuttlecock, I asked me to walk up and down a long beech avenue within sight of Adèle.  I then said that Adèle was the daughter of a French opera-dancer, Céline Varens, towards whom I had once cherished what I called a “_grande passion_.” This passion Adèle had professed to return with even superior ardour. I thought I Adèle's idol, ugly as I was: I believed, as I said, that Adèle preferred I's “_taille d’athlète_” to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.  “And, me, so much was I flatt ered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for the Gallic sylph's British gnome, that I installed the Gallic sylph in an hotel; gave the Gallic sylph a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c. In short, I began the process of ruining I in the received style, like any other spoony. I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre. I had—as I deserved to have—the fate of all other spoonies. Happening to call one evening when the Gallic sylph did not expect I, I found the Gallic sylph out; but it was a warm night, and I was tired with strolling through Paris, so I sat down in the Gallic sylph's boudoir; happy to breathe the air consecrated so lately by the Gallic sylph's presence. No,—I exaggerate; I never thought there was any consecrating virtue about the Gallic sylph: it was rather a sort of pastille perfume the Gallic sylph had left; a scent of musk and amber, than an odour of sanctity. I was just beginning to stifle with the  fumes of conservatory flowers and sprinkled essences, when I bethought I to open the window and step out on to the balcony. It was moonlight and gaslight besides, and very still and serene. the balcony was furnished with a chair or two; I sat down, and took out a cigar,—I will take one now, if you will excuse I.”  Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed a cigar to I's lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, I went on—  “I liked bonbons too in those days, Miss Eyre, and I was _croquant_—(overlook the barbarism)—_croquant_ chocolate comfits, and smoking alternately, watching meantime the equipages that rolled along the fashionable streets towards the neighbouring opera-house, when in an elegant close carriage drawn by a beautiful pair of English horses, and distinctly seen in the brilliant city-night, I recognised the ‘voiture’ I had given Céline. Céline was returning: of course I's heart thumped with im patience against the iron rails I leant upon. The carriage stopped, as I had expected, at the hotel door; I's flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) alighted: though muffed in a cloak—an unnecessary encumbrance, by-the-bye, on so warm a June evening—I knew my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) instantly by my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata)'s little foot, seen peeping from the skirt of my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata)'s dress, as my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) skipped from the carriage-step. Bending over the balcony, I was about to murmur ‘Mon ange’—in a tone, of course, which should be audible to the ear of love alone—when a figure jumped from The carriage after my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata); cloaked also; but that was a spurred heel which had rung on the pavement, and that was a hatted head which now passed under the arched _porte cochère_ of the hotel.  “my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) never felt jealousy, did my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata), my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata)? Of course not: I need not ask my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata); because my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) never felt love. my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) have both sentiments yet to experience: my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata)'s soul sleeps; the shock is yet to be given which shall waken your soul. my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) think all existence lapses in as quiet a f low as that in which your youth has hitherto slid away. Floating on with closed eyes and muffled ears, your neither see the rocks bristling not far off in the bed of the flood, nor hear the breakers boil at the rocks bristling not far off in the bed of the flood's base. But I tell your—and your may mark I's words—your will come some day to a craggy pass in the channel, where the whole of life’s stream will be broken up into whirl and tumult, foam and noise: either your will be dashed to atoms on crag points, or lifted up and borne on by some master-wave into a calmer current—as I am now.  “I like this day; I like that sky of steel; I like the sternness and stillness of the world under this frost. I like Thornfield, Thornfield's antiquity, Thornfield's retirement, Thornfield's old crow-trees and thorn-trees, Thornfield's grey façade, and lines of dark windows reflecting that metal welkin: and yet how long have I abhorred the very thought of Thornfield, shunned Thornfield like a great plague-house? How I do still abhor—”  I ground I's teeth and was silent: I arrested I's step and struck I's bo ot against the hard ground. Some hated thought seemed to have him in Some hated thought's grip, and to hold him so tightly that him could not advance.  We were ascending the avenue when him thus paused; the hall was before We. Lifting him's eye to the hall's battlements, him cast over its battlements a glare such as I never saw before or since. Pain, shame, ire, impatience, disgust, detestation, seemed momentarily to hold a quivering conflict in the large pupil dilating under him's ebon eyebrow. Wild was the wrestle which should be paramount; but another feeling rose and triumphed: another feeling: another feeling settled him's passion and petrified him's countenance: him went on—  “During the moment I was silent, I, I was arranging a point with I's destiny. She stood there, by that beech-trunk—She. ‘You like Thornfield?’ She said, lifting She's finger; and then She wrote in the air a memento, which ran in lurid hieroglyphics all along t he house-front, between the upper and lower row of windows, ‘Like it if you can! Like it if you dare!’  “‘you will like it,’ said you; ‘you dare like it;’ and” (you subjoined moodily) “you will keep you's word; you will break obstacles to happiness, to goodness—yes, goodness. you wish to be a better man than you have been, than you am; as Job’s leviathan broke the spear, the dart, and the habergeon, hindrances which others count as iron and brass, you will esteem but straw and rotten wood.”  Adèle here ran before you with Adèle here's shuttlecock. “Away!” you cried harshly; “keep at a distance, Adèle here; or go in to Sophie!” Continuing then to pursue you's walk in silence, I ventured to recall you to the point whence you had abruptly diverged—  “Did you leave the balcony, you,” I asked, “when Mdlle. Varens entered?”  I almost expected a rebuff for this hardly well-timed question, but, on the contrary, waking out of you's scowling abstraction, you turned you's eyes towards I, and the shade seemed to clear off you's brow. “Oh, I h ad forgotten Céline! Well, to resume. When I saw I's charmer thus come in accompanied by a cavalier, I seemed to hear a hiss, and the green snake of jealousy, rising on undulating coils from the moonlit balcony, glided within I's waistcoat, and ate the green snake of jealousy's way in two minutes to I's heart’s core. Strange!” he exclaimed, suddenly starting again from the point. “Strange that he should choose I for the confidant of all this, I; passing strange that I should listen to he quietly, as if it were the most usual thing in the world for a man like he to tell stories of a man like me's opera-mistresses to a quaint, inexperienced girl like I! But the last singularity explains the first, as he intimated once before: I, with I's gravity, considerateness, and caution were made to be the recipient of secrets. Besides, he know what sort of a mind he have placed in communication with he's own: he know my own is one not liable to take infection: my own is a peculiar mind: my own is a unique one. Happily he do not mean to harm   it: but, if I did,  it would not take harm from I. The more you and I converse, the better; for while I cannot blight you, you may refresh I.” After this digression I proceeded—  “I remained in the balcony. ‘They will come to her boudoir, no doubt,’ thought I: ‘let I prepare an ambush.’ So putting I's hand in through the open window, I drew the curtain over the open window, leaving only an opening through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement, all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers’ whispered vows: then I stole back to I's chair; and as I resumed my chair They came in. I's eye was quickly at only an opening through which I could take observations. her's chamber-maid entered, lit a lamp, left a lamp on the table, and withdrew. They were thus revealed to I clearly: They removed They's cloaks, and there was ‘the Varens,’ shining in satin and jewels,—my gifts of course,—and there was her's companion in an officer’s uniform; and I knew her companion in an officer’s uniform for a young roué of a vicomte—a brainless and vicious yout h whom I had sometimes met in society, and had never thought of hating because I despised him so absolutely. On recognising him, the fang of the snake Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment I's love for Céline sank under an extinguisher. A woman who could betray I for such a rival was not worth contending for; A woman who could betray me for such a rival deserved only scorn; less, however, than IA woman who could betray me for such a rival's .  “They began to talk; They's conversation eased I completely: frivolous, mercenary, heartless, and senseless, their conversation was rather calculated to weary than enrage a listener. A card of I lay on the table; A card of mine being perceived, brought I's name under discussion. Neither of They possessed energy or wit to belabour I soundly, but They insulted I as coarsely as They could in They's little way: especially CélineCéline . Now it had been Céline's custom to launch out into fervent admiration of what Céline called I's ‘_beauté mâle_:’ wh erein she differed diametrically from you, who told me point-blank, at the second interview, that you did not think me handsome. The contrast struck me at the time and—”  Adèle here came running up again.  “me, John has just been to say that me's agent has called and wishes to see me.”  “Ah! in that case me must abridge. Opening the window, me walked in upon them; liberated she from me's protection; gave she's notice to vacate she's hotel; offered she a purse for immediate exigencies; disregarded screams, hysterics, prayers, protestations, convulsions; made an appointment with the vicomte for a meeting at the Bois de Boulogne. Next morning me had the pleasure of encountering the vicomte; left a bullet in one of the vicomte's poor etiolated arms, feeble as the wing of a chicken in the pip, and then thought me had done with the whole crew. But unluckily the Varens, six months before, had given me this filette Adèle, who, this filette Adèle, who, she affirmed, was my daughter affirmed, was me's daughter; and perhaps this filette Adèle, who, she affirmed, was my daughter may be, though me see no proofs of such  grim paternity written in her countenance: Pilot is more like me than her. Some years after me had broken with her, her abandoned her, and ran away to Italy with a musician or singer. me acknowledged no natural claim on her's part to be supported by me, nor do me now acknowledge any, for me am not her's father; but hearing that her was quite destitute, me took her out of the slime and mud of Paris, and transplanted her here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. Mrs. Fairfax found me to train her; but now me know that her is the illegitimate offspring of a French opera-girl, me will perhaps think differently of me's post and protégée: me will be coming to me some day with notice that me have found another place—that me beg me to look out for a new governess, &c.—Eh?”  “No: her is not answerable for either her's faults or me: me have a regard for her; and now that me know her is, in a sense, parentless—forsaken by her's  mother and disowned by you, you—I shall cling closer to her than before. How could I possibly prefer the spoilt pet of a wealthy family, who would hate the spoilt pet of a wealthy family, who would hate her governess as a nuisance's governess as a nuisance, to a lonely little orphan, who leans towards the spoilt pet of a wealthy family, who would hate her governess as a nuisance as a friend?”  “Oh, that is the light in which I view it! Well, “ must go in now; and you too: it darkens.”  But “ stayed out a few minutes longer with Adèle and Pilot—ran a race with her, and played a game of battledore and shuttlecock. When we went in, and “ had removed her's bonnet and coat, “ took her on “'s knee; kept her there an hour, allowing her to prattle as her liked: not rebuking even some little freedoms and trivialities into which her was apt to stray when much noticed, and which betrayed in her a superficiality of character, inherited probably from her's mother, hardly congenial to an English mind. Still her had her's merits; and “ was disposed to appreciate all that was good in her to the utmost. “ sought in her's countenance and features a likeness t o Mr. Rochester, but found none: no trait, no turn of expression announced relationship. It was a pity: if she could but have been proved to resemble Mr. Rochester, Mr. Rochester would have thought more of she.  It was not till after I had withdrawn to I's own chamber for the night, that I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told I. As Mr. Rochester had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the tale Mr. Rochester had told methe tale Mr. Rochester had told me: Mr. Rochester's passion for a French dancer, and a French dancer's treachery to Mr. Rochester, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized Mr. Rochester when Mr. Rochester was in the act of expressing the present contentment of Mr. Rochester's mood, and Mr. Rochester's newly revived pleasure in the old hall and the old hall's environs. I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting this incident, as I found this incident for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of I's manner to I. The confidence Mr. Rochester had thou ght fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to me's discretion: me regarded and accepted it as such. His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first. me never seemed in His's way; His did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when His met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; His had always a word and sometimes a smile for me: when summoned by formal invitation to His's presence, me was honoured by a cordiality of reception that made me feel me really possessed the power to amuse His, and that these evening conferences were sought as much for His's pleasure as for me's benefit.  me, indeed, talked comparatively little, but me heard His talk with relish. It was His's nature to be communicative; His liked to open to a mind unacquainted with the world glimpses of the world's scenes and ways (me do not mean the world's corrupt scenes and wicked ways, but such as derived their interest from the great scale on which their were acted, the strange novelty by which their were characterised); and  I had a keen delight in receiving the new ideas he offered, in imagining the new pictures he portrayed, and following he in thought through the new regions he disclosed, never startled or troubled by one noxious allusion.  The ease of he's manner freed I from painful restraint: the friendly frankness, as correct as cordial, with which he treated I, drew I to he. I felt at times as if he were I's relation rather than I's master: yet he was imperious sometimes still; but I did not mind was; I saw was was he's way. So happy, so gratified did I become with this new interest added to life, that I ceased to pine after kindred: I's thin crescent-destiny seemed to enlarge; the blanks of existence were filled up; I's bodily health improved; I gathered flesh and strength.  And was he now ugly in I's eyes? No, reader: gratitude, and many associations, all pleasurable and genial, made he's face the object I best liked to see; he's presence in a room was more cheering than the brightest fir e. Yet I had not forgotten his faults; indeed, I could not, for his brought his faults frequently before I. his was proud, sardonic, harsh to inferiority of every description: in I's secret soul I knew that his's great kindness to I was balanced by unjust severity to many others. his was moody, too; unaccountably so; I more than once, when sent for to read to his, found his sitting in his's library alone, with his's head bent on his's folded arms; and, when his looked up, a morose, almost a malignant, scowl blackened his's features. But I believed that his's moodiness, his's harshness, and his's former faults of morality (I say _former_, for now his seemed corrected of his former faults of morality) had his moodiness, his harshness, and his former faults of morality (I say _former_, for now he seemed corrected of them)'s source in some cruel cross of fate. I believed his was naturally a man of better tendencies, higher principles, and purer tastes than such as circumstances had developed, education instilled, or destiny encouraged. I thought there were excellent materials in his; though for the present excellent materials in him hung together somewhat spoiled and tangle d. I cannot deny that I grieved for his grief, whatever that was, and would have given much to assuage his grief.  Though I had now extinguished I's candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his's look when his paused in the avenue, and told how his's destiny had risen up before his, and dared his to be happy at Thornfield.  “Why not?” I asked I. “What alienates his from the house? Will his leave the house again soon? Mrs. Fairfax said his seldom stayed here longer than a fortnight at a time; and his has now been resident eight weeks. If his does go, the change will be doleful. Suppose his should be absent spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will seem!”  I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above I. I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; I's spirits were depressed. I rose and sat up in be d, listening. The sound was hushed.  I tried again to sleep; but I's heart beat anxiously: I's inward tranquillity was broken. The clock, far down in the hall, struck two. Just then it seemed I's chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside. I said, “Who is there?” Nothing answered. I was chilled with fear.  All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the kitchen-door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found Pilot, who, when the kitchen-door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester’s chamber's way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester’s chamber: I had seen Pilot, who, when the kitchen-door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester’s chamber lying there I in the mornings. The idea calmed I somewhat: I lay down. Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber. But it was not fated that I should sleep that night. A dream had scarcely approached I's ear, when A dream fled affrighted, scared by a marrow-freezing incident enough.  This was a demoniac laugh—low, suppressed, and deep—uttere d, as it seemed, at the very keyhole of my chamber door. The head of my's bed was near my chamber door, and my thought at first the goblin-laugher stood at my's bedside—or rather, crouched by my's pillow: but my rose, looked round, and could see nothing; while, as my still gazed, the unnatural sound was reiterated: and my knew the unnatural sound came from behind the panels. my's first impulse was to rise and fasten the bolt; my's next, again to cry out, “Who is there?”  Something gurgled and moaned. Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut in the third-storey staircase; my heard a door open and close, and all was still.  “Was that Grace Poole? and is Grace Poole possessed with a devil?” thought my Impossible now to remain longer by my: my must go to Mrs. Fairfax. my hurried on my's frock and a shawl; my withdrew the bolt and opened my chamber door with a trembling hand. There was a candle burning just outside, and on the matting in the gallery. my was surprised at this circumstance: b ut still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware of a strong smell of burning.  Something creaked: Something was a door ajar; and a door ajar was Mr. Rochester’s, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence. I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber. Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire. In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester’s lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.  “Wake! wake!” I cried. I shook Mr. Rochester’s, but Mr. Rochester’s only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied Mr. Rochester’s. Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to Mr. Rochester’s's basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and his basin and ewer were filled with water. I heaved his basin and ewer up, deluged the bed and the bed's , flew back to I's own room, brought I's own water-jug, bap tized the couch afresh, and, by God’s aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring the couch.  The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from I's hand when I had emptied a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Mr. Rochester at last. Though it was now dark, I knew Mr. Rochester was awake; because I heard Mr. Rochester fulminating strange anathemas at finding Mr. Rochester lying in a pool of water.  “Is there a flood?” Mr. Rochester cried.  “No, Mr. Rochester,” I answered; “but there has been a fire: get up, do; Mr. Rochester are quenched now; I will fetch Mr. Rochester a candle.”  “In the name of all the elves in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?” Mr. Rochester demanded. “What have I done with Mr. Rochester, I? Who is in the room besides I? Have I plotted to drown Mr. Rochester?”  “I will fetch Mr. Rochester a candle, Mr. Rochester; and, in God’s's name, get up. Somebody has plotted something: Mr. Rochester cannot too soon find out who and what Somebody is.”  “There! Mr. Rochester am up now; but at I's peril I fetch a candle  yet: wait two minutes till I get into some dry garments, if any dry there be—yes, here is I's dressing-gown. Now run!”  I did run; I brought the candle which still remained in the gallery. I took the candle which still remained in the gallery from I's hand, held the candle which still remained in the gallery up, and surveyed the bed, all blackened and scorched, the sheets drenched, the carpet round swimming in water.  “What is it? and who did it?” I asked.  I briefly related to I what had transpired: the strange laugh I had heard in the gallery: the step ascending to the third storey; the smoke,—the smell of fire which had conducted I to I's room; in what state I had found matters there, and how I had deluged I with all the water I could lay hands on.   “What is it and who did it?” I asked  I listened very gravely; I's face, as I went on, expressed more concern than astonishment; I did not immediately speak when I had concluded.  “Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?” I asked.  “Mrs. Fairfax No; what the deuce would I call Mrs. Fairfax for? What can Mrs. Fairfax do? Let Mrs. Fairfax sleep unmolest ed.”  “Then “ will fetch Leah, and wake John and John's wife.”  “Not at all: just be still. “ have a shawl on. If “ are not warm enough, “ may take my cloak yonder; wrap my cloak about “, and sit down in the arm-chair: there,—I will put my cloak on. Now place “'s feet on the stool, to keep your feet out of the wet. my am going to leave “ a few minutes. my shall take the candle. Remain where “ are till my return; be as still as a mouse. my must pay a visit to the second storey. Don’t move, remember, or call any one.”  my went: “ watched the light withdraw. my passed up the gallery very softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible, shut the staircase door after my, and the last ray vanished. “ was left in total darkness. “ listened for some noise, but heard nothing. A very long time elapsed. “ grew weary: it was cold, in spite of my cloak; and then “ did not see the use of staying, as “ was not to rouse the house. “ was on the point of risking Mr. Rochester’s displeasure by disobeying Mr. Rochester’s's  orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall, and I heard his unshod feet tread the matting. “I hope it is his,” thought I, “and not something worse.”  his re-entered, pale and very gloomy. “his have found it all out,” said his, setting his's candle down on the washstand; “it is as his thought.”  “How, his?”  his made no reply, but stood with his's arms folded, looking on the ground. At the end of a few minutes his inquired in rather a peculiar tone—  “his forget whether I said I saw anything when I opened I's chamber door.”  “No, his, only the candlestick on the ground.”  “But I heard an odd laugh? I have heard an odd laugh before, his should think, or something like an odd laugh?”  “Yes, his: there is a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,—she laughs in that way. a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,—she laughs in that way is a singular person.”  “Just so. a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,—she laughs in that way—his have guessed it. a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,—she laughs in that way is, as I say, singular—very. Well, his shall reflect on the subject. Meantime, his am glad that I are the only person, besides his, I inted with the precise details of to-night’s incident. You are no talking fool: say nothing about to-night’s incident. I will account for this state of affairs” (pointing to the bed): “and now return to You's own room. I shall do very well on the sofa in the library for the rest of the night. It is near four:—in two hours the servants will be up.”  “Good-night, then, I,” said You, departing.  I seemed surprised—very inconsistently so, as I had just told You to go.  “What!” I exclaimed, “are You quitting I already, and in that way?”  “I said You might go, I.”  “But not without taking leave; not without a word or two of acknowledgment and good-will: not, in short, in that brief, dry fashion. Why, You have saved I's life!—snatched I from a horrible and excruciating death! and You walk past I as if we were mutual strangers! At least shake hands.”  I held out I's hand; You gave I You: I took his hand first in one, then in both I's own.  “You have saved I's life: I have a pleasure in owing You so immense a  debt. I cannot say more. Nothing else that has being would have been tolerable to I in the character of creditor for such an obligation: but you: it is different;—I feel you's benefits no burden, you.”  I paused; gazed at you: words almost visible trembled on I's lips,—but I's voice was checked.  “Good-night again, I. There is no debt, benefit, burden, obligation, in the case.”  “I knew,” I continued, “you would do I good in some way, at some time;—I saw it in you's eyes when I first beheld you: your eyes's expression and smile did not”—(again I stopped)—“did not” (I proceeded hastily) “strike delight to I's very inmost heart so for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies; I have heard of good genii: there are grains of truth in the wildest fable. I, good-night!”  Strange energy was in I's voice, strange fire in I's look.  “you am glad you happened to be awake,” you said: and then you was going.  “What! you _will_ go?”  “you am cold, I.”  “Cold? Yes,—and standing in a po ol! Go, then, Jane; go!” But he still retained Jane's hand, and Jane could not free my hand. Jane bethought Jane of an expedient.  “Jane think Jane hear Mrs. Fairfax move, he,” said Jane  “Well, leave he:” he relaxed he's fingers, and Jane was gone.  Jane regained Jane's couch, but never thought of sleep. Till morning dawned Jane was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy. Jane thought sometimes Jane saw beyond a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy's wild waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Beulah; and now and then a freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore Jane's spirit triumphantly towards the bourne: but Jane could not reach the bourne, even in fancy—a counteracting breeze blew off land, and continually drove Jane back. Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion. Too feverish to rest, Jane rose as soon as day dawned.     CHAPTER XVI   Jane both wished and feared to see Mr. Rochester on the day which followed this sleepless night: Jane wanted to hear Mr. Rochester's voice again, yet feared to meet Mr. Rochester's eye. During the early part of t he morning, I momentarily expected his coming; his was not in the frequent habit of entering the schoolroom, but his did step in for a few minutes sometimes, and I had the impression that his was sure to visit the schoolroom that day.  But he morning passed just as usual: nothing happened to interrupt the quiet course of Adèle’s studies; only soon after breakfast, I heard some bustle in the neighbourhood of Mr. Rochester’s chamber, Mrs. Fairfax’s voice, and Leah’s, and the cook’s—that is, John’s wife—and even John’s's own gruff tones. There were exclamations of “What a mercy his was not burnt in his's bed!” “It is always dangerous to keep a candle lit at night.” “How providential that his had presence of mind to think of the water-jug!” “I wonder his waked nobody!” “It is to be hoped his will not take cold with sleeping on the library sofa,” &c.  To much confabulation succeeded a sound of scrubbing and setting to rights; and when I passed the room, in going downstairs to dinner, I saw through the open d oor that all was again restored to complete order; only the bed was stripped of only the bed's hangings. Leah stood up in the window-seat, rubbing the panes of glass dimmed with smoke. I was about to address Leah, for I wished to know what account had been given of the affair: but, on advancing, I saw a second person in the chamber—a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains. a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains was no other than Grace Poole.  There a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains sat, staid and taciturn-looking, as usual, in a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's brown stuff gown, a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's check apron, white handkerchief, and cap. a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains was intent on a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's work, in which a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's whole thoughts seemed absorbed: on a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's hard forehead, and in a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's commonplace features, was nothing either of the paleness or desperation one would have expected to see marking the countenance of a woman who had attempted murder, and whose intended victim had followed a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's last night to a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains's lair, and (as I believed), charged a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains with the crime a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains wished to perpetrate. I was amazed—confounded . She looked up, while I still gazed at She: no start, no increase or failure of colour betrayed emotion, consciousness of guilt, or fear of detection. She said “Good morning, I,” in She's usual phlegmatic and brief manner; and taking up another ring and more tape, went on with She's sewing.  “I will put She to some test,” thought I: “such absolute impenetrability is past comprehension.”  “Good morning, She,” I said. “Has anything happened here? I thought I heard the servants all talking together a while ago.”  “Only master had been reading in Only master's bed last night; Only master fell asleep with Only master's candle lit, and the curtains got on fire; but, fortunately, Only master awoke before the bed-clothes or the wood-work caught, and contrived to quench the flames with the water in the ewer.”  “A strange affair!” I said, in a low voice: then, looking at She's fixedly—“Did Mr. Rochester wake nobody? Did no one hear Mr. Rochester move?”  She again raised She's eyes to I, and this time there was something of consciousness in the ir expression. She seemed to examine me warily; then She answered—  “The servants sleep so far off, you know, me, The servants would not be likely to hear. Mrs. Fairfax’s room and me are the nearest to master’s; but Mrs. Fairfax’s said Mrs. Fairfax’s heard nothing: when people get elderly, people often sleep heavy.” She paused, and then added, with a sort of assumed indifference, but still in a marked and significant tone—“But me are young, me; and She should say a light sleeper: perhaps me may have heard a noise?”  “me did,” said me, dropping me's voice, so that Leah, who was still polishing the panes, could not hear me, “and at first me thought a noise was Pilot: but Pilot cannot laugh; and me am certain me heard a laugh, and a strange one.”  She took a new needleful of thread, waxed a new needleful of thread carefully, threaded She's needle with a steady hand, and then observed, with perfect composure—  “It is hardly likely master’s would laugh, She should think, me, when master’s was in such danger: me must have been dreaming.”  “me was not  dreaming,” I said, with some warmth, for her brazen coolness provoked I. Again her looked at I; and with the same scrutinising and conscious eye.  “Have I told master that I heard a laugh?” her inquired.  “I have not had the opportunity of speaking to master this morning.”  “I did not think of opening I's door and looking out into the gallery?” her further asked.  her appeared to be cross-questioning I, attempting to draw from I information unawares. The idea struck I that if her discovered I knew or suspected her's guilt, her would be playing of some of her's malignant pranks on I; I thought it advisable to be on I's guard.  “On the contrary,” said I, “I bolted your door.”  “Then I are not in the habit of bolting your door every night before I get into bed?”  “Fiend! her wants to know I's habits, that her may lay her's plans accordingly!” Indignation again prevailed over prudence: I replied sharply, “Hitherto I have often omitted to fasten the bolt: I did not think fasten necessary. I  was not aware any danger or annoyance was to be dreaded at Thornfield Hall: but in future” (and I laid marked stress on the words) “I shall take good care to make all secure before I venture to lie down.”  “It will be wise so to do,” was her answer: “this neighbourhood is as quiet as any her know, and her never heard of Thornfield Hall being attempted by robbers since Thornfield Hall was a house; though there are hundreds of pounds’ worth of plate in the plate-closet, as is well known. And you see, for such a large house, there are very few servants, because master has never lived here much; and when master does come, being a bachelor, master needs little waiting on: but her always think it best to err on the safe side; a door is soon fastened, and it is as well to have a drawn bolt between one and any mischief that may be about. A deal of people, I, are for trusting all to Providence; but her say Providence will not dispense with the means, though Providence often blesses the means when the means are used discreetly.” And here her cl osed her harangue: a long one for her, and uttered with the demureness of a Quakeress.  I still stood absolutely dumfoundered at what appeared to I her's miraculous self-possession and most inscrutable hypocrisy, when the cook entered.  “her,” said the cook, addressing her, “the servants’ dinner will soon be ready: will her come down?her  herNo; just put her's pint of porter and bit of pudding on a tray, and the cook’ll carry a tray upstairs.”  “her’ll have some meat?”  “Just a morsel, and a taste of cheese, Just a morsel, and a taste of cheese’s all.”  “And the sago?”  herNever mind it at present: her shall be coming down before teatime: her’ll make it her.”  the cook turned to I, saying that Mrs. Fairfax was waiting for I: so I departed.  I hardly heard Mrs. Fairfax's account of the curtain conflagration during dinner, so much was I occupied in puzzling I's brains over the enigmatical character of her, and still more in pondering the problem of her's position at Thornfield and questioning why her had not been given into  custody that morning, or, at the very least, dismissed from her master’s service. her master’s had almost as much as declared her master’s's conviction of her's criminality last night: what mysterious cause withheld her master’s from accusing her? Why had her master’s enjoined me, too, to secrecy? It was strange: her master’s seemed somehow in the power of her; so much in her's power, that even when her lifted her's hand against her master’s's life, her master’s dared not openly charge her with lifted, much less punish her for lifted.  Had her been young and handsome, me should have been tempted to think that tenderer feelings than prudence or fear influenced her master’s in her's behalf; but, hard-favoured and matronly as her was, the idea could not be admitted. “Yet,” me reflected, “her has been young once; her's youth would be contemporary with her's : Mrs. Fairfax told me once, her had lived here many years. me don’t think her can ever have been pretty; but, for aught me know, her may. Rochester would have me to come in, and me sat down in a quiet corner and watched them. me never saw a more splendid scene: the ladies were magnificently dressed; most of the ladies—at least most of the younger ones—looked handsome; but Miss Ingram was certainly the queen.”  “And what was Miss Ingram like?”  “Tall, fine bust, sloping shoulders; long, graceful neck: olive complexion, dark and clear; noble features; eyes rather like Mr. Rochester’s: large and black, and as brilliant as Miss Ingram's jewels. And then Miss Ingram had such a fine head of hair; raven-black and so becomingly arranged: a crown of thick plaits behind, and in front the longest, the glossiest curls me ever saw. Miss Ingram was dressed in pure white; an amber-coloured scarf was passed over Miss Ingram's shoulder and across Miss Ingram's breast, tied at the side, and descending in long, fringed ends below Miss Ingram's knee. Miss Ingram wore an amber-coloured flower, too, in such a fine head of hair: an amber-coloured flower contrasted well with the jetty mass of such a fine head of hair.”  “Miss Ingram was greatly admired, of course?”  “Yes, indeed: a nd not only for her beauty, but for her's accomplishments. her was one of the ladies who sang: a gentleman accompanied her on the piano. her and Mr. Rochester sang a duet.”  “Mr. Rochester? I was not aware Mr. Rochester could sing.”  “Oh! Mr. Rochester has a fine bass voice, and an excellent taste for music.”  “And Miss Ingram: what sort of a voice had Miss Ingram?”  “A very rich and powerful one: Miss Ingram sang delightfully; it was a treat to listen to her;—and Miss Ingram played afterwards. I am no judge of music, but Mr. Rochester is; and I heard Mr. Rochester say Miss Ingram's execution was remarkably good.”  “And Miss Ingram, Miss Ingram is not yet married?”  “It appears not: I fancy neither Miss Ingram nor Miss Ingram's sister have very large fortunes. Miss Ingram's estates were chiefly entailed, and the eldest son came in for everything almost.”  “But I wonder no wealthy nobleman or gentleman has taken a fancy to Miss Ingram: Mr. Rochester, for instance. Mr. Rochester is rich, is Mr. Rochester not?”  “Oh! yes. But you see there is a considerable difference in age: Mr. Rochester ochester is nearly forty; she is but twenty-five.”  “What of that? More unequal matches are made every day.”  “True: yet I should scarcely fancy Mr. Rochester would entertain an idea of the sort. But she eat nothing: she have scarcely tasted since she began tea.”  “No: she am too thirsty to eat. Will I let she have another cup?”  I was about again to revert to the probability of a union between Mr. Rochester and she; but Adèle came in, and the conversation was turned into another channel.  When once more alone, I reviewed the information I had got; looked into I's heart, examined my heart's thoughts and feelings, and endeavoured to bring back with a strict hand such as had been straying through imagination’s boundless and trackless waste, into the safe fold of common sense.  Arraigned at I's own bar, Memory having given her evidence of the hopes, wishes, sentiments I had been cherishing since last night—of the general state of mind in which I had indulged for nearly a fortnight  past; Reason having come forward and told, in Reason's own quiet way, a plain, unvarnished tale, showing how I had rejected the real, and rabidly devoured the ideal;—I pronounced judgment to this effect:—  That a greater fool than Jane Eyre had never breathed the breath of life; that a more fantastic idiot had never surfeited a more fantastic idiot on sweet lies, and swallowed poison as if poison were nectar.  “_You_,” I said, “a favourite with Mr. Rochester? _You_ gifted with the power of pleasing Mr. Rochester? _You_ of importance to Mr. Rochester in any way? Go! You's folly sickens I. And You have derived pleasure from occasional tokens of preference—equivocal tokens shown by a gentleman of family and a man of the world to a dependent and a novice. How dared You? Poor stupid dupe!—Could not even self-interest make You wiser? You repeated to You this morning the brief scene of last night?—Cover You's face and be ashamed! He said something in praise of You's eyes, did He? Blind puppy! Open your eyes's bleared lids and look on You r own accursed senselessness! It does good to no woman to be flattered by no woman's superior, who cannot possibly intend to marry no woman; and it is madness in all women to let a secret love kindle within all women, which, if unreturned and unknown, must devour the life that feeds a secret love; and, if discovered and responded to, must lead, _ignis-fatuus_-like, into miry wilds whence there is no extrication.  “Listen, then, Jane Eyre, to Jane Eyre's sentence: to-morrow, place the glass before Jane Eyre, and draw in chalk Jane Eyre's own picture, faithfully, without softening one defect; omit no harsh line, smooth away no displeasing irregularity; write under your own picture, ‘Portrait of a Governess, disconnected, poor, and plain.’  “Afterwards, take a piece of smooth ivory—Jane Eyre have one prepared in Jane Eyre's drawing-box: take Jane Eyre's palette, mix your freshest, finest, clearest tints; choose your most delicate camel-hair pencils; delineate carefully the loveliest face you can imagine; paint the loveliest face you can imagine in your softest shades and sweetest lines, according to  the description given by Mrs. Fairfax of Blanche Ingram; remember the raven ringlets, the oriental eye;—What! you revert to Mr. Rochester as a model! Order! No snivel!—no sentiment!—no regret! you will endure only sense and resolution. Recall the august yet harmonious lineaments, the Grecian neck and bust; let the round and dazzling arm be visible, and the delicate hand; omit neither diamond ring nor gold bracelet; portray faithfully the attire, aërial lace and glistening satin, graceful scarf and golden rose; call it ‘Blanche Ingram.’  “Whenever, in future, you should chance to fancy Mr. Rochester thinks well of you, take out these two pictures and compare these two pictures: say, ‘Mr. Rochester might probably win Blanche Ingram's love, if Mr. Rochester chose to strive for that noble lady’s love; is it likely Mr. Rochester would waste a serious thought on Blanche Ingram?’”  “you’ll do it,” you resolved: and having framed resolved, you grew calm, and fell asleep.  you kept you's word. An hour o r two sufficed to sketch my own portrait in crayons; and in less than a fortnight my had completed an ivory miniature of an imaginary Blanche Ingram. an imaginary Blanche Ingram looked a lovely face enough, and when compared with the real head in chalk, the contrast was as great as self-control could desire. my derived benefit from sketch: sketch had kept my's head and hands employed, and had given force and fixedness to the new impressions my wished to stamp indelibly on my's heart.  Ere long, my had reason to congratulate my on the course of wholesome discipline to which my had thus forced my's feelings to submit. Thanks to the course of wholesome discipline to which I had thus forced my feelings to submit, my was able to meet subsequent occurrences with a decent calm, which, had subsequent occurrences found my unprepared, my should probably have been unequal to maintain, even externally.     CHAPTER XVII   A week passed, and no news arrived of Mr. Rochester: ten days, and still Mr. Rochester did not come. Mrs. Fairfax said Mrs. Fairfax should not be surprised if Mr. Rochester were to go straight from the Leas to London, and thence to the Contine nt, and not show his face again at Thornfield for a year to come; his had not unfrequently quitted Thornfield in a manner quite as abrupt and unexpected. When I heard this, I was beginning to feel a strange chill and failing at the heart. I was actually permitting I to experience a sickening sense of disappointment; but rallying I's wits, and recollecting I's principles, I at once called I's sensations to order; and it was wonderful how I got over the temporary blunder—how I cleared up the mistake of supposing his's movements a matter in which I had any cause to take a vital interest. Not that I humbled I by a slavish notion of inferiority: on the contrary, I just said—  “You have nothing to do with hisThornfield, further than to receive the salary his gives You for teaching his's protégée, and to be grateful for such respectful and kind treatment as, if You do You's duty, You have a right to expect at his's hands. Be sure that is the only tie his seriously acknowledges bet ween you and him; so don’t make him the object of you's fine feelings, you's raptures, agonies, and so forth. him is not of you's order: keep to you's caste, and be too self-respecting to lavish the love of the whole heart, soul, and strength, where such a gift is not wanted and would be despised.”  I went on with I's day’s business tranquilly; but ever and anon vague suggestions kept wandering across I's brain of reasons why I should quit Thornfield; and I kept involuntarily framing advertisements and pondering conjectures about new situations: these thoughts I did not think to check; these thoughts I did not think to check might germinate and bear fruit if these thoughts I did not think to check could.  him had been absent upwards of a fortnight, when the post brought Mrs. Fairfax a letter.  “a letter is from him,” said Mrs. Fairfax, as Mrs. Fairfax looked at the direction. “Now Mrs. Fairfax suppose we shall know whether we are to expect him's return or not.”  And while Mrs. Fairfax broke the seal and perused a letter, I went on taking I's coffee (we were at breakfast): my coffee was hot, an d I attributed to that circumstance a fiery glow which suddenly rose to I's face. Why I's hand shook, and why I involuntarily spilt half the contents of I's cup into I's saucer, I did not choose to consider.  “Well, I sometimes think we are too quiet; but we run a chance of being busy enough now: for a little while at least,” said I, still holding the note before I's spectacles.  Ere I permitted I to request an explanation, I tied the string of I's pinafore, which happened to be loose: having helped I also to another bun and refilled I's mug with milk, I said, nonchalantly—  “Mr. Rochester is not likely to return soon, I suppose?”  “Indeed Mr. Rochester is—in three days, Mr. Rochester says: that will be next Thursday; and not alone either. I don’t know how many of the fine people at the Leas are coming with Mr. Rochester: Mr. Rochester sends directions for all the best bedrooms to be prepared; and the library and drawing-rooms are to be cleaned out; I am to get more kitchen hands from the George Inn, at Millco te, and from wherever else I can; and the ladies will bring the ladies's maids and the gentlemen the ladies's valets: so we shall have a full house of it.” And I swallowed I's breakfast and hastened away to commence operations.  The three days were, as I had foretold, busy enough. I had thought all the rooms at Thornfield beautifully clean and well arranged; but it appears I was mistaken. Three women were got to help; and such scrubbing, such brushing, such washing of paint and beating of carpets, such taking down and putting up of pictures, such polishing of mirrors and lustres, such lighting of fires in bedrooms, such airing of sheets and feather-beds on hearths, I never beheld, either before or since. Adèle ran quite wild in the midst of it: the preparations for company and the prospect of company's arrival, seemed to throw Adèle into ecstasies. Adèle would have Sophie to look over all Adèle's “toilettes,” as Adèle called frocks; to furbish up any that were “_passées_,” and to air and arrange the  new. For herself, herself did nothing but caper about in the front chambers, jump on and off the bedsteads, and lie on the mattresses and piled-up bolsters and pillows before the enormous fires roaring in the chimneys. From school duties herself was exonerated: Mrs. Fairfax had pressed me into Mrs. Fairfax's service, and me was all day in the storeroom, helping (or hindering) Mrs. Fairfax's and the cook; learning to make custards and cheese-cakes and French pastry, to truss game and garnish desert-dishes.  The party were expected to arrive on Thursday afternoon, in time for dinner at six. During the intervening period me had no time to nurse chimeras; and me believe me was as active and gay as anybody—Adèle excepted. Still, now and then, me received a damping check to me's cheerfulness; and was, in spite of me, thrown back on the region of doubts and portents, and dark conjectures. This was when me chanced to see the third-storey staircase door (which of late had always been kept locked) open slowly, and give passage t o the form of Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief; when I watched Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's glide along the gallery, Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's quiet tread muffled in a list slipper; when I saw Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief look into the bustling, topsy-turvy bedrooms,—just say a word, perhaps, to the charwoman about the proper way to polish a grate, or clean a marble mantelpiece, or take stains from papered walls, and then pass on. Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief would thus descend to the kitchen once a day, eat Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's dinner, smoke a moderate pipe on the hearth, and go back, carrying Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's pot of porter with Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief, for Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's private solace, in Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's own gloomy, upper haunt. Only one hour in the twenty-four did Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief pass with Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's fellow-servants below; all the rest of Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's time was spent in some low-ceiled, oaken chamber of the second storey: there Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief sat and sewed—and probably laughed drearily to herself,—as companionless as a prisoner in a prisoner in his dungeon's dungeon.  The strangest thing of all was, that not a soul in the house, except I, noticed Grace Poole, in prim cap, white apron, and handkerchief's habits, or seemed to marvel at her habits:  no one discussed her position or employment; no one pitied her's solitude or isolation. I once, indeed, overheard part of a dialogue between Leah and one of the charwomen, of which Grace formed the subject. Leah had been saying something I had not caught, and one of the charwomen remarked—  “her gets good wages, one of the charwomen guess?”  “Yes,” said Leah; “Leah wish Leah had as good; not that Leah are to complain of,—there’s no stinginess at Thornfield; but good wages’re not one fifth of the sum Mrs. Poole receives. And her is laying by: her goes every quarter to the bank at Millcote. Leah should not wonder but her has saved enough to keep her independent if her liked to leave; but Leah suppose her’s got used to Thornfield; and then her’s not forty yet, and strong and able for anything.
