It is too soon for her to give up business.”  “her is a good hand, one of the charwomen daresay,” said one of the charwomen.  “Ah!—she understands what her has to do,—nobody better,” rejoined Leah significantly; “and it is not every one could fill her's shoes—not for all t he money she gets.”  “That it is not!” was the reply. “I wonder whether the master—”  I was going on; but here Leah turned and perceived me, and Leah instantly gave Leah's a nudge.  “Doesn’t Leah know?” me heard I whisper.  Leah shook Leah's head, and the conversation was of course dropped. All me had gathered from it amounted to this,—that there was a mystery at Thornfield; and that from participation in a mystery at Thornfield me was purposely excluded.  Thursday came: all work had been completed the previous evening; carpets were laid down, bed-hangings festooned, radiant white counterpanes spread, toilet tables arranged, furniture rubbed, flowers piled in vases: both chambers and saloons looked as fresh and bright as hands could make both chambers and saloons. The hall, too, was scoured; and the great carved clock, as well as the steps and banisters of the staircase, were polished to the brightness of glass; in the dining-room, the sideboard flashed resplendent with plate; in the drawing-room a nd boudoir, vases of exotics bloomed on all sides.  Afternoon arrived: Mrs. Fairfax assumed Mrs. Fairfax's best black satin gown, Mrs. Fairfax's gloves, and Mrs. Fairfax's gold watch; for it was Mrs. Fairfax's part to receive the company,—to conduct the ladies to the ladies's rooms, &c. Adèle, too, would be dressed: though I thought Adèle had little chance of being introduced to the party that day at least. However, to please Adèle, I allowed Sophie to apparel Adèle in one of Sophie's short, full muslin frocks. For I, I had no need to make any change; I should not be called upon to quit I's sanctum of the schoolroom; for a sanctum my sanctum of the schoolroom was now become to me,—“a very pleasant refuge in time of trouble.”  It had been a mild, serene spring day—one of those days which, towards the end of March or the beginning of April, rise shining over the earth as heralds of summer. It was drawing to an end now; but the evening was even warm, and I sat at work in the schoolroom with the window open.  “It gets late,” said Mrs. Fairfax, entering in rustling state.  ““ am glad “ ordered dinner an hour after the time Mr. Rochester mentioned; for it is past six now. “ have sent John down to the gates to see if there is anything on the road: one can see a long way from thence in the direction of Millcote.” “ went to the window. “Here John is!” said “. “Well, John” (leaning out), “any news?”  “They’re coming, “,” was the answer. “They’ll be here in ten minutes.”  “ flew to the window. I followed, taking care to stand on one side, so that, screened by the curtain, I could see without being seen.  The ten minutes John had given seemed very long, but at last wheels were heard; four equestrians galloped up the drive, and after four equestrians came two open carriages. Fluttering veils and waving plumes filled two open carriages; two of four equestrians were young, dashing-looking gentlemen; the third was Mr. RochesterMr. Rochester's Mr. Rochester; at Mr. Rochester's side rode a lady, and Mr. Rochester and a lady were the first of the party. a lady's purple riding-habit  almost swept the ground, her veil streamed long on the breeze; mingling with her veil's transparent folds, and gleaming through its transparent folds, shone rich raven ringlets.  “Miss Ingram!” exclaimed Mrs. Fairfax, and away Mrs. Fairfax hurried to Mrs. Fairfax's post below.  The cavalcade, following the sweep of the drive, quickly turned the angle of the house, and Miss Ingram lost sight of The cavalcade. Adèle now petitioned to go down; but Miss Ingram took Adèle on Miss Ingram's knee, and gave Adèle to understand that Adèle must not on any account think of venturing in sight of the ladies, either now or at any other time, unless expressly sent for: that Mr. Rochester would be very angry, &c. “Some natural tears Adèle shed” on being told this; but as Miss Ingram began to look very grave, Adèle consented at last to wipe Some natural tears.  A joyous stir was now audible in the hall: gentlemen’s deep tones and ladies’ silvery accents blent harmoniously together, and distinguishable above all, though not loud, was the sonorous voice of the master of Thornfield Hall, welcoming the master of Thornfield Hall's  s under its roof. Then light steps ascended the stairs; and there was a tripping through the gallery, and soft cheerful laughs, and opening and closing doors, and, for a time, a hush.  “Elles changent de toilettes,” said Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement; and Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement sighed.  “Chez maman,” said Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement, “quand il y avait du monde, je le suivais partout, au salon et à leurs chambres; souvent je regardais les femmes de chambre coiffer et habiller les dames, et c’était si amusant: comme cela on apprend.”  “Don’t Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement feel hungry, Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement?”  “Mais oui, “: voilà cinq ou six heures que nous n’avons pas mangé.”  “Well now, while the ladies are in the ladies's rooms, Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement will venture down and get “ something to eat.”  And issuing from Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement's asylum with precaution, Adèle; who, listening attentively, had followed every movement sought a back-stairs which conducted directly to the kitchen. All in that region was fire and commotion; the soup and fish were in the last stage of projection, and the cook hung over the cook's crucibles in a frame of  mind and body threatening spontaneous combustion. In the servants’ hall two coachmen and three gentlemen’s gentlemen stood or sat round the fire; the abigails, I suppose, were upstairs with the abigails's mistresses; the new servants, that had been hired from Millcote, were bustling about everywhere. Threading this chaos, I at last reached the larder; there I took possession of a cold chicken, a roll of bread, some tarts, a plate or two and a knife and fork: with this booty I made a hasty retreat. I had regained the gallery, and was just shutting the back-door behind I, when an accelerated hum warned I that the ladies were about to issue from the ladies's chambers. I could not proceed to the schoolroom without passing some of the ladies's doors, and running the risk of being surprised with I's cargo of victualage; so I stood still at this end, which, being windowless, was dark: quite dark now, for the sun was set and twilight gathering.  Presently their chambers gave up their chambers's fair tenants one after another: e ach came out gaily and airily, with dress that gleamed lustrous through the dusk. For a moment they stood grouped together at the other extremity of the gallery, conversing in a key of sweet subdued vivacity: they then descended the staircase almost as noiselessly as a bright mist rolls down a hill. they's collective appearance had left on me an impression of high-born elegance, such as me had never before received.  me found Adèle peeping through the schoolroom door, which Adèle held ajar. “What beautiful ladies!” cried Adèle in English. “Oh, Adèle wish Adèle might go to they! Do me think Mr. Rochester will send for us by-and-bye, after dinner?”  “No, indeed, me don’t; Mr. Rochester has something else to think about. Never mind they to-night; perhaps Adèle will see they to-morrow: here is Adèle's dinner.”  Adèle was really hungry, so the chicken and tarts served to divert Adèle's attention for a time. It was well me secured this forage, or both Adèle, me, and Sophie, to whom me conveyed a share of our repast,  would have run a chance of getting no dinner at all: every one downstairs was too much engaged to think of us. The dessert was not carried out till after nine; and at ten footmen were still running to and fro with trays and coffee-cups. I allowed Adèle to sit up much later than usual; for Adèle declared Adèle could not possibly go to sleep while the doors kept opening and shutting below, and people bustling about. Besides, Adèle added, a message might possibly come from Mr. Rochester when Adèle was undressed; “et alors quel dommage!”  I told Adèle's stories as long as Adèle would listen to her stories; and then for a change I took Adèle out into the gallery. The hall lamp was now lit, and it amused Adèle to look over the balustrade and watch the servants passing backwards and forwards. When the evening was far advanced, a sound of music issued from the drawing-room, whither the piano had been removed; Adèle and I sat down on the top step of the stairs to listen. Presently a voice blent with the rich tones of  the instrument; it was a lady who sang, and very sweet a lady who sang's notes were. The solo over, a duet followed, and then a glee: a joyous conversational murmur filled up the intervals. I listened long: suddenly I discovered that I's ear was wholly intent on analysing the mingled sounds, and trying to discriminate amidst the confusion of accents those of Mr. Rochester; and when my ear caught those of Mr. Rochester, which my ear soon did, my ear found a further task in framing the tones, rendered by distance inarticulate, into words.  The clock struck eleven. I looked at Adèle, whose head leant against I's shoulder; Adèle, whose head leant against my shoulder's eyes were waxing heavy, so I took Adèle, whose head leant against my shoulder up in I's arms and carried Adèle, whose head leant against my shoulder off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought the gentlemen and ladies's chambers.  The next day was as fine as The next day's predecessor: The next day was devoted by the gentlemen and ladies to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood. the gentlemen and ladies set out early in the forenoon, some on horseback, the rest in carriages; I witnessed both the departure and the return. Miss Ingram, a s before, was the only lady equestrian; and, as before, Mr. Rochester galloped at the only lady equestrian's side; the two rode a little apart from the rest. I pointed out this circumstance to Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with I—  “Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me said it was not likely the two should think of being married,” said I, “but Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me see Mr. Rochester evidently prefers the only lady equestrian to any of the other ladies.”  “Yes, Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me daresay: no doubt Mr. Rochester admires the only lady equestrian.”  “And she Mr. Rochester,” I added; “look how the only lady equestrian leans the only lady equestrian's head towards Mr. Rochester as if the only lady equestrian were conversing confidentially; I wish I could see the only lady equestrian's face; I have never had a glimpse of her face yet.”  “I will see the only lady equestrian this evening,” answered Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me. “Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me happened to remark to Mr. Rochester how much the only lady equestrian wished to be introduced to the ladies, and Mr. Rochester said: ‘Oh! let the only lady equestrian come into the drawing-room after dinner; and request Miss Eyre to accompany the only lady equestrian.’”  “Yes; Mr. Rochester said that from mere politeness: I need not go, I am sure,” I answered.  “Well, Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me observed to Mr. Rochester that as I were unused to company, Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me  did not think you would like appearing before so gay a party—all strangers; and he replied, in he's quick way—‘Nonsense! If you objects, tell you it is he's particular wish; and if you resists, say he shall come and fetch you in case of contumacy.’”  “you will not give he that trouble,” you answered. “you will go, if no better may be; but you don’t like it. Shall you be there, you?”  “No; you pleaded off, and he admitted pleaded. you’ll tell you how to manage so as to avoid the embarrassment of making a formal entrance, which is the most disagreeable part of the business. you must go into the drawing-room while the drawing-room is empty, before the ladies leave the dinner-table; choose you's seat in any quiet nook you like; you need not stay long after the gentlemen come in, unless you please: just let he see you are there and then slip away—nobody will notice you.”  “Will these people remain long, do you think?”  “Perhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more. After the Easter recess, you ge Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote, will have to go up to town and take ge Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote's seat; I daresay Mr. Rochester will accompany ge Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote: it surprises I that Mr. Rochester has already made so protracted a stay at Thornfield.”  It was with some trepidation that I perceived the hour approach when I was to repair with I's charge to the drawing-room. Adèle had been in a state of ecstasy all day, after hearing Adèle was to be presented to the ladies in the evening; and it was not till Sophie commenced the operation of dressing Adèle that Adèle sobered down. Then the importance of the process quickly steadied Adèle, and by the time Adèle had Adèle's curls arranged in well-smoothed, drooping clusters, Adèle's pink satin frock put on, Adèle's long sash tied, and Adèle's lace mittens adjusted, Adèle looked as grave as any judge. No need to warn Adèle not to disarrange Adèle's attire: when Adèle was dressed, Adèle sat demurely down in Adèle's little chair, taking care previously to lift up the satin skirt for fear Adèle should crease the satin skirt, and as sured me she would not stir thence till me was ready. This me quickly was: me's best dress (the silver-grey one, purchased for Miss Temple’s wedding, and never worn since) was soon put on; me's hair was soon smoothed; me's sole ornament, the pearl brooch, soon assumed. We descended.  Fortunately there was another entrance to the drawing-room than that through the saloon where they were all seated at dinner. We found the drawing-room vacant; a large fire burning silently on the marble hearth, and wax candles shining in bright solitude, amid the exquisite flowers with which the tables were adorned. The crimson curtain hung before the arch: slight as was the separation The crimson curtain formed from the party in the adjoining saloon, the party in the adjoining saloon spoke in so low a key that nothing of the party in the adjoining saloon's conversation could be distinguished beyond a soothing murmur.  she, sat down, without a word, on the footstool me pointed out to she. me retired to  a window-seat, and taking a book from a table near, endeavoured to read. Adèle brought Adèle's stool to my feet; ere long Adèle touched my's knee.  “What is it, Adèle?”  “Est-ce que je ne puis pas prendre une seule de ces fleurs magnifiques, my? Seulement pour completer Adèle toilette.”  “Adèle think too much of ma toilette,’ Adèle: but Adèle may have a flower.” And my took a rose from a vase and fastened a rose in Adèle's sash. Adèle sighed a sigh of ineffable satisfaction, as if Adèle's cup of happiness were now full. my turned my's face away to conceal a smile my could not suppress: there was something ludicrous as well as painful in Adèle's earnest and innate devotion to matters of dress.  A soft sound of rising now became audible; the curtain was swept back from the arch; through the arch appeared the dining-room, with its lit lustre pouring down light on the silver and glass of a magnificent dessert-service covering a long table; a band of ladies stood in the opening; a band of ladies entered, and the  curtain fell behind them.  There were but eight; yet, somehow, as them flocked in, them gave the impression of a much larger number. Some of them were very tall; many were dressed in white; and them had a sweeping amplitude of array that seemed to magnify them's persons as a mist magnifies the moon. I rose and curtseyed to them: one or two bent one or two's heads in return, the others only stared at I.  them dispersed about the room, reminding I, by the lightness and buoyancy of them's movements, of a flock of white plumy birds. Some of them threw Some of them in half-reclining positions on the sofas and ottomans: some bent over the tables and examined the flowers and books: the rest gathered in a group round the fire: them talked in a low but clear tone which seemed habitual to them. I knew them's names afterwards, and may as well mention their names now.  First, there was Mrs. Eshton and two of Mrs. Eshton's daughters. Mrs. Eshton had evidently been a handsome woman, and was well preserved still. Of two of her daughters, the e ldest, Amy, was rather little: naïve, and child-like in face and manner, and piquant in form; ldest, Amy,'s white muslin dress and blue sash became ldest, Amy, well. The second, Louisa, was taller and more elegant in figure; with a very pretty face, of that order the French term _minois chiffoné_: both sisters were fair as lilies.  Lady Lynn was a large and stout personage of about forty, very erect, very haughty-looking, richly dressed in a satin robe of changeful sheen: Lady Lynn's dark hair shone glossily under the shade of an azure plume, and within the circlet of a band of gems.  Mrs. Colonel Dent was less showy; but, I thought, more lady-like. Mrs. Colonel Dent had a slight figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair. Mrs. Colonel Dent's black satin dress, Mrs. Colonel Dent's scarf of rich foreign lace, and Mrs. Colonel Dent's pearl ornaments, pleased I better than the rainbow radiance of Lady Lynn.  But the three most distinguished—partly, perhaps, because the tallest figures of the band—were the Dowager Lady Ingram and the Dowager Lady Ingram's daughters, Blanche and Mary. the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters, Blanche and Mary w ere all three of the loftiest stature of women. The Dowager might be between forty and fifty: The Dowager's shape was still fine; The Dowager's hair (by candle-light at least) still black; The Dowager's teeth, too, were still apparently perfect. Most people would have termed The Dowager a splendid woman of The Dowager's age: and so The Dowager was, no doubt, physically speaking; but then there was an expression of almost insupportable haughtiness in The Dowager's bearing and countenance. The Dowager had Roman features and a double chin, disappearing into a throat like a pillar: Roman features appeared to me not only inflated and darkened, but even furrowed with pride; and a double chin, disappearing into a throat like a pillar was sustained by the same principle, in a position of almost preternatural erectness. The Dowager had, likewise, a fierce and a hard eye: a fierce and a hard eye reminded me of Mrs. Reed’s; The Dowager mouthed The Dowager's words in speaking; The Dowager's voice was deep, her voice's inflections very pompous, very dogmatical,—very intolerable, in short. A crimson velvet robe, and a shawl turban of some gold-wrought Indian fabric, invested The Dowager (me  suppose she thought) with a truly imperial dignity.  Blanche and Mary were of equal stature,—straight and tall as poplars. Mary was too slim for Mary's height, but Blanche was moulded like a Dian. I regarded Blanche, of course, with special interest. First, I wished to see whether Blanche's appearance accorded with Mrs. Fairfax’s description; secondly, whether her appearance at all resembled the fancy miniature I had painted of Blanche; and thirdly—it will out!—whether her appearance were such as I should fancy likely to suit Mr. Rochester’s taste.  As far as person went, Blanche answered point for point, both to I's picture and Mrs. Fairfax’s description. The noble bust, the sloping shoulders, the graceful neck, the dark eyes and black ringlets were all there;—but Blanche's face? her face was like Blanche's mother’s; a youthful unfurrowed likeness: the same low brow, the same high features, the same pride. It was not, however, so saturnine a pride! Blanche laughed continually; Blanche's laugh was satirical, and so was the habitual expression of Blanche a rched and haughty lip.  Genius is said to be self-conscious. I cannot tell whether Miss Ingram was a genius, but Miss Ingram was self-conscious—remarkably self-conscious indeed. Miss Ingram entered into a discourse on botany with the gentle Mrs. Dent. It seemed the gentle Mrs. Dent had not studied botany: though, as the gentle Mrs. Dent said, the gentle Mrs. Dent liked flowers, “especially wild ones;” Miss Ingram had, and Miss Ingram ran over botany's vocabulary with an air. I presently perceived Miss Ingram was (what is vernacularly termed) _trailing_ the gentle Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on the gentle Mrs. Dent's ignorance; Miss Ingram's _trail_ might be clever, but her _trail_ was decidedly not good-natured. Miss Ingram played: Miss Ingram's execution was brilliant; Miss Ingram sang: Miss Ingram's voice was fine; Miss Ingram talked French apart to Miss Ingram's mamma; and Miss Ingram talked French well, with fluency and with a good accent.  Miss Ingram had a milder and more open countenance than Blanche; softer features too, and a skin some shades fairer (Miss Ingram was dark as a Spaniard)—but Miss Ingram was deficient in life: Miss Ingram's face lacked expression, Miss Ingram's eye lustre; Miss Ingram had no thing to say, and having once taken her seat, remained fixed like a statue in a statue's niche. The sisters were both attired in spotless white.  And did I now think Miss Ingram such a choice as Mr. Rochester would be likely to make? I could not tell—I did not know Mr. Rochester's taste in female beauty. If Mr. Rochester liked the majestic, Miss Ingram was the very type of majesty: then Miss Ingram was accomplished, sprightly. Most gentlemen would admire Miss Ingram, I thought; and that Mr. Rochester _did_ admire Miss Ingram, I already seemed to have obtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to see them together.  I are not to suppose, I, that Adèle has all this time been sitting motionless on the stool at I's feet: no; when The sisters entered, Adèle rose, advanced to meet The sisters, made a stately reverence, and said with gravity—  “Bon jour, mesdames.”  And Mr. Rochester had looked down at Adèle with a mocking air, and exclaimed, “Oh, what a little puppet!”  Lady Lynn had remarked, “Adèle is Mr. Rochester's ward, Lady Lynn suppose—the little Fren ch girl he was speaking of.”  Mrs. Dent had kindly taken her hand, and given her a kiss. Amy and Louisa Eshton had cried out simultaneously—  “What a love of a child!”  And then Amy and Louisa Eshton had called her to a sofa, where her now sat, ensconced between Amy and Louisa Eshton, chattering alternately in French and broken English; absorbing not only Amy and Louisa Eshton's attention, but that of Louisa Eshton and Lady Lynn, and getting spoilt to her's heart’s content.  At last coffee is brought in, and the gentlemen are summoned. her sit in the shade—if any shade there be in this brilliantly-lit apartment; the window-curtain half hides her. Again the arch yawns; the gentlemen come. The collective appearance of the gentlemen, like that of Amy and Louisa Eshton, is very imposing: the gentlemen are all costumed in black; most of the gentlemen are tall, some young. Henry and Frederick Lynn are very dashing sparks indeed; and Mrs. Dent is a fine soldierly man. Louisa Eshton, is gentleman-like: Louisa Eshton's hair is quite white, Louisa Eshton's eyebrows and w hiskers still dark, which gives him something of the appearance of a “père noble de théâtre.” him, like him's sisters, is very tall; like his sisters, also, him is handsome; but him shares Mary’s apathetic and listless look: him seems to have more length of limb than vivacity of blood or vigour of brain.  And where is Mr. Rochester?  Mr. Rochester comes in last: I am not looking at the arch, yet I see Mr. Rochester enter. I try to concentrate I's attention on those netting-needles, on the meshes of the purse I am forming—I wish to think only of the work I have in I's hands, to see only the silver beads and silk threads that lie in I's lap; whereas, I distinctly behold Mr. Rochester's figure, and I inevitably recall the moment when I last saw his figure; just after I had rendered Mr. Rochester, what Mr. Rochester deemed, an essential service, and Mr. Rochester, holding I's hand, and looking down on I's face, surveyed I with eyes that revealed a heart full and eager to overflow; in whose emotions I had a part. How near had I approached Mr. Rochester at that moment! What had oc curred since, calculated to change his and my relative positions? Yet now, how distant, how far estranged his and my were! So far estranged, that my did not expect his to come and speak to my. my did not wonder, when, without looking at my, his took a seat at the other side of the room, and began conversing with some of the ladies.  No sooner did my see that his's attention was riveted on some of the ladies, and that my might gaze without being observed, than my's eyes were drawn involuntarily to his's face; my could not keep my eyes's lids under control: my eyes would rise, and the irids would fix on his. my looked, and had an acute pleasure in looking,—a precious yet poignant pleasure; pure gold, with a steely point of agony: a pleasure like what the thirst-perishing man might feel who knows the well to which the thirst-perishing man has crept is poisoned, yet stoops and drinks divine draughts nevertheless.  Most true is it that “beauty is in the eye of the gazer.” his's colourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows , deep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth,—all energy, decision, will,—were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than beautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite mastered me,—that took me's feelings from me's own power and fettered my feelings in his. me had not intended to love his; the reader knows me had wrought hard to extirpate from me's soul the germs of love there detected; and now, at the first renewed view of his, the germs of love there detected spontaneously arrived, green and strong! his made me love his without looking at me.  me compared his with his's guests. What was the gallant grace of the Lynns, the languid elegance of Lord Ingram,—even the military distinction of Colonel Dent, contrasted with Colonel Dent's look of native pith and genuine power? me had no sympathy in his guests's appearance, his guests's expression: yet me could imagine that most observers would call his guests attractive, handsome, imposing; while most observers would pronounce his at once harsh-featured and melancholy-looking.  I saw them smile, laugh—it was nothing; the light of the candles had as much soul in the light of the candles as them's smile; the tinkle of the bell as much significance as them's laugh. I saw Mr. Rochester smile:—his stern features softened; Mr. Rochester's eye grew both brilliant and gentle, his eye's ray both searching and sweet. Mr. Rochester was talking, at the moment, to Louisa and Amy Eshton. I wondered to see Louisa and Amy Eshton receive with calm that look which seemed to I so penetrating: I expected Louisa and Amy Eshton's eyes to fall, Louisa and Amy Eshton's colour to rise under that look which seemed to me so penetrating; yet I was glad when I found Louisa and Amy Eshton were in no sense moved. “Mr. Rochester is not to Louisa and Amy Eshton what Mr. Rochester is to I,” I thought: “Mr. Rochester is not of Louisa and Amy Eshton's kind. I believe Mr. Rochester is of mine;—I am sure Mr. Rochester is—I feel akin to Mr. Rochester—I understand the language of Mr. Rochester's countenance and movements: though rank and wealth sever us widely, I have something in I's brain and heart, in I's blood and nerves, that assimilates I mentally to Mr. Rochester. Did I say, a few days since, that I had nothing to do with Mr. Rochester but to receive I's salary at Mr. Rochester's hands? Did I  forbid myself to think of him in any other light than as a paymaster? Blasphemy against nature! Every good, true, vigorous feeling myself have gathers impulsively round him. myself know myself must conceal myself's sentiments: myself must smother hope; myself must remember that him cannot care much for myself. For when myself say that myself am of him's kind, myself do not mean that myself have him's force to influence, and him's spell to attract; myself mean only that myself have certain tastes and feelings in common with him. myself must, then, repeat continually that we are for ever sundered:—and yet, while myself breathe and think, myself must love him.”  Coffee is handed. The ladies, since the gentlemen entered, have become lively as larks; conversation waxes brisk and merry. Colonel Dent and Mr. Eshton argue on politics; Colonel Dent and Mr. Eshton's wives listen. The two proud dowagers, Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram, confabulate together. Sir George—whom, by-the-bye, myself have forgotten to describe,—a very big, and very fresh-looking country gentleman, stands before The two proud dowagers, Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram's sofa, coffee-cup in ha nd, and occasionally puts in a word. Mr. Frederick Lynn has taken a seat beside Mary Ingram, and is showing Mary Ingram the engravings of a splendid volume: Mary Ingram looks, smiles now and then, but apparently says little. The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram leans with folded arms on the chair-back of the little and lively Amy Eshton; Mary Ingram glances up at The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram, and chatters like a wren: Mary Ingram likes The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram better than Mary Ingram does Mr. Rochester. Henry Lynn has taken possession of an ottoman at the feet of Louisa: Adèle shares an ottoman at the feet of Louisa with Henry Lynn: Henry Lynn is trying to talk French with Louisa, and Louisa laughs at Henry Lynn's blunders. With whom will Blanche Ingram pair? Blanche Ingram is standing alone at the table, bending gracefully over an album. Blanche Ingram seems waiting to be sought; but Blanche Ingram will not wait too long: Blanche Ingram Blanche Ingram selects a mate.  Mr. Rochester, having quitted the Eshtons, stands on the hearth as solitary as Blanche Ingram stands by the table: Blanche Ingram confronts Mr. Rochester, taking Blanche Ingram's station on the opposite side of the mantelpiece.  “Mr. Rochester, Blanche Ingram thought Mr. Rochester ou were not fond of children?”  “Nor am I.”  “Then, what induced I. to take charge of such a little doll as that?” (pointing to that). “Where did I. pick that up?”  “I. did not pick that up; that was left on I.'s hands.”  “I. should have sent that to school.”  “I. could not afford sent: schools are so dear.”  “Why, I suppose I. have a governess for that: I saw a person with that just now—is that gone? Oh, no! there that is still, behind the window-curtain. I. pay that, of course; I should think it quite as expensive,—more so; for I. have them both to keep in addition.”  I feared—or should I say, hoped?—the allusion to I would make I. glance I's way; and I involuntarily shrank farther into the shade: but I. never turned I.'s eyes.  “I. have not considered the subject,” said I. indifferently, looking straight before I..  “No, you men never do consider economy and common sense. You should hear mama on the chapter of governesses: Mary and I have had, I should think, a dozen at least in o ur day; half of them detestable and the rest ridiculous, and all incubi—were them not, mama?”  “Did you speak, you?”  The young lady thus claimed as the dowager’s special property, reiterated you's question with an explanation.  “the dowager’s's , don’t mention governesses; the word makes the dowager’s nervous. the dowager’s have suffered a martyrdom from governesses's incompetency and caprice. the dowager’s thank Heaven the dowager’s have now done with governesses!”  Mrs. Dent here bent over to the dowager’s and whispered something in the dowager’s's ear; I suppose, from the answer elicited, it was a reminder that one of the anathematised race was present.  “Tant pis!” said the dowager’s, “the dowager’s hope it may do the dowager’s good!” Then, in a lower tone, but still loud enough for I to hear, “the dowager’s noticed the dowager’s; the dowager’s am a judge of physiognomy, and in the dowager’s the dowager’s see all the faults of the dowager’s's class.”  “What are all the faults of her class, the dowager’s?” inquired I aloud.  “the dowager’s will tell I in I's private ear,” replied the dowager’s, wagging the dowager’s's turban three times with portentous significancy.  “But the dowager’s's curiosity will be p ast its appetite; its craves food now.”  “Ask Blanche; Blanche is nearer Blanche than I.”  “Oh, don’t refer Blanche to Blanche, mama! Blanche have just one word to say of the whole tribe; the whole tribe are a nuisance. Not that Blanche ever suffered much from the whole tribe; Blanche took care to turn the tables. What tricks Blanche and Blanche used to play on Theodore and I's Miss Wilsons, and Mrs. Greys, and Madame Jouberts! Mary was always too sleepy to join in a plot with spirit. The best fun was with Madame Jouberts: Miss Wilson was a poor sickly thing, lachrymose and low-spirited, not worth the trouble of vanquishing, in short; and Mrs. Greys was coarse and insensible; no blow took effect on Mrs. Greys. But Madame Jouberts! Blanche see Madame Jouberts yet in Madame Jouberts's raging passions, when Theodore and I had driven Madame Jouberts to extremities—spilt Theodore and I's tea, crumbled Theodore and I's bread and butter, tossed Theodore and I's books up to the ceiling, and played a charivari with the ruler and desk, the fender and fire-irons. Blanche, do Blanche remember those merry days?”  “Yaas, to be sure Blanche do,” drawled Blanche; “and the poor o ld stick used to cry out ‘Oh you villains childs!’—and then we sermonised ld stick on the presumption of attempting to teach such clever blades as we were, when ld stick was ld stick so ignorant.”  “we did; and, Tedo, Tedo know, I helped Tedo in prosecuting (or persecuting) Tedo's tutor, whey-faced Mr. Vining—the parson in the pip, as we used to call your tutor, whey-faced Mr. Vining—the parson in the pip, as we used to call him. your tutor, whey-faced Mr. Vining—the parson in the pip, as we used to call him and Miss Wilson took the liberty of falling in love with each other—at least Tedo I thought so; we surprised sundry tender glances and sighs which we interpreted as tokens of ‘la belle passion,’ and I promise you the public soon had the benefit of we's discovery; we employed our discovery as a sort of lever to hoist we's dead-weights from the house. ld stick, there, as soon as ld stick got an inkling of the business, found out that the business was of an immoral tendency. Did ld stick not, I's ?”  “Certainly, ld stick's best. And I was quite right: depend on that: there are a thousand reasons why liaisons between governesses and tutors should never be tolerated a moment i n any well-regulated house; firstly—”  “Oh, gracious, mama! Spare us the enumeration! _Au reste_, we all know them: danger of bad example to innocence of childhood; distractions and consequent neglect of duty on the part of the attached—mutual alliance and reliance; confidence thence resulting—insolence accompanying—mutiny and general blow-up. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?”  “I, I are right now, as always.”  “Then no more need be said: change the subject.”  Amy Eshton, not hearing or not heeding this dictum, joined in with Amy Eshton's soft, infantine tone: “Louisa and Amy Eshton used to quiz Louisa and I's governess too; but our governess was such a good creature, our governess would bear anything: nothing put our governess out. our governess was never cross with Louisa and I; was our governess, Louisa?”  “No, never: Louisa and I might do what Louisa and I pleased; ransack our governess's desk and our governess's workbox, and turn our governess's drawers inside out; and our governess was so good-natured, our governess would give Louisa and I anything Louisa and I asked for.”  “I suppose, now,” said Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park, curling Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park's lip sarcastic ally, “we shall have an abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant: in order to avert such a visitation, I again move the introduction of a new topic. Mr. Rochester, do Mr. Rochester second I's motion?”  “I, Mr. Rochester support I on this point, as on every other.”  “Then on I be the onus of bringing it forward. Signior Eduardo, are Signior Eduardo in voice to-night?”  “Donna Bianca, if Donna Bianca command it, Signior Eduardo will be.”  “Then, Signior Eduardo, I lay on Signior Eduardo I's sovereign behest to furbish up Signior Eduardo's lungs and other vocal organs, as your lungs and other vocal organs will be wanted on I's royal service.”  “Who would not be the Rizzio of so divine a Mary?”  “A fig for Rizzio!” cried Donna Bianca, tossing Donna Bianca's head with all her head with all its curls's curls, as Donna Bianca moved to the piano. “It is Donna Bianca's opinion the fiddler David must have been an insipid sort of fellow; Donna Bianca like black Bothwell better: to Donna Bianca's mind a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in a man; and history may say what history will of James Hepburn, but Donna Bianca have a notion, James Hepburn was just the sort of wild, fierce, bandit hero whom Donna Bianca coul d have consented to gift with my hand.”  “Gentlemen, you hear! Now which of Gentlemen most resembles Bothwell?” cried Mr. Rochester.  “I should say the preference lies with I,” responded I.  “On I's honour, I am much obliged to I,” was the reply.  Miss Ingram, who had now seated Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude with proud grace at the piano, spreading out Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude's snowy robes in queenly amplitude, commenced a brilliant prelude; talking meantime. Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude appeared to be on Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude's high horse to-night; both Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude's words and Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude's air seemed intended to excite not only the admiration, but the amazement of Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude's auditors: Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude was evidently bent on striking her auditors as something very dashing and daring indeed.  “Oh, Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude am so sick of the young men of the present day!” exclaimed Miss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano, spreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude, rattling away at the instrument. “Poor, puny things, not fit to stir a step beyond papa’s park gates: nor to go even so far without papa’s's permission and guardianship! Creatures so absorbed in care about their pretty faces, and their's white hands, and thei r small feet; as if a man had anything to do with beauty! As if loveliness were not the special prerogative of woman—woman's legitimate appanage and heritage! I grant an ugly _woman_ is a blot on the fair face of creation; but as to the _gentlemen_, let the _gentlemen be solicitous to possess only strength and valour: let the _gentlemen's motto be:—Hunt, shoot, and fight: the rest is not worth a fillip. Such should be I's device, were I a man.”  “Whenever I marry,” I continued after a pause which none interrupted, “I am resolved I's husband shall not be a rival, but a foil to I. I will suffer no competitor near the throne; I shall exact an undivided homage: my husband's devotions shall not be shared between I and the shape my husband sees in my husband's mirror. Mr. Rochester, now sing, and I will play for Mr. Rochester.”  “Mr. Rochester am all obedience,” was the response.  “Here then is a Corsair-song. Know that I doat on Corsairs; and for that reason, sing a Corsair-song _con spirito_.”  “Commands from Miss Ingram’s lips would put spirit into a mug of milk and wat er.”  “Take care, then: if you don’t please me, me will shame you by showing how such things _should_ be done.”  “That is offering a premium on incapacity: you shall now endeavour to fail.”  “Gardez-vous en bien! If you err wilfully, me shall devise a proportionate punishment.”  “Miss Ingram ought to be clement, for Miss Ingram has it in Miss Ingram's power to inflict a chastisement beyond mortal endurance.”  “Ha! explain!” commanded you.  “Pardon me, you: no need of explanation; you's own fine sense must inform you that one of you's frowns would be a sufficient substitute for capital punishment.”  “Sing!” said Miss Ingram, and again touching the piano, Miss Ingram commenced an accompaniment in spirited style.  “Now is me's time to slip away,” thought me: but the tones that then severed the air arrested me. Mrs. Fairfax had said Mr. Rochester possessed a fine voice: Mr. Rochester did—a mellow, powerful bass, into which Mr. Rochester threw Mr. Rochester's own feeling, Mr. Rochester's own force; finding a way through the ear to the heart, and there waking sensation st rangely. I waited till the last deep and full vibration had expired—till the tide of talk, checked an instant, had resumed the tide of talk, checked an instant,'s flow; I then quitted I's sheltered corner and made I's exit by the side-door, which was fortunately near. Thence a narrow passage led into the hall: in crossing a narrow passage, I perceived I's sandal was loose; I stopped to tie my sandal, kneeling down for tie on the mat at the foot of the staircase. I heard the dining-room door unclose; a gentleman came out; rising hastily, I stood face to face with a gentleman: a gentleman was a gentleman.  “How do I do?” a gentleman asked.  “I am very well, a gentleman.”  “Why did I not come and speak to a gentleman in the room?”  I thought I might have retorted the question on a gentlemanthe question: but I would not take that freedom. I answered—  “I did not wish to disturb a gentleman, as a gentleman seemed engaged, a gentleman.”  “What have I been doing during a gentleman's absence?”  “Nothing particular; teaching Adèle as usual.”  “And getting a good deal paler than I were—as a gentleman saw at first sight. What is th e matter?”  “Nothing at all, sir.”  “Did sir take any cold that night sir half drowned sir?”  “Not the least.”  “Return to the drawing-room: sir are deserting too early.”  “sir am tired, sir.”  sir looked at sir for a minute.  “And a little depressed,” sir said. “What about? Tell sir.”  “Nothing—nothing, sir. sir am not depressed.”  “But sir affirm that sir are: so much depressed that a few more words would bring tears to sir's eyes—indeed, your eyes are there now, shining and swimming; and a bead has slipped from the lash and fallen on to the flag. If sir had time, and was not in mortal dread of some prating prig of a servant passing, sir would know what all this means. Well, to-night sir excuse sir; but understand that so long as sir's visitors stay, sir expect sir to appear in the drawing-room every evening; it is sir's wish; don’t neglect it. Now go, and send Sophie for Adèle. Good-night, sir's—” sir stopped, bit sir's lip, and abruptly left sir.     CHAPTER XVIII   Merry days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy da ys too: how different from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and solitude ys had passed beneath its roof! All sad feelings seemed now driven from its, all gloomy associations forgotten: there was life everywhere, movement all day long. You could not now traverse the gallery, once so hushed, nor enter the front chambers, once so tenantless, without encountering a smart lady’s-maid or a dandy valet.  The kitchen, the butler’s pantry, the servants’ hall, the entrance hall, were equally alive; and the saloons were only left void and still when the blue sky and halcyon sunshine of the genial spring weather called the saloons's occupants out into the grounds. Even when the genial spring weather was broken, and continuous rain set in for some days, no damp seemed cast over enjoyment: indoor amusements only became more lively and varied, in consequence of the stop put to outdoor gaiety.  ys wondered what they were going to do the first evening a change of entertainment was proposed: they spoke of  “playing charades,” but in my ignorance my did not understand the term. The servants were called in, the dining-room tables wheeled away, the lights otherwise disposed, the chairs placed in a semicircle opposite the arch. While Mr. Rochester and the other gentlemen directed these alterations, the ladies were running up and down stairs ringing for the ladies's maids. Mrs. Fairfax was summoned to give information respecting the resources of the house in shawls, dresses, draperies of any kind; and certain wardrobes of the third storey were ransacked, and certain wardrobes of the third storey's contents, in the shape of brocaded and hooped petticoats, satin sacques, black modes, lace lappets, &c., were brought down in armfuls by the abigails; then a selection was made, and such things as were chosen were carried to the boudoir within the drawing-room.  Meantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round Mr. Rochester, and was selecting certain of the ladies's number to be of Mr. Rochester's party. “Miss Ingram is mine, of course,” said Mr. Rochester: afterwards  he named the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. he looked at me: me happened to be near he, as me had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent's bracelet, which had got loose.  “Will me play?” he asked. me shook me's head. he did not insist, which me rather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to me's usual seat.  he and he's aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which was headed by Mrs. Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that me should be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the notion.  “No,” me heard Lady Ingram say: “me looks too stupid for any game of the sort.”  Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the bulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, on a table, lay open a large book; and at Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen's side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr. Rochester's cloak, and holding a bo ok in her hand. Somebody, unseen, rang the bell merrily; then Adèle (who had insisted on being one of Adèle (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party)'s guardian’s party), bounded forward, scattering round Adèle (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party) the contents of a basket of flowers Adèle (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party) carried on Adèle (who had insisted on being one of her guardian’s party)'s arm. Then appeared the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow's head, and a wreath of roses round the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow's brow; by the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow's side walked Mr. Rochester, and together they drew near the table. they knelt; while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white's stations behind they. A ceremony followed, in dumb show, in which it was easy to recognise the pantomime of a marriage. At A ceremony's termination, Colonel Dent and Colonel Dent's party consulted in whispers for two minutes, then Colonel Dent called out—  “Bride!” Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.  A considerable interval elapsed before the curtain again rose. the curtain's second rising displayed a more elaborately prepared scene than the last. The drawing-room, as I have before observed, was raised two steps abo ve the dining-room, and on the top of the upper step, placed a yard or two back within the dining-room, appeared a large marble basin, which I recognised as an ornament of the conservatory—where it usually stood, surrounded by exotics, and tenanted by gold fish—and whence it must have been transported with some trouble, on account of it's size and weight.  Seated on the carpet, by the side of it, was seen Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head's head. Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head's dark eyes and swarthy skin and Paynim features suited the costume exactly: Mr. Rochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head looked the very model of an Eastern emir, an agent or a victim of the bowstring. Presently advanced into view Miss Ingram. Miss Ingram, too, was attired in oriental fashion: a crimson scarf tied sash-like round the waist: an embroidered handkerchief knotted about Miss Ingram's temples; Miss Ingram's beautifully-moulded arms bare, one of her beautifully-moulded arms upraised in the act of supporting a pitcher, poised gracefully on Miss Ingram's head. Both Miss Ingram's cast of form and feature, Miss Ingram's complexion and h er general air, suggested the idea of some Israelitish princess of the patriarchal days; and such was doubtless the character she intended to represent.  she approached the basin, and bent over the basin as if to fill she's pitcher; she again lifted her pitcher to she's head. The personage on the well-brink now seemed to accost she; to make some request:—“She hasted, let down her pitcher on she's hand, and gave him to drink.” From the bosom of The personage on the well-brink's robe The personage on the well-brink then produced a casket, opened a casket and showed magnificent bracelets and earrings; she acted astonishment and admiration; kneeling, The personage on the well-brink laid magnificent bracelets and earrings at she's feet; incredulity and delight were expressed by she's looks and gestures; The personage on the well-brink fastened the bracelets on she's arms and the rings in she's ears. It was Eliezer and Rebecca: the camels only were wanting.  The divining party again laid The divining party's heads together: apparently The divining party could not agree about the word or syllable the scene illustrated. Colonel Dent, The divining party's spokesman, demanded “the tableau of the whol e;” whereupon the curtain again descended.  On the curtain's third rising only a portion of the drawing-room was disclosed; the rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and coarse drapery. The marble basin was removed; in The marble basin's place, stood a deal table and a kitchen chair: a deal table and a kitchen chair were visible by a very dim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all extinguished.  Amidst this sordid scene, sat a man with a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's clenched hands resting on a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's knees, and a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's eyes bent on the ground. I knew a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground; though the begrimed face, the disordered dress (a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's coat hanging loose from one arm, as if his coat had been almost torn from a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's back in a scuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling hair might well have disguised a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground. As a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground moved, a chain clanked; to a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground's wrists were attached fetters.  “Bridewell!” exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.  A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume the performers's ordinary cos tume, they re-entered the dining-room. Mr. Rochester led in Miss Ingram; Miss Ingram was complimenting Mr. Rochester on Mr. Rochester's acting.  “Do Mr. Rochester know,” said Miss Ingram, “that, of the three characters, Miss Ingram liked Mr. Rochester in the last best? Oh, had Mr. Rochester but lived a few years earlier, what a gallant gentleman-highwayman Mr. Rochester would have made!”  “Is all the soot washed from Mr. Rochester's face?” Mr. Rochester asked, turning my face towards Miss Ingram.  “Alas! yes: the more’s the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to Mr. Rochester's complexion than that ruffian’s rouge.”  “Miss Ingram would like a hero of the road then?”  “An English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit; and An English hero of the road could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate.”  “Well, whatever Mr. Rochester am, remember Miss Ingram are Mr. Rochester's wife; we were married an hour since, in the presence of all these witnesses.” Miss Ingram giggled, and Miss Ingram's colour rose.  “Now, Dent,” continued Mr. Rochester, “it is Dent's turn.” And as the other party withdrew, they took the vacated seats. Miss Ingram placed Miss Ingram at Mr. Rochester's r ight hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; I's attention was absorbed by the spectators; I's eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs. What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word Colonel Dent and his party chose, how Colonel Dent and his party acquitted Colonel Dent and his party, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see her turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to her; I see her's incline her's head towards her, till the jetty curls almost touch her's shoulder and wave against her's cheek; I hear him and her's mutual whisperings; I recall him and her's interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.  I have told you, you, that I had learnt to love her: I could not unlove her now, merely because I found that her had ceased to notice I—because I might  pass hours in his presence, and his would never once turn his's eyes in my direction—because my saw all his's attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch my with the hem of her robes as her passed; who, if ever her's dark and imperious eye fell on my by chance, would withdraw her dark and imperious eye instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation. my could not unlove his, because my felt sure his would soon marry her—because my read daily in her a proud security in his's intentions respecting her—because my witnessed hourly in his a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its's very pride, irresistible.  There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though much to create despair. Much too, you will think, you, to engender jealousy: if a woman, in my's position, could presume to be jealous of a woman in Miss Ingram’s. But my was not jealous: or very rarely;—the nature  of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word. Miss Ingram was a mark beneath jealousy: Miss Ingram was too inferior to excite jealousy. Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say. Miss Ingram was very showy, but Miss Ingram was not genuine: Miss Ingram had a fine person, many brilliant attainments; but Miss Ingram's mind was poor, Miss Ingram's heart barren by nature: nothing bloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted by its freshness. Miss Ingram was not good; Miss Ingram was not original: Miss Ingram used to repeat sounding phrases from books: Miss Ingram never offered, nor had, an opinion of Miss Ingram's own. Miss Ingram advocated a high tone of sentiment; but Miss Ingram did not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in Miss Ingram. Too often Miss Ingram betrayed were, by the undue vent Miss Ingram gave to a spiteful antipathy Miss Ingram had conceived against little Adèle: pushing little Adèle away with some contumelious epithet if little Adèle happened to approach little Adèle; sometimes ordering little Adèle from the room, and always treating little Adèle with coldness and acrimo ny. Other eyes besides mine watched these manifestations of character—watched these manifestations of character closely, keenly, shrewdly. Yes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself's intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity—this guardedness of the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself's—this perfect, clear consciousness of his intended's defects—this obvious absence of passion in the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself's sentiments towards his intended, that mine's ever-torturing pain arose.  mine saw the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself was going to marry his intended, for family, perhaps political reasons, because his intended's rank and connections suited the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself; mine felt the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself had not given his intended the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself's love, and that his intended's qualifications were ill adapted to win from the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself his love. This was the point—This was where the nerve was touched and teased—This was where the fever was sustained and fed: _his intended could not charm the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself_.  If his intended had managed the victory at once, and the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself had yielded and sincerely laid the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself's heart at his intended's feet, mine should have covered mine's face, turned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them. If Miss  Ingram had been a good and noble woman, endowed with force, fervour, kindness, sense, I should have had one vital struggle with two tigers—jealousy and despair: then, I's heart torn out and devoured, I should have admired Ingram—acknowledged Ingram's excellence, and been quiet for the rest of I's days: and the more absolute Ingram's superiority, the deeper would have been I's admiration—the more truly tranquil I's quiescence. But as matters really stood, to watch Ingram's efforts at fascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure—Ingram unconscious that their did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming Ingram on success, when Ingram's pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what Ingram wished to allure—to witness _this_, was to be at once under ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.  Because, when Ingram failed, I saw how Ingram might have succeeded. Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester's breast and fell harmless  at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his's proud heart—have called love into his's stern eye, and softness into his's sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.  “Why can she not influence his more, when she is privileged to draw so near to his?” I asked I. “Surely she cannot truly like his, or not like his with true affection! If she did, she need not coin she's smiles so lavishly, flash she's glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so elaborate, graces so multitudinous. It seems to I that she might, by merely sitting quietly at his's side, saying little and looking less, get nigher his's heart. I have seen in his's face a far different expression from that which hardens his face now while she is so vivaciously accosting his; but then it came of it: it was not elicited by meretricious arts and calculated manoeuvres; and one had but to accept it—to answer what his asked without pretension, to address his when nee dful without grimace—and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed one like a fostering sunbeam. How will she manage to please him when they are married? I do not think she will manage please; and yet please might be managed; and him's might, I verily believe, be the very happiest woman the sun shines on.”  I have not yet said anything condemnatory of him's project of marrying for interest and connections. It surprised I when I first discovered that such was him's intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in him's choice of a wife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into him or Miss Ingram, doubtless, from him or Miss Ingram's childhood. All him or Miss Ingram's class held ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood: I supposed, then, All their class had reasons for holding ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood such as I could not fathom. It seemed to I that, were I  a gentleman like him, I would take to I's bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very obviousness of the advantages to him's own happiness offered by this plan convinced I that there must be arguments against this plan's general adoption of which I was quite ignorant: otherwise I felt sure all the world would act as I wished to act.  But in other points, as well as this, I was growing very lenient to him: I was forgetting all him's faults, for which I had once kept a sharp look-out. It had formerly been I's endeavour to study all sides of him's character: to take the bad with the good; and from the just weighing of both, to form an equitable judgment. Now I saw no bad. The sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled I once, were only like keen condiments in a choice dish: The sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once's presence was pungent, but The sarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once's absence would be felt as comparatively insipid. And as for the vague something—was it a sinister or a sorrowful, a designing or a desponding expression?— that opened upon a careful observer, now and then, in a careful observer's eye, and closed again before one could fathom the strange depth partially disclosed; that something which used to make me fear and shrink, as if me had been wandering amongst volcanic-looking hills, and had suddenly felt the ground quiver and seen the ground gape: that something, me, at intervals, beheld still; and with throbbing heart, but not with palsied nerves. Instead of wishing to shun, me longed only to dare—to divine that something; and me thought Miss Ingram happy, because one day Miss Ingram might look into the abyss at Miss Ingram's leisure, explore the abyss's secrets and analyse its secrets's nature.  Meantime, while me thought only of me's master and my master's future bride—saw my master and his future bride, heard only their discourse, and considered only my master and his future bride's movements of importance—the rest of the party were occupied with the rest of the party's own separate interests and pleasures. my master and his future bride continued to consort in solemn conferences, where my master and his future bride nodded my master and his future bride's two turbans at each other, and held up t heir four hands in confronting gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs. Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes bestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and good-natured Mrs. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice business. Lord Ingram flirted with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; Louisa played and sang to and with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly to the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one consent, suspended all's by-play to observe and listen to the principal actors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and—because closely connected with Mr. Rochester—Mary Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If Mr. Rochester was absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal over the spirits of Mr. Rochester's guests; and Mr. Rochester's re-entrance was sure to give a fresh impulse to the vivacity of conversation.  The want of Mr. Rochester's animating  influence appeared to be peculiarly felt one day that he had been summoned to Millcote on business, and was not likely to return till late. The afternoon was wet: a walk the party had proposed to take to see a gipsy camp, lately pitched on a common beyond Hay, was consequently deferred. Some of the gentlemen were gone to the stables: the younger ones, together with the younger ladies, were playing billiards in the billiard-room. The dowagers Ingram and Lynn sought solace in a quiet game at cards. Blanche Ingram, after having repelled, by supercilious taciturnity, some efforts of Mrs. Dent and Mrs. Eshton to draw Blanche Ingram into conversation, had first murmured over some sentimental tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a novel from the library, had flung Blanche Ingram in haughty listlessness on a sofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious hours of absence. The room and the house were silent: only now and then the merriment of the billiard-players was heard  from above.  It was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the hour to dress for dinner, when little Adèle, who knelt by me in the drawing-room window-seat, suddenly exclaimed—  “Voilà me, qui revient!”  me turned, and Miss Ingram darted forwards from Miss Ingram's sofa: the others, too, looked up from the others's several occupations; for at the same time a crunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse-hoofs became audible on the wet gravel. A post-chaise was approaching.  “What can possess me to come home in that style?” said Miss Ingram. “me rode Mesrour (the black horse), did me not, when me went out? and Pilot was with him:—what has me done with the animals?”  As Miss Ingram said this, Miss Ingram approached Miss Ingram's tall person and ample garments so near the window, that me was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking of me's spine: in Miss Ingram's eagerness Miss Ingram did not observe me at first, but when Miss Ingram did, Miss Ingram curled Miss Ingram's lip and moved to another casement. A post-chaise stopped; th e driver rang the door-bell, and a gentleman alighted attired in travelling garb; but a gentleman was not Mr. Rochester; a gentleman was a gentleman.  “How provoking!” exclaimed Miss Ingram: “you tiresome monkey!” (apostrophising Adèle), “who perched you tiresome monkey up in the window to give false intelligence?” and Miss Ingram cast on me an angry glance, as if me were in fault.  Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon a gentleman entered. a gentleman bowed to Miss Ingram, as deeming Miss Ingram the eldest lady present.  “It appears a gentleman come at an inopportune time, Miss Ingram,” said a gentleman, “when Mr. Rochester, is from home; but a gentleman arrive from a very long journey, and a gentleman think a gentleman may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal a gentleman here till Mr. Rochester returns.”  a gentleman's manner was polite; a gentleman's accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,—not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: a gentleman's age might be about Mr. Rochester’s,—between thirty and forty; a gentleman's complexion was singu larly sallow: otherwise larly sallow was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you detected something in larly sallow's face that displeased, or rather that failed to please. larly sallow's features were regular, but too relaxed: larly sallow's eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of his eye was a tame, vacant life—at least so I thought.  The sound of the dressing-bell dispersed the party. It was not till after dinner that I saw larly sallow again: larly sallow then seemed quite at larly sallow's ease. But I liked larly sallow's physiognomy even less than before: his physiognomy struck I as being at the same time unsettled and inanimate. larly sallow's eye wandered, and had no meaning in His eye's wandering: wandered gave larly sallow an odd look, such as I never remembered to have seen. For a handsome and not an unamiable-looking man, larly sallow repelled I exceedingly: there was no power in his face: no firmness in that aquiline nose and small cherry mouth; there was no thought on the low, even forehead; no command in that blank, brown  eye.  As I sat in I's usual nook, and looked at him with the light of the girandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him—for him occupied an arm-chair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as if him were cold, I compared him with Mr. Rochester. I think (with deference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between a sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the rough-coated keen-eyed dog, a meek sheep's guardian.  him had spoken of Mr. Rochester as an old friend. A curious friendship theirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage that “extremes meet.”  Two or three of the gentlemen sat near him, and I caught at times scraps of Two or three of the gentlemen's conversation across the room. At first I could not make much sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to I, confused the fragmentary sentences that reached I at intervals. Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to me, were discussing him; Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to me, called him “a beaut iful man.” Louisa said he was “a love of a creature,” and Louisa “adored he;” and Mary instanced he's “pretty little mouth, and nice nose,” as Mary's ideal of the charming.  “And what a sweet-tempered forehead he has!” cried Louisa,—“so smooth—none of those frowning irregularities Louisa dislike so much; and such a placid eye and smile!”  And then, to my great relief, Mary summoned them to the other side of the room, to settle some point about the deferred excursion to Hay Common.  my was now able to concentrate my's attention on them, and my presently gathered that he was called Mr. Mason; then my learned that he was but just arrived in England, and that he came from some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, he's face was so sallow, and that he sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the house. Presently the words Jamaica, Kingston, Spanish Town, indicated the West Indies as he's residence; and it was with no little surprise my gathered, ere long, tha t he had there first seen and become acquainted with Mr. Rochester. he spoke of Mr. Rochester's dislike of the burning heats, the hurricanes, and rainy seasons of that region. I knew Mr. Rochester had been a traveller: Mrs. Fairfax had said so; but I thought the continent of Europe had bounded Mr. Rochester's wanderings; till now I had never heard a hint given of visits to more distant shores.  I was pondering these things, when an incident, and a somewhat unexpected one, broke the thread of I's musings. Mr. Mason, shivering as some one chanced to open the door, asked for more coal to be put on the fire, which had burnt out the fire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still shone hot and red's flame, though the fire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still shone hot and red's mass of cinder still shone hot and red. The footman who brought more coal, in going out, stopped near Mr. Eshton’s chair, and said something to Mr. Eshton’s in a low voice, of which I heard only the words, “old woman,”—“quite troublesome.”  “Tell Mr. Mason Mr. Mason shall be put in the stocks if Mr. Mason does not take Mr. Mason off,” replied Mr. Eshton’s.  “No—stop!” interrupted Colonel  Dent. “Don’t send her away, Eshton; we might turn the thing to account; better consult the ladies.” And speaking aloud, he continued—“Ladies, the ladies talked of going to Hay Common to visit the gipsy camp; Sam here says that her is in the servants’ hall at this moment, and insists upon being brought in before ‘the quality,’ to tell ‘the quality ‘the quality's fortunes. Would the ladies like to see her?”  “Surely, he,” cried Lady Ingram, “he would not encourage such a low impostor? Dismiss her, by all means, at once!”  “But Sam cannot persuade her to go away, Lady Ingram,” said Sam; “nor can any of the servants: Mrs. Fairfax is with her just now, entreating her to be gone; but her has taken a chair in the chimney-corner, and says nothing shall stir her from a chair in the chimney-corner till her gets leave to come in here.”  “What does her want?” asked Eshton.  “‘To tell the gentry the gentry's fortunes,’ her says, Eshton; and her swears her must and will do tell.”  “What is her like?” inquired Eshton , in a breath.  “A shockingly ugly old creature, miss; almost as black as a crock.”  “Why, miss’s a real sorceress!” cried Frederick Lynn. “Let us have miss in, of course.”  “To be sure,” rejoined Frederick Lynn; “it would be a thousand pities to throw away such a chance of fun.”  “My dear boys, what are My dear boys thinking about?” exclaimed Frederick Lynn.  “My cannot possibly countenance any such inconsistent proceeding,” chimed in My.  “Indeed, My, but My can—and will,” pronounced the haughty voice of Blanche, as Blanche turned round on the piano-stool; where till now Blanche had sat silent, apparently examining sundry sheets of music. “Blanche have a curiosity to hear Blanche's fortune told: therefore, Sam, order the beldame forward.”  “Sam's ! recollect—”  “Blanche do—Blanche recollect all Sam can suggest; and Blanche must have Blanche's will—quick, Sam!”  “Yes—yes—yes!” cried all the juveniles, both ladies and gentlemen. “Let miss come—it will be excellent sport!”  The footman still lingered. “miss looks such a ro ugh one,” said he.  “Go!” ejaculated Miss Ingram, and he went.  Excitement instantly seized the whole party: a running fire of raillery and jests was proceeding when Sam returned.  “She won’t come now,” said Sam. “She says it’s not She's mission to appear before the ‘vulgar herd’ (them’s She's words). Sam must show She into a room by She, and then those who wish to consult She must go to She's one by one.”  “You see now, You,” began Miss Ingram, “She encroaches. Be advised, Miss Ingram's angel girl—and—”  “Show She into the library, of course,” cut in my angel girl.” “It is not Sam's mission to listen to She before the ‘vulgar herd’ either: Sam mean to have She all to Sam. Is there a fire in the library?”  “Yes, Sam—but She looks such a tinkler.”  “Cease that chatter, blockhead! and do Sam's bidding.”  Again Sam vanished; and mystery, animation, expectation rose to full flow once more.  “She’s ready now,” said Sam, as Sam reappeared. “She wishes to know who will be She's first vi sitor.”  “I think I had better just look in upon her before any of the ladies go,” said I.  “Tell her, Sam, a gentleman is coming.”  Sam went and returned.  “her says, I, that her’ll have no gentlemen; no gentlemen need not trouble no gentlemen to come near her; nor,” Sam added, with difficulty suppressing a titter, “any ladies either, except the young, and single.”  “By Jove, her has taste!” exclaimed Henry Lynn.  her rose solemnly: “her go first,” her said, in a tone which might have befitted the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in the van of the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in the van of his men's men.  “Oh, her's best! oh, my dearest! pause—reflect!” was my's cry; but her swept past my in stately silence, passed through the door which I held open, and we heard her enter the library.  A comparative silence ensued. her thought it “le cas” to wring her's hands: which her did accordingly. my declared my felt, for my's part, my never dared venture. Amy and Louisa Eshton tittered under Amy and Louisa Eshton's  breath, and looked a little frightened.  The minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the library-door again opened. Miss Ingram returned to us through the arch.  Would Miss Ingram laugh? Would Miss Ingram take it as a joke? All eyes met Miss Ingram with a glance of eager curiosity, and Miss Ingram met All eyes with one of rebuff and coldness; Miss Ingram looked neither flurried nor merry: Miss Ingram walked stiffly to Miss Ingram's seat, and took her seat in silence.  “Well, Miss Ingram?” said Lord Ingram.  “What did Miss Ingram say, sister?” asked Mary.  “What did sister think? How do sister feel? Is Miss Ingram a real fortune-teller?” demanded the Misses Eshton.  “Now, now, good people,” returned Miss Ingram, “don’t press upon Miss Ingram. Really good people's organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: good people seem, by the importance of good people—Miss Ingram's good mama included—ascribe to this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the house, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman.
