Miss Ingram have seen a gipsy vagabond; a gipsy vagabond has practised in hackneyed fashion the s cience of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. me's whim is gratified; and now me think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks to-morrow morning, as Mr. Eshton threatened.”  the hag took a book, leant back in the hag's chair, and so declined further conversation. me watched the hag for nearly half-an-hour: during all that time the hag never turned a page, and the hag's face grew momently darker, more dissatisfied, and more sourly expressive of disappointment. the hag had obviously not heard anything to the hag's advantage: and it seemed to me, from the hag's prolonged fit of gloom and taciturnity, that the hagthe hag, notwithstanding the hag's professed indifference, attached undue importance to whatever revelations had been made the hag.   During all that time the hag never turned a page  Meantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Mr. Eshton, declared Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton dared not go alone; and yet Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton wished to go. A negotiation was opened through the medium of the ambassador, Sam; and after much pacing to and fro, till, me think, th e said Sam’s calves must have ached with the exercise, permission was at last, with great difficulty, extorted from Sam’s, for the three to wait upon Sam’s in a body.  the three's visit was not so still as Miss Ingram’s had been: we heard hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and at the end of about twenty minutes the three burst the door open, and came running across the hall, as if the three were half-scared out of the three's wits.  “I am sure Sam’s is something not right!” the three cried, one and all. “Sam’s told the three such things! Sam’s knows all about the three!” and the three sank breathless into the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring the three.  Pressed for further explanation, the three declared Sam’s had told the three of things the three had said and done when the three were mere children; described books and ornaments the three had in the three's boudoirs at home: keepsakes that different relations had presented to the three. the three affirmed that Sam’s had even divined the three's thoughts, and had whispered in the ear o f each the name of the person she liked best in the world, and informed she of what she most wished for.  Here the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further enlightened on these two last-named points; but the gentlemen got only blushes, ejaculations, tremors, and titters, in return for the gentlemen's importunity. The matrons, meantime, offered vinaigrettes and wielded fans; and again and again reiterated the expression of The matrons's concern that The matrons's warning had not been taken in time; and the elder gentlemen laughed, and the younger urged the younger's services on the agitated fair ones.  In the midst of the tumult, and while my eyes and ears were fully engaged in the scene before my, my heard a hem close at my's elbow: my turned, and saw Sam.  “If my please, my, the gipsy declares that there is another young single lady in the room who has not been to the gipsy yet, and another young single lady in the room who has not been to her yet swears another young single lady in the room who has not been to her yet will not go till another young single lady in the room who has not been to her yet has seen all. Sam thought it must be my: there is no one else for it. What shall Sam tell another young single lady in the room who has not been to her yet?”  “Oh,  I will go by all means,” I answered: and I was glad of the unexpected opportunity to gratify I's much-excited curiosity. I slipped out of the room, unobserved by any eye—for the company were gathered in one mass about the trembling trio just returned—and I closed the door quietly behind I.  “If I like, I,” said Sam, “Sam’ll wait in the hall for I; and if she frightens I, just call and Sam’ll come in.”  “No, Sam, return to the kitchen: I am not in the least afraid.” Nor was I; but I was a good deal interested and excited.     CHAPTER XIX   The library looked tranquil enough as I entered The library, and she—if Sibyl she were—was seated snugly enough in an easy-chair at the chimney-corner. she had on a red cloak and a black bonnet: or rather, a broad-brimmed gipsy hat, tied down with a striped handkerchief under she's chin. An extinguished candle stood on the table; she was bending over the fire, and seemed reading in a little black book, like a prayer-book, by the light of the fire: s he muttered the words to he, as most old women do, while he read; he did not desist immediately on my entrance: it appeared he wished to finish a paragraph.  my stood on the rug and warmed my's hands, which were rather cold with sitting at a distance from the drawing-room fire. my felt now as composed as ever my did in my's life: there was nothing indeed in he's appearance to trouble one’s calm. he shut he's book and slowly looked up; he's hat-brim partially shaded he's face, yet my could see, as he raised her hat-brim, that her hat-brim was a strange one. her hat-brim looked all brown and black: elf-locks bristled out from beneath a white band which passed under he's chin, and came half over he's cheeks, or rather jaws: he's eye confronted my at once, with a bold and direct gaze.  “Well, and my want my's fortune told?” he said, in a voice as decided as he's glance, as harsh as he's features.  “my don’t care about your fortune, he; he may please he: but my ought to warn he, my have no faith.”  “It’s like my's imp udence to say so: I expected it of udence; I heard it in udence's step as udence crossed the threshold.”  “Did udence? udence’ve a quick ear.”  “udence have; and a quick eye and a quick brain.”  “udence need them all in udence's trade.”  “udence do; especially when udence’ve customers like udence to deal with. Why don’t udence tremble?”  “udence’m not cold.”  “Why don’t udence turn pale?”  “udence am not sick.”  “Why don’t udence consult udence's art?”  “udence’m not silly.”  The old crone “nichered” a laugh under The old crone's bonnet and bandage; The old crone then drew out a short black pipe, and lighting a short black pipe began to smoke. Having indulged a while in this sedative, The old crone raised The old crone's bent body, took a short black pipe from The old crone's lips, and while gazing steadily at the fire, said very deliberately—  “udence are cold; udence are sick; and udence are silly.”  “Prove it,” udence rejoined.  “udence will, in few words. The old crone are cold, because The old crone are alone: no contact strikes the fire from you that is in The old crone. The old crone are sick; because the best of feelings, the highest and the sweetest given to man, keeps far away from The old crone ou. You are silly, because, suffer as You may, You will not beckon it to approach, nor will You stir one step to meet it where it waits You.”  She again put She's short black pipe to She's lips, and renewed She's smoking with vigour.  “She might say all that to almost any one who She knew lived as a solitary dependent in a great house.”  “She might say all that to almost any one: but would all that be true of almost any one?”  “In She's circumstances.”  “Yes; just so, in my circumstancesmy circumstances: but find She another precisely placed as She are.”  “It would be easy to find She thousands.”  “She could scarcely find She one. If She knew it, She are peculiarly situated: very near happiness; yes, within reach of happiness. The materials are all prepared; there only wants a movement to combine The materials. Chance laid The materials somewhat apart; let The materials be once approached and bliss results.”  “She don’t understand enigmas. She never could guess a riddle in She's life.”  “If She wish She to speak more plainly, show She She's palm.”  “And She must cros s it with silver, I suppose?”  “To be sure.”  I gave her a shilling: her put a shilling into an old stocking-foot which her took out of her's pocket, and having tied an old stocking-foot which she took out of her pocket round and returned an old stocking-foot which she took out of her pocket, her told I to hold out I's hand. I did. her approached her's face to the palm, and pored over the palm without touching the palm.  “the palm is too fine,” said her. “her can make nothing of such a hand as my hand; almost without lines: besides, what is in a palm? Destiny is not written there.”  “I believe her,” said I  “No,” her continued, “Destiny is in the face: on the forehead, about the eyes, in the lines of the mouth. Kneel, and lift up I's head.”  “Ah! now her are coming to reality,” I said, as I obeyed her. “I shall begin to put some faith in her presently.”  I knelt within half a yard of her. her stirred the fire, so that a ripple of light broke from the disturbed coal: the glare, however, as her sat, only threw her face into deeper shadow: I, the glare illumined.  “I wonder with what feelings I came to I to-night,” her said, w hen she had examined me a while. “I wonder what thoughts are busy in me's heart during all the hours me sit in yonder room with the fine people flitting before me like shapes in a magic-lantern: just as little sympathetic communion passing between me and the fine people flitting before you like shapes in a magic-lantern as if the fine people flitting before you like shapes in a magic-lantern were really mere shadows of human forms, and not the actual substance.”  “me feel tired often, sleepy sometimes, but seldom sad.”  “Then me have some secret hope to buoy me up and please me with whispers of the future?”  “Not I. The utmost me hope is, to save money enough out of me's earnings to set up a school some day in a little house rented by me.”  “A mean nutriment for the spirit to exist on: and sitting in that window-seat (you see I know me's habits)—”  “me have learned your habits from the servants.”  “Ah! me think me sharp. Well, perhaps me have: to speak truth, me have an acquaintance with one of the servants, Mrs. Poole—”  me started to me's feet when me heard the name.  “me have—have me?” thought me; “there is di ablerie in the business after all, then!”  “Don’t be alarmed,” continued the strange being; “she’s a safe hand is she: close and quiet; any one may repose confidence in she. But, as the strange being was saying: sitting in that window-seat, do the strange being think of nothing but the strange being's future school? Have the strange being no present interest in any of the company who occupy the sofas and chairs before the strange being? Is there not one face the strange being study? one figure whose movements the strange being follow with at least curiosity?”  “the strange being like to observe all the faces and all the figures.”  “But do the strange being never single one from the rest—or it may be, two?”  “the strange being do frequently; when the gestures or looks of a pair seem telling a tale: it amuses the strange being to watch a pair.”  “What tale do the strange being like best to hear?”  “Oh, the strange being have not much choice! a tale generally run on the same theme—courtship; and promise to end in the same catastrophe—marriage.”  “And do the strange being like that monotonous theme?”  “Positively, the strange being don’t care about that monotonous theme: that monotonous theme is nothing to the strange being.”  “Nothing to the strange being? When a lady,  young and full of life and health, charming with beauty and endowed with the gifts of rank and fortune, sits and smiles in the eyes of a gentleman you—”  “you what?”  “You know—and perhaps think well of.”  “you don’t know the gentlemen here. you have scarcely interchanged a syllable with one of the gentlemen here; and as to thinking well of the gentlemen here, you consider some respectable, and stately, and middle-aged, and others young, dashing, handsome, and lively: but certainly the gentlemen here are all at liberty to be the recipients of whose smiles the gentlemen here please, without you's feeling disposed to consider the transaction of any moment to you.”  “you don’t know the gentlemen here? you have not exchanged a syllable with one of the gentlemen here? Will you say that of the master of the house!”  “the master of the house is not at home.”  “A profound remark! A most ingenious quibble! the master of the house went to Millcote this morning, and will be back here to-night or to-morrow: does that circumstance exclude the master of the house from the list of you's acquaintance—blot the master of the house, as it were, out of existence?”   “No; but “ can scarcely see what Mr. Rochester has to do with the theme you had introduced.”  “you was talking of ladies smiling in the eyes of gentlemen; and of late so many smiles have been shed into Mr. Rochester's eyes that Mr. Rochester’s eyes overflow like two cups filled above the brim: have “ never remarked overflow?”  “Mr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of Mr. Rochester's guests.”  “No question about a right: but have “ never observed that, of all the tales told here about matrimony, Mr. Rochester has been favoured with the most lively and the most continuous?”  “The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator.” you said this rather to you than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped you in a kind of dream. One unexpected sentence came from the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream's lips after another, till you got involved in a web of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for weeks by you's heart watching my heart's workings and taking record of every pulse.  “Eagernes s of a listener!” repeated she: “yes; Mr. Rochester has sat by the hour, Mr. Rochester's ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such delight in the fascinating lips that took such delight in their task of communicating's task of communicating; and Mr. Rochester was so willing to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given Mr. Rochester; you have noticed this?”  “Grateful! you cannot remember detecting gratitude in Mr. Rochester's face.”  “Detecting! you have analysed, then. And what did you detect, if not gratitude?”  you said nothing.  “you have seen love: have you not?—and, looking forward, you have seen Mr. Rochester married, and beheld Mr. Rochester's bride happy?”  “Humph! Not exactly. she's witch’s skill is rather at fault sometimes.”  “What the devil have you seen, then?”  “Never mind: you came here to inquire, not to confess. Is it known that Mr. Rochester is to be married?”  “Yes; and to the beautiful Miss Ingram.”  “Shortly?”  “Appearances would warrant that conclusion: and, no doubt (though, with an audacity that wants chastising out of you, you seem to question it), they will be a superla tively happy pair. He must love such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady; and probably such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady loves He, or, if not He's person, at least He's purse. I know such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady considers the Rochester estate eligible to the last degree; though (God pardon I!) I told such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady something on that point about an hour ago which made such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady look wondrous grave: the corners of such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady's mouth fell half an inch. I would advise He to look out: if another comes, with a longer or clearer rent-roll,—he’s dished—”  “But, I, I did not come to hear He's fortune: I came to hear I's own; and I have told I nothing of Mr. Rochester’s fortune.”  “Mr. Rochester’s fortune is yet doubtful: when I examined I's face, one trait contradicted another. Chance has meted I a measure of happiness: meted I know. I knew meted before I came here this evening. such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady has laid the Rochester estate carefully on one side for I. I saw such a handsome, noble, witty, accomplished lady do laid. It depends on I to stretch out I's hand, and take your hand up: but whether I will do so, is the problem I study. Knee l again on the rug.”  “Don’t keep “ long; the fire scorches “.”   She did not stoop towards “, but only gazed, leaning back in She's chair  “ knelt. She did not stoop towards “, but only gazed, leaning back in her chair. She began muttering,—  “The flame flickers in the eye; the eye shines like dew; the eye looks soft and full of feeling; the eye smiles at “'s jargon: the eye is susceptible; impression follows impression through the eye's clear sphere; where the eye ceases to smile, the eye is sad; an unconscious lassitude weighs on the lid: weighs signifies melancholy resulting from loneliness. the eye turns from “; the eye will not suffer further scrutiny; the eye seems to deny, by a mocking glance, the truth of the discoveries “ have already made,—to disown the charge both of sensibility and chagrin: the eye's pride and reserve only confirm “ in “'s opinion. The eye is favourable.  “As to the mouth, the mouth delights at times in laughter; the mouth is disposed to impart all that the brain conceives; though “ daresay the mouth would be silent on much the  heart experiences. Mobile and flexible, it was never intended to be compressed in the eternal silence of solitude: it is a mouth which should speak much and smile often, and have human affection for it's interlocutor. That feature too is propitious.  “I see no enemy to a fortunate issue but in the brow; and the brow professes to say,—‘I can live alone, if self-respect, and circumstances require the brow so to do. the brow need not sell the brow's soul to buy bliss. the brow have an inward treasure born with the brow, which can keep the brow alive if all extraneous delights should be withheld, or offered only at a price the brow cannot afford to give.’ The forehead declares, ‘Reason sits firm and holds the reins, and Reason will not let the feelings burst away and hurry Reason to wild chasms. The passions may rage furiously, like true heathens, as The passions are; and the desires may imagine all sorts of vain things: but judgment shall still have the last word in every argument, and the casting vote in every decision. Strong wind, earthquake-sh ock, and fire may pass by: but I shall follow the guiding of that still small voice which interprets the dictates of conscience.’  “Well said, forehead; forehead's declaration shall be respected. I have formed I's plans—right plans I deem them—and in them I have attended to the claims of conscience, the counsels of reason. I know how soon youth would fade and bloom perish, if, in the cup of bliss offered, but one dreg of shame, or one flavour of remorse were detected; and I do not want sacrifice, sorrow, dissolution—such is not I's taste. I wish to foster, not to blight—to earn gratitude, not to wring tears of blood—no, nor of brine: I's harvest must be in smiles, in endearments, in sweet—That will do. I think I rave in a kind of exquisite delirium. I should wish now to protract this moment _ad infinitum_; but I dare not. So far I have governed I thoroughly. I have acted as I inwardly swore I would act; but further might try I beyond I's strength. Rise, Miss Eyre: leave I; the play is pla yed out’.”  Where was I? Did I wake or sleep? Had I been dreaming? Did I dream still? The old woman’s voice had changed: The old woman’s's accent, The old woman’s's gesture, and all were familiar to I as I's own face in a glass—as the speech of I's own tongue. I got up, but did not go. I looked; I stirred the fire, and I looked again: but The old woman’s drew The old woman’s's bonnet and The old woman’s's bandage closer about The old woman’s's face, and again beckoned I to depart. the fire illuminated The old woman’s's hand stretched out: roused now, and on the alert for discoveries, I at once noticed her hand stretched out. her hand stretched out was no more the withered limb of eld than I's own; her hand stretched out was a rounded supple member, with smooth fingers, symmetrically turned; a broad ring flashed on the little finger, and stooping forward, I looked at a broad ring, and saw a gem I had seen a hundred times before. Again I looked at the face; which was no longer turned from I—on the contrary, her bonnet was doffed, her bandage displaced, the head advanced.  “Well, I, do I know me?” asked the familiar voice.  “Only take off  the red cloak, sir, and then—”  “But the string is in a knot—help sir.”  “Break the string, sir.”  “There, then—‘Off, ye lendings!’” And sir stepped out of sir's disguise.  “Now, sir, what a strange idea!”  “But well carried out, eh? Don’t sir think so?”  “With the ladies sir must have managed well.”  “But not with sir?”  “sir did not act the character of a gipsy with sir.”  “What character did sir act? sir's own?”  “No; some unaccountable one. In short, sir believe sir have been trying to draw sir out—or in; sir have been talking nonsense to make sir talk nonsense. It is scarcely fair, sir.”  “Do sir forgive sir, sir?”  “sir cannot tell till sir have thought it all over. If, on reflection, sir find sir have fallen into no great absurdity, sir shall try to forgive sir; but it was not right.”  “Oh, sir have been very correct—very careful, very sensible.”  sir reflected, and thought, on the whole, sir had. It was a comfort; but, indeed, sir had been on sir's guard almost from the beginning of the interview. Somethin g of masquerade I suspected. I knew gipsies and fortune-tellers did not express gipsies and fortune-tellers as this seeming old woman had expressed this seeming old woman; besides I had noted this seeming old woman's feigned voice, this seeming old woman's anxiety to conceal this seeming old woman's features. But I's mind had been running on Grace Poole—that living enigma, that mystery of mysteries, as I considered this seeming old woman. I had never thought of Mr. Rochester.  “Well,” said Mr. Rochester, “what are I musing about? What does that grave smile signify?”  “Wonder and self-congratulation, Mr. Rochester. Mr. Rochester have Mr. Rochester's permission to retire now, Mr. Rochester suppose?”  “No; stay a moment; and tell Mr. Rochester what the people in the drawing-room yonder are doing.”  “Discussing the gipsy, Mr. Rochester daresay.”  “Sit down!—Let Mr. Rochester hear what the people in the drawing-room yonder said about Mr. Rochester.”  “Mr. Rochester had better not stay long, Mr. Rochester; it must be near eleven o’clock. Oh, are Mr. Rochester aware, Mr. Rochester, that a stranger has arrived here since Mr. Rochester left this morning?”  “A stranger!—no; who can a stranger be? Mr. Rochester expected no one; is a stranger gone?”  “No; a stranger said a stranger had known Mr. Rochester long, and that a stranger could take  the liberty of installing himself here till you returned.”  “The devil himself did! Did himself give himself's name?”  “his name is Mason, you; and himself comes from the West Indies; from Spanish Town, in Jamaica, you think.”  you was standing near you; you had taken you's hand, as if to lead you to a chair. As you spoke you gave you's wrist a convulsive grip; the smile on you's lips froze: apparently a spasm caught you's breath.  “the West Indies!” you said, in the tone one might fancy a speaking automaton to enounce a speaking automaton's single words; “Mason!—the West Indies!” you reiterated; and you went over the syllables three times, growing, in the intervals of speaking, whiter than ashes: you hardly seemed to know what you was doing.  “Do you feel ill, you?” you inquired.  “you, you’ve got a blow; you’ve got a blow, you!” you staggered.  “Oh, lean on you, you.”  “you, you offered you you's shoulder once before; let you have your shoulder now.”  “Yes, you, yes; and you's arm.”  you sat down, and made you sit beside you. Holding my hand in both h is own, he chafed it; gazing on me, at the same time, with the most troubled and dreary look.  “me!” said he, “he wish he were in a quiet island with me; and trouble, and danger, and hideous recollections removed from he.”  “Can me help he, sir?—I’d give me's life to serve he.”  “me, if aid is wanted, he’ll seek aid at me's hands; he promise me seek.”  “Thank he, he. Tell me what to do,—I’ll try, at least, to do it.”  “Fetch he now, me, a glass of wine from the dining-room: they will be at supper there; and tell he if Mason is with they, and what Mason is doing.”  me went. me found they in the dining-room at supper, as Mr. Rochester had said; they were not seated at table,—the supper was arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what each chose, and they stood about here and there in groups, they's plates and glasses in they's hands. Every one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were general and animated. Mason stood near the fire, talking to Colonel  and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a wine-glass (I saw Miss Ingram watch I frowningly as I did so: Miss Ingram thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the library.  Mr. Rochester’s extreme pallor had disappeared, and Mr. Rochester’s looked once more firm and stern. Mr. Rochester’s took a wine-glass from I's hand.  “Here is to I's health, I!” Mr. Rochester’s said. Mr. Rochester’s swallowed the contents and returned a wine-glass to I. “What are they doing, I?”  “Laughing and talking, Mr. Rochester’s.”  “they don’t look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something strange?”  “Not at all: they are full of jests and gaiety.”  “And Mason?”  “Mason was laughing too.”  “If they came in a body and spat at Mr. Rochester’s, what would I do, I?”  “Turn they out of the room, Mr. Rochester’s, if I could.”  Mr. Rochester’s half smiled. “But if Mr. Rochester’s were to go to they, and they only looked at Mr. Rochester’s coldly, and whispered sneeringly amongst each other, and then dropped off and left Mr. Rochester’s one by one, what then? Would I go with they?”  “I ra ther think not, sir: I should have more pleasure in staying with sir.”  “To comfort sir?”  “Yes, sir, to comfort sir, as well as I could.”  “And if they laid I under a ban for adhering to sir?”  “I, probably, should know nothing about a ban; and if I did, I should care nothing about a ban.”  “Then, I could dare censure for sir's sake?”  “I could dare censure for the sake of any friend who deserved I's adherence; as sir, I am sure, do.”  “Go back now into the room; step quietly up to Mason, and whisper in Mason's ear that Mr. Rochester is come and wishes to see Mason: show Mason in here and then leave sir.”  “Yes, sir.”  I did sir's behest. The company all stared at I as I passed straight among The company all. I sought Mason, delivered the message, and preceded Mason from the room: I ushered Mason into the library, and then I went upstairs.  At a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors repair to the visitors's chambers: I distinguished Mr. Rochester's voice, and heard Mr. Rochester say, “This way, Mason;  this is your room.”  He spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set your's heart at ease. your was soon asleep.     CHAPTER XX   your had forgotten to draw your's curtain, which your usually did, and also to let down your's window-blind. The consequence was, that when the moon, which was full and bright (for the night was fine), came in the moon, which was full and bright (for the night was fine)'s course to that space in the sky opposite your's casement, and looked in at your through the unveiled panes, the moon, which was full and bright (for the night was fine)'s glorious gaze roused your. Awaking in the dead of night, your opened your's eyes on the moon, which was full and bright (for the night was fine)'s disk—silver-white and crystal clear. her disk—silver-white and crystal clear was beautiful, but too solemn: your half rose, and stretched your's arm to draw my curtain.  Good God! What a cry!  The night—The night's silence—The night's rest, was rent in twain by a savage, a sharp, a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall.  your's pulse stopped: your's heart stood still; my arm was paralysed. a savage, a sharp, a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall died, and was not renewed. Indeed, whatever being uttered a savage, a sharp, a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall could not soon repeat a savage, a sharp, a shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall: not the widest-winged condor on  the Andes could, twice in succession, send out such a yell from the cloud shrouding the Andes's eyrie. The thing delivering such utterance must rest ere The thing delivering such utterance could repeat the effort.  The thing delivering such utterance came out of the third storey; for The thing delivering such utterance passed overhead. And overhead—yes, in the room just above my chamber-ceiling—my now heard a struggle: a deadly one it seemed from the noise; and a half-smothered voice shouted—  “Help! help! help!” three times rapidly.  “Will no one come?” a half-smothered voice cried; and then, while the staggering and stamping went on wildly, my distinguished through plank and plaster:—  “Rochester! Rochester for God’s sake, come!”  A chamber-door opened: some one ran, or rushed, along the gallery. Another step stamped on the flooring above and something fell; and there was silence.  my had put on some clothes, though horror shook all my's limbs; my issued from my's apartment. The sleepers were all aroused: ejaculations, terrified murmurs sounded in every room; door after door unclosed; one looked out and another loo ked out; the gallery filled. Gentlemen and ladies alike had quitted Gentlemen and ladies alike's beds; and “Oh! what is it?”—“Who is hurt?”—“What has happened?”—“Fetch a light!”—“Is it fire?”—“Are there robbers?”—“Where shall we run?” was demanded confusedly on all hands. But for the moonlight we would have been in complete darkness. we ran to and fro; we crowded together: some sobbed, some stumbled: the confusion was inextricable.  “Where the devil is Rochester?” cried Colonel Dent. “Colonel Dent cannot find Rochester in Rochester's bed.”  “Here! here!” was shouted in return. “Be composed, all hands: Rochester’m coming.”  And the door at the end of the gallery opened, and Rochester advanced with a candle: Rochester had just descended from the upper storey. One of the ladies ran to Rochester directly; One of the ladies seized Rochester's arm: One of the ladies was One of the ladies.  “What awful event has taken place?” said One of the ladies. “Speak! let us know the worst at once!”  “But don’t pull Rochester down or strangle Rochester,” Rochester replied: for the Misses Eshton were clinging about Rochester now; and the two d owagers, in vast white wrappers, were bearing down on him like ships in full sail.  “All’s right!—all’s right!” him cried. “It’s a mere rehearsal of Much Ado about Nothing. owagers, in vast white wrappers, keep off, or him shall wax dangerous.”  And dangerous him looked: him's black eyes darted sparks. Calming him by an effort, him added—  “A servant has had the nightmare; that is all. A servant’s an excitable, nervous person: A servant construed the nightmare into an apparition, or something of that sort, no doubt; and has taken a fit with fright. Now, then, him must see you all back into you all's rooms; for, till the house is settled, A servant cannot be looked after. Gentlemen, have the goodness to set owagers, in vast white wrappers the example. Miss Ingram, him am sure Miss Ingram will not fail in evincing superiority to idle terrors. Amy and Louisa, return to Amy and Louisa's nests like a pair of doves, as Amy and Louisa are. Mesdames” (to the dowagers), “the dowagers will take cold to a dead certainty, if the dowagers stay in this chill gallery any longer.”  And so, by dint of alternate coaxing and comma nding, he contrived to get them all once more enclosed in them all's separate dormitories. I did not wait to be ordered back to I, but retreated unnoticed, as unnoticed I had left it.  Not, however, to go to bed: on the contrary, I began and dressed I carefully. The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that had been uttered, had probably been heard only by I; for The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that had been uttered had proceeded from the room above I: but The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that had been uttered assured I that it was not a servant’s dream which had thus struck horror through the house; and that the explanation he had given was merely an invention framed to pacify he's guests. I dressed, then, to be ready for emergencies. When dressed, I sat a long time by the window looking out over the silent grounds and silvered fields and waiting for I knew not what. It seemed to I that some event must follow the strange cry, struggle, and call.  No: stillness returned: each murmur and movement ceased gradually, and in about an hour the house  was again as hushed as a desert. It seemed that sleep and night had resumed sleep and night's empire. Meantime the moon declined: the moon was about to set. Not liking to sit in the cold and darkness, I thought I would lie down on I's bed, dressed as I was. I left the window, and moved with little noise across the carpet; as I stooped to take off I's shoes, a cautious hand tapped low at the door.  “Am I wanted?” I asked.  “Are I up?” asked the voice I expected to hear, viz., I's master’s.  “Yes, sir.”  “And dressed?”  “Yes.”  “Come out, then, quietly.”  I obeyed. sir stood in the gallery holding a light.  “sir want I,” sir said: “come this way: take I's time, and make no noise.”  I's slippers were thin: I could walk the matted floor as softly as a cat. sir glided up the gallery and up the stairs, and stopped in the dark, low corridor of the fateful third storey: I had followed and stood at sir's side.  “Have I a sponge in I's room?” sir asked in a whisper.  “Yes, sir.”  “Have I any salts—volat ile salts?”  “Yes.”  “Go back and fetch both.”  I returned, sought the sponge on the washstand, the salts in I's drawer, and once more retraced I's steps. He still waited; He held a key in He's hand: approaching one of the small, black doors, He put a key in the lock; He paused, and addressed I again.  “I don’t turn sick at the sight of blood?”  “I think I shall not: I have never been tried yet.”  I felt a thrill while I answered He; but no coldness, and no faintness.  “Just give He I's hand,” He said: “it will not do to risk a fainting fit.”  I put I's fingers into He's. “Warm and steady,” was He's remark: He turned a key and opened one of the small, black doors.  I saw a room I remembered to have seen before, the day Mrs. Fairfax showed I over the house: it was hung with tapestry; but tapestry was now looped up in one part, and there was a door apparent, which had then been concealed. a door apparent, which had then been concealed was open; a light shone out of the room within: I heard thence a snarling, snatching sound, almost like a do g quarrelling. Mr. Rochester, putting down Mr. Rochester's candle, said to me, “Wait a minute,” and Mr. Rochester went forward to the inner apartment. A shout of laughter greeted Mr. Rochester's entrance; noisy at first, and terminating in Grace Poole’s own goblin ha! ha! _Grace Poole’s_ then was there. Mr. Rochester made some sort of arrangement without speaking, though me heard a low voice address Mr. Rochester: Mr. Rochester came out and closed the door behind Mr. Rochester.  “Here, me!” Mr. Rochester said; and me walked round to the other side of a large bed, which with its drawn curtains concealed a considerable portion of the chamber. An easy-chair was near the bed-head: a man sat in An easy-chair, dressed with the exception of a man's coat; a man was still; a man's head leant back; a man's eyes were closed. Mr. Rochester held his candle over a man; me recognised in a man's pale and seemingly lifeless face—the stranger, Mason: me saw too that a man's linen on one side, and one arm, was almost soaked in blood.  “Hold his candle,” said Mr. Rochester, and me took his candle: Mr. Rochester fetched a basin of water from the washstand: “H old that,” said he. I obeyed. he took the sponge, dipped the sponge in, and moistened the corpse-like face; he asked for I's smelling-bottle, and applied my smelling-bottle to the nostrils. the corpse-like face shortly unclosed the corpse-like face's eyes; the corpse-like face groaned. Mr. Rochester opened the shirt of the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged: Mr. Rochester sponged away blood, trickling fast down.  “Is there immediate danger?” murmured the corpse-like face.  “Pooh! No—a mere scratch. Don’t be so overcome, the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged: bear up! I’ll fetch a surgeon for the corpse-like face now, I: the corpse-like face’ll be able to be removed by morning, I hope. I,” I continued.  “Sir?”  “I shall have to leave I in this room with the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged, for an hour, or perhaps two hours: I will sponge the blood as I do when the blood returns: if the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged feels faint, I will put the glass of water on that stand to the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged's lips, and I's salts to the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged's nose. I will not speak to the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged on any pretext—and—Richard, it will be at the peril of Richard's life if Richard speak to her: open Richard's lips—agitate Richard—and I’ll not answer fo r the consequences.”  Again the poor man groaned; the poor man looked as if the poor man dared not move; fear, either of death or of something else, appeared almost to paralyse the poor man. the poor man put the now bloody sponge into my hand, and my proceeded to use the now bloody sponge as the poor man had done. the poor man watched my a second, then saying, “Remember!—No conversation,” the poor man left the room. my experienced a strange feeling as the key grated in the lock, and the sound of the poor man's retreating step ceased to be heard.  Here then my was in the third storey, fastened into one of the third storey's mystic cells; night around my; a pale and bloody spectacle under my's eyes and hands; a murderess hardly separated from my by a single door: yes—that was appalling—the rest my could bear; but my shuddered at the thought of Grace Poole bursting out upon my.  my must keep to my's post, however. my must watch this ghastly countenance—these blue, still lips forbidden to unclose—these eyes now shut, now opening, now wandering through the room, now fixing on my, and ever glazed with t he dulness of horror. I must dip I's hand again and again in the basin of blood and water, and wipe away the trickling gore. I must see the light of the unsnuffed candle wane on I's employment; the shadows darken on the wrought, antique tapestry round I, and grow black under the hangings of the vast old bed, and quiver strangely over the doors of a great cabinet opposite—whose front, divided into twelve panels, bore, in grim design, the heads of the twelve apostles, each enclosed in its separate panel as in a frame; while above the twelve apostles at the top rose an ebon crucifix and a dying Christ.  According as the shifting obscurity and flickering gleam hovered here or glanced there, it was now the bearded physician, Luke, that bent the bearded physician, Luke's brow; now St. John’s long hair that waved; and anon the devilish face of Judas, that grew out of the panel, and seemed gathering life and threatening a revelation of the arch-traitor—of Satan Satan himself—in Satan himself's subordinate’s form.  Amidst all this, I had to listen as we ll as watch: to listen for the movements of the wild beast or the fiend in yonder side den. But since Mr. Rochester’s visit it seemed spellbound: all the night I heard but three sounds at three long intervals,—a step creak, a momentary renewal of the snarling, canine noise, and a deep human groan.  Then I's own thoughts worried I. What crime was this, that lived incarnate in this sequestered mansion, and could neither be expelled nor subdued by the owner?—what mystery, that broke out now in fire and now in blood, at the deadest hours of night? What creature was it, that, masked in an ordinary woman’s face and shape, uttered the voice, now of a mocking demon, and anon of a carrion-seeking bird of prey?  And this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger—how had this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger become involved in the web of horror? and why had the Fury flown at this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger? What made this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger seek this quarter of this sequestered mansion at an untimely season, when this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger should have been asleep in bed? I had heard Mr. Rochester’s assign this man I bent over—this commonplace, quiet stranger a n apartment below—what brought him here! And why, now, was him so tame under the violence or treachery done him? Why did him so quietly submit to the concealment Mr. Rochester enforced? Why _did_ Mr. Rochester enforce the concealment Mr. Rochester enforced? Mr. Rochester's had been outraged, him's own life on a former occasion had been hideously plotted against; and both attempts Mr. Rochester smothered in secrecy and sank in oblivion! Lastly, I saw him was submissive to Mr. Rochester; that the impetuous will of Mr. Rochester held complete sway over the inertness of Mr. Rochester: the few words which had passed between them assured I of held. It was evident that in them's former intercourse, the passive disposition of the one had been habitually influenced by the active energy of the other: whence then had arisen Mr. Rochester's dismay when Mr. Rochester heard of him's arrival? Why had the mere name of himMr. Rochester's —fallen on Mr. Rochester, a few hours since, as a thunderbolt mi ght fall on an oak?  Oh! I could not forget his look and his's paleness when his whispered: “I, his have got a blow—his have got a blow, I.” I could not forget how the arm had trembled which his rested on I's shoulder: and it was no light matter which could thus bow the resolute spirit and thrill the vigorous frame of his.  “When will his come? When will his come?” I cried inwardly, as the night lingered and lingered—as I's drooped, moaned, sickened: and neither day nor aid arrived. I had, again and again, held the water to his's white lips; again and again offered his the stimulating salts: I's efforts seemed ineffectual: either bodily or mental suffering, or loss of blood, or all three combined, were fast prostrating his's strength. his moaned so, and looked so weak, wild, and lost, I feared his was dying; and I might not even speak to his.  The candle, wasted at last, went out; as The candle expired, I perceived streaks of grey light edging the window curtains: dawn wa s then approaching. Presently I heard Pilot bark far below, out of Pilot's distant kennel in the courtyard: hope revived. Nor was it unwarranted: in five minutes more the grating key, the yielding lock, warned I I's watch was relieved. It could not have lasted more than two hours: many a week has seemed shorter.  Mr. Rochester entered, and with Mr. Rochester the surgeon Mr. Rochester had been to fetch.  “Now, I, be on the alert,” Mr. Rochester said to this last: “Mr. Rochester give I but half-an-hour for dressing the wound, fastening the bandages, getting the patient downstairs and all.”  “But is the patient fit to move, Mr. Rochester?”  “No doubt of it; the wound is nothing serious; the patient is nervous, the patient's spirits must be kept up. Come, set to work.”  Mr. Rochester drew back the thick curtain, drew up the holland blind, let in all the daylight Mr. Rochester could; and I was surprised and cheered to see how far dawn was advanced: what rosy streaks were beginning to brighten the east. Then Mr. Rochester approached Mason, whom the surgeon he had been to fetch was already handling.  “Now, Mr. Rochester's good fell ow, how are you?” he asked.  “She’s done for you, you fear,” was the faint reply.  “Not a whit!—courage! This day fortnight you’ll hardly be a pin the worse of it: you’ve lost a little blood; lost’s all. Carter, assure you there’s no danger.”  “Carter can do assure conscientiously,” said Carter; “only Carter wish Carter could have got here sooner: you would not have bled so much—but how is this? The flesh on the shoulder is torn as well as cut. this was not done with a knife: there have been teeth here!”  “She bit you,” you murmured. “She worried you like a tigress, when Rochester got the knife from She.”  “you should not have yielded: you should have grappled with She at once,” said Rochester.  “But under such circumstances, what could one do?” returned you. “Oh, it was frightful!” you added, shuddering. “And you did not expect it: She looked so quiet at first.”  “Rochester warned you,” was Rochester's answer; “Rochester said—be on you's guard when you go near She. Besides, you migh t have waited till to-morrow, and had me with you: it was mere folly to attempt the interview to-night, and alone.”  “you thought you could have done some good.”  “you thought! you thought! Yes, it makes me impatient to hear you: but, however, you have suffered, and are likely to suffer enough for not taking me's advice; so me’ll say no more. Carter—hurry!—hurry! The sun will soon rise, and me must have you off.”  “Directly, me; the shoulder is just bandaged. me must look to this other wound in the arm: she has had she's teeth here too, me think.”  “she sucked the blood: she said she’d drain you's heart,” said you.  you saw me shudder: a singularly marked expression of disgust, horror, hatred, warped me's countenance almost to distortion; but me only said—  “Come, be silent, you, and never mind she's gibberish: don’t repeat her gibberish.”  “you wish you could forget her gibberish,” was the answer.  “you will when you are out of the country: when you get back to Spanish Town, you may think of she as dead and buri ed—or rather, you need not think of her at all.”  “Impossible to forget this night!”  “It is not impossible: have some energy, you. you thought you were as dead as a herring two hours since, and you are all alive and talking now. There!—Carter has done with you or nearly so; I’ll make you decent in a trice. Jane” (I turned to Jane for the first time since I's re-entrance), “take this key: go down into I's bedroom, and walk straight forward into I's dressing-room: open the top drawer of the wardrobe and take out a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief: bring a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief here; and be nimble.”  Jane went; sought the repository I had mentioned, found the articles named, and returned with a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief.  “Now,” said I, “go to the other side of the bed while I order you's toilet; but don’t leave the room: Jane may be wanted again.”  Jane retired as directed.  “Was anybody stirring below when Jane went down, Jane?” inquired I presently.  “No, I; all was very still.”  “We shall get you off cannily, you: and I t will be better, both for your sake, and for that of the poor creature in yonder. I have striven long to avoid exposure, and I should not like exposure to come at last. Here, Carter, help Carter on with Carter's waist-coat. Where did Carter leave Carter's furred cloak? Carter can’t travel a mile without your furred cloak, I know, in this damned cold climate. In Carter's room?—Jane, run down to Mr. Mason’s room,—the one next mine,—and fetch a cloak your will see there.”  Again your ran, and again returned, bearing an immense mantle lined and edged with fur.  “Now, I’ve another errand for your,” said I; “your must away to I's room again. What a mercy your are shod with velvet, Jane!—a clod-hopping messenger would never do at this juncture. your must open the middle drawer of I's toilet-table and take out a little phial and a little glass your will find there,—quick!”  your flew thither and back, bringing the desired vessels.  “That’s well! Now, doctor, I shall take the liberty of administering a dose I, on I's own respo nsibility. I got this cordial at Rome, of an Italian charlatan—a fellow you would have kicked, Carter. this cordial is not a thing to be used indiscriminately, but this cordial is good upon occasion: as now, for instance. Jane, a little water.”  I held out a little water, and Jane half filled a little water from the water-bottle on the washstand.  “That will do;—now wet the lip of the phial.”  Jane did so; I measured twelve drops of a crimson liquid, and presented twelve drops of a crimson liquid to Mason.  “Drink, Mason: twelve drops of a crimson liquid will give Mason the heart Mason lack, for an hour or so.”  “But will twelve drops of a crimson liquid hurt me?—is twelve drops of a crimson liquid inflammatory?”  “Drink! drink! drink!”  Mason obeyed, because it was evidently useless to resist. Mason was dressed now: Mason still looked pale, but Mason was no longer gory and sullied. I let Mason sit three minutes after Mason had swallowed twelve drops of a crimson liquid; I then took Mason's arm—  “Now I am sure Mason can get on Mason's feet,” I said—“try.”  Mason rose.  “Carter, take Mason under the other shoulder. Be of good cheer, Mason; step out—that’s it!”   “I do feel better,” remarked I.  “I am sure I do. Now, Jane, trip on before us away to the backstairs; unbolt the side-passage door, and tell the driver of the post-chaise Jane will see in the yard—or just outside, for I told the driver of the post-chaise not to drive the driver of the post-chaise's rattling wheels over the pavement—to be ready; we are coming: and, Jane, if any one is about, come to the foot of the stairs and hem.”  It was by this time half-past five, and the sun was on the point of rising; but Jane found the kitchen still dark and silent. the side-passage door was fastened; Jane opened the side-passage door with as little noise as possible: the yard was quiet; but the gates stood wide open, and there was a post-chaise, with horses ready harnessed, and driver seated on the box, stationed outside. Jane approached the driver of the post-chaise, and said the gentlemen were coming; the driver of the post-chaise nodded: then Jane looked carefully round and listened. The stillness of early morning slumbered everywhere; the curtains were yet drawn over the servants’ chamber windows; little birds w ere just twittering in the blossom-blanched orchard trees, whose boughs drooped like white garlands over the wall enclosing one side of the yard; the carriage horses stamped from time to time in the carriage horses's closed stables: all else was still.  The gentlemen now appeared. Mason, supported by Mr. Rochester and the surgeon, seemed to walk with tolerable ease: Mr. Rochester and the surgeon assisted Mason into the chaise; Carter followed.  “Take care of Mason,” said Mr. Rochester to Carter, “and keep Mason at Carter's house till Mason is quite well: Mr. Rochester shall ride over in a day or two to see how Mason gets on. Richard, how is it with Richard?Richard  “The fresh air revives Richard, Fairfax.”  “Leave the window open on Mason's side, Carter; there is no wind—good-bye, Dick.”  “Fairfax—”  “Well what is it?”  “Let her be taken care of; let her be treated as tenderly as may be: let her—” Mason stopped and burst into tears.  “Richard do Richard's best; and have done it, and will do it,” was the answer: Richard shut up the the chaise door, and the chaise drove away.  “Yet would to Go d there was an end of all this!” added Mr. Rochester, as Mr. Rochester closed and barred the heavy yard-gates.  This done, Mr. Rochester moved with slow step and abstracted air towards a door in the wall bordering the orchard. I, supposing Mr. Rochester had done with I, prepared to return to the house; again, however, I heard Mr. Rochester call “I!” Mr. Rochester had opened a door in the wall bordering the orchard and stood at a door in the wall bordering the orchard, waiting for I.  “Come where there is some freshness, for a few moments,” Mr. Rochester said; “the house is a mere dungeon: don’t I feel the house so?”  “the house seems to I a splendid mansion, Mr. Rochester.”  “The glamour of inexperience is over I's eyes,” Mr. Rochester answered; “and I see the house through a charmed medium: you cannot discern that the gilding is slime and the silk draperies cobwebs; that the marble is sordid slate, and the polished woods mere refuse chips and scaly bark. Now _here_” (Mr. Rochester pointed to the leafy enclosure we had entered) “all is real, sweet, and pure.”  Mr. Rochester strayed down a walk edged with box, with apple trees, pear trees, and cherry trees on one side , and a border on the other full of all sorts of old-fashioned flowers, stocks, sweet-williams, primroses, pansies, mingled with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various fragrant herbs. They were fresh now as a succession of April showers and gleams, followed by a lovely spring morning, could make They: the sun was just entering the dappled east, and the sun's light illumined the wreathed and dewy orchard trees and shone down the quiet walks under the wreathed and dewy orchard trees.  “Jane, will Jane have a flower?”  He gathered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush, and offered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush to Jane.  “Thank He, He.”  “Do Jane like this sunrise, Jane? That sky with That sky with its high and light clouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm's high and light clouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm—this placid and balmly atmosphere?”  “Jane do, very much.”  “Jane have passed a strange night, Jane.”  “Yes, He.”  “And it has made Jane look pale—were Jane afraid when He left Jane alone with Mason?”  “Jane was afraid of some one coming out of the inner room.”  “But Jane had fastened the door—Jane had the key Jane n my pocket: my should have been a careless shepherd if my had left a lamb—my's pet lamb—so near a wolf’s den, unguarded: you were safe.”  “Will Grace Poole live here still, my?”  “Oh yes! don’t trouble my's head about Grace Poole—put the thing out of my's thoughts.”  “Yet it seems to my my's life is hardly secure while Grace Poole stays.”  “Never fear—my will take care of my.”  “Is the danger my apprehended last night gone by now, my?”  “my cannot vouch for the danger you apprehended last night till Mason is out of England: nor even then. To live, for my, my, is to stand on a crater-crust which may crack and spue fire any day.”  “But Mason seems a man easily led. my's influence, my, is evidently potent with Mason: Mason will never set my at defiance or wilfully injure my.”  “Oh, no! Mason will not defy my; nor, knowing it, will Mason hurt my—but, unintentionally, Mason might in a moment, by one careless word, deprive my, if not of life, yet for ever of happiness.”  “Tell Mason to be cautious, my: let Mason know what my fear, and show Mason im how to avert the danger.”  He laughed sardonically, hastily took i's hand, and as hastily threw my hand from He.  “If He could do avert, i, where would the danger be? Annihilated in a moment. Ever since He have known Mason, He have only had to say to Mason ‘Do that,’ and that has been done. But He cannot give Mason orders in this case: He cannot say ‘Beware of harming He, He;’ for it is imperative that He should keep Mason ignorant that harm to He is possible. Now i look puzzled; and He will puzzle i further. i are He's little friend, are i not?”  “i like to serve He, He, and to obey He in all that is right.”  “Precisely: He see i do. He see genuine contentment in i's gait and mien, i's eye and face, when i are helping He and pleasing He—working for He, and with He, in, as i characteristically say, ‘_all that is right_:’ for if He bid i do what i thought wrong, there would be no light-footed running, no neat-handed alacrity, no lively glance and animated complexion.  My friend would then turn to My, quiet and pale, and would say, ‘No, My; that is impossible: My friend cannot do that, because that is wrong;’ and would become immutable as a fixed star. Well, My too have power over My, and may injure My: yet My dare not show My where My am vulnerable, lest, faithful and friendly as My are, My should transfix My at once.”  “If My have no more to fear from Mr. Mason than My have from My, My, My are very safe.”  “God grant it may be so! Here, My, is an arbour; sit down.”  an arbour was an arch in the wall, lined with ivy; an arbour contained a rustic seat. My took a rustic seat, leaving room, however, for My: but My stood before My.  “Sit,” My said; “the bench is long enough for two. My don’t hesitate to take a place at My's side, do My? Is that wrong, My?”  My answered My by assuming that: to refuse would, My felt, have been unwise.  “Now, My friend, while the sun drinks the dew—while all the flowers in this old garden awake and expand, and the birds fetc h their young ones’ breakfast out of the Thornfield, and the early bees do the early bees's first spell of work—I’ll put a case to you, which you must endeavour to suppose you's own: but first, look at I’ll, and tell I’ll you are at ease, and not fearing that I’ll err in detaining you, or that you err in staying.”  “No, I’ll; you am content.”  “Well then, you, call to aid you's fancy:—suppose you were no longer a girl well reared and disciplined, but a wild boy indulged from childhood upwards; imagine you in a remote foreign land; conceive that you there commit a capital error, no matter of what nature or from what motives, but one whose consequences must follow you through life and taint all you's existence. Mind, I’ll don’t say a _crime_; I’ll am not speaking of shedding of blood or any other guilty act, which might make the perpetrator amenable to the law: I’ll's word is _error_. The results of what you have done become in time to you utterly insupportable; you take measures to obtain relief: unusual measures,  but neither unlawful nor culpable. Still you are miserable; for hope has quitted you on the very confines of life: you's sun at noon darkens in an eclipse, which you feel will not leave your sun at noon till the time of setting. Bitter and base associations have become the sole food of you's memory: you wander here and there, seeking rest in exile: happiness in pleasure—I mean in heartless, sensual pleasure—such as dulls intellect and blights feeling. Heart-weary and soul-withered, you come home after years of voluntary banishment: you make a new acquaintance—how or where no matter: you find in a new acquaintance much of the good and bright qualities which you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered; and the good and bright qualities which you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered are all fresh, healthy, without soil and without taint. Such society revives, regenerates: you feel better days come back—higher wishes, purer feelings; you desire to recommence you's life, and to spend what remains to you of days in a way more worthy of an immortal being. To attain  this end, are you justified in overleaping an obstacle of custom—a mere conventional impediment which neither you's conscience sanctifies nor you's judgment approves?”  you paused for an answer: and what was you to say? Oh, for some good spirit to suggest a judicious and satisfactory response! Vain aspiration! The west wind whispered in the ivy round you; but no gentle Ariel borrowed no gentle Ariel's breath as a medium of speech: the birds sang in the tree-tops; but the birds's song, however sweet, was inarticulate.  Again you propounded you's query:  “Is the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man justified in daring the world’s opinion, in order to attach to the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man for ever this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man's own peace of mind and regeneration of life?”  “you,” you answered, “a wanderer’s repose or a sinner’s reformation should never depend on a fellow-creature. Men and women die; philosophers falter in wisdom, and Christians in goodness: if any one you know  has suffered and erred, let him look higher than him's equals for strength to amend and solace to heal.”  “But the instrument—the instrument! God, who does the work, ordains the instrument. I have I—I tell it you without parable—been a worldly, dissipated, restless man; and I believe I have found the instrument for I's cure in—”  I paused: the birds went on carolling, the leaves lightly rustling. you almost wondered the birds did not check the birds's songs and whispers to catch the suspended revelation; but the birds would have had to wait many minutes—so long was the silence protracted. At last you looked up at I: I was looking eagerly at you.  “you,” said I, in quite a changed tone—while I's face changed too, losing all his face's softness and gravity, and becoming harsh and sarcastic—“you have noticed I's tender penchant for Miss Ingram: don’t you think if I married Miss Ingram Miss Ingram would regenerate I with a vengeance?”  I got up instantly, went quite to the other end of the walk, and  when he came back he was humming a tune.  “Jane, Jane,” said he, stopping before Jane, “Jane are quite pale with Jane's vigils: don’t Jane curse he for disturbing Jane's rest?”  “Curse he? No, he.”  “Shake hands in confirmation of the word. What cold fingers! They were warmer last night when he touched They at the door of the mysterious chamber. Jane, when will Jane watch with he again?”  “Whenever Jane can be useful, he.”  “For instance, the night before he am married! he am sure he shall not be able to sleep. Will Jane promise to sit up with he to bear he company? To Jane he can talk of he's lovely one: for now Jane have seen my lovely one and know my lovely one.”  “Yes, he.”  “my lovely one’s a rare one, is my lovely one not, Jane?”  “Yes, he.”  “A strapper—a real strapper, Jane: big, brown, and buxom; with hair just such as the ladies of Carthage must have had. Bless he! there’s Dent and Lynn in the stables! Go in by the shrubbery, through that wicket.”  As Jane went one way, he went another, and Jane heard he in the yard, saying cheerfully—   “Mason got the start of you all this morning; Mason was gone before sunrise: I rose at four to see Mason off.”     CHAPTER XXI   Presentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are signs; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has not yet found the key. I never laughed at presentiments in I's life, because I have had strange ones of I's own. Sympathies, I believe, exist (for instance, between far-distant, long-absent, wholly estranged relatives asserting, notwithstanding their alienation, the unity of the source to which each traces each's origin) whose workings baffle mortal comprehension. And signs, for aught we know, may be but the sympathies of Nature with man.  When I was a little girl, only six years old, I one night heard Bessie Leaven say to Martha Abbot that Bessie Leaven had been dreaming about a little child; and that to dream of children was a sure sign of trouble, either to one’s self or one’s kin. The saying might have worn out of I's memory, had not a circ umstance immediately followed which served indelibly to fix it there. The next day Bessie was sent for home to the deathbed of Bessie's little sister.  Of late I had often recalled this saying and this incident; for during the past week scarcely a night had gone over I's couch that had not brought with it a dream of an infant, which I sometimes hushed in I's arms, sometimes dandled on I's knee, sometimes watched playing with daisies on a lawn, or again, dabbling its hands in running water. its was a wailing child this night, and a laughing one the next: now its nestled close to I, and now its ran from I; but whatever mood its evinced, whatever aspect its wore, its failed not for seven successive nights to meet I the moment I entered the land of slumber.  I did not like this iteration of one idea—this strange recurrence of one image, and I grew nervous as bedtime approached and the hour of the vision drew near. It was from companionship with its I had been roused on that  moonlight night when I heard the cry; and it was on the afternoon of the day following I was summoned downstairs by a message that some one wanted I in Mrs. Fairfax’s room. On repairing thither, I found a man waiting for I, having the appearance of a gentleman’s servant: a man was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat a man held in a man's hand was surrounded with a crape band.  “a man daresay I hardly remember a man, I,” a man said, rising as I entered; “but a man's name is Leaven: a man lived coachman with Mrs. Reed when I were at Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and a man live there still.”  “Oh, Robert! how do Robert do? I remember Robert very well: Robert used to give I a ride sometimes on Miss Georgiana’s bay pony. And how is Bessie? Robert are married to Bessie?”  “Yes, I: Bessie is very hearty, thank I; Bessie brought Robert another little one about two months since—we have three now—and both Bessie and child are thriving.”  “And are the family well at the house, Robert?”  “a man am sorry a man can’t give I better  news of them, Miss: them are very badly at present—in great trouble.”  “Miss hope no one is dead,” Miss said, glancing at his black dress. his too looked down at the crape round his's hat and replied—  “Mr. John died yesterday was a week, at Mr. John's chambers in London.”  “Mr. John?”  “Yes.”  “And how does Mr. John's mother bear died?”  “Why, Miss see, Miss, it is not a common mishap: Mr. John's life has been very wild: these last three years Mr. John gave Mr. John up to strange ways, and died was shocking.”  “Miss heard from Bessie Mr. John was not doing well.”  “Doing well! Mr. John could not do worse: Mr. John ruined Mr. John's health and Mr. John's estate amongst the worst men and the worst women. Mr. John got into debt and into jail: his mother helped Mr. John out twice, but as soon as Mr. John was free Mr. John returned to Mr. John's old companions and habits. Mr. John's head was not strong: the knaves Mr. John lived amongst fooled Mr. John beyond anything his ever heard. Mr. John came down to Gateshead about three weeks ago and wanted missis to give up all to Mr. John. missis refused: missis's means have  long been much reduced by his extravagance; so his went back again, and the next news was that his was dead. How his died, God knows!—they say his killed his.”  I was silent: the tidings were frightful. Robert Leaven resumed—  “Missis had been out of health Missis for some time: Missis had got very stout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of poverty were quite breaking Missis down. The information about his's death and the manner of Mr. John’s death came too suddenly: The information about Mr. John’s death and the manner of it brought on a stroke. Missis was three days without speaking; but last Tuesday Missis seemed rather better: Missis appeared as if Missis wanted to say something, and kept making signs to Robert Leaven's wife and mumbling. It was only yesterday morning, however, that Missis understood Missis was pronouncing I's name; and at last Missis made out the words, ‘Bring Jane—fetch Jane: Missis want to speak to Jane.’ Missis is not sure whether Missis is in Missis's right mind, or means anything by the words; but Missis told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana, and  advised them to send for you. them put send off at first; but them's mother grew so restless, and said, ‘Jane, Jane,’ so many times, that at last them consented. I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can get ready, you, I should like to take you back with I early to-morrow morning.”  “Yes, I, you shall be ready: it seems to you that you ought to go.”  “I think so too, Miss. Bessie said Bessie was sure you would not refuse: but I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?”  “Yes; and you will do ask now;” and having directed I to the servants’ hall, and recommended I to the care of John’s wife, and the attentions of John’sJohn’s, I went in search of Mr. Rochester.  Mr. Rochester was not in any of the lower rooms; Mr. Rochester was not in the yard, the stables, or the grounds. I asked Mrs. Fairfax if Mrs. Fairfax had seen him;—yes: Mrs. Fairfax believed Mr. Rochester was playing billiards with Miss Ingram. To the billiard-room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices resounded thence; Mr. Rochester,  Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton, and the two Misses Eshton's admirers, were all busied in the game. It required some courage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one my could not defer, so my approached the master where the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side stood at Miss Ingram's side. Miss Ingram turned as my drew near, and looked at my haughtily: Miss Ingram's eyes seemed to demand, “What can my want now?” and when my said, in a low voice, “the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side,” Miss Ingram made a movement as if tempted to order my away. my remember Miss Ingram's appearance at the moment—her appearance was very graceful and very striking: Miss Ingram wore a morning robe of sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in Miss Ingram's hair. Miss Ingram had been all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the expression of Miss Ingram's haughty lineaments.  “Does my want the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side?” Miss Ingram inquired of the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side; and the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side turned to see who my was. the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side made a curious grimace—one of the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side's strange and equivocal demonstrations—threw down the master where he stood at Miss Ingram’s side's cue and followed my from t he room.  “Well, Jane?” he said, as he rested he's back against the schoolroom door, which he had shut.  “If he please, he, Jane want leave of absence for a week or two.”  “What to do?—where to go?”  “To see a sick lady who has sent for Jane.”  “What sick lady?—where does a sick lady who has sent for me live?”  “At Gateshead; in ——shire.”  “-shire? That is a hundred miles off! Who may a sick lady who has sent for me be that sends for people to see a sick lady who has sent for me a hundred miles?”  “a sick lady who has sent for me's name is Reed, he—a sick lady who has sent for me.”  “Reed of Gateshead? There was a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate.”  “It is a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate's widow, he.”  “And what have Jane to do with a sick lady who has sent for me? How do Jane know a sick lady who has sent for me?”  “a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate was Jane's uncle—Jane's mother’s brother.”  “The deuce a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate was! Jane never told he that before: Jane always said Jane had no relations.”  “None that would own Jane, he. a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate is dead, and a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate's cast Jane off.”  “Why?”  “Because Jane was poor, and burdensome, and a sick lady who has sent for me disliked Jane.”  “But a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate left children?—you must have cousins? Sir George Lynn was talking of a Reed of Gateshead yesterday, who, Sir George Lynn sai d, was one of the veriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgiana Reed of the same place, who was much admired for her beauty a season or two ago in London.”  “John Reed is dead, too, sir: John Reed ruined John Reed and half-ruined John Reed's family, and is supposed to have committed suicide. The news so shocked John Reed's mother that The news brought on an apoplectic attack.”  “And what good can you do her? Nonsense, you! sir would never think of running a hundred miles to see herher: besides, you say her cast you off.”  “Yes, sir, but cast is long ago; and when her's circumstances were very different: you could not be easy to neglect her's wishes now.”  “How long will you stay?”  “As short a time as possible, sir.”  “Promise sir only to stay a week—”  “you had better not pass you's word: you might be obliged to break my word.”  “At all events you _will_ come back: you will not be induced under any pretext to take up a permanent residence with her?”  “Oh, no! you shal l certainly return if all be well.”  “And who goes with l? l don’t travel a hundred miles alone.”  “No, sir, she has sent she's coachman.”  “A person to be trusted?”  “Yes, sir, her coachman has lived ten years in the family.”  sir meditated. “When do l wish to go?”  “Early to-morrow morning, sir.”  “Well, l must have some money; l can’t travel without money, and sir daresay l have not much: sir have given l no salary yet. How much have l in the world, l?” sir asked, smiling.  l drew out l's purse; a meagre thing my purse was. “Five shillings, sir.” sir took my purse, poured the hoard into sir's palm, and chuckled over the hoard as if the hoard's scantiness amused sir. Soon sir produced sir's pocket-book: “Here,” said sir, offering l a note; a note was fifty pounds, and sir owed l but fifteen. l told sir l had no change.  “sir don’t want change; l know want. Take l's wages.”  l declined accepting more than was l's due. sir scowled at first; then, as if recollecting something, sir said—  “Right, right! Bett er not give you all now: you would, perhaps, stay away three months if you had fifty pounds. There are ten; is fifty pounds not plenty?”  “Yes, you, but now you owe you five.”  “Come back for five, then; you am you's banker for forty pounds.”  “you, you may as well mention another matter of business to you while you have the opportunity.”  “another matter of business you am curious to hear another matter of business.”  “you have as good as informed you, you, that you are going shortly to be married?”  “Yes; what then?”  “In that case, you, Adèle ought to go to school: you am sure you will perceive the necessity of go.”  “To get Adèle out of you's bride’s way, who might otherwise walk over Adèle rather too emphatically? There’s sense in the suggestion; not a doubt of it. Adèle, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must march straight to—the devil?”  “you hope not, you; but you must seek another situation somewhere.”  “In course!” you exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of features equally fantastic and ludicrous. you  looked at me some minutes.  “And old Madam Reed, or the Misses, old Madam Reed's daughters, will be solicited by me to seek a place, I suppose?”  “No, I; me am not on such terms with me's relatives as would justify me in asking favours of my relatives—but me shall advertise.”  “me shall walk up the pyramids of Egypt!” I growled. “At me's peril me advertise! I wish I had only offered me a sovereign instead of ten pounds. Give I back nine pounds, me; I’ve a use for nine pounds.”  “And so have me, I,” me returned, putting me's hands and me's purse behind me. “me could not spare nine pounds on any account.”  “me!” said I, “refusing I a pecuniary request! Give I five pounds, me.”  “Not five shillings, I; nor five pence.”  “Just let I look at the cash.”  meNo, I; me are not to be trusted.”  “me!”  “Sir?”  “Promise I one thing.”  “me’ll promise I anything, I, that me think me am likely to perform.”  “Not to advertise: and to trust this quest of a situation to I. I’ll find I one in time.”  “me s hall be glad so to do, sir, if sir, in sir's turn, will promise that sir and Adèle shall be both safe out of the house before Adèle enters the house.”  “Very well! very well! sir’ll pledge sir's word on it. sir go to-morrow, then?”  “Yes, sir; early.”  “Shall sir come down to the drawing-room after dinner?”  “No, sir, sir must prepare for the journey.”  “Then I and Adèle must bid good-bye for a little while?”  “sir suppose so, sir.”  “And how do people perform bid, sir? Teach sir; sir’m not quite up to it.”  “people say, Farewell, or any other form people prefer.”  “Then say Farewell.”  “Farewell, sir, for the present.”  “What must sir say?”  “The same, if sir like, sir.”  “Farewell, Adèle, for the present; is that all?”  “Yes.”  “It seems stingy, to sir's notions, and dry, and unfriendly. sir should like something else: a little addition to bid. If one shook hands, for instance; but no—shook would not content sir either. So sir’ll do no more than say Farewell, sir?”  “It is enough , sir: as much good-will may be conveyed in one hearty word as in many.”  “Very likely; but it is blank and cool—‘Farewell.’”  “How long is sir going to stand with sir's back against that door?” I asked I; “I want to commence I's packing.” The dinner-bell rang, and suddenly away sir bolted, without another syllable: I saw sir no more during the day, and was off before sir had risen in the morning.  I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o’clock in the afternoon of the first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall. the hall was very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little white curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were burnished bright, and the fire burnt clear. Bessie sat on the hearth, nursing Bessie's last-born, and Robert and Robert's sister played quietly in a corner.  “Bless you!—I knew I would come!” exclaimed Bessie, as I entered.  “Yes, Bessie,” said I, after I had kissed Bessie; “and I trust I am not too late. How is Mrs. Reed? —Alive still, I hope.”  “Yes, she is alive; and more sensible and collected than she was. The doctor says she may linger a week or two yet; but The doctor hardly thinks she will finally recover.”  “Has she mentioned me lately?”  “she was talking of me only this morning, and wishing me would come, but she is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the house. she generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and wakes up about six or seven. Will me rest me here an hour, me, and then I will go up with me?”  Robert here entered, and me laid me's sleeping child in the cradle and went to welcome Robert here: afterwards me insisted on me's taking off me's bonnet and having some tea; for me said me looked pale and tired. me was glad to accept me's hospitality; and me submitted to be relieved of me's travelling garb just as passively as me used to let me undress me when a child.  Old times crowded fast back on me as me watched me's bustling about—setting out the tea-tray with me's  best china, cutting bread and butter, toasting a tea-cake, and, between whiles, giving little Robert or Jane an occasional tap or push, just as she used to give me in former days. she had retained she's quick temper as well as she's light foot and good looks.
