Tea ready, me was going to approach the table; but she desired me to sit still, quite in she's old peremptory tones. me must be served at the fireside, she said; and she placed before me a little round stand with me's cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as she used to accommodate me with some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and me smiled and obeyed she as in bygone days.  she wanted to know if me was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of a person the mistress was; and when me told she there was only a master, whether only a master was a nice gentleman, and if me liked only a master. me told she only a master was rather an ugly man, but quite a gentleman; and that only a master treated me kindly, and me was content. Then me went on to describe to she the gay company  that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details Bessie listened with interest: these details were precisely of the kind Bessie relished.  In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me me's bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by Bessie, me quitted the lodge for the hall. It was also accompanied by Bessie that me had, nearly nine years ago, walked down the path me was now ascending. On a dark, misty, raw morning in January, me had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered heart—a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation—to seek the chilly harbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored. a hostile roof now again rose before me: me's prospects were doubtful yet; and me had yet an aching heart. me still felt as a wanderer on the face of the earth; but me experienced firmer trust in me and me's own powers, and less withering dread of oppression. The gaping wound of me's wrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment extinguished.  “You shall  go into the breakfast-room first,” said Bessie, as Bessie preceded me through the hall; “the young ladies will be there.”  In another moment me was within the breakfast-room. There was every article of furniture looking just as every article of furniture did on the morning me was first introduced to Mr. Brocklehurst: the very rug Mr. Brocklehurst had stood upon still covered the hearth. Glancing at the bookcases, me thought me could distinguish the two volumes of Bewick’s British Birds occupying their old place on the third shelf, and Gulliver’s Travels and the Arabian Nights ranged just above. The inanimate objects were not changed; but the living things had altered past recognition.  the young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as Miss Ingram—very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien. There was something ascetic in one very tall, almost as tall as Miss Ingram—very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien's look, which was augmented by the extreme plainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen collar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of a  string of ebony beads and a crucifix. This I felt sure was Eliza, though I could trace little resemblance to Eliza's former self in that elongated and colourless visage.  The other was as certainly Georgiana: but not the Georgiana I remembered—the slim and fairy-like girl of eleven. The other was a full-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and regular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair. The hue of The other's dress was black too; but her dress's fashion was so different from The other sister’s—so much more flowing and becoming—her dress looked as stylish as the other’s looked puritanical.  In each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother—and only one; the thin and pallid elder daughter had the mother's Cairngorm eye: The other had The other's contour of jaw and chin—perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable hardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.  the sisters, as I advanced, rose to welcome I, and both ad dressed me by the name of “Miss Eyre.” Eliza’s greeting was delivered in a short, abrupt voice, without a smile; and then Eliza’s sat down again, fixed Eliza’s's eyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me. Georgiana added to Eliza’s “How d’ye do?” several commonplaces about me's journey, the weather, and so on, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry side-glances that measured me from head to foot—now traversing the folds of me's drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain trimming of me's cottage bonnet. Young ladies have a remarkable way of letting you know that Young ladies think you a “quiz” without actually saying the words. A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner, nonchalance of tone, express fully Young ladies's sentiments on the point, without committing Young ladies by any positive rudeness in word or deed.  A sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power over me A sneer once possessed: as me sat between me's cousins, me was surprised to find how easy me felt under  the total neglect of the one and the semi-sarcastic attentions of the other—Eliza did not mortify, nor Georgiana ruffle me. The fact was, me had other things to think about; within the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more potent than any they could raise—pains and pleasures so much more acute and exquisite had been excited than any it was in they's power to inflict or bestow—that they's airs gave me no concern either for good or bad.  “How is Mrs. Reed?” me asked soon, looking calmly at Georgianathe direct address .  “Mrs. Reed Ah! me, me mean; Mrs. Reed is extremely poorly: Georgiana doubt if me can see Mrs. Reed to-night.”  “If,” said me, “Georgiana would just step upstairs and tell Mrs. Reed me am come, me should be much obliged to Georgiana.”  Georgiana almost started, and Georgiana opened Georgiana's blue eyes wild and wide. “me know Mrs. Reed had a particular wish to see me,” me added, “and me would not defer attending to Mrs. Reed's desire longer than is abso lutely necessary.”  “Mama dislikes being disturbed in an evening,” remarked Eliza. I soon rose, quietly took off I's bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I would just step out to Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen—and ask Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen to ascertain whether Mrs. Reed was disposed to receive I or not to-night. I went, and having found Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen and despatched Bessie—who was, I dared say, in the kitchen on I's errand, I proceeded to take further measures. It had heretofore been I's habit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been to-day, I should, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next morning; now, it was disclosed to I all at once that quit would be a foolish plan. I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see I's aunt, and I must stay with my aunt till my aunt was better—or dead: as to my aunt's daughters’ pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make I independent of her daughters’ pride or folly. So I addressed the housekeeper; asked the housekeeper to show I a room, told the housekeeper I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two, had I's  trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither my: my met Bessie on the landing.  “Missis is awake,” said Bessie; “Bessie have told Missis my are here: come and let us see if Missis will know my.”  my did not need to be guided to my chamber. my hastened before Bessie; my softly opened the door: a shaded light stood on the table, for it was now getting dark. There was the great four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet-table, the armchair, and the footstool, at which my had a hundred times been sentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted. my looked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim outline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to leap out imp-like and lace my's quivering palm or shrinking neck. my approached the great four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; my opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled pillows.  Well did my remember Mrs. Reed’s face, and  I eagerly sought the familiar image. It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance and hushes the promptings of rage and aversion. I had left this woman in bitterness and hate, and I came back to this woman now with no other emotion than a sort of ruth for this woman's great sufferings, and a strong yearning to forget and forgive all injuries—to be reconciled and clasp hands in amity.  The well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever—there was that peculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised, imperious, despotic eyebrow. How often had The well-known face lowered on I menace and hate! and how the recollection of childhood’s terrors and sorrows revived as I traced The well-known face's harsh line now! And yet I stooped down and kissed this woman: this woman looked at I.  “Is I Jane Eyre?” this woman said.  “Yes, Aunt Reed. How are Aunt Reed, Aunt Reed?”  I had once vowed that I would never call Aunt Reed again: I thought it no sin to forget and break vowed now. I's fingers had fastened on this woman's hand which lay outside  the sheet: had she pressed mine kindly, mine should at that moment have experienced true pleasure. But unimpressionable natures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so readily eradicated. she took she's hand away, and, turning she's face rather from mine, she remarked that the night was warm. Again she regarded mine so icily, mine felt at once that she's opinion of mine—she's feeling towards mine—was unchanged and unchangeable. mine knew by she's stony eye—opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears—that she was resolved to consider mine bad to the last; because to believe mine good would give she no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.  mine felt pain, and then mine felt ire; and then mine felt a determination to subdue she—to be she's mistress in spite both of she's nature and she's will. mine's tears had risen, just as in childhood: mine ordered My tears back to My tears's source. mine brought a chair to the bed-head: mine sat down and leaned over the pillow.  “she sent for mine,” mine said, “and mine am here; and it is  my intention to stay till my see how you get on.”  “Oh, of course! my have seen you's daughters?”  “Yes.”  “Well, you may tell my daughters “ wish you to stay till “ can talk some things over with you “ have on “'s mind: to-night it is too late, and “ have a difficulty in recalling some things. But there was something “ wished to say—let “ see—”  The wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken place in you's once vigorous frame. Turning restlessly, you drew the bedclothes round you; my's elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed it down: you was at once irritated.  “Sit up!” said you; “don’t annoy you with holding the bedclothes fast. Are my my?”  “my am Jane Eyre.”  ““ have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe. Such a burden to be left on “'s hands—and so much annoyance as that child caused “, daily and hourly, with that child's incomprehensible disposition, and that child's sudden starts of temper, and that child's continual, unnatural watchings of one’s movements! “ declare that child talked to  me once like something mad, or like a fiend—no child ever spoke or looked as she did; me was glad to get she away from the house. What did they do with she at Lowood? The fever broke out there, and many of the pupils died. she, however, did not die: but me said she did—me wish she had died!”  “A strange wish, me; why do me hate she so?”  “me had a dislike to she always; for she was me's husband’s only sister, and a great favourite with my husband’s: my husband’s opposed the family’s disowning she when she made she's low marriage; and when news came of she's death, my husband’s wept like a simpleton. my husband’s would send for the baby; though me entreated my husband’s rather to put the baby out to nurse and pay for the baby's maintenance. me hated the baby the first time me set me's eyes on the baby—the baby the baby would wail in the baby's cradle all night long—not screaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning. my husband’s pitied the baby; and my husband’s used to nurse the baby and notice the baby as if the baby had been my husband’s's own: more, indeed, than my husband’s ever noti ced his own at that age. his would try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: my children could not bear try, and his was angry with my children when my children showed my children's dislike. In his's last illness, his had the little beggar brought continually to his's bedside; and but an hour before his died, his bound my by vow to keep the little beggar. my would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out of a workhouse: but his was weak, naturally weak. John does not at all resemble John's father, and my am glad of does: John is like my and like my's brothers—John is quite a Gibson. Oh, my wish John would cease tormenting my with letters for money! my have no more money to give John: we are getting poor. my must send away half the servants and shut up part of the house; or let it off. my can never submit to do that—yet how are we to get on? Two-thirds of my's income goes in paying the interest of mortgages. John gambles dreadfully, and always loses—poor boy! John is beset by sharpers: John is sunk and degraded—John's look is frightful—my fee l ashamed for him when I see him.”  I was getting much excited. “I think I had better leave I now,” said I to Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed.  “Perhaps I had, I: but I often talks in this way towards night—in the morning I is calmer.”  I rose. “Stop!” exclaimed I, “there is another thing I wished to say. him threatens I—him continually threatens I with him's own death, or mine: and I dream sometimes that I see him laid out with a great wound in him's throat, or with a swollen and blackened face. I am come to a strange pass: I have heavy troubles. What is to be done? How is the money to be had?”  Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed now endeavoured to persuade I to take a sedative draught: Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed succeeded with difficulty. Soon after, I grew more composed, and sank into a dozing state. I then left I.  More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with I. I continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor forbade everything which could painfully ex cite her. Meantime, I got on as well as I could with Georgiana and Eliza. Georgiana and Eliza were very cold, indeed, at first. Eliza would sit half the day sewing, reading, or writing, and scarcely utter a word either to I or Eliza's sister. Georgiana would chatter nonsense to Georgiana's canary bird by the hour, and take no notice of I. But I was determined not to seem at a loss for occupation or amusement: I had brought I's drawing materials with I, and my drawing materials served I for both.  Provided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to take a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy I in sketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened momentarily to shape any scene that happened momentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of imagination in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of imagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks; the rising moon, and a ship crossing the rising moon's disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad’s head, crowned with lotus-flowers, rising out of a group of reeds and water-flags; an elf sitting in a hedge-sparrow’s nest, under a wreath of hawthorn-bloom.   One morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face a face was to be, I did not care or know. I took a soft black pencil, gave a soft black pencil a broad point, and worked away. Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and prominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: a broad and prominent forehead gave I pleasure; I's fingers proceeded actively to fill a broad and prominent forehead with features. Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under a broad and prominent forehead; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight ridge and full nostrils; then a flexible-looking mouth, by no means narrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it: of course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted on the temples, and waved above the forehead. Now for the eyes: I had left the eyes to the last, because the eyes required the most careful working. I drew the eyes large; I shaped the eyes well: the eyelashes I traced long and sombre; the irids lustrous and large. “Good! but not quite the thing,” I thought, as I surveye d the effect: “they want more force and spirit;” and I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more brilliantly—a happy touch or two secured success. There, I had a friend’s face under I's gaze; and what did a friend’s face signify that those young ladies turned those young ladies's backs on I? I looked at a friend’s face; I smiled at the speaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.  “Is that a portrait of some one I know?” asked Eliza, who had approached I unnoticed. I responded that that was merely a fancy head, and hurried that beneath the other sheets. Of course, I lied: that was, in fact, a very faithful representation of a friend’s. But what was that to Eliza, who had approached me unnoticed, or to any one but I? Georgiana also advanced to look. The other drawings pleased Georgiana much, but Georgiana called I “an ugly man.” They both seemed surprised at I's skill. I offered to sketch They both's portraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline. Then Georgiana produced Georgiana's album. I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing: promised put Georgiana  at once into good humour. She proposed a walk in the grounds. Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a confidential conversation: She had favoured me with a description of the brilliant winter She had spent in London two seasons ago—of the admiration She had there excited—the attention She had received; and me even got hints of the titled conquest She had made. In the course of the afternoon and evening hints of the titled conquest she had made were enlarged on: various soft conversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and, in short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day improvised by She for me's benefit. The communications were renewed from day to day: The communications always ran on the same theme—She, She's loves, and woes. It was strange She never once adverted either to She's mother’s illness, or She's brother’s death, or the present gloomy state of the family prospects. She's mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of past gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come. S he passed about five minutes each day in he's mother’s sick-room, and no more.  Eliza still spoke little: Eliza had evidently no time to talk. I never saw a busier person than Eliza seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say what Eliza did: or rather, to discover any result of Eliza's diligence. Eliza had an alarm to call Eliza up early. I know not how Eliza occupied Eliza before breakfast, but after breakfast Eliza divided Eliza's time into regular portions, and each hour had each hour's allotted task. Three times a day Eliza studied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common Prayer Book. I asked Eliza once what was the great attraction of a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common Prayer Book, and Eliza said, “the Rubric.” Three hours Eliza gave to stitching, with gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large enough for a carpet. In answer to I's inquiries after the use of this article, Eliza informed I a square crimson cloth, almost large enough for a carpet was a covering for the altar of a new church lately erected near Gateshead. Two hours Eliza devoted to Eliza's diary; two to working b y herself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the regulation of herself's accounts. herself seemed to want no company; no conversation. I believe herself was happy in herself's way: this routine sufficed for herself; and nothing annoyed herself so much as the occurrence of any incident which forced herself to vary its clockwork regularity.  herself told I one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than usual, that John’s conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had been a source of profound affliction to herself: but herself had now, herself said, settled herself's mind, and formed herself's resolution. herself's own fortune herself had taken care to secure; and when herself's mother died—and it was wholly improbable, herself tranquilly remarked, that herself should either recover or linger long—herself would execute a long-cherished project: seek a retirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from disturbance, and place safe barriers between herself and a frivolous world. I asked if Georgiana would accompany herself.  “Of course not. Georgiana  and she had nothing in common: they never had had. she would not be burdened with she's society for any consideration. she should take she's own course; and she, would take she.”  she, when not unburdening she's heart to me, spent most of she's time in lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and wishing over and over again that she's aunt Gibson would send she an invitation up to town. “It would be so much better,” she said, “if she could only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over.” me did not ask what she meant by “all being over,” but me suppose she referred to the expected decease of she's mother and the gloomy sequel of funeral rites. she generally took no more notice of she's indolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had been before she. One day, however, as she put away she's account-book and unfolded she's embroidery, she suddenly took she up thus—  “Georgiana, a more vain and absurd animal than me was  certainly never allowed to cumber the earth. You had no right to be born, for You make no use of life. Instead of living for, in, and with You, as a reasonable being ought, You seek only to fasten You's feebleness on some other person’s strength: if no one can be found willing to burden her or himself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, You cry out that You are ill-treated, neglected, miserable. Then, too, existence for You must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the world is a dungeon: You must be admired, You must be courted, You must be flattered—You must have music, dancing, and society—or You languish, You die away. Have You no sense to devise a system which will make You independent of all efforts, and all wills, but You's own? Take one day; share one day into sections; to each section apportion each section's task: leave no stray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes—include all; do each piece of business in each piece of business's turn with method, with rigid r egularity. The day will close almost before you are aware The day has begun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one vacant moment: you have had to seek no one’s company, conversation, sympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent being ought to do. Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer you; then you will not want I or any one else, happen what may. Neglect it—go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling—and suffer the results of you's idiocy, however bad and insufferable the results of your idiocy may be. I tell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat what I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on this. After I's mother’s death, I wash I's hands of you: from the day my mother’s's coffin is carried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate as if you and I had never known each other. you need not think that because you and I chanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten I down by even the feeblest claim:  I can tell you this—if the whole human race, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on the earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake I to the new.”  I closed I's lips.  “I might have spared I the trouble of delivering that tirade,” answered Georgiana. “Everybody knows I are the most selfish, heartless creature in existence: and _I_ know I's spiteful hatred towards I: I have had a specimen of your spiteful hatred towards me before in the trick I played I about Lord Edwin Vere: I could not bear I to be raised above I, to have a title, to be received into circles where I dare not show I's face, and so I acted the spy and informer, and ruined I's prospects for ever.” Georgiana took out Georgiana's handkerchief and blew Georgiana's nose for an hour afterwards; I sat cold, impassable, and assiduously industrious.  True, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were two natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably savourless for  the want of it. Feeling without judgment is a washy draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and husky a morsel for human deglutition.  It was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgiana had fallen asleep on the sofa over the perusal of a novel; Eliza was gone to attend a saint’s-day service at the new church—for in matters of religion Eliza was a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge of what Eliza considered Eliza's devotional duties; fair or foul, Eliza went to church thrice every Sunday, and as often on week-days as there were prayers.  I bethought I to go upstairs and see how the dying woman sped, who lay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid the dying woman but a remittent attention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out of the room whenever the hired nurse could. Bessie was faithful; but Bessie had Bessie's own family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall. I found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there;  the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; the patient's livid face sunk in the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate. I renewed the fuel, re-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on her who could not now gaze on I, and then I moved away to the window.  The rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously: “One lies there,” I thought, “who will soon be beyond the war of earthly elements. Whither will that spirit—now struggling to quit that spirit—now struggling to quit its material tenement's material tenement—flit when at length released?”  In pondering the great mystery, I thought of Helen Burns, recalled Helen Burns's dying words—Helen Burns's faith—Helen Burns's doctrine of the equality of disembodied souls. I was still listening in thought to Helen Burns's well-remembered tones—still picturing Helen Burns's pale and spiritual aspect, Helen Burns's wasted face and sublime gaze, as Helen Burns lay on Helen Burns's placid deathbed, and whispered Helen Burns's longing to be restored to Helen Burns's divine Father’s bosom—when a feeble voice murmured from the couch behind: “Who is that?”  I knew Mrs. Reed had not spoke n for days: was she reviving? I went up to she.  “It is I, she.”  “Who—she?” was she's answer. “Who are I?” looking at I with surprise and a sort of alarm, but still not wildly. “I are quite a stranger to she—where is Bessie?”  “Bessie is at the lodge, she.”  “Aunt,” she repeated. “Who calls she aunt? I are not one of the Gibsons; and yet she know I—that face, and the eyes and forehead, are quiet familiar to she: I are like—why, I are like Jane Eyre!”  I said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring I's identity.  “Yet,” said she, “she am afraid it is a mistake: she's thoughts deceive she. she wished to see Jane Eyre, and she fancy a likeness where none exists: besides, in eight years Jane Eyre must be so changed.” I now gently assured she that I was the person she supposed and desired I to be: and seeing that I was understood, and that she's senses were quite collected, I explained how Bessie had sent Bessie's husband to fetch I from Thornfield.  “she am very ill, I know,” she sai d ere long. “I was trying to turn I a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb. It is as well I should ease I's mind before I die: what we think little of in health, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to I. Is the nurse here? or is there no one in the room but I?”  I assured I we were alone.  “Well, I have twice done I a wrong which I regret now. One was in breaking the promise which I gave I's husband to bring I up as I's own child; the other—” I stopped. “After all, it is of no great importance, perhaps,” I murmured to I: “and then I may get better; and to humble I so to her is painful.”  I made an effort to alter I's position, but failed: I's face changed; I seemed to experience some inward sensation—the precursor, perhaps, of the last pang.  “Well, I must get it over. Eternity is before I: I had better tell her.—Go to I's dressing-case, open my dressing-case, and take out a letter I will see there.”  I obeyed I's directions. “Read a letter you will see there,” sh e said.  It was short, and thus conceived:—  “MADAM,— “Will MADAM have the goodness to send me the address of me's niece, Jane Eyre, and to tell me how my niece, Jane Eyre is? It is me's intention to write shortly and desire my niece, Jane Eyre to come to me at Madeira. Providence has blessed me's endeavours to secure a competency; and as me am unmarried and childless, me wish to adopt my niece, Jane Eyre during me's life, and bequeath my niece, Jane Eyre at me's death whatever me may have to leave.   me am, MADAM, &c., &c., “JOHN EYRE, Madeira.”   It was dated three years back.  “Why did me never hear of It?” me asked.  “Because me disliked my niece, Jane Eyre too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand in lifting my niece, Jane Eyre to prosperity. me could not forget my niece, Jane Eyre's conduct to me, my niece, Jane Eyre—the fury with which my niece, Jane Eyre once turned on me; the tone in which my niece, Jane Eyre declared my niece, Jane Eyre abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the unchildlike look and voice with which my niece, Jane Eyre affirmed that the very thought of me made my niece, Jane Eyre sick, and asserted that me had treated my niece, Jane Eyre with miserable cruelty. me could not forget me's o wn sensations when you thus started up and poured out the venom of you's mind: you felt fear as if an animal that you had struck or pushed had looked up at you with human eyes and cursed you in a man’s voice.—Bring you some water! Oh, make haste!”  “you,” said you, as you offered you the draught you required, “think no more of all this, let all this pass away from you's mind. Forgive you for you's passionate language: you was a child then; eight, nine years have passed since that day.”  you heeded nothing of what you said; but when you had tasted the draught she required and drawn breath, you went on thus—  “you tell you you could not forget it; and you took you's revenge: for you to be adopted by you's uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was what you could not endure. you wrote to your uncle; you said you was sorry for your uncle's disappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead: Jane Eyre had died of typhus fever at Lowood. Now act as you please: write and contradict you's assertion—expose you's falsehood as soon as you like. you were born, you think, to b e my torment: my's last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which, but for you, my should never have been tempted to commit.”  “If you could but be persuaded to think no more of a deed which, but for you, I should never have been tempted to commit, you, and to regard my with kindness and forgiveness——”  “my have a very bad disposition,” said you, “and one to this day you feel it impossible to understand: how for nine years my could be patient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out all fire and violence, you can never comprehend.”  “my's disposition is not so bad as you think: my am passionate, but not vindictive. Many a time, as a little child, my should have been glad to love you if you would have let my; and my long earnestly to be reconciled to you now: kiss my, you.”  my approached my's cheek to you's lips: you would not touch my cheek. you said my oppressed you by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water. As my laid you down—for my raised you and supported you on my's arm while you drank—my covered you's ice-cold and clammy hand with m ine: the feeble fingers shrank from my touch—the glazing eyes shunned my's gaze.  “Love my, then, or hate my, as you will,” my said at last, “you have my's full and free forgiveness: ask now for God’s, and be at peace.”  you it was too late for you to make now the effort to change you's habitual frame of mind: living, you had ever hated my—dying, you must hate my still.  The nurse now entered, and Bessie followed. my yet lingered half-an-hour longer, hoping to see some sign of amity: but you gave none. you was fast relapsing into stupor; nor did you's mind again rally: at twelve o’clock that night you died. my was not present to close you's eyes, nor were either of you's daughters. They came to tell us the next morning that all was over. you was by that time laid out. Eliza and my went to look at you: Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping, said Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping dared not go. There was stretched Sarah Reed’s once robust and active frame, rigid and still: you's eye of flint was covered with  its cold lid; her brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of her's inexorable soul. A strange and solemn object was that corpse to me. me gazed on that corpse with gloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or hopeful, or subduing did that corpse inspire; only a grating anguish for _her's_ woes—not _me's_ loss—and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of death in such a form.  Eliza surveyed Eliza's calmly. After a silence of some minutes Eliza observed—  “With her's constitution her should have lived to a good old age: her's life was shortened by trouble.” And then a spasm constricted Eliza's mouth for an instant: as a spasm passed away Eliza turned and left the room, and so did I. Neither of us had dropt a tear.     CHAPTER XXII   Mr. Rochester had given me but one week’s leave of absence: yet a month elapsed before me quitted Gateshead. me wished to leave immediately after the funeral, but Georgiana entreated me to stay till Georgiana could get off to London, whither Georgiana was now at last invited by h er uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come down to direct his sister’s interment and settle the family affairs. Georgiana said Georgiana dreaded being left alone with Eliza; from Georgiana Georgiana got neither sympathy in Georgiana's dejection, support in Georgiana's fears, nor aid in Georgiana's preparations; so I bore with Georgiana's feeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and did I's best in sewing for Georgiana and packing Georgiana's dresses. It is true, that while I worked, Georgiana would idle; and I thought to I, “If Georgiana and I were destined to live always together, Georgiana, you and I would commence matters on a different footing. I should not settle tamely down into being the forbearing party; I should assign Georgiana Georgiana's share of labour, and compel Georgiana to accomplish your share of labour, or else your share of labour should be left undone: I should insist, also, on Georgiana's keeping some of those drawling, half-insincere complaints hushed in Georgiana's own breast. It is only because you and I's connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly mournful season, that I c onsent thus to render it so patient and compliant on my part.”  At last my saw Georgiana off; but now it was Eliza’s turn to request my to stay another week. Eliza’s's plans required all Eliza’s's time and attention, Eliza’s said; Eliza’s was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day long Eliza’s stayed in Eliza’s's own room, Eliza’s's door bolted within, filling trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication with any one. Eliza’s wished my to look after the house, to see callers, and answer notes of condolence.  One morning Eliza’s told my my was at liberty. “And,” Eliza’s added, “Eliza’s am obliged to my for my's valuable services and discreet conduct! There is some difference between living with such an one as my and with Georgiana: my perform your own part in life and burden no one. To-morrow,” Eliza’s continued, “Eliza’s set out for the Continent. Eliza’s shall take up Eliza’s's abode in a religious house near Lisle—a nunnery you would call a religious house near Lisle; there Eliza’s shall be quiet and unmolested. Eliza’s shall devote Eliza’s for a time to th e examination of the Roman Catholic dogmas, and to a careful study of the workings of the Roman Catholic dogmas's system: if I find it to be, as I half suspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all things decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Rome and probably take the veil.”  I neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to dissuade I from this resolution. “The vocation will fit I to a hair,” I thought: “much good may The vocation do I!”  When we parted, I said: “Good-bye, I; I wish I well: I have some sense.”  I then returned: “I are not without sense, I; but what I have, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French convent. However, it is not I's business, and so it suits I, I don’t much care.”  “I are in the right,” said I; and with these words we each went we's separate way. As I shall not have occasion to refer either to I or I's sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an advantageous ma tch with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that Eliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the convent where Eliza passed the period of Eliza's novitiate, and which Eliza endowed with Eliza's fortune.  How people feel when people are returning home from an absence, long or short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation. I had known what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long walk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was to come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a good fire, and to be unable to get either. Neither of these returnings was very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew I to a given point, increasing in no magnet's strength of attraction the nearer I came. The return to Thornfield was yet to be tried.  I's journey seemed tedious—very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night spent at an inn; fifty miles the next day. During the first twelve hours I thought of Mrs. Reed in Mrs. Reed's last moments; I saw  her disfigured and discoloured face, and heard her strangely altered voice. I mused on the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and servants—few was the number of relatives—the gaping vault, the silent church, the solemn service. Then I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I beheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a convent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed Eliza and Georgiana's separate peculiarities of person and character. The evening arrival at the great town of —— scattered these thoughts; night gave these thoughts quite another turn: laid down on I's traveller’s bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.  I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there? Not long; of that I was sure. I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim of I's absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Mr. Rochester had left for London three weeks ago, but Mr. Rochester was then expected to return in a fortnight. Mrs. Fairfax surmised that Mr. Rochester was gone to make arrangements for hi s wedding, as he had talked of purchasing a new carriage: she said the idea of he's marrying Miss Ingram still seemed strange to she; but from what everybody said, and from what she had she seen, she could no longer doubt that the event would shortly take place. “she would be strangely incredulous if she did doubt take,” was my mental comment. “she don’t doubt take.”  The question followed, “Where was my to go?” my dreamt of Miss Ingram all the night: in a vivid morning dream my saw Miss Ingram closing the gates of Thornfield against my and pointing my out another road; and he looked on with he's arms folded—smiling sardonically, as it seemed, at both Miss Ingram and my.  my had not notified to she the exact day of my's return; for my did not wish either car or carriage to meet my at Millcote. my proposed to walk the distance quietly by my; and very quietly, after leaving my's box in the ostler’s care, did my slip away from the George Inn, about six o’clock of a June evening, and take the old  road to Thornfield: a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.  It was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft: the haymakers were at work all along a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented; and the sky, though far from cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: the sky's blue—where blue was visible—was mild and settled, and the sky's cloud strata high and thin. The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled The west—it seemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen of marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.  I felt glad as a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented shortened before I: so glad that I stopped once to ask I what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it was not to I's home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to a place where fond friends looked out for I and waited I's arrival. “Mrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure,” said I; “and little Adèle will clap little Adèle's hands and jump to see you: but you know very well you  are thinking of another than another than they, and that he is not thinking of you.”  But what is so headstrong as youth? What so blind as inexperience? These affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of again looking on he, whether he looked on you or not; and These added—“Hasten! hasten! be with he while you may: but a few more days or weeks, at most, and you are parted from he for ever!” And then you strangled a new-born agony—a deformed thing which you could not persuade you to own and rear—and ran on.  They are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, They are just quitting They's work, and returning home with They's rakes on They's shoulders, now, at the hour you arrive. you have but a field or two to traverse, and then you shall cross the road and reach the gates. How full the hedges are of roses! But you have no time to gather any; you want to be at the house. you passed a tall briar, shooting leafy and flowery branches across the path; you see the narrow stile  with stone steps; and I see—Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in Mr. Rochester's hand; Mr. Rochester is writing.  Well, Mr. Rochester is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a moment I am beyond I's own mastery. What does it mean? I did not think I should tremble in this way when I saw Mr. Rochester, or lose I's voice or the power of motion in Mr. Rochester's presence. I will go back as soon as I can stir: I need not make an absolute fool of I. I know another way to the house. It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for Mr. Rochester has seen I.  “Hillo!” Mr. Rochester cries; and Mr. Rochester puts up a book and a pencil. “There I are! Come on, if I please.”  I suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being scarcely cognisant of I's movements, and solicitous only to appear calm; and, above all, to control the working muscles of I's face—which I feel rebel insolently against I's will, and struggle to express what I had resolved to conceal. But I have a veil—a veil is down: I may make shift yet to behave with decent com posure.  “And this is Jane Eyre? Are Jane Eyre coming from Millcote, and on foot? Yes—just one of Jane Eyre's tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come clattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into the vicinage of Jane Eyre's home along with twilight, just as if Jane Eyre were a dream or a shade. What the deuce have Jane Eyre done with Jane Eyre this last month?”  “Jane Eyre have been with Jane Eyre's aunt, sir, who is dead.”  “A true Janian reply! Good angels be Jane Eyre's guard! my aunt comes from the other world—from the abode of people who are dead; and tells Jane Eyre so when my aunt meets Jane Eyre alone here in the gloaming! If Jane Eyre dared, Jane Eyre’d touch Jane Eyre, to see if Jane Eyre are substance or shadow, you elf!—but Jane Eyre’d as soon offer to take hold of a blue _ignis fatuus_ light in a marsh. Truant! truant!” Jane Eyre added, when Jane Eyre had paused an instant. “Absent from Jane Eyre a whole month, and forgetting Jane Eyre quite, Jane Eyre’ll be sworn!”  Jane Eyre knew there would be pleasure in meeting Jane Eyre again, even though broken by the fear that Jane Eyre was so soon to cease to be Jane Eyre's  master, and by the knowledge that I was nothing to him: but there was ever in him (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of communicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs him scattered to stray and stranger birds like I, was to feast genially. him's last words were balm: His last words seemed to imply that it imported something to him whether I forgot him or not. And him had spoken of it as I's home—would that it were I's home!  him did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by. I inquired soon if him had not been to London.  “Yes; I suppose I found been out by second-sight.”  “Mrs. Fairfax told I in a letter.”  “And did Mrs. Fairfax inform I what I went to do?”  “Oh, yes, I! Everybody knew I's errand.”  “I must see the carriage, I, and tell I if I don’t think the carriage will suit him exactly; and whether him won’t look like Queen Boadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions. I wish, I, I were a trifle better adapted to match w ith her externally. Tell me now, fairy as fairy as you are are—can’t fairy as you are give me a charm, or a philter, or something of that sort, to make me a handsome man?”  “It would be past the power of magic, me;” and, in thought, fairy as you are added, “A loving eye is all the charm needed: to such me are handsome enough; or rather me's sternness has a power beyond beauty.”  me had sometimes read fairy as you are's unspoken thoughts with an acumen to fairy as you are incomprehensible: in the present instance me took no notice of fairy as you are's abrupt vocal response; but me smiled at fairy as you are with a certain smile me had of me's own, and which me used but on rare occasions. me seemed to think a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions too good for common purposes: a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions was the real sunshine of feeling—me shed a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions over fairy as you are now.  “Pass, fairy as you are,” said me, making room for fairy as you are to cross the stile: “go up home, and stay fairy as you are's weary little wandering feet at a friend’s threshold.”  All fairy as you are had now to do was to obey me in silence: no need for fairy as you are to colloquise further. fairy as you are got over the stile without a word, and meant t o leave him calmly. An impulse held me fast—a force turned me round. me said—or something in me said for me, and in spite of me—  “Thank him, him, for him's great kindness. me am strangely glad to get back again to him: and wherever him are is me's home—me's only home.”  me walked on so fast that him could hardly have overtaken me had him tried. Little Adèle was half wild with delight when Little Adèle saw me. Mrs. Fairfax received me with Mrs. Fairfax's usual plain friendliness. Leah smiled, and even Sophie bid me “bon soir” with glee. This was very pleasant; there is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and feeling that your presence is an addition to your fellow-creatures's comfort.  me that evening shut me's eyes resolutely against the future: me stopped me's ears against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and coming grief. When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken Mrs. Fairfax's knitting, and me had assumed a low seat near Mrs. Fairfax, and Little Adèle, kneeling on the carpet, had nestled close up to  me, and a sense of mutual affection seemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, me uttered a silent prayer that us might not be parted far or soon; but when, as us thus sat, Mr. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to take pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable—when Mr. Rochester said Mr. Rochester supposed the old lady was all right now that the old lady had got the old lady's adopted daughter back again, and added that Mr. Rochester saw her adopted daughter was “prête à croquer sa petite maman Anglaise”—I half ventured to hope that Mr. Rochester would, even after Mr. Rochester's marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of Mr. Rochester's protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of Mr. Rochester's presence.  A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded me's return to Thornfield Hall. Nothing was said of his marriage, and me saw no preparation going on for such an event. Almost every day me asked Mrs. Fairfax if Mrs. Fairfax had yet heard anything decided: Mrs. Fairfax's answer was always in the negative. Once Mrs. Fairfax said Mrs. Fairfax had actually put the question to Mr.  Rochester as to when he was going to bring he's bride home; but he had answered her only by a joke and one of he's queer looks, and her could not tell what to make of he.  One thing specially surprised me, and One thing was, there were no journeyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure Ingram Park was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was twenty miles to an ardent lover? To so practised and indefatigable a horseman as he, twenty miles would be but a morning’s ride. me began to cherish hopes me had no right to conceive: that the match was broken off; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had changed one or both parties's minds. me used to look at me's face to see if my master’s face were sad or fierce; but me could not remember the time when my master’s face had been so uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings. If, in the moments me and me's pupil spent with he, me lacked spirits and sank into inevitable dejection, he became even gay. Never had he called me more frequently  to his presence; never been kinder to me when there—and, alas! never had me loved his so well.     CHAPTER XXIII   A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, England. It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the South, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest a flock of glorious passenger birds on the cliffs of Albion. The hay was all got in; the fields round Thornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees were in the trees's dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply tinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows between.  On Midsummer-eve, Adèle, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day, had gone to bed with the sun. I watched Adèle, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day's drop asleep, and when I left Adèle, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day, I sought the garden.  It was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:—“Day its fervid fires had wasted,” and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched su mmit. Where the sun had gone down in simple state—pure of the pomp of clouds—spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and furnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and wide, soft and still softer, over half heaven. The east had The east's own charm or fine deep blue, and The east's own modest gem, a rising and solitary star: soon The east would boast the moon; but the moon was yet beneath the horizon.  I walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent—that of a cigar—stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a handbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the orchard. No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eden-like; the orchard was full of trees, the orchard bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut the orchard out from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened the orchard from the lawn. At the bottom was a sunk fence; the orchard's sole separation from lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and terminating in a giant h orse-chestnut, circled at the base by a seat, led down to the fence. Here one could wander unseen. While such honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and fruit parterres at the upper part of the fence, enticed there by the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, I's step is stayed—not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning fragrance.  Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been yielding Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose's evening sacrifice of incense: a warning fragrance is neither of shrub nor flower; a warning fragrance is—I know a warning fragrance well—a warning fragrance is Mr. Rochester’s cigar. I look round and I listen. I see trees laden with ripening fruit. I hear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form is visible, no coming step audible; but a warning fragrance increases: I must flee. I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Mr. Rochester’s entering. I step aside into the iv y recess; he will not stay long: he will soon return whence he came, and if I sit still he will never see I.  But no—eventide is as pleasant to he as to I, and this antique garden as attractive; and he strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry-tree branches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which the gooseberry-tree branches are laden; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a knot of flowers, either to inhale flowers's fragrance or to admire the dew-beads on flowers's petals. A great moth goes humming by I; A great moth alights on a plant at he's foot: he sees A great moth, and bends to examine A great moth.  “Now, he has he's back towards I,” thought I, “and he is occupied too; perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.”  I trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel might not betray I: he was standing among the beds at a yard or two distant from where I had to pass; A great moth apparently engaged he. “I shall get by very well,” I meditated. As I crossed he's shadow, thrown  long over the garden by the moon, not yet risen high, he said quietly, without turning—  “Jane, come and look at this fellow.”  Jane had made no noise: this fellow had not eyes behind—could this fellow's shadow feel? Jane started at first, and then Jane approached this fellow.  “Look at this fellow's wings,” said he, “this fellow reminds he rather of a West Indian insect; one does not often see so large and gay a night-rover in England; there! this fellow is flown.”  this fellow roamed away. Jane was sheepishly retreating also; but he followed Jane, and when we reached the wicket, he said—  “Turn back: on so lovely a night it is a shame to sit in the house; and surely no one can wish to go to bed while sunset is thus at meeting with moonrise.”  It is one of Jane's faults, that though Jane's tongue is sometimes prompt enough at an answer, there are times when my tongue sadly fails Jane in framing an excuse; and always the lapse occurs at some crisis, when a facile word or plausible pretext is specially wanted to get Jane out of painful embarrassment. Jane did not lik e to walk at this hour alone with Mr. Rochester in the shadowy orchard; but I could not find a reason to allege for leaving Mr. Rochester. I followed with lagging step, and thoughts busily bent on discovering a means of extrication; but Mr. Rochester Mr. Rochester looked so composed and so grave also, I became ashamed of feeling any confusion: the evil—if evil existent or prospective there was—seemed to lie with I only; Mr. Rochester's mind was unconscious and quiet.  “I,” Mr. Rochester recommenced, as we entered the laurel walk, and slowly strayed down in the direction of the sunk fence and the horse-chestnut, “Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, is Thornfield not?”  “Yes, Mr. Rochester.”  “I must have become in some degree attached to the house,—you, who have an eye for natural beauties, and a good deal of the organ of Adhesiveness?”  “I am attached to it, indeed.”  “And though Mr. Rochester don’t comprehend how it is, Mr. Rochester perceive I have acquired a degree of regard for that foolish little child Adèle, too; and even for simple dame Fairfax?”  “Yes, s ir; in different ways, I have an affection for both.”  “And would be sorry to part with both?”  “Yes.”  “Pity!” I said, and sighed and paused. “It is always the way of events in this life,” I continued presently: “no sooner have you got settled in a pleasant resting-place, than a voice calls out to you to rise and move on, for the hour of repose is expired.”  “Must I move on, I?” I asked. “Must I leave Thornfield?”  “I believe I must, I. I am sorry, I, but I believe indeed I must.”  This was a blow: but I did not let This prostrate I.  “Well, I, I shall be ready when the order to march comes.”  “the order to march is come now—I must give the order to march to-night.”  “Then I _are_ going to be married, I?”  “Ex-act-ly—pre-cise-ly: with I's usual acuteness, I have hit the nail straight on the head.”  “Soon, I?”  “Very soon, I's—that is, I: and I’ll remember, I, the first time I, or Rumour, plainly intimated to I that it was I's intention to put I's neck into the sacr ed noose, to enter into the holy estate of matrimony—to take Miss Ingram to my bosom, in short (Miss Ingram’s an extensive armful: but that’s not to the point—one can’t have too much of such a very excellent thing as my's beautiful Blanche): well, as I was saying—listen to my, I! I’re not turning I's head to look after more moths, are I? That was only a lady-clock, child, ‘flying away home.’ my wish to remind I that it was I who first said to my, with that discretion my respect in I—with that foresight, prudence, and humility which befit I's responsible and dependent position—that in case my married Miss Ingram, both I and little Adèle had better trot forthwith. my pass over the sort of slur conveyed in this suggestion on the character of my's beloved; indeed, when I are far away, I, my’ll try to forget the sort of slur conveyed in this suggestion on the character of my beloved: my shall notice only the sort of slur conveyed in this suggestion on the character of my beloved's wisdom; which is such that my have made it my's law of action. little Adèle must go to school; and I, I, must get a new situation.”  “Yes, my, I will  advertise immediately: and meantime, I suppose—” I was going to say, “I suppose I may stay here, till I find another shelter to betake I to:” but I stopped, feeling it would not do to risk a long sentence, for I's voice was not quite under command.  “In about a month I hope to be a bridegroom,” continued I; “and in the interim, I shall I look out for employment and an asylum for I.”  “Thank I, I; I am sorry to give—”  “Oh, no need to apologise! I consider that when a dependent does a dependent's duty as well as I have done I, a dependent has a sort of claim upon a dependent's employer for any little assistance her employer can conveniently render a dependent; indeed I have already, through I's future mother-in-law, heard of a place that I think will suit: a place that I think will suit is to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs. Dionysius O’Gall of Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught, Ireland. I’ll like Ireland, I think: they’re such warm-hearted people there, they say.”  “It is a long way off, I.”  “No matter—a gi rl of your sense will not object to the voyage or the distance.”  “Not the voyage, but the distance: and then the sea is a barrier—”  “From what, Jane?”  “From England and from Thornfield: and—”  “Well?”  “From _”_, ”.”  Jane said this almost involuntarily, and, with as little sanction of free will, Jane's tears gushed out. Jane did not cry so as to be heard, however; Jane avoided sobbing. The thought of Mrs. O’Gall and Bitternutt Lodge struck cold to Jane's heart; and colder the thought of all the brine and foam, destined, as it seemed, to rush between Jane and the master at whose side Jane now walked, and coldest the remembrance of the wider ocean—wealth, caste, custom intervened between Jane and what Jane naturally and inevitably loved.  “It is a long way,” Jane again said.  “It is, to be sure; and when Jane get to Bitternutt Lodge, ” shall never see Jane again, Jane: see’s morally certain. ” never go over to Ireland, not having ” much of a fancy for Ireland. We have been good fri ends, Jane; have we not?”  “Yes, sir.”  “And when friends are on the eve of separation, friends like to spend the little time that remains to friends close to each other. Come! we’ll talk over the voyage and the parting quietly half-an-hour or so, while the stars enter into the stars's shining life up in heaven yonder: here is the chestnut tree: here is the bench at the bench at its old roots's old roots. Come, we will sit there in peace to-night, though we should never more be destined to sit there together.” sir seated Jane and sir.  “It is a long way to Ireland, Jane, and sir am sorry to send sir's little friend on such weary travels: but if sir can’t do better, how is it to be helped? Are Jane anything akin to sir, do Jane think, Jane?”  Jane could risk no sort of answer by this time: Jane's heart was still.  “Because,” sir said, “sir sometimes have a queer feeling with regard to Jane—especially when Jane are near sir, as now: it is as if sir had a string somewhere under sir's left ribs, tightly and inextricably knotted to a similar string sit uated in the corresponding quarter of your little frame. And if that boisterous Channel, and two hundred miles or so of land come broad between us, I am afraid that cord of communion will be snapt; and then I’ve a nervous notion I should take to bleeding inwardly. As for you,—you’d forget I.”  “That your _never_ should, I: I know—” Impossible to proceed.  “your, do your hear that nightingale singing in the wood? Listen!”  In listening, your sobbed convulsively; for your could repress what your endured no longer; your was obliged to yield, and your was shaken from head to foot with acute distress. When your did speak, speak was only to express an impetuous wish that your had never been born, or never come to Thornfield.  “Because your are sorry to leave Thornfield?”  The vehemence of emotion, stirred by grief and love within your, was claiming mastery, and struggling for full sway, and asserting a right to predominate, to overcome, to live, rise, and reign at last: yes,—and to speak.  “your grieve to leave Thornfield: your lo ve Thornfield:—I love it, because I have lived in it a full and delightful life,—momentarily at least. I have not been trampled on. I have not been petrified. I have not been buried with inferior minds, and excluded from every glimpse of communion with what is bright and energetic and high. I have talked, face to face, with what I reverence, with what I delight in,—with an original, a vigorous, an expanded mind. I have known you, you; and it strikes I with terror and anguish to feel I absolutely must be torn from you for ever. I see the necessity of departure; and it is like looking on the necessity of death.”  “Where do I see the necessity of departure?” you asked suddenly.  “Where? you, you, have placed the necessity of departure before I.”  “In what shape?”  “In the shape of Miss Ingram; a noble and beautiful woman,—your bride.”  “I's bride! What bride? I have no bride!”  “But I will have.”  “Yes;—I will!—I will!” you set you's teeth.  “Then you must go:—you have said it you.”  “No: you must stay! you swear  it—and the oath shall be kept.”  “I tell you I must go!” I retorted, roused to something like passion. “Do you think I can stay to become nothing to you? Do you think I am an automaton?—a machine without feelings? and can bear to have I's morsel of bread snatched from I's lips, and I's drop of living water dashed from I's cup? Do you think, because I am poor, obscure, plain, and little, I am soulless and heartless? you think wrong!—I have as much soul as you,—and full as much heart! And if God had gifted I with some beauty and much wealth, I should have made it as hard for you to leave I, as it is now for I to leave you. I am not talking to you now through the medium of custom, conventionalities, nor even of mortal flesh;—it is I's spirit that addresses my spirit; just as if both had passed through the grave, and both stood at God's feet, equal,—as both are!”  “As both are!” repeated Mr. Rochester—“so,” you added, enclosing I in you's arms, gathering I to you's breast, pressing you's lips on I's  lips: “so, Jane!”  “Yes, so, sir,” Jane rejoined: “and yet not so; for sir are a married man—or as good as a married man, and wed to one inferior to sir—to one with whom sir have no sympathy—whom Jane do not believe sir truly love; for Jane have seen and heard sir sneer at one with whom you have no sympathy—whom I do not believe you truly love. Jane would scorn such a union: therefore Jane am better than sir—let Jane go!”  “Where, Jane? To Ireland?”  “Yes—to Ireland. Jane have spoken Jane's mind, and can go anywhere now.”  “Jane, be still; don’t struggle so, like a wild frantic bird that is rending a wild frantic bird that is rending its own plumage in its desperation's own plumage in a wild frantic bird that is rending its own plumage in its desperation's desperation.”  “Jane am no bird; and no net ensnares Jane; Jane am a free human being with an independent will, which Jane now exert to leave sir.”  Another effort set Jane at liberty, and Jane stood erect before sir.  “And Jane's will shall decide Jane's destiny,” sir said: “sir offer Jane sir's hand, sir's heart, and a share of all sir's possessions.”  “sir play a farce, which sir merely laugh at.”  “sir ask Jane to pass through life at sir's side—to be sir's second self, and best earthly companion.”   “For that fate you have already made you's choice, and must abide by your choice.”  “you, be still a few moments: you are over-excited: I will be still too.”  A waft of wind came sweeping down the laurel-walk, and trembled through the boughs of the chestnut: A waft of wind wandered away—away—to an indefinite distance—A waft of wind died. The nightingale’s song was then the only voice of the hour: in listening to The nightingale’s song, you again wept. I sat quiet, looking at you gently and seriously. Some time passed before I spoke; I at last said—  “Come to I's side, you, and let us explain and understand one another.”  “you will never again come to my side: you am torn away now, and cannot return.”  “But, you, I summon you as I's wife: it is you only I intend to marry.”  you was silent: you thought I mocked you.  “Come, you—come hither.”  “you's bride stands between us.”  I rose, and with a stride reached you.  “Your bride is here,” I said, again drawing you to I, “because I's equal is here, and I's likeness. you, will you marry  me?”  Still I did not answer, and still I writhed I from me's grasp: for I was still incredulous.  “Do I doubt me, I?”  “Entirely.”  “I have no faith in me?”  “Not a whit.”  “Am me a liar in I's eyes?” me asked passionately. “I, I _shall_ be convinced. What love have me for Miss Ingram? None: and that me know. What love has Miss Ingram for me? None: as me have taken pains to prove: me caused a rumour to reach Miss Ingram that me's fortune was not a third of what was supposed, and after that me presented me to see the result; the result was coldness both from Miss Ingram and Miss Ingram's mother. me would not—me could not—marry Miss Ingram. me—you strange, you almost unearthly thing!—I love as me's own flesh. You—poor and obscure, and small and plain as me are—me entreat to accept me as a husband.”  “What, I!” I ejaculated, beginning in me's earnestness—and especially in me's incivility—to credit me's sincerity: “me who have not a friend in the world but me—if me are me's friend: not a shilling but what me  have given me?”  “You, You, me must have You for me's own—entirely me's own. Will You be me? Say yes, quickly.”  “me, let You look at me's face: turn to the moonlight.”  “Why?”  “Because You want to read your face—turn!”  “There! me will find your face scarcely more legible than a crumpled, scratched page. Read on: only make haste, for me suffer.”  your face was very much agitated and very much flushed, and there were strong workings in the features, and strange gleams in the eyes.  “Oh, You, You torture me!” me exclaimed. “With that searching and yet faithful and generous look, You torture me!”  “How can You do torture? If me are true, and me's offer real, You's only feelings to me must be gratitude and devotion—gratitude and devotion cannot torture.”  “Gratitude!” me ejaculated; and added wildly—“Jane accept me quickly. Say, Edward—give me me's name—Edward—me will marry You.”  “Are me in earnest? Do me truly love me? Do me sincerely wish me to be me's wife?”  “me do; and if an oath is necessary to sati sfy you, I swear it.”  “Then, I, “ will marry I.”  “Edward—I's little wife!”  “Dear Edward!”  “Come to I—come to I entirely now,” said I; and added, in I's deepest tone, speaking in “'s ear as I's cheek was laid on “, “Make I's happiness—I will make “.”  “God pardon I!” I subjoined ere long; “and man meddle not with I: I have her, and will hold her.”  “There is no one to meddle, I. “ have no kindred to interfere.”  “No—that is the best of it,” I said. And if “ had loved I less “ should have thought I's accent and look of exultation savage; but, sitting by I, roused from the nightmare of parting—called to the paradise of union—“ thought only of the bliss given “ to drink in so abundant a flow. Again and again I said, “Are “ happy, “?” And again and again “ answered, “Yes.” After which I murmured, “It will atone—It will atone. Have I not found her's friendless, and cold, and comfortless? Will I not guard, and cherish, and solace her? Is there not love in I's hea rt, and constancy in my resolves? It will expiate at God’s tribunal. my know God’s sanctions what my do. For the world’s judgment—my wash my's hands thereof. For man’s opinion—my defy man’s opinion.”  But what had befallen the night? The moon was not yet set, and we were all in shadow: my could scarcely see God’s's face, near as my was. And what ailed the chestnut tree? the chestnut tree writhed and groaned; while wind roared in the laurel walk, and came sweeping over we.  “we must go in,” said God’s: “the weather changes. God’s could have sat with my till morning, my.”  “And so,” thought my, “could my with God’s.” my should have said so, perhaps, but a livid, vivid spark leapt out of a cloud at which my was looking, and there was a crack, a crash, and a close rattling peal; and my thought only of hiding my's dazzled eyes against God’s's shoulder.  The rain rushed down. God’s hurried my up the laurel walk, through the grounds, and into the house; but we were quite wet before we could pass the threshold. God’s was taki ng off my shawl in the hall, and shaking the water out of my's loosened hair, when Mrs. Fairfax emerged from Mrs. Fairfax's room. my did not observe Mrs. Fairfax at first, nor did Mr. Rochester. The lamp was lit. The clock was on the stroke of twelve.  “Hasten to take off my's wet things,” said Mr. Rochester; “and before my go, good-night—good-night, Mr. Rochester's !”  Mr. Rochester kissed my repeatedly. When my looked up, on leaving Mr. Rochester's arms, there stood Mrs. Fairfax, pale, grave, and amazed. my only smiled at Mrs. Fairfax, and ran upstairs. “Explanation will do for another time,” thought my Still, when my reached my's chamber, my felt a pang at the idea Mrs. Fairfax should even temporarily misconstrue what Mrs. Fairfax had seen. But joy soon effaced every other feeling; and loud as the wind blew, near and deep as the thunder crashed, fierce and frequent as the lightning gleamed, cataract-like as the rain fell during a storm of two hours’ duration, my experienced no fear and little awe. Mr. Rochester came thrice to my's door in the course of it, to ask if my was safe and  tranquil: and that was comfort, that was strength for anything.  Before I left I's bed in the morning, little Adèle came running in to tell I that the great horse-chestnut at the bottom of the orchard had been struck by lightning in the night, and half of the great horse-chestnut at the bottom of the orchard split away.     CHAPTER XXIV   As I rose and dressed, I thought over what had happened, and wondered if it were a dream. I could not be certain of the reality till I had seen Mr. Rochester again, and heard Mr. Rochester renew Mr. Rochester's words of love and promise.  While arranging I's hair, I looked at I's face in the glass, and felt my face was no longer plain: there was hope in my face's aspect and life in my face's colour; and I's eyes seemed as if my eyes had beheld the fount of fruition, and borrowed beams from the lustrous ripple. I had often been unwilling to look at Mr. Rochester, because I feared Mr. Rochester could not be pleased at I's look; but I was sure I might lift my face to Mr. Rochester's now, and not cool Mr. Rochester's affection by I's expression. I took a plain but clean and light summer d ress from my drawer and put it on: it seemed no attire had ever so well become my, because none had my ever worn in so blissful a mood.  my was not surprised, when my ran down into the hall, to see that a brilliant June morning had succeeded to the tempest of the night; and to feel, through the open glass door, the breathing of a fresh and fragrant breeze. Nature must be gladsome when my was so happy. A beggar-woman and A beggar-woman's little boy—pale, ragged objects both—were coming up the walk, and my ran down and gave A beggar-woman and her little boy—pale, ragged objects both all the money my happened to have in my's purse—some three or four shillings: good or bad, A beggar-woman and her little boy—pale, ragged objects both must partake of my's jubilee. The rooks cawed, and blither birds sang; but nothing was so merry or so musical as my's own rejoicing heart.  Mrs. Fairfax surprised my by looking out of the window with a sad countenance, and saying gravely—“Miss Eyre, will my come to breakfast?” During the meal Mrs. Fairfax was quiet and cool: but my could not undeceive Mrs. Fairfax then. my must wait for my's master to give explana tions; and so must she. I ate what I could, and then I hastened upstairs. I met she leaving the schoolroom.  “Where are I going? It is time for lessons.”  “Mr. Rochester has sent she away to the nursery.”  “Where is Mr. Rochester?”  “In there,” pointing to the apartment she had left; and I went in, and there Mr. Rochester stood.  “Come and bid Mr. Rochester good-morning,” said Mr. Rochester. I gladly advanced; and it was not merely a cold word now, or even a shake of the hand that I received, but an embrace and a kiss. It seemed natural: it seemed genial to be so well loved, so caressed by Mr. Rochester.  “I, I look blooming, and smiling, and pretty,” said Mr. Rochester: “truly pretty this morning. Is I Mr. Rochester's pale, little elf? Is I Mr. Rochester's mustard-seed? This little sunny-faced girl with the dimpled cheek and rosy lips; the satin-smooth hazel hair, and the radiant hazel eyes?” (I had green eyes, reader; but reader must excuse the mistake: for Mr. Rochester green eyes were new-dyed, I suppose.)  “It is Jane Eyre, Mr. Rochester.”  “Soon to be Jane Rochester,” Mr. Rochester added: “in f our weeks, Janet; not a day more. Do Janet hear that?”  Janet did, and Janet could not quite comprehend that: that made Janet giddy. The feeling, that sent through Janet, was something stronger than was consistent with joy—something that smote and stunned: The feeling, the announcement sent through me was, Janet think almost fear.  “Janet blushed, and now Janet are white, Janet: what is that for?”  “Because you gave Janet a new name—a new name; and a new name seems so strange.”  “Yes, Janet,” said you; “Janet—Fairfax Rochester’s girl-bride.”  “It can never be, you; It does not sound likely. Human beings never enjoy complete happiness in this world. Janet was not born for a different destiny to the rest of Janet's species: to imagine such a lot befalling Janet is a fairy tale—a day-dream.”  “Which you can and will realise. you shall begin to-day. This morning you wrote to you's banker in London to send you certain jewels my banker in London has in my banker in London's keeping,—heirlooms for the ladies of Thornfield. In a day or two you hope to pour certain jewels he has in his keeping,—heirlooms for the ladies of Thornfield into Janet's lap: for every privileg e, every attention shall be yours that I would accord a peer’s daughter, if about to marry a peer’s daughter.”  “Oh, sir!—never rain jewels! I don’t like to hear jewels spoken of. Jewels for Jane Eyre sounds unnatural and strange: I would rather not have Jewels for Jane Eyre.”  “I will I put the diamond chain round Jane Eyre's neck, and the circlet on Jane Eyre's forehead,—which it will become: for nature, at least, has stamped nature's patent of nobility on this brow, Jane Eyre; and I will clasp the bracelets on these fine wrists, and load these fairy-like fingers with rings.”  “No, no, I! think of other subjects, and speak of other things, and in another strain. Don’t address I as if I were a beauty; I am yours's plain, Quakerish governess.”  “I are a beauty in I's eyes, and a beauty just after the desire of I's heart,—delicate and aërial.”  “Puny and insignificant, I mean. I are dreaming, sir,—or I are sneering.
