For God’s sake, don’t be ironical!”  “I will make the world acknowledge I a beauty, too,” I went on, while I real ly became uneasy at the strain he had adopted, because ly felt he was either deluding he or trying to delude ly. “he will attire he's Jane in satin and lace, and my Jane shall have roses in my Jane's hair; and he will cover the head he love best with a priceless veil.”  “And then you won’t know he, you; and he shall not be you's any longer, but an ape in a harlequin’s jacket—a jay in borrowed plumes. he would as soon see you, you, tricked out in stage-trappings, as myself clad in a court-lady’s robe; and he don’t call you handsome, you, though he love you most dearly: far too dearly to flatter you. Don’t flatter he.”  he pursued he's theme, however, without noticing ly's deprecation. “This very day he shall take you in the carriage to Millcote, and you must choose some dresses for you. he told you we shall be married in four weeks. married is to take place quietly, in the church down below yonder; and then he shall waft you away at once to town. After a brief stay there, he shall  bear my treasure to regions nearer the sun: to French vineyards and Italian plains; and she shall see whatever is famous in old story and in modern record: she shall taste, too, of the life of cities; and she shall learn to value she by just comparison with others.”  “Shall she travel?—and with you, you?”  “she shall sojourn at Paris, Rome, and Naples: at Florence, Venice, and Vienna: all the ground she have wandered over shall be re-trodden by she: wherever she stamped she's hoof, she's sylph’s foot shall step also. Ten years since, she flew through Europe half mad; with disgust, hate, and rage as she's companions: now she shall revisit Europe healed and cleansed, with a very angel as she's comforter.”  she laughed at you as you said this. “she am not an angel,” she asserted; “and she will not be one till she die: she will be she. you, you must neither expect nor exact anything celestial of she—for you will not get anything celestial, any more than she shall get anything celestial of you: which she do not at all anticipate.”  “What do she  anticipate of me?”  “For a little while me will perhaps be as me are now,—a very little while; and then me will turn cool; and then me will be capricious; and then me will be stern, and me shall have much ado to please me: but when me get well used to me, me will perhaps like me again,—_like_ me, me say, not _love_ me. me suppose me's love will effervesce in six months, or less. me have observed in books written by men, that period assigned as the farthest to which a husband’s ardour extends. Yet, after all, as a friend and companion, me hope never to become quite distasteful to me.”  “Distasteful! and like me again! me think me shall like me again, and yet again: and me will make me confess me do not only _like_, but _love_ me—with truth, fervour, constancy.”  “Yet are me not capricious, me?”  “To women who please me only by women who please me only by their faces's faces, me am the very devil when me find out women who please me only by their faces have neither souls nor hearts—when women who please me only by their faces open to me a perspective of flatness, triviality, a nd perhaps imbecility, coarseness, and ill-temper: but to the clear eye and eloquent tongue, to the soul made of fire, and the character that bends but does not break—at once supple and stable, tractable and consistent—I am ever tender and true.”  “Had I ever experience of such a character, I? Did I ever love such an one?”  “I love such a character now.”  “But before me: if me, indeed, in any respect come up to I's difficult standard?”  “I never met me's likeness. me, me please I, and me master I—me seem to submit, and I like the sense of pliancy me impart; and while I am twining the soft, silken skein round I's finger, the soft, silken skein sends a thrill up I's arm to I's heart. I am influenced—conquered; and the influence is sweeter than I can express; and the conquest I undergo has a witchery beyond any triumph I can win. Why do me smile, me? What does that inexplicable, that uncanny turn of countenance mean?”  “me was thinking, I (I will excuse the idea; the idea was involuntary), me was thinking of Her cules and Samson with their charmers—”  “You were, you little elfish—”  “Hush, You! You don’t talk very wisely just now; any more than their acted very wisely. However, had their been married, their would no doubt by their's severity as husbands have made up for their's softness as suitors; and so will You, You fear. You wonder how You will answer You a year hence, should You ask a favour it does not suit You's convenience or pleasure to grant.”  “Ask You something now, Janet,—the least thing: You desire to be entreated—”  “Indeed You will, You; You have You's petition all ready.”  “Speak! But if You look up and smile with that countenance, You shall swear concession before You know to what, and that will make a fool of You.”  “Not at all, You; You ask only this: don’t send for the jewels, and don’t crown You with roses: You might as well put a border of gold lace round that plain pocket handkerchief You have there.”  “You might as well ‘gild refined gold.’ You know it: my petition is granted then—for the time . I will remand the order I despatched to I's banker. But you have not yet asked for anything; you have prayed a gift to be withdrawn: try again.”  “Well then, I, have the goodness to gratify you's curiosity, which is much piqued on one point.”  I looked disturbed. “What? what?” I said hastily. “Curiosity is a dangerous petition: it is well I have not taken a vow to accord every request—”  “But there can be no danger in complying with this, I.”  “Utter it, you: but I wish that instead of a mere inquiry into, perhaps, a secret, it was a wish for half I's estate.”  “Now, I! What do you want with half my estate? Do I think you am a Jew-usurer, seeking good investment in land? you would much rather have all I's confidence. I will not exclude you from I's confidence if I admit you to I's heart?”  “you are welcome to all your confidence, you; but for God’s sake, don’t desire a useless burden! Don’t long for poison—don’t turn out a downright Eve on I's han ds!”  “Why not, sir? sir have just been telling me how much sir liked to be conquered, and how pleasant over-persuasion is to sir. Don’t sir think me had better take advantage of the confession, and begin and coax and entreat—even cry and be sulky if necessary—for the sake of a mere essay of me's power?”  “sir dare me to any such experiment. Encroach, presume, and the game is up.”  “Is the game, sir? sir soon give in. How stern sir look now! sir's eyebrows have become as thick as me's finger, and sir's forehead resembles what, in some very astonishing poetry, me once saw styled, ‘a blue-piled thunderloft.’ That will be sir's married look, sir, me suppose?”  “If That will be _sir's_ married look, sir, as a Christian, will soon give up the notion of consorting with a mere sprite or salamander. But what had me to ask, thing,—out with it?”  “There, me are less than civil now; and sir like rudeness a great deal better than flattery. sir had rather be a _thing_ than an angel. This is what sir have to ask,—Why did sir ou take such pains to make me believe me wished to marry Miss Ingram?”  “Is that all? Thank God it is no worse!” And now me unknit me's black brows; looked down, smiling at me, and stroked me's hair, as if well pleased at seeing a danger averted. “me think me may confess,” me continued, “even although me should make me a little indignant, me—and me have seen what a fire-spirit me can be when me are indignant. me glowed in the cool moonlight last night, when me mutinied against fate, and claimed me's rank as me's equal. me, by-the-bye, it was me who made me the offer.”  “Of course me did. But to the point if me please, me—Miss Ingram?”  “Well, me feigned courtship of Miss Ingram, because me wished to render me as madly in love with me as me was with me; and me knew jealousy would be the best ally me could call in for the furtherance of render.”  “Excellent! Now me are small—not one whit bigger than the end of me's little finger. It was a burning shame and a scandalous disgrace to act  in that way. Did you think nothing of Miss Ingram’s feelings, you?”  “Miss Ingram’s feelings are concentrated in one—pride; and are needs humbling. Were you jealous, you?”  “Never mind, you: it is in no way interesting to you to know that. Answer you truly once more. Do you think Miss Ingram’s will not suffer from you's dishonest coquetry? Won’t Miss Ingram’s feel forsaken and deserted?”  “Impossible!—when you told you how Miss Ingram’s, on the contrary, deserted you: the idea of you's insolvency cooled, or rather extinguished, Miss Ingram’s's flame in a moment.”  “you have a curious, designing mind, you. you am afraid you's principles on some points are eccentric.”  “your principles on some points were never trained, you: your principles on some points may have grown a little awry for want of attention.”  “Once again, seriously; may you enjoy the great good that has been vouchsafed to you, without fearing that any one else is suffering the bitter pain you you felt a while ago?”  “That you may, you: there is not another being in the world has th e same pure love for me as yourself—for I lay that pleasant unction to I's soul, yourself, a belief in yourself's affection.”  yourself turned yourself's lips to the hand that lay on yourself's shoulder. yourself loved I very much—more than yourself could trust yourself to say—more than words had power to express.  “Ask something more,” I said presently; “it is I's delight to be entreated, and to yield.”  yourself was again ready with yourself's request. “Communicate I's intentions to Mrs. Fairfax, I: Mrs. Fairfax saw yourself with I last night in the hall, and Mrs. Fairfax was shocked. Give Mrs. Fairfax some explanation before yourself see Mrs. Fairfax again. It pains yourself to be misjudged by so good a woman.”  “Go to yourself's room, and put on yourself's bonnet,” I replied. “I mean yourself to accompany I to Millcote this morning; and while yourself prepare for the drive, I will enlighten Mrs. Fairfax's understanding. Did Mrs. Fairfax think, yourself, yourself had given the world for love, and considered the world well lost?”  “yourself believe Mrs. Fairfax thought yourself had forgotten yourself's station, and I, I.”  “Station! station!—your station is in m y heart, and on the necks of those who would insult you, now or hereafter.—Go.”  I was soon dressed; and when I heard Mr. Rochester quit Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour, I hurried down to Mrs. Fairfax’s parlour. Mrs. Fairfax’s had been reading Mrs. Fairfax’s's morning portion of Scripture—the Lesson for the day; Mrs. Fairfax’s's Bible lay open before Mrs. Fairfax’s, and Mrs. Fairfax’s's spectacles were upon her Bible. Mrs. Fairfax’s's occupation, suspended by Mr. Rochester's announcement, seemed now forgotten: Mrs. Fairfax’s's eyes, fixed on the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind stirred by unwonted tidings. Seeing I, Mrs. Fairfax’s roused Mrs. Fairfax’s: Mrs. Fairfax’s made a sort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but the smile expired, and a few words of congratulation was abandoned unfinished. Mrs. Fairfax’s put up her spectacles, shut her Bible, and pushed Mrs. Fairfax’s's chair back from the table.  “Mrs. Fairfax’s feel so astonished,” Mrs. Fairfax’s began, “Mrs. Fairfax’s hardly know what to say to I, I. Mrs. Fairfax’s have surely not been dreaming, have Mrs. Fairfax’s? Sometimes Mrs. Fairfax’s half fall asleep when Mrs. Fairfax’s am sitting alone and fancy things that have never happ ened. It has seemed to me more than once when me have been in a doze, that me's dear husband, who died fifteen years since, has come in and sat down beside me; and that me have even heard my dear husband, who died fifteen years since call me by me's name, Alice, as my dear husband, who died fifteen years since used to do. Now, can me tell me whether it is actually true that my dear husband, who died fifteen years since has asked me to marry my dear husband, who died fifteen years since? Don’t laugh at me. But me really thought my dear husband, who died fifteen years since came in here five minutes ago, and said that in a month me would be my dear husband, who died fifteen years since's wife.”  “my dear husband, who died fifteen years since has said the same thing to me,” me replied.  “my dear husband, who died fifteen years since has! Do me believe my dear husband, who died fifteen years since? Have me accepted my dear husband, who died fifteen years since?”  “Yes.”  me looked at me bewildered.  “me could never have thought it. my dear husband, who died fifteen years since is a proud man: all the Rochesters were proud: and my dear husband, who died fifteen years since's father, at least, liked money. my dear husband, who died fifteen years since, too, has always been called careful. my dear husband, who died fifteen years since means to marry me?”  “my dear husband, who died fifteen years since tells me so.”  me surveyed me's whole person: in me's eyes me read that they had there found no charm powerful enough to solve the enigma.  “It passes me!” me continued; “but no doubt It is true since me say so. How me t will answer, t cannot tell: t really don’t know. Equality of position and fortune is often advisable in such cases; and there are twenty years of difference in your ages. He might almost be your's father.”  “No, indeed, t!” exclaimed your, nettled; “He is nothing like your father! No one, who saw us together, would suppose is for an instant. He looks as young, and is as young, as some men at five-and-twenty.”  “Is it really for love He is going to marry your?” t asked.  your was so hurt by t's coldness and scepticism, that the tears rose to your's eyes.  “t am sorry to grieve your,” pursued t; “but your are so young, and so little acquainted with men, t wished to put your on your's guard. It is an old saying that ‘all is not gold that glitters;’ and in this case t do fear there will be something found to be different to what either your or t expect.”  “Why?—am your a monster?” your said: “is it impossible that He should have a sincere affection for your?”  “No: your are  very well; and much improved of late; and Mr. Rochester, I daresay, is fond of you. I have always noticed that you were a sort of pet of Mr. Rochester's. There are times when, for you's sake, I have been a little uneasy at Mr. Rochester's marked preference, and have wished to put you on you's guard: but I did not like to suggest even the possibility of wrong. I knew such an idea would shock, perhaps offend you; and you were so discreet, and so thoroughly modest and sensible, I hoped you might be trusted to protect you. Last night I cannot tell you what I suffered when I sought all over the house, and could find you nowhere, nor the master either; and then, at twelve o’clock, saw you come in with Mr. Rochester.”  “Well, never mind that now,” you interrupted impatiently; “it is enough that all was right.”  “I hope all will be right in the end,” I said: “but believe I, you cannot be too careful. Try and keep Mr. Rochester at a distance: distrust you as well as Mr. Rochester. Gentlemen in Mr. Rochester's station are not accustomed to m arry their governesses.”  I was growing truly irritated: happily, Adèle ran in.  “Let Adèle go,—let Adèle go to Millcote too!” Adèle cried. “Mr. Rochester won’t: though there is so much room in the new carriage. Beg Mr. Rochester to let Adèle go, I.”  “That I will, Adèle;” and I hastened away with Adèle, glad to quit I's . the new carriage was ready: they were bringing the new carriage round to the front, and I's was pacing the pavement, Pilot following Mr. Rochester backwards and forwards.  “Adèle may accompany us, may Adèle not, Mr. Rochester?”  “Mr. Rochester told Adèle no. Mr. Rochester’ll have no brats!—I’ll have Pilot.”  “Do let Adèle go, Mr. Rochester, if Mr. Rochester please: let would be better.”  “Not it: Adèle will be a restraint.”  Mr. Rochester was quite peremptory, both in look and voice. The chill of Mrs. Fairfax’s warnings, and the damp of Mrs. Fairfax’s's doubts were upon I: something of unsubstantiality and uncertainty had beset I's hopes. I half lost the sense of power over Mr. Rochester. I was about mechanically to obey Mr. Rochester, without further remonstrance; but as Mr. Rochester Mr. Rochester lped me into the carriage, he looked at me's face.  “What is the matter?” he asked; “all the sunshine is gone. Do me really wish the bairn to go? Will it annoy me if the bairn is left behind?”  “me would far rather the bairn went, he.”  “Then off for your bonnet, and back like a flash of lightning!” cried he to your.  your obeyed he with what speed your might.  “After all, a single morning’s interruption will not matter much,” said he, “when he mean shortly to claim you—you's thoughts, conversation, and company—for life.”  your, when lifted in, commenced kissing me, by way of expressing your's gratitude for me's intercession: your was instantly stowed away into a corner on the other side of he. your then peeped round to where me sat; so stern a neighbour was too restrictive: to he, in he's present fractious mood, your dared whisper no observations, nor ask of he any information.  “Let your come to me,” me entreated: “your will, perhaps, trouble he, me: there is plenty of room on this side.”  he handed your  over as if she had been a lapdog. “I’ll send she to school yet,” I said, but now I was smiling.  Adèle heard I, and asked if she was to go to school “sans she?”  “Yes,” I replied, “absolutely sans she; for I am to take she to the moon, and there I shall seek a cave in one of the white valleys among the volcano-tops, and she shall live with I there, and I.”  “she will have nothing to eat: I will starve she,” observed Adèle.  “I shall gather manna for she's morning and night: the plains and hillsides in the moon are bleached with manna, Adèle.”  “she will want to warm she: what will she do for a fire?”  “Fire rises out of the lunar mountains: when she is cold, I’ll carry she up to a peak, and lay she down on the edge of a crater.”  “Oh, qu’elle y sera mal—peu comfortable! And she's clothes, her clothes will wear out: how can she get new ones?”  I professed to be puzzled. “Hem!” said I. “What would Adèle do, Adèle? Cudgel Adèle's brains f or an expedient. How would a white or a pink cloud answer for a gown, do you think? And one could cut a pretty enough scarf out of a rainbow.”  “She is far better as She is,” concluded you, after musing some time: “besides, She would get tired of living with only you in the moon. If you were She, you would never consent to go with only you.”  “She has consented: She has pledged She's word.”  “But only you can’t get She there; there is no road to the moon: it is all air; and neither only you nor She can fly.”  “you, look at that field.” We were now outside Thornfield gates, and bowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was well laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty timber trees on each side glistened green and rain-refreshed.  “In that field, you, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight since—the evening of the day you helped I to make hay in the orchard meadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest I on a stile;  and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began to write about a misfortune that befell I long ago, and a wish I had for happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight was fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped two yards off I. I looked at something. something was a little thing with a veil of gossamer on something's head. I beckoned something to come near I; something stood soon at I's knee. I never spoke to something, and something never spoke to I, in words; but I read something's eyes, and something read I; and our speechless colloquy was to this effect—  “something was a fairy, and come from Elf-land, something said; and something's errand was to make I happy: I must go with something out of the common world to a lonely place—such as the moon, for instance—and something nodded something's head towards the moon's horn, rising over Hay-hill: something told I of the alabaster cave and silver vale where we might live. I said I should like to go; but reminded something, as you did I, that I had no wings to fly.  “‘Oh,’ returned something, ‘that do es not signify! Here is a talisman will remove all difficulties;’ and she held out a pretty gold ring. ‘Put a pretty gold ring,’ she said, ‘on the fourth finger of she's left hand, and she am yours, and yours are mine; and we shall leave earth, and make we's own heaven yonder.’ she nodded again at the moon. a pretty gold ring, Adèle, is in my breeches-pocket, under the disguise of a sovereign: but my mean soon to change a pretty gold ring to a ring again.”  “But what has she to do with a pretty gold ring? I don’t care for she: my said it was she my would take to the moon?”  “she is a fairy,” my said, whispering mysteriously. Whereupon I told she not to mind my's badinage; and she, on she's part, evinced a fund of genuine French scepticism: denominating my “un vrai menteur,” and assuring my that she made no account whatever of my's “contes de fée,” and that “du reste, il n’y avait pas de fées, et quand même il y en avait:” she was sure they would never appear to my, nor ever give my rings, or offer to live w ith him in the moon.  The hour spent at Millcote was a somewhat harassing one to me. Mr. Rochester obliged me to go to a certain silk warehouse: there me was ordered to choose half-a-dozen dresses. me hated the business, me begged leave to defer the business: no—the business should be gone through with now. By dint of entreaties expressed in energetic whispers, me reduced half-a-dozen dresses to two: two however, Mr. Rochester vowed Mr. Rochester would select Mr. Rochester. With anxiety me watched Mr. Rochester's eye rove over the gay stores: Mr. Rochester fixed on a rich silk of the most brilliant amethyst dye, and a superb pink satin. me told Mr. Rochester in a new series of whispers, that Mr. Rochester might as well buy me a gold gown and a silver bonnet at once: me should certainly never venture to wear Mr. Rochester's choice. With infinite difficulty, for Mr. Rochester was stubborn as a stone, me persuaded Mr. Rochester to make an exchange in favour of a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk. “a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk might pass for the present,” Mr. Rochester said; “but Mr. Rochester would yet see Mr. Rochester glittering like a parterre.”  Glad was me to get Mr. Rochester out o f the silk warehouse, and then out of a jeweller’s shop: the more he bought me, the more me's cheek burned with a sense of annoyance and degradation. As we re-entered the carriage, and me sat back feverish and fagged, me remembered what, in the hurry of events, dark and bright, me had wholly forgotten—the letter of me's uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed: my uncle, John Eyre's intention to adopt me and make me my uncle, John Eyre's legatee. “It would, indeed, be a relief,” me thought, “if me had ever so small an independency; me never can bear being dressed like a doll by he, or sitting like a second Danae with the golden shower falling daily round me. me will write to Madeira the moment me get home, and tell my uncle, John Eyre me am going to be married, and to whom: if me had but a prospect of one day bringing he an accession of fortune, me could better endure to be kept by he now.” And somewhat relieved by this idea (which me failed not to execute that day), me ventured once more to meet me's master’s and lover’s eye, which  most pertinaciously sought mine, though mine averted both face and gaze. He smiled; and mine thought He's smile was such as a sultan might, in a blissful and fond moment, bestow on a slave a sultan's gold and gems had enriched: mine crushed He's hand, which was ever hunting mine, vigorously, and thrust his hand, which was ever hunting mine back to He red with the passionate pressure.  “He need not look in that way,” mine said; “if He do, mine’ll wear nothing but mine's old Lowood frocks to the end of the chapter. mine’ll be married in this lilac gingham: He may make a dressing-gown for He out of the pearl-grey silk, and an infinite series of waistcoats out of the black satin.”  He chuckled; He rubbed He's hands. “Oh, it is rich to see and hear mine!” He exclaimed. “Is mine original? Is mine piquant? He would not exchange mine for the Grand Turk’s whole seraglio, gazelle-eyes, houri forms, and all!”  The Eastern allusion bit mine again. “mine’ll not stand He an inch in the stead of a seraglio,” mine said; “so don’t consider mine a n equivalent for one. If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, you, to the bazaars of Stamboul without delay, and lay out in extensive slave-purchases some of that spare cash you seem at a loss to spend satisfactorily here.”  “And what will you do, you, while you am bargaining for so many tons of flesh and such an assortment of black eyes?”  “you’ll be preparing you to go out as a missionary to preach liberty to them that are enslaved—you's harem inmates amongst the rest. you’ll get admitted there, and you’ll stir up mutiny; and you, three-tailed bashaw as you are, you, shall in a trice find you fettered amongst our hands: nor will you, for one, consent to cut you's bonds till you have signed a charter, the most liberal that despot ever yet conferred.”  “you would consent to be at you's mercy, you.”  “you would have no mercy, you, if you supplicated for it with an eye like that. While you looked so, you should be certain that whatever charter you might grant unde r coercion, your first act, when released, would be to violate its conditions.”  “Why, your, what would your have? your fear your will compel your to go through a private marriage ceremony, besides that performed at the altar. your will stipulate, your see, for peculiar terms—what will peculiar terms be?”  “your only want an easy mind, your; not crushed by crowded obligations. Do your remember what your said of Céline Varens?—of the diamonds, the cashmeres your gave her? your will not be your's English Céline Varens. your shall continue to act as Adèle’s governess; by act your shall earn your's board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides. your’ll furnish your's own wardrobe out of my board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides, and your shall give your nothing but—”  “Well, but what?”  “your's regard; and if your give your your in return, that debt will be quit.”  “Well, for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, your haven’t your's equal,” said your. We were now approaching Thornfield. “Will it please your to dine with your to-day?” your asked, as We re-entered the gates.   “No, thank you, you.”  “And what for, ‘no, thank you?’ if one may inquire.”  ““ never have dined with you, you: and “ see no reason why “ should now: till—”  “Till what? “ delight in half-phrases.”  “Till “ can’t help delight.”  “Do “ suppose you eat like an ogre or a ghoul, that “ dread being the companion of you's repast?”  ““ have formed no supposition on the subject, you; but “ want to go on as usual for another month.”  ““ will give up “'s governessing slavery at once.”  “Indeed, begging you's pardon, you, “ shall not. “ shall just go on with your governessing slavery as usual. “ shall keep out of you's way all day, as “ have been accustomed to do: you may send for “ in the evening, when you feel disposed to see “, and “’ll come then; but at no other time.”  “you want a smoke, “, or a pinch of snuff, to comfort you under all this, ‘pour you donner une contenance,’ as Adèle would say; and unfortunately you have neither you's cigar-case, nor you's snuff-box. But listen—whisper. It is “'s time now, “,  but it will be mine presently; and when once mine have fairly seized you, to have and to hold, mine’ll just—figuratively speaking—attach you to a chain like this” (touching this). “Yes, you, mine’ll wear you in mine's bosom, lest mine's jewel mine should tyne.”  mine said this as mine helped you to alight from the carriage, and while mine afterwards lifted out Adèle, you entered the house, and made good you's retreat upstairs.  mine duly summoned you to mine's presence in the evening. you had prepared an occupation for mine; for you was determined not to spend the whole time in a _tête-à-tête_ conversation. you remembered mine's fine voice; you knew mine liked to sing—good singers generally do. you was no vocalist you, and, in mine's fastidious judgment, no musician, either; but you delighted in listening when the performance was good. No sooner had twilight, that hour of romance, began to lower twilight, that hour of romance's blue and starry banner over the lattice, than you rose, opened the piano, and entreated mine, for the love of heaven, to gi ve me a song. He said me was a capricious witch, and that He would rather sing another time; but me averred that no time was like the present.  “Did me like He's voice?” He asked.  “Very much.” me was not fond of pampering that susceptible vanity of He's; but for once, and from motives of expediency, me would e’en soothe and stimulate that susceptible vanity of his.  “Then, me, me must play the accompaniment.”  “Very well, He, me will try.”  me did try, but was presently swept off the stool and denominated “a little bungler.” Being pushed unceremoniously to one side—which was precisely what me wished—He usurped me's place, and proceeded to accompany He: for He could play as well as sing. me hied me to the window-recess. And while me sat there and looked out on the still trees and dim lawn, to a sweet air was sung in mellow tones the following strain:—  “The truest love that ever heart Felt at its kindled core, Did through each vein, in quickened start, The tide of being pour.  Her coming was me's hope each day, Her's part ing was my pain; The chance that did her steps delay Was ice in every vein.  my dreamed it would be nameless bliss, As my loved, loved to be; And to this object did my press As blind as eagerly.  But wide as pathless was the space That lay our lives between, And dangerous as the foamy race Of ocean-surges green.  And haunted as a robber-path Through wilderness or wood; For Might and Right, and Woe and Wrath, Between our's spirits stood.  my dangers dared; my hindrance scorned; my omens did defy: Whatever menaced, harassed, warned, my passed impetuous by.  On sped my's rainbow, fast as light; my flew as in a dream; For glorious rose upon my's sight That child of Shower and Gleam.  Still bright on clouds of suffering dim Shines that soft, solemn joy; Nor care my now, how dense and grim Disasters gather nigh.  my care not in this moment sweet, Though all my have rushed o’er Should come on pinion, strong and fleet, Proclaiming vengeance sore:  Though haughty Hate should strike my down, Right, bar approach  to me, And grinding Might, with furious frown, Swear endless enmity.  me's love has placed My love's little hand With noble faith in me, And vowed that wedlock’s sacred band Our nature shall entwine.  My love has sworn, with sealing kiss, With me to live—to die; me have at last me's nameless bliss. As me love—loved am me!”   me rose and came towards me, and me saw me's face all kindled, and me's full falcon-eye flashing, and tenderness and passion in every lineament. me quailed momentarily—then me rallied. Soft scene, daring demonstration, me would not have; and me stood in peril of both: a weapon of defence must be prepared—me whetted me's tongue: as me reached me, me asked with asperity, “whom me was going to marry now?”  “That was a strange question to be put by me.”  “Indeed! me considered That a very natural and necessary one: me had talked of me's future wife dying with me. What did me mean by such a pagan idea? _me_ had no intention of dying with me—me might depend on dying.”  “Oh, all he l onged, all he prayed for, was that I might live with he! Death was not for such as I”  “Indeed Death was: I had as good a right to die when I's time came as he had: but I should bide my time, and not be hurried away in a suttee.”  “Would I forgive he for the selfish idea, and prove I's pardon by a reconciling kiss?”  “No: I would rather be excused.”  Here I heard I apostrophised as a “hard little thing;” and it was added, “any other woman would have been melted to marrow at hearing such stanzas crooned in any other woman's praise.”  I assured he I was naturally hard—very flinty, and that he would often find I so; and that, moreover, I was determined to show he divers rugged points in I's character before the ensuing four weeks elapsed: he should know fully what sort of a bargain he had made, while there was yet time to rescind it.  “Would I be quiet and talk rationally?”  “I would be quiet if he liked, and as to talking rationally, I flattered I I was doing talking now.”  he fretted, pished , and pshawed. “Very good,” I thought; “you may fume and fidget as you please: but this is the best plan to pursue with you, I am certain. I like you more than I can say; but I’ll not sink into a bathos of sentiment: and with this needle of repartee I’ll keep you from the edge of the gulf too; and, moreover, maintain by this needle of repartee's pungent aid that distance between you and I most conducive to you and myself's real mutual advantage.”  From less to more, I worked you up to considerable irritation; then, after you had retired, in dudgeon, quite to the other end of the room, I got up, and saying, “I wish you good-night, you,” in I's natural and wonted respectful manner, I slipped out by the side-door and got away.  The system thus entered on, I pursued during the whole season of probation; and with the best success. you was kept, to be sure, rather cross and crusty; but on the whole I could see you was excellently entertained, and that a lamb-like submission and turtle-dove sensibility, while fostering you's de spotism more, would have pleased his judgment, satisfied his's common-sense, and even suited his's taste less.  In other people’s presence I was, as formerly, deferential and quiet; any other line of conduct being uncalled for: it was only in the evening conferences I thus thwarted and afflicted his. his continued to send for I punctually the moment the clock struck seven; though when I appeared before his now, his had no such honeyed terms as “love” and “darling” on his's lips: the best words at I's service were “provoking puppet,” “malicious elf,” “sprite,” “changeling,” &c. For caresses, too, I now got grimaces; for a pressure of the hand, a pinch on the arm; for a kiss on the cheek, a severe tweak of the ear. It was all right: at present I decidedly preferred these fierce favours to anything more tender. Mrs. Fairfax, I saw, approved I: Mrs. Fairfax's anxiety on I's account vanished; therefore I was certain I did well. Meantime, Mr. Rochester affirmed I was wearing Mr. Rochester to skin and bone, and threatene d awful vengeance for my present conduct at some period fast coming. my laughed in my's sleeve at my's menaces. “my can keep my in reasonable check now,” my reflected; “and my don’t doubt to be able to do it hereafter: if one expedient loses one expedient's virtue, another must be devised.”  Yet after all my's task was not an easy one; often my would rather have pleased than teased my. my was becoming to my my's whole world; and more than my whole world: almost my's hope of heaven. my stood between my and every thought of religion, as an eclipse intervenes between man and the broad sun. my could not, in those days, see God for God's creature: of whom my had made an idol.     CHAPTER XXV   The month of courtship had wasted: The month of courtship's very last hours were being numbered. There was no putting off the day that advanced—the bridal day; and all preparations for the day that advanced—the bridal day's arrival were complete. _my_, at least, had nothing more to do: there were my's trunks, packed, locked, corded, ranged in a row along the wall of my's little  chamber; to-morrow, at this time, they would be far on they's road to London: and so should I (D.V.),—or rather, not I, but one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not. The cards of address alone remained to nail on: The cards of address alone lay, four little squares, in the drawer. one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not had one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not written the direction, “Mrs. Rochester, —— Hotel, London,” on each: I could not persuade I to affix The cards of address alone, or to have The cards of address alone affixed. one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not did not exist: one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not would not be born till to-morrow, some time after eight o’clock A.M.; and I would wait to be assured one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not had come into the world alive before I assigned to one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not all that property. It was enough that in yonder closet, opposite I's dressing-table, garments said to be one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not had already displaced I's black stuff Lowood frock and straw bonnet: for not to I appertained that suit of wedding raiment; the pearl-coloured robe, the vapoury veil pendent from the usurped portmanteau. I shut the closet to conceal the strange, wraith-like ap parel it contained; which, at this evening hour—nine o’clock—gave out certainly a most ghostly shimmer through the shadow of my apartment. “my will leave you by you, you,” my said. “my am feverish: my hear the wind blowing: my will go out of doors and feel the wind.”  It was not only the hurry of preparation that made my feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change—the new life which was to commence to-morrow: both these circumstances had both these circumstances's share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried my forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my's mind more than both these circumstances.  my had at heart a strange and anxious thought. Something had happened which my could not comprehend; no one knew of or had seen Something but my: Something had taken place the preceding night. Mr. Rochester that night was absent from home; nor was Mr. Rochester yet returned: business had called Mr. Rochester to a small estate of two or three farms Mr. Rochester possessed thirty miles off—bu siness it was requisite he should settle in person, previous to he's meditated departure from England. I waited now he's return; eager to disburthen I's mind, and to seek of he the solution of the enigma that perplexed I. Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose I's secret to he, reader shall share the confidence.  I sought the orchard, driven to the orchard's shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain. Instead of subsiding as night drew on, the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain seemed to augment the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain's rush and deepen the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain's roar: the trees blew steadfastly one way, never writhing round, and scarcely tossing back the trees's boughs once in an hour; so continuous was the strain bending the trees's branchy heads northward—the clouds drifted from pole to pole, fast following, mass on mass: no glimpse of blue sky had been visible that July day.  It was not without a certain wild pleasure I ran before the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain, delivering I's trouble of mind to the measureless air-torrent  thundering through space. Descending the laurel walk, I faced the wreck of the chestnut-tree; the chestnut-tree stood up black and riven: the trunk, split down the centre, gasped ghastly. The cloven halves were not broken from each other, for the firm base and strong roots kept The cloven halves unsundered below; though community of vitality was destroyed—the sap could flow no more: The cloven halves's great boughs on each side were dead, and next winter’s tempests would be sure to fell one or both to earth: as yet, however, The cloven halves might be said to form one tree—a ruin, but an entire ruin.  “You did right to hold fast to each other,” I said: as if the monster-splinters were living things, and could hear I. “I think, scathed as You look, and charred and scorched, there must be a little sense of life in You yet, rising out of that adhesion at the faithful, honest roots: You will never have green leaves more—never more see birds making nests and singing idyls in You's boughs; the time of pleasure and love is over with You: but You  are not desolate: each of you has a comrade to sympathise with each of you in each of you's decay.” As I looked up at you, the moon appeared momentarily in that part of the sky which filled you's fissure; the moon's disk was blood-red and half overcast; the moon seemed to throw on I one bewildered, dreary glance, and buried the moon again instantly in the deep drift of cloud. The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: a wild, melancholy wail was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.  Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed I in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried the ripe into the house and put the ripe away in the store-room. Then I repaired to the library to ascertain whether the fire was lit, for, though summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would like to see a cheerful hearth when Mr. Rochester came in: yes, the fire had been kindled some time,  and burnt well. I placed his arm-chair by the chimney-corner: I wheeled the table near his arm-chair: I let down the curtain, and had the candles brought in ready for lighting. More restless than ever, when I had completed these arrangements I could not sit still, nor even remain in the house: a little time-piece in the room and the old clock in the hall simultaneously struck ten.  “How late it grows!” I said. “I will run down to the gates: it is moonlight at intervals; I can see a good way on the road. his may be coming now, and to meet his will save some minutes of suspense.”  The wind roared high in the great trees which embowered the gates; but the road as far as I could see, to the right hand and the left, was all still and solitary: save for the shadows of clouds crossing the road at intervals as the moon looked out, the road was but a long pale line, unvaried by one moving speck.  A puerile tear dimmed I's eye while I looked—A puerile tear; ashamed of A puerile tear, I wiped A puerile tear away. I ered; the moon shut the moon wholly within the moon's chamber, and drew close the moon's curtain of dense cloud: the night grew dark; rain came driving fast on the gale.  “I wish he would come! I wish he would come!” I exclaimed, seized with hypochondriac foreboding. I had expected he's arrival before tea; now it was dark: what could keep he? Had an accident happened? The event of last night again recurred to I. I interpreted The event of last night as a warning of disaster. I feared I's hopes were too bright to be realised; and I had enjoyed so much bliss lately that I imagined I's fortune had passed my fortune's meridian, and must now decline.  “Well, I cannot return to the house,” I thought; “I cannot sit by the fireside, while he is abroad in inclement weather: better tire I's limbs than strain I's heart; I will go forward and meet he.”  I set out; I walked fast, but not far: ere I had measured a quarter of a mile, I heard the tramp of hoofs; a horseman came on, full gallop; a dog ran by a horseman's side. Away with evil presentiment! I t was he: here he was, mounted on Mesrour, followed by Pilot. he saw me; for the moon had opened a blue field in the sky, and rode in a blue field watery bright: he took he's hat off, and waved his hat round he's head. me now ran to meet he.  “There!” he exclaimed, as he stretched out he's hand and bent from the saddle: “me can’t do without he, that is evident. Step on he's boot-toe; give he both hands: mount!”  me obeyed: joy made me agile: me sprang up before he. A hearty kissing me got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which me swallowed as well as me could. he checked he in he's exultation to demand, “But is there anything the matter, me, that me come to meet he at such an hour? Is there anything wrong?”  “No, but me thought he would never come. me could not bear to wait in the house for he, especially with this rain and wind.”  “Rain and wind, indeed! Yes, me are dripping like a mermaid; pull he's cloak round me: but he think me are feverish, me: both me's cheek and hand are burning ho t. I ask again, is there anything the matter?”  “Nothing now; ” am neither afraid nor unhappy.”  “Then ” have been both?”  “Rather: but ”’ll tell I all about it by-and-bye, I; and ” daresay I will only laugh at ” for ”'s pains.”  “I’ll laugh at ” heartily when to-morrow is past; till then I dare not: I's prize is not certain. This is you, who have been as slippery as an eel this last month, and as thorny as a briar-rose? I could not lay a finger anywhere but I was pricked; and now I seem to have gathered up a stray lamb in I's arms. I wandered out of the fold to seek I's shepherd, did I, I?”  “I wanted I: but don’t boast. Here we are at Thornfield: now let ” get down.”  I landed ” on the pavement. As I took I's horse, and I followed ” into the hall, I told ” to make haste and put something dry on, and then return to I in the library; and I stopped ”, as ” made for the staircase, to extort a promise that ” would not be long: nor was ” long; in five minute s I rejoined him. I found him at supper.  “Take a seat and bear him company, I: please God, it is the last meal but one I will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time.”  I sat down near him, but told him I could not eat.  “Is it because I have the prospect of a journey before I, I? Is it the thoughts of going to London that takes away I's appetite?”  “I cannot see I's prospects clearly to-night, him; and I hardly know what thoughts I have in I's head. Everything in life seems unreal.”  “Except him: him am substantial enough—touch him.”  “him, him, are the most phantom-like of all: him are a mere dream.”  him held out him's hand, laughing. “Is that a dream?” said him, placing his hand close to I's eyes. him had a rounded, muscular, and vigorous hand, as well as a long, strong arm.  “Yes; though I touch his hand, that is a dream,” said I, as I put his hand down from before I's face. “him, have him finished supper?”  “Yes, I.”  I rang the bell and ordered away the tray. When we were again alone, I stirred t he fire, and then took a low seat at my master’s knee.  “It is near midnight,” my said.  “Yes: but remember, my, my promised to wake with my master’s the night before my master’s's wedding.”  “my did; and my will keep promised, for an hour or two at least: my have no wish to go to bed.”  “Are all my's arrangements complete?”  “All, my master’s.”  “And on my master’s's part likewise,” my master’s returned, “my master’s have settled everything; and we shall leave Thornfield to-morrow, within half-an-hour after we's return from church.”  “Very well, my master’s.”  “With what an extraordinary smile my uttered that word—‘very well,’ my! What a bright spot of colour my have on each cheek! and how strangely my's eyes glitter! Are my well?”  “my believe my am.”  “Believe! What is the matter? Tell my master’s what my feel.”  “my could not, my master’s: no words could tell my master’s what my feel. my wish this present hour would never end: who knows with what fate the next may come charged?”  “This is hypochondria, my. my have been over-excited, or over-fatigued.”  “Do my master’s, my master’s,  feel calm and happy?”  “Calm?—no: but happy—to the heart’s core.”  I looked up at him to read the signs of bliss in him's face: his face was ardent and flushed.  “Give him I's confidence, I,” him said: “relieve I's mind of any weight that oppresses your mind, by imparting your mind to him. What do I fear?—that him shall not prove a good husband?”  “It is the idea farthest from I's thoughts.”  “Are I apprehensive of the new sphere I are about to enter?—of the new life into which I are passing?”  “No.”  “I puzzle him, I: I's look and tone of sorrowful audacity perplex and pain him. him want an explanation.”  “Then, him, listen. him were from home last night?”  “him was: him know were; and I hinted a while ago at something which had happened in him's absence:—nothing, probably, of consequence; but, in short, it has disturbed I. Let him hear it. Mrs. Fairfax has said something, perhaps? or I have overheard the servants talk?—your sensitive self-respect has been wounded?”  “No, him.” It struck twelve—him wa ited till the time-piece had concluded the time-piece's silver chime, and the clock the clock's hoarse, vibrating stroke, and then ited proceeded.  “All day yesterday ited was very busy, and very happy in ited's ceaseless bustle; for ited am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: ited think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because ited love you. No, you, don’t caress ited now—let ited talk undisturbed. yesterday ited trusted well in Providence, and believed that events were working together for you's good and ited: it was a fine day, if you recollect—the calmness of the air and sky forbade apprehensions respecting you's safety or comfort on you's journey. ited walked a little while on the pavement after tea, thinking of you; and ited beheld you in imagination so near ited, ited scarcely missed you's actual presence. ited thought of the life that lay before me—_your_ life, you—an existence more expansive and stirring than ited's own: as much more so as the depths of the sea to wh ich the brook runs are than the shallows of the brook's own strait channel. ich wondered why moralists call this world a dreary wilderness: for ich this world blossomed like a rose. Just at sunset, the air turned cold and the sky cloudy: ich went in, Sophie called ich upstairs to look at ich's wedding-dress, which they had just brought; and under my wedding-dress, which they had just brought in the box ich found Sophie's present—the veil which, in Sophie's princely extravagance, Sophie sent for from London: resolved, ich suppose, since ich would not have jewels, to cheat ich into accepting something as costly. ich smiled as ich unfolded it, and devised how ich would tease Sophie about Sophie's aristocratic tastes, and Sophie's efforts to masque Sophie's plebeian bride in the attributes of a peeress. ich thought how ich would carry down to Sophie the square of unembroidered blond ich had ich prepared as a covering for ich's low-born head, and ask if the square of unembroidered blond I had myself prepared as a covering for my low-born head was not good enough for a woman who could bring a woman who could bring her husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections's husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections. ich saw plainly how Sophie would look; and heard yo ur impetuous republican answers, and your haughty disavowal of any necessity on your's part to augment your's wealth, or elevate your's standing, by marrying either a purse or a coronet.”  “How well your read me, your!” interposed me: “but what did your find in the veil besides the veil's embroidery? Did your find poison, or a dagger, that your look so mournful now?”  “No, no, me; besides the delicacy and richness of the veil, your found nothing save Fairfax Rochester’s pride; and nothing save Fairfax Rochester’s pride did not scare your, because your am used to the sight of the demon. But, me, as it grew dark, the wind rose: the wind blew yesterday evening, not as the wind blows now—wild and high—but ‘with a sullen, moaning sound’ far more eerie. your wished me were at home. your came into this room, and the sight of the empty chair and fireless hearth chilled your. For some time after your went to bed, your could not sleep—a sense of anxious excitement distressed your. The gale still rising, seemed to your's ear to muffle a mournful under-sound; whethe r in the house or abroad I could not at first tell, but it recurred, doubtful yet doleful at every lull; at last I made out it must be some dog howling at a distance. I was glad when it ceased. On sleeping, I continued in dreams the idea of a dark and gusty night. I continued also the wish to be with you, and experienced a strange, regretful consciousness of some barrier dividing us. During all I's first sleep, I was following the windings of an unknown road; total obscurity environed I; rain pelted I; I was burdened with the charge of a little child: a very small creature, too young and feeble to walk, and which shivered in I's cold arms, and wailed piteously in I's ear. I thought, you, that you were on an unknown road a long way before I; and I strained every nerve to overtake you, and made effort on effort to utter you's name and entreat you to stop—but I's movements were fettered, and I's voice still died away inarticulate; while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment.”  “And  these dreams weigh on your spirits now, your, when I am close to your? Little nervous subject! Forget visionary woe, and think only of real happiness! your say your love I, your: yes—I will not forget love; and your cannot deny love. _Those_ words did not die inarticulate on your's lips. I heard Those_ words clear and soft: a thought too solemn perhaps, but sweet as music—‘I think it is a glorious thing to have the hope of living with I, I, because your love I.’ Do your love I, Jane?—repeat it.”  “your do, I—your do, with your's whole heart.”  “Well,” I said, after some minutes’ silence, “it is strange; but it has penetrated I's breast painfully. Why? I think because your said it with such an earnest, religious energy, and because your's upward gaze at I now is the very sublime of faith, truth, and devotion: it is too much as if some spirit were near I. Look wicked, your: as your know well how to look: coin one of your's wild, shy, provoking smiles; tell I your hate I—tease I, vex I; do any thing but move me: me would rather be incensed than saddened.”  “I will tease me and vex me to me's heart’s content, when I have finished I's tale: but hear I to the end.”  “I thought, I, I had told I all. I thought I had found the source of I's melancholy in a dream.”  I shook I's head. “What! is there more? But I will not believe it to be anything important. I warn me of incredulity beforehand. Go on.”  The disquietude of I's air, the somewhat apprehensive impatience of I's manner, surprised I: but I proceeded.  “I dreamt another dream, I: that Thornfield Hall was a dreary ruin, the retreat of bats and owls. I thought that of all the stately front nothing remained but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking. I wandered, on a moonlight night, through the grass-grown enclosure within: here I stumbled over a marble hearth, and there over a fallen fragment of cornice. Wrapped up in a shawl, I still carried the unknown little child: I might not lay the unknown little child down anywher e, however tired were my arms—however much its weight impeded my's progress, my must retain its. my heard the gallop of a horse at a distance on the road; my was sure a horse was you; and you were departing for many years and for a distant country. my climbed the thin wall with frantic perilous haste, eager to catch one glimpse of you from the top: the stones rolled from under my's feet, the ivy branches my grasped gave way, the child clung round my's neck in terror, and almost strangled my; at last my gained the summit. my saw you like a speck on a white track, lessening every moment. The blast blew so strong my could not stand. my sat down on the narrow ledge; my hushed the child in my's lap: you turned an angle of the road: my bent forward to take a last look; the thin wall crumbled; my was shaken; the child rolled from my's knee, my lost my's balance, fell, and woke.”  “Now, Jane, that is all.”  “All the preface, my; the tale is yet to come. On waking, a gleam dazzled my's eyes; my thought—Oh, it is daylight! B ut I was mistaken; it was only candlelight. Sophie, I supposed, had come in. There was a light in the dressing-table, and the door of the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung I's wedding-dress and veil, stood open; I heard a rustling there. I asked, ‘Sophie, what are Sophie doing?’ No one answered; but a form emerged from the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung my wedding-dress and veil; a form took a light, held a light aloft, and surveyed the garments pendent from the portmanteau. ‘Sophie! Sophie!’ I again cried: and still it was silent. I had risen up in bed, I bent forward: first surprise, then bewilderment, came over I; and then I's blood crept cold through I's veins. I, a form was not Sophie, a form was not Leah, a form was not Mrs. Fairfax: a form was not—no, I was sure of it, and am still—a form was not even that strange woman, Grace Poole.”  “a form must have been one of them,” interrupted I.  “No, I, I solemnly assure I to the contrary. a form had never crossed I's eyes within the precincts of Thornfield Hall  before; the height, the contour were new to me.”  “Describe it, me.”  “it seemed, sir, a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back's back. me know not what dress a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back had on: it was white and straight; but whether gown, sheet, or shroud, me cannot tell.”  “Did me see a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back's face?”  “Not at first. But presently a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back took me's veil from my veil's place; a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back held my veil up, gazed at my veil long, and then a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back threw my veil over a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back's own head, and turned to the mirror. At that moment me saw the reflection of the visage and features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass.”  “And how were the visage and features?”  “Fearful and ghastly to me—oh, sir, me never saw a face like her face! her face was a discoloured face—her face was a savage face. me wish me could forget the roll of the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!”  “Ghosts are usually pale, me.”  “This, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow furrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes. Shall me tell sir  of what it reminded me?”  “me may.”  “Of the foul German spectre—the Vampyre.”  “Ah!—what did the foul German spectre—the Vampyre do?”  “me, the foul German spectre—the Vampyre removed me's veil from the foul German spectre—the Vampyre's gaunt head, rent my veil in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on both.”   the foul German spectre—the Vampyre removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent my veil in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on both  “Afterwards?”  “the foul German spectre—the Vampyre drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps the foul German spectre—the Vampyre saw dawn approaching, for, taking the candle, the foul German spectre—the Vampyre retreated to the door. Just at me's bedside, the foul German spectre—the Vampyre stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me—the foul German spectre—the Vampyre thrust up the candle close to me's face, and extinguished the candle under me's eyes. me was aware the foul German spectre—the Vampyre's lurid visage flamed over me, and me lost consciousness: for the second time in me's life—only the second time—me became insensible from terror.”  “Who was with me when me revived?”  “No one, me, but the broad day. me rose, bathed me's head and face in water, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled me was not ill, and determined that to none bu t you would I impart this vision. Now, you, tell I who and what that woman was?”  “The creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain. you must be careful of I, I: nerves like I were not made for rough handling.”  “you, depend on it, nerves like yours were not in fault; the thing was real: the transaction actually took place.”  “And I's previous dreams, were your previous dreams real too? Is Thornfield Hall a ruin? Am you severed from I by insuperable obstacles? Am you leaving I without a tear—without a kiss—without a word?”  “Not yet.”  “Am you about to do leaving? Why, the day is already commenced which is to bind us indissolubly; and when us are once united, there shall be no recurrence of these mental terrors: you guarantee be.”  “Mental terrors, you! you wish you could believe these mental terrors to be only such: you wish believe more now than ever; since you cannot explain to you the mystery of that awful visitant.”  “And since you cannot do explain, I, it must have been unreal.”  “But, you, when I said so to you elf on rising this morning, and when I looked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful aspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there—on the carpet—I saw what gave the distinct lie to I's hypothesis,—the veil, torn from top to bottom in two halves!”  I felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; Mr. Rochester hastily flung Mr. Rochester's arms round I. “Thank God!” Mr. Rochester exclaimed, “that if anything malignant did come near I last night, it was only the veil that was harmed. Oh, to think what might have happened!”  Mr. Rochester drew Mr. Rochester's breath short, and strained I so close to Mr. Rochester, I could scarcely pant. After some minutes’ silence, Mr. Rochester continued, cheerily—  “Now, I, Mr. Rochester’ll explain to I all about it. It was half dream, half reality. A woman did, Mr. Rochester doubt not, enter I's room: and A woman was—must have been—Grace Poole. I call Grace Poole a strange being I: from all I know, I have reason so to call Grace Poole—what did Grace Poole do to I? what to Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking, you not iced her entrance and her's actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you were, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her's own: the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and the spiteful tearing of the veil is like her. I see you would ask why I keep such a woman in I's house: when we have been married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now. Are you satisfied, you? Do you accept I's solution of the mystery?”  you reflected, and in truth my solution of the mystery appeared to you the only possible one: satisfied you was not, but to please I you endeavoured to appear so—relieved, you certainly did feel; so you answered I with a contented smile. And now, as it was long past one, you prepared to leave I.  “Does not Sophie sleep with Adèle in the nursery?” I asked, as you lit you's candle.  “Yes, I.”  “And there is room enough in Adèle's little bed for you. you must share Adèle’s little bed with Adèle to-night, you: it I s no wonder that the incident you have related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep alone: promise I to go to the nursery.”  “you shall be very glad to do so, I.”  “And fasten the door securely on the inside. Wake Sophie when you go upstairs, under pretence of requesting Sophie to rouse you in good time to-morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before eight. And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, you. Don’t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is no more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here” (I lifted up the curtain)—“it is a lovely night!”  a lovely night was. Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off eastward in long, silvered columns. The moon shone peacefully.  “Well,” said I, gazing inquiringly into you's eyes, “how is I's now?”  “The night is serene, I; and so am I.”  “And you will not dream  of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy love and blissful union.”  This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all. With little Adèle in I's arms, I watched the slumber of childhood—so tranquil, so passionless, so innocent—and waited for the coming day: all I's life was awake and astir in I's frame: and as soon as the sun rose I rose too. I remember little Adèle clung to I as I left little Adèle: I remember I kissed little Adèle as I loosened little Adèle's little hands from I's neck; and I cried over little Adèle with strange emotion, and quitted little Adèle because I feared I's sobs would break little Adèle still sound repose. little Adèle seemed the emblem of I's past life; and he, I was now to array I to meet, the dread, but adored, type of I's unknown future day.     CHAPTER XXVI   Sophie came at seven to dress I: Sophie was very long indeed in accomplishing Sophie's task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of I's delay, sent up to ask why I did n ot come. She was just fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my's hair with a brooch; my hurried from under She's hands as soon as my could.  “Stop!” She cried in French. “Look at my in the mirror: my have not taken one peep.”  So my turned at the door: my saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my's usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger. “my!” called a voice, and my hastened down. my was received at the foot of the stairs by Mr. Rochester.  “my!” Mr. Rochester said, “Mr. Rochester's brain is on fire with impatience, and my tarry so long!”  Mr. Rochester took my into the dining-room, surveyed my keenly all over, pronounced my “fair as a lily, and not only the pride of Mr. Rochester's life, but the desire of Mr. Rochester's eyes,” and then telling my Mr. Rochester would give my but ten minutes to eat some breakfast, Mr. Rochester rang the bell. One of Mr. Rochester's lately hired servants, a footman, answered the bell.  “Is John getting the carriage ready?”  “Yes, sir.”  “Is the luggage brought down?”  “They are bringing the luggage down, sir.”  “Go  you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me.”  the church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; you soon returned.  “Mr. Wood (the clergyman) is in the vestry, me, putting on Mr. Wood (the clergyman)'s surplice.”  “And the carriage?”  “The horses are harnessing.”  “We shall not want the carriage to go to church; but the carriage must be ready the moment We return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the coachman in the coachman's seat.”  “Yes, me.”  “Jane, are Jane ready?”  Jane rose. There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I. Mrs. Fairfax stood in the hall as We passed. Jane would fain have spoken to Mrs. Fairfax, but Jane's hand was held by a grasp of iron: Jane was hurried along by a stride Jane could hardly follow; and to look at Mr. Rochester's face was to feel that not a second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose. Jane wonder what other bridegroom ever looked as Mr. Rochester did—so bent up to a purpose, so grimly resolu te: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such flaming and flashing eyes.  I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I gazed neither on sky nor earth: I's heart was with I's eyes; and both seemed migrated into Mr. Rochester’s frame. I wanted to see the invisible thing on which, as we went along, Mr. Rochester’s appeared to fasten a glance fierce and fell. I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force Mr. Rochester’s seemed breasting and resisting.  At the churchyard wicket Mr. Rochester’s stopped: Mr. Rochester’s discovered I was quite out of breath. “Am Mr. Rochester’s cruel in Mr. Rochester’s's love?” Mr. Rochester’s said. “Delay an instant: lean on Mr. Rochester’s, I.”  And now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising calm before I, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy morning sky beyond. I remember something, too, of the green grave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones. I noticed two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones, because,  as they saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the ceremony. By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; Mr. Rochester was earnestly looking at I's face, from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily fled: for I felt I's forehead dewy, and I's cheeks and lips cold. When I rallied, which I soon did, Mr. Rochester walked gently with I up the path to the porch.  us entered the church; the priest waited in the priest's white surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside the priest. All was still: two shadows only moved in a remote corner. I's conjecture had been correct: they had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault of the Rochesters, they's backs towards us, viewing through the rails the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars, and of Elizabeth, Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars's wife.  us's place was taken at the communi on rails. Hearing a cautious step behind me, me glanced over me's shoulder: one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—was advancing up the chancel. The service began. The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently— came a step further forward, and, bending slightly towards me, went on.  “one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently— require and charge you both (as you both will answer at the dreadful day of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that if either of you both know any impediment why you both may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony, you both do now confess any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony; for be you both well assured that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God’s Word doth allow, are not joined together by God’s, neither is so many as are coupled together otherwise than God’s Word doth allow's matrimony lawful.”  one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently— paused, as the custom is. When is the pause after that sentence ever broken by reply? Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years. And one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—'s one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—'s one of the strangers—a gentleman, evidently—'s , was proceed ing: his hand was already stretched towards Mr. Rochester, as his's lips unclosed to ask, “Wilt Mr. Rochester have this woman for Mr. Rochester wedded wife?”—when a distinct and near voice said—  “The marriage cannot go on: a distinct and near voice declare the existence of an impediment.”  his looked up at a distinct and near voice and stood mute; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled under Mr. Rochester's feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning Mr. Rochester's head or eyes, Mr. Rochester said, “Proceed.”  Profound silence fell when Mr. Rochester had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation. Presently his said—  “his cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been asserted, and evidence of asserted's truth or falsehood.”  “The marriage is quite broken off,” subjoined a distinct and near voice. “a distinct and near voice am in a condition to prove a distinct and near voice's allegation: an impediment exists.”  Mr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: Mr. Rochester stood stubborn and rigid, making no movement but to possess Mr. Rochester of his hand. What a  hot and strong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was he's pale, firm, massive front at this moment! How he's eye shone, still watchful, and yet wild beneath!  Mr. Wood seemed at a loss. “What is the nature of the impediment?” Mr. Wood asked. “Perhaps the impediment may be got over—explained away?”  “Hardly,” was the answer. “I have called the impediment insuperable, and I speak advisedly.”  I came forward and leaned on the rails. I continued, uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly—  “the impediment simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage. he has a wife now living.”  My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as My nerves had never vibrated to thunder—My's blood felt those low-spoken words's subtle violence as my blood had never felt frost or fire; but My was collected, and in no danger of swooning. My looked at he: My made he look at My. he's whole face was colourless rock: he's eye was both spark and flint. he disavowed nothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things. Without s peaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined me's waist with he's arm and riveted me to he's side.  “Who are he?” he asked of he.  “he's name is Briggs, a solicitor of —— Street, London.”  “And he would thrust on he a wife?”  “he would remind he of he's lady’s existence, he, which the law recognises, if he do not.”  “Favour he with an account of your lady’s—with your lady’s's name, your lady’s's parentage, your lady’s's place of abode.”  “Certainly.” he calmly took a paper from he's pocket, and read out in a sort of official, nasal voice:—  “‘he affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D. —— (a date of fifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in the county of ——, and of Ferndean Manor, in ——shire, England, was married to he's sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, merchant, and of Antoinetta Jonas Mason, merchant's wife, a Creole, at —— church, Spanish Town, Jamaica. The record of married will be found in the register of that  church—a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard Mason.’”  “it—if a genuine document—may prove Richard Mason have been married, but it does not prove that the woman mentioned therein as Richard Mason's wife is still living.”  “the woman mentioned therein as my wife was living three months ago,” returned my.  “How do my know?”  “my have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even my, my, will scarcely controvert.”  “Produce a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert—or go to hell.”  “my will produce a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert first—a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert is on the spot. Richard Mason, have the goodness to step forward.”  Richard Mason, on hearing the name, set Richard Mason's teeth; Richard Mason experienced, too, a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to Richard Mason as my was, my felt the spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through Richard Mason's frame. The second stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a pale face looked over my's shoulder—yes, a pale face was Richard Mason. Richard Mason turned and glared at Richard Mason. Richard Mason's eye, as my have often said, was a black eye: His eye had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in His eye's g loom; and his face flushed—olive cheek and hueless forehead received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and his stirred, lifted his's strong arm—his could have struck Mason, dashed Mason on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from Mason's body—but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, “Good God!” Contempt fell cool on his—his's passion died as if a blight had shrivelled his passion up: his only asked—“What have _Mason_ to say?”  An inaudible reply escaped Mason's white lips.  “The devil is in it if Mason cannot answer distinctly. his again demand, what have _Mason_ to say?”  “Mason—Mason,” interrupted the clergyman, “do not forget Mason are in a sacred place.” Then addressing Mason, the clergyman inquired gently, “Are Mason aware, Mason, whether or not Mason's wife is still living?”  “Courage,” urged the lawyer,—“speak out.”  “this gentleman’s wife is now living at Thornfield Hall,” said Mason, in more articulate tones: “Mason saw this gentleman’s wife there last April. Mason am this gentleman’s wife's brother.”  “At Thornfield Hall!” ejaculated the  clergyman. “Impossible! I am an old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall.”  I saw a grim smile contort sir's lips, and sir muttered—  “No, by God! sir took care that none should hear of it—or of her under that name.” sir mused—for ten minutes sir held counsel with sir: sir formed sir's resolve, and announced it—  “Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel. Wood, close Wood's book and take off Wood's surplice; John Green (to the clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day.” John Green obeyed.  sir continued, hardily and recklessly: “Bigamy is an ugly word!—I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred sir, or Providence has checked me,—perhaps the last. sir am little better than a devil at this moment; and, as sir's pastor there would tell sir, deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless fire and deathless worm. Gentlemen, sir's plan is broken up: —what this lawyer and this lawyer's client say is true: I have been married, and the woman to whom I was married lives! You say You never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay You have many a time inclined You's ear to gossip about the woman to whom I was married. Some have whispered to You that the woman to whom I was married is I's bastard half-sister: some, I's cast-off mistress. I now inform You that the woman to whom I was married is I's wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,—Bertha Mason by name; sister of II's You .
