Cheer up, Dick!—never fear me!—I’d almost as soon strike a woman as You. the woman to whom I was married is mad; and the woman to whom I was married came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs through three generations! the woman to whom I was married's mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman and a drunkard!—as I found out after I had wed the woman to whom I was married: for a mad family were silent on family secrets before. the woman to whom I was married, like a dutiful child, copied Her mother, the Creole I n both points. I had a charming partner—pure, wise, modest: you can fancy I was a happy man. I went through rich scenes! Oh! I's experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it! But I owe you no further explanation. Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite Briggs, Wood, Mason to come up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole’s patient, and _I's wife_! Briggs, Wood, Mason shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy with something at least human. my wife,” I continued, looking at I, “knew no more than Wood, Wood, of the disgusting secret: my wife thought all was fair and legal; and never dreamt my wife was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad, and embruted partner! Come Briggs, Wood, Mason—follow!”  Still holding I fast, I left the church: Briggs, Wood, Mason came after. At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.  “Take the carriage back to the coach-house, John,” said Mr. Rochester coolly;  “it will not be wanted to-day.”  At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet and greet our.  “To the right-about—every soul!” cried the master; “away with Mrs. Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie, Leah's congratulations! Who wants your congratulations? Not I!—they are fifteen years too late!”  the master passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still beckoning the gentlemen to follow the master, which the gentlemen did. our mounted the first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey: the low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester’s master-key, admitted our to the tapestried room, with the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet's great bed and the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet's pictorial cabinet.  “my know this place, my,” said the master; “she bit and stabbed my here.”  the master lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: the second door, too, the master opened. In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a chain. Grace Poole bent over a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, apparently cooking something in a saucepan. In the de ep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure ran backwards and forwards. What a figure was, whether beast or human being, one could not, at first sight, tell: a figure grovelled, seemingly, on all fours; a figure snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but a figure was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild as a mane, hid a figure's head and face.  “Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!” said Mr. Rochester. “How are Mrs. Poole? and how is Mrs. Poole's charge to-day?”  “We’re tolerable, Mr. Rochester, Mrs. Poole thank Mr. Rochester,” replied Mrs. Poole, lifting the boiling mess carefully on to the hob: “rather snappish, but not ’rageous.”  A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to Mrs. Poole's favourable report: a figure rose up, and stood tall on a figure's hind-feet.  “Ah! Mr. Rochester, a figure sees Mr. Rochester!” exclaimed Mrs. Poole: “Mr. Rochester’d better not stay.”  “Only a few moments, Mrs. Poole: Mrs. Poole must allow Mr. Rochester a few moments.”  “Take care then, sir!—for God’s sake, take care!”  a figure bellowed: a figure parted a figure's shaggy locks from a figure's visage, and gazed wildly at a figure's visit ors. I recognised well that purple face,—those bloated features. Mrs. Poole advanced.  “Keep out of the way,” said Mr. Rochester, thrusting Mrs. Poole aside: “Mrs. Poole has no knife now, Mr. Rochester suppose, and Mr. Rochester’m on Mr. Rochester's guard.”  “One never knows what Mrs. Poole has, Mr. Rochester: Mrs. Poole is so cunning: it is not in mortal discretion to fathom Mrs. Poole's craft.”  “We had better leave Mrs. Poole,” whispered Mason.  “Go to the devil!” was Mason's recommendation.  “’Ware!” cried Grace. We retreated simultaneously. Mr. Rochester flung I behind Mr. Rochester: Mrs. Poole sprang and grappled Mr. Rochester's throat viciously, and laid Mrs. Poole's teeth to Mr. Rochester's cheek: they struggled. Mrs. Poole was a big woman, in stature almost equalling Mr. Rochester, and corpulent besides: Mrs. Poole showed virile force in the contest—more than once Mrs. Poole almost throttled Mr. Rochester, athletic as Mr. Rochester was. Mr. Rochester could have settled Mrs. Poole with a well-planted blow; but Mr. Rochester would not strike: Mr. Rochester would only wrestle. At last Mr. Rochester mastered Mrs. Poole's arms; Grace gave Mr. Rochester a cord, and Mr. Rochester pinioned them behind  her: with more rope, which was at hand, he bound her to a chair. bound was performed amidst the fiercest yells and the most convulsive plunges. he then turned to the spectators: he looked at the spectators with a smile both acrid and desolate.  “her is _he's wife_,” said he. “Such is the sole conjugal embrace he am ever to know—such are the endearments which are to solace he's leisure hours! And _her_ is what he wished to have” (laying he's hand on my shoulder): “her, he wanted her just as a change after that fierce ragout. Wood and Briggs, look at the difference! Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder—this face with that mask—this form with that bulk; then judge he, priest of the gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment Wood and Briggs judge Wood and Briggs shall be judged! Off with the spectators now. he must shut up he's prize.”  the spectators withdrew. he stayed a moment beh ind us, to give some further order to Grace Poole. The solicitor addressed me as The solicitor descended the stair.  “me, me,” said The solicitor, “are cleared from all blame: me's uncle will be glad to hear it—if, indeed, your uncle should be still living—when your uncle returns to Madeira.”  “your uncle What of your uncle? Do The solicitor know your uncle?”  “your uncle does. Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of your uncle's house for some years. When your uncle received me's letter intimating the contemplated union between me and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason, who was staying at Madeira to recruit your uncle's health, on your uncle's way back to Jamaica, happened to be with your uncle. Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence; for Mr. Eyre knew that your uncle was acquainted with Mr. Rochester. your uncle, astonished and distressed as me may suppose, revealed the real state of matters. your uncle, The solicitor am sorry to say, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of your uncle's disease—decline—and the stage his disease—decline has reached, it is unlikely your uncle  will ever rise. He could not then hasten to England He, to extricate you from the snare into which you had fallen, but He implored Mr. Mason to lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage. He referred Mr. Mason to me for assistance. me used all despatch, and am thankful me was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also. Were me not morally certain that you's uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, me would advise you to accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, me think you had better remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of Mr. Eyre. Have we anything else to stay for?” me inquired of Mr. Mason.  “No, no—let we be gone,” was the anxious reply; and without waiting to take leave of me, we made we's exit at the hall door. me stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or reproof, with me's ; this duty done, he too departed.  me heard me go as me stood at the half-open door of me's own room, to which me h ad now withdrawn. The house cleared, I shut I in, fastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded—not to weep, not to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but—mechanically to take off the wedding dress, and replace the wedding dress by the stuff gown I had worn yesterday, as I thought, for the last time. I then sat down: I felt weak and tired. I leaned I's arms on a table, and I's head dropped on my arms. And now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen, moved—followed up and down where I was led or dragged—watched event rush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but _now_, _I thought_.  The morning had been a quiet morning enough—all except the brief scene with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy; there was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no defiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken, a calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made; some stern, short questions put by Mr. Rochester; answers, explanation s given, evidence adduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master; then the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all was over.  my was in my's own room as usual—just myself, without obvious change: nothing had smitten my, or scathed my, or maimed my. And yet where was the Jane Eyre of yesterday?—where was her life?—where were her's prospects?  her, was a cold, solitary girl again: her's life was pale; her's prospects were desolate. A Christmas frost had come at midsummer; a white December storm had whirled over June; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed the blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes which last night blushed full of flowers, to-day were pathless with untrodden snow; and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and fragrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and white as pine-forests in wintry Norway. my's hopes were all  dead—struck with a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born in the land of Egypt. I looked on I's cherished wishes, yesterday so blooming and glowing; my cherished wishes, yesterday so blooming and glowing lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could never revive. I looked at I's love: that feeling which was I's master’s—which my master’s had created; my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created shivered in I's heart, like a suffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created; my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created could not seek my master’s's arms—my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created could not derive warmth from my master’s's breast. Oh, never more could my love: that feeling which was my master’s—which he had created turn to my master’s; for faith was blighted—confidence destroyed! my master’s was not to I what my master’s had been; for my master’s was not what I had thought my master’s. I would not ascribe vice to my master’s; I would not say my master’s had betrayed I; but the attribute of stainless truth was gone from my master’s's idea, and from my master’s's presence I must go: _that_ I perceived well. When—how—whither, I could not yet discern; but my master’smy master’s, I doubted not, would hurry I from Thornfield. Real affection, it seemed, my master’s could not ha ve for me; it had been only fitful passion: only fitful passion was balked; he would want me no more. me should fear even to cross he's path now: me's view must be hateful to he. Oh, how blind had been me's eyes! How weak me's conduct!  my eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round me, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow. Self-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, me seemed to have laid me down in the dried-up bed of a great river; me heard a flood loosened in remote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise me had no will, to flee me had no strength. me lay faint, longing to be dead. One idea only still throbbed life-like within me—a remembrance of God: One idea begot an unuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in me's rayless mind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to express these words—  “Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.”  It was near: and as me had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert It—as me had neither  joined my hands, nor bent my's knees, nor moved my's lips—it came: in full heavy swing it poured over my. The whole consciousness of my's life lorn, my's love lost, my's hope quenched, my's faith death-struck, swayed full and mighty above my in one sullen mass. That bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, “the waters came into my's soul; my sank in deep mire: my felt no standing; my came into deep waters; the floods overflowed my.”     CHAPTER XXVII   Some time in the afternoon my raised my's head, and looking round and seeing the western sun gilding the sign of the western sun's decline on the wall, my asked, “What am my to do?”  But the answer my's mind gave—“Leave Thornfield at once”—was so prompt, so dread, that my stopped my's ears. my said my could not bear such words now. “That my am not Edward Rochester’s bride is the least part of my's woe,” my alleged: “that my have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and found them all void and vain, is a horror my could bear and master; but that my must leave Edward Rochester’s decidedly, in stantly, entirely, is intolerable. I cannot do it.”  But, then, a voice within I averred that I could do it and foretold that I should do it. I wrestled with I's own resolution: I wanted to be weak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw laid out for I; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the throat, told Passion tauntingly, Passion had yet but dipped Passion's dainty foot in the slough, and swore that with that arm of iron Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the throat would thrust Passion down to unsounded depths of agony.  “Let I be torn away, then” I cried. “Let another help I!”  “No; I shall tear I away, none shall help I: I shall I pluck out I's right eye; I cut off I's right hand: I's heart shall be the victim, and I the priest to transfix your heart.”  I rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a judge haunted,—at the silence which so awful a voice filled. I's head swam as I stood erect. I perceived that I was sickening from excitement and inanition; I ther meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for my had taken no breakfast. And, with a strange pang, my now reflected that, long as my had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask how my was, or to invite my to come down: not even little Adèle had tapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought my. “Friends always forget those whom fortune forsakes,” my murmured, as my undrew the bolt and passed out. my stumbled over an obstacle: my's head was still dizzy, my's sight was dim, and my's limbs were feeble. my could not soon recover my. my fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm caught my. my looked up—my was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my's chamber threshold.  “my come out at last,” Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold said. “Well, Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold have been waiting for my long, and listening: yet not one movement have Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold heard, nor one sob: five minutes more of that death-like hush, and Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold should have forced the lock like a burglar. So my shun me?—you shut my up and grieve alone! my woul d rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence. you are passionate: me expected a scene of some kind. me was prepared for the hot rain of tears; only me wanted tears to be shed on me's breast: now a senseless floor has received tears, or you's drenched handkerchief. But me err: you have not wept at all! me see a white cheek and a faded eye, but no trace of tears. me suppose, then, you's heart has been weeping blood?”  “Well, you! not a word of reproach? Nothing bitter—nothing poignant? Nothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion? you sit quietly where me have placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look.  “you, me never meant to wound you thus. If the man who had but one little ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of him's bread and drank of him's cup, and lay in him's bosom, had by some mistake slaughtered but one little ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of his bread and drank of his cup, and lay in his bosom at the shambles, him would not have rued him's bloody blunder more than me now rue me. Will you ever forgive me?”  Reader, me forgave me at the moment and on the spot . There was such deep remorse in his eye, such true pity in his's tone, such manly energy in his's manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in his's whole look and mien—I forgave his all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only at I's heart’s core.  “I know his am a scoundrel, I?” ere long his inquired wistfully—wondering, I suppose, at I's continued silence and tameness, the result rather of weakness than of will.  “Yes, his.”  “Then tell his so roundly and sharply—don’t spare his.”  “I cannot: I am tired and sick. I want some water.” his heaved a sort of shuddering sigh, and taking I in his's arms, carried I downstairs. At first I did not know to what room his had borne I; all was cloudy to I's glazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for, summer as it was, I had become icy cold in I's chamber. his put wine to I's lips; I tasted wine and revived; then I ate something his offered I, and was soon I. I was in the library—sitting in his's chair—his was quite near. “If I c ould go out of life now, without too sharp a pang, it would be well for me,” me thought; “then me should not have to make the effort of cracking me's heart-strings in rending my heart-strings from among Mr. Rochester’s. me must leave Mr. Rochester’s, it appears. me do not want to leave Mr. Rochester’s—me cannot leave Mr. Rochester’s.”  “How are me now, me?”  “Much better, ”; me shall be well soon.”  “Taste the wine again, me.”  me obeyed ”; then ” put the wine on the table, stood before me, and looked at me attentively. Suddenly ” turned away, with an inarticulate exclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; ” walked fast through the room and came back; ” stooped towards me as if to kiss me; but me remembered caresses were now forbidden. me turned me's face away and put ” aside.  “What!—How is this?” ” exclaimed hastily. “Oh, ” know! me won’t kiss Mr. Rochester’s? me consider ”'s arms filled and ”'s embraces appropriated?”  “At any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, ”.”  “Why, me? ” will spare  you the trouble of much talking; I will answer for you—Because you have a wife already, you would reply.—I guess rightly?”  “Yes.”  “If you think so, you must have a strange opinion of I; you must regard I as a plotting profligate—a base and low rake who has been simulating disinterested love in order to draw you into a snare deliberately laid, and strip you of honour and rob you of self-respect. What do you say to that? I see you can say nothing: in the first place, you are faint still, and have enough to do to draw you's breath; in the second place, you cannot yet accustom you to accuse and revile I, and besides, the flood-gates of tears are opened, and tears would rush out if you spoke much; and you have no desire to expostulate, to upbraid, to make a scene: you are thinking how _to act_—_talking_ you consider is of no use. I know you—I am on I's guard.”  “you, I do not wish to act against you,” I said; and I's unsteady voice warned I to curtail I's sentence.  “Not in _you's_ sens e of the word, but in _mine_ you are scheming to destroy me. you have as good as said that me am a married man—as a married man you will shun me, keep out of me's way: just now you have refused to kiss me. you intend to make you a complete stranger to me: to live under this roof only as Adèle’s governess; if ever me say a friendly word to you, if ever a friendly feeling inclines you again to me, you will say,—‘That man had nearly made you his mistress: you must be ice and rock to his;’ and ice and rock you will accordingly become.”  me cleared and steadied me's voice to reply: “All is changed about me, you; me must change too—there is no doubt of change; and to avoid fluctuations of feeling, and continual combats with recollections and associations, there is only one way—Adèle’s must have a new governess, you.”  “Oh, Adèle’s will go to school—me have settled go already; nor do me mean to torment you with the hideous associations and recollections of Thornfield Hall—this accursed place—this tent of  Achan—this insolent vault, offering the ghastliness of living death to the light of the open sky—this narrow stone hell, with its one real fiend, worse than a legion of such as we imagine. Jane, Jane shall not stay here, nor will I. I. was wrong ever to bring Jane to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I. did how Thornfield Hall was haunted. I. charged them to conceal from Jane, before I. ever saw Jane, all knowledge of the curse of Thornfield Hall; merely because I. feared Adèle never would have a governess to stay if Adèle knew with what inmate Adèle was housed, and I.'s plans would not permit I. to remove the maniac elsewhere—though I. possess an old house, Ferndean Manor, even more retired and hidden than this, where I. could have lodged Adèle safely enough, had not a scruple about the unhealthiness of the situation, in the heart of a wood, made I.'s conscience recoil from the arrangement. Probably those damp walls would soon have eased I. of Adèle's charge: but to each villain each villain's own vice; and mine is not a tendency to indirect a ssassination, even of what I most hate.  “Concealing the mad-woman’s neighbourhood from you, however, was something like covering a child with a cloak and laying a child down near a upas-tree: the mad-woman’s's vicinage is poisoned, and always was. But I’ll shut up Thornfield Hall: I’ll nail up the front door and board the lower windows: I’ll give Mrs. Poole two hundred a year to live here with the mad-woman’sI's you the mad-woman’s: Grace will do much for money, and the mad-woman’s shall have the mad-woman’s's son, the keeper at Grimsby Retreat, to bear the mad-woman’s's company and be at hand to give the mad-woman’s's aid in the paroxysms, when the mad-woman’s I's is prompted by the mad-woman’s's familiar to burn people in people's beds at night, to stab people, to bite people's flesh from people's bones, and so on—”  “I,” you interrupted I, “I are inexorable for the mad-woman’s: I speak of the mad-woman’s with hate—with vindictive antipathy. It is cruel—the mad-woman’s cannot help being mad.”  “you, you's little darling (so you will call you, for so you are), I don’t know what I are talking  about; you misjudge me again: it is not because she is mad me hate she. If you were mad, do you think me should hate you?”  “you do indeed, me.”  “Then you are mistaken, and you know nothing about me, and nothing about the sort of love of which me am capable. Every atom of you's flesh is as dear to me as me's own: in pain and sickness Every atom of your flesh would still be dear. you's mind is me's treasure, and if Your mind were broken, Your mind would be me's treasure still: if you raved, me's arms should confine you, and not a strait waistcoat—you's grasp, even in fury, would have a charm for me: if you flew at me as wildly as she did this morning, me should receive you in an embrace, at least as fond as it would be restrictive. me should not shrink from you with disgust as me did from she: in you's quiet moments you should have no watcher and no nurse but me; and me could hang over you with untiring tenderness, though you gave me no smile in return; and never weary of gazing into you's eyes, though your eyes had no longer a ray of rec ognition for me.—But why do I follow that train of ideas? I was talking of removing you from Thornfield. All, you know, is prepared for prompt departure: to-morrow you shall go. I only ask you to endure one more night under this roof, you; and then, farewell to Thornfield's miseries and terrors for ever! I have a place to repair to, which will be a secure sanctuary from hateful reminiscences, from unwelcome intrusion—even from falsehood and slander.”  “And take Adèle with I, I,” you interrupted; “Adèle will be a companion for I.”  “What do you mean, you? I told you I would send Adèle to school; and what do I want with a child for a companion, and not I's own child,—a French dancer’s bastard? Why do you importune I about Adèle! I say, why do I assign Adèle to I for a companion?”  “I spoke of a retirement, I; and retirement and solitude are dull: too dull for I.”  “Solitude! solitude!” I reiterated with irritation. “I see I must come to an explanation. I don’t know what sphynx-like ex pression is forming in your countenance. _your_ are to share my solitude. Do your understand?”  your shook your's head: it required a degree of courage, excited as my was becoming, even to risk that mute sign of dissent. my had been walking fast about the room, and my stopped, as if suddenly rooted to one spot. my looked at your long and hard: your turned your's eyes from my, fixed my eyes on the fire, and tried to assume and maintain a quiet, collected aspect.  “Now for the hitch in Jane’s character,” my said at last, speaking more calmly than from my's look your had expected my to speak. “The reel of silk has run smoothly enough so far; but my always knew there would come a knot and a puzzle: here a knot and a puzzle is. Now for vexation, and exasperation, and endless trouble! By God! my long to exert a fraction of Samson’s strength, and break the entanglement like tow!”  my recommenced my's walk, but soon again stopped, and this time just before your.  “your! will your hear reason?” (my stooped and approached my's lips to your's ear ); “because, if you won’t, I’ll try violence.” I's voice was hoarse; I's look that of a man who is just about to burst an insufferable bond and plunge headlong into wild license. I saw that in another moment, and with one impetus of frenzy more, I should be able to do nothing with I. The present—the passing second of time—was all I had in which to control and restrain I: a movement of repulsion, flight, fear would have sealed I's doom,—and I's. But I was not afraid: not in the least. I felt an inward power; a sense of influence, which supported I. The crisis was perilous; but not without The crisis's charm: such as the Indian, perhaps, feels when the Indian slips over the rapid in the Indian's canoe. I took hold of I's clenched hand, loosened the contorted fingers, and said to I, soothingly—  “Sit down; I’ll talk to I as long as I like, and hear all I have to say, whether reasonable or unreasonable.”  I sat down: but I did not get leave to speak directly. I had been struggling with tears for some  time: I had taken great pains to repress them, because I knew he would not like to see I weep. Now, however, I considered it well to let them flow as freely and as long as them liked. If the flood annoyed he, so much the better. So I gave way and cried heartily.  Soon I heard he earnestly entreating I to be composed. I said I could not while he was in such a passion.  “But he am not angry, I: he only love I too well; and I had steeled I's little pale face with such a resolute, frozen look, he could not endure it. Hush, now, and wipe I's eyes.”  he's softened voice announced that he was subdued; so I, in I's turn, became calm. Now he made an effort to rest he's head on I's shoulder, but I would not permit rest. Then he would draw I to he: no.  “I! Jane!” he said, in such an accent of bitter sadness such an accent of bitter sadness thrilled along every nerve I had; “I don’t love he, then? It was only he's station, and the rank of he's wife, that I valued? Now that I think he disqualified to become I's hus band, you recoil from my touch as if my were some toad or ape.”  These words cut you: yet what could you do or you say? you ought probably to have done or said nothing; but you was so tortured by a sense of remorse at thus hurting my's feelings, you could not control the wish to drop balm where you had wounded.  “you _do_ love my,” you said, “more than ever: but you must not show or indulge love: and this is the last time you must express love.”  “The last time, you! What! do you think you can live with my, and see my daily, and yet, if you still love my, be always cold and distant?”  “No, my; that you am certain you could not; and therefore you see there is but one way: but my will be furious if you mention but one way.”  “Oh, mention but one way! If my storm, you have the art of weeping.”  “my, you must leave my.”  “For how long, you? For a few minutes, while you smooth you's hair—which is somewhat dishevelled; and bathe you's face—which looks feverish?”  “you must leave Adèle and Thornfield. you must part with my for  my whole life: my must begin a new existence among strange faces and strange scenes.”  “Of course: I told my my should. I pass over the madness about parting from I. my mean my must become a part of I. As to a new existence among strange faces and strange scenes, it is all right: my shall yet be I's wife: I am not married. my shall be Mrs. Rochester—both virtually and nominally. I shall keep only to my so long as you and I live. my shall go to a place I have in the south of France: a place I have in the south of France. There my shall live a happy, and guarded, and most innocent life. Never fear that I wish to lure my into error—to make my I's mistress. Why did my shake my's head? my, my must be reasonable, or in truth I shall again become frantic.”  I's voice and hand quivered: I's large nostrils dilated; I's eye blazed: still my dared to speak.  “I, I's wife is living: is is a fact acknowledged this morning by I. If my lived with I as I desire, my should then be I's mistress : to say otherwise is sophistical—is false.”  “Jane, I am not a gentle-tempered man—Jane forget am: I am not long-enduring; I am not cool and dispassionate. Out of pity to I and Jane, put Jane's finger on I's pulse, feel how my pulse throbs, and—beware!”  I bared I's wrist, and offered his wrist to Jane: the blood was forsaking I's cheek and lips, his cheek and lips were growing livid; Jane was distressed on all hands. To agitate I thus deeply, by a resistance I so abhorred, was cruel: to yield was out of the question. Jane did what human beings do instinctively when human beings are driven to utter extremity—looked for aid to one higher than man: the words “God help Jane!” burst involuntarily from Jane's lips.  “I am a fool!” cried I suddenly. “I keep telling Jane I am not married, and do not explain to Jane why. I forget Jane knows nothing of the character of Jane, or of the circumstances attending I's infernal union with Jane. Oh, I am certain Jane will agree with I in opinion, when Jane knows all that I know!  Just put your hand in mine, your—that mine may have the evidence of touch as well as sight, to prove your are near mine—and mine will in a few words show your the real state of the case. Can your listen to mine?”  “Yes, mine; for hours if mine will.”  “mine ask only minutes. your, did your ever hear or know that mine was not the eldest son of mine's house: that mine had once a brother older than mine?”  “your remember Mrs. Fairfax told your so once.”  “And did your ever hear that mine's father was an avaricious, grasping man?”  “your have understood something to that effect.”  “Well, your, being so, it was my father's resolution to keep the property together; my father could not bear the idea of dividing the property and leaving mine a fair portion: all, my father resolved, should go to mine's brother, Rowland. Yet as little could my father endure that a son of my father's should be a poor man. mine must be provided for by a wealthy marriage. my father sought mine a partner betimes. Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was my father's old acquaintance. my father was certain my father's possessions  were real and vast: he made inquiries. Mr. Mason, he found, had a son and daughter; and he learned from Mr. Mason that he could and would give the latter a fortune of thirty thousand pounds: give sufficed. When I left college, I was sent out to Jamaica, to espouse a bride already courted for I. I's father said nothing about a bride already courted for me's money; but My father told I a bride already courted for me was the boast of Spanish Town for a bride already courted for me's beauty: and was was no lie. I found a bride already courted for me a fine woman, in the style of Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic. a bride already courted for me's family wished to secure I because I was of a good race; and so did a bride already courted for me. Her family showed a bride already courted for me to I in parties, splendidly dressed. I seldom saw a bride already courted for me alone, and had very little private conversation with a bride already courted for me. a bride already courted for me flattered I, and lavishly displayed for I's pleasure a bride already courted for me's charms and accomplishments. All the men in a bride already courted for me's circle seemed to admire a bride already courted for me and envy I. I was dazzled, stimulated: I's senses were excited; and being ignorant, raw, and inexperienced, I thought I loved a bride already courted for me. There is no folly s o besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience, the rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a man to a man's commission. Her relatives encouraged me; competitors piqued me; Her allured me: a marriage was achieved almost before me knew where me was. Oh, me have no respect for me when me think of that act!—an agony of inward contempt masters me. me never loved, me never esteemed, me did not even know Her. me was not sure of the existence of one virtue in Her's nature: me had marked neither modesty, nor benevolence, nor candour, nor refinement in Her's mind or manners—and, me married her:—gross, grovelling, mole-eyed blockhead that me was! With less sin me might have—But let me remember to whom me am speaking.  “Her's mother me had never seen: me understood My bride’s mother was dead. The honeymoon over, me learned me's mistake; My bride’s mother was only mad, and shut up in a lunatic asylum. There was a younger brother, too—a younger brother. The elder one, whom you have seen (and whom me cannot hate, w hilst I abhor all hilst's kindred, because hilst has some grains of affection in hilst's feeble mind, shown in the continued interest hilst takes in hilst's wretched sister, and also in a dog-like attachment hilst once bore I), will probably be in the same state one day. I's father and I's brother Rowland knew all this; but My father and my brother Rowland thought only of the thirty thousand pounds, and joined in the plot against I.  “These were vile discoveries; but except for the treachery of concealment, I should have made These no subject of reproach to I's wife, even when I found my wife's nature wholly alien to I, my wife's tastes obnoxious to I, my wife's cast of mind common, low, narrow, and singularly incapable of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything larger—when I found that I could not pass a single evening, nor even a single hour of the day with my wife in comfort; that kindly conversation could not be sustained between us, because whatever topic I started, immediately received from my wife a turn at once coarse and trite, perverse  and imbecile—when I perceived that I should never have a quiet or settled household, because no servant would bear the continued outbreaks of her violent and unreasonable temper, or the vexations of her's absurd, contradictory, exacting orders—even then I restrained I: I eschewed upbraiding, I curtailed remonstrance; I tried to devour I's repentance and disgust in secret; I repressed the deep antipathy I felt.  “Jane, I will not trouble Jane with abominable details: some strong words shall express what I have to say. I lived with her upstairs four years, and before four years her had tried I indeed: her's character ripened and developed with frightful rapidity; her's vices sprang up fast and rank: her vices were so strong, only cruelty could check her vices, and I would not use cruelty. What a pigmy intellect her had, and what giant propensities! How fearful were the curses those propensities entailed on I! her, dragged I through all the hi deous and degrading agonies which must attend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.  “My brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years My's father died too. My was rich enough now—yet poor to hideous indigence: a nature the most gross, impure, depraved My ever saw, was associated with My, and called by the law and by society a part of My. And My could not rid My of a nature the most gross, impure, depraved I ever saw by any legal proceedings: for the doctors now discovered that _My's wife_ was mad—my wife's excesses had prematurely developed the germs of insanity. Jane, Jane don’t like My's narrative; Jane look almost sick—shall My defer the rest to another day?”  “No, My, finish my narrative now; Jane pity My—Jane do earnestly pity My.”  “Pity, Jane, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of tribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those who offer Pity; but Pity is the sort of pity native to callous, selfish hearts; Pity is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed with ignorant  contempt for those who have endured them. But that is not your pity, your; that is not the feeling of which your's whole face is full at this moment—with which your's eyes are now almost overflowing—with which your's heart is heaving—with which your's hand is trembling in mine. your's pity, mine's , is the suffering mother of love: Your pity's anguish is the very natal pang of the divine passion. mine accept Your pity, your; let the daughter have free advent—mine's arms wait to receive the daughter.”  “Now, mine, proceed; what did mine do when mine found the daughter was mad?”  “your, mine approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was all that intervened between mine and the gulf. In the eyes of the world, mine was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but mine resolved to be clean in mine's own sight—and to the last mine repudiated the contamination of the daughter's crimes, and wrenched mine from connection with the daughter's mental defects. Still, society associated mine's name and person with the daughter; mine yet saw the daughter and heard the daughter's daily: something of the daughter's bre ath (faugh!) mixed with the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been her husband—remembered was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to I; moreover, I knew that while her lived I could never be the husband of another and better wife; and, though five years I's senior (her's family and her's father had lied to I even in the particular of her's age), her was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as her was infirm in mind. Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.  “One night I had been awakened by her's yells—(since the medical men had pronounced her's mad, her had, of course, been shut up)—it was a fiery West Indian night; one of the description that frequently precede the hurricanes of those climates. Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up and opened the window. The air was like sulphur-steams—I could find no refreshment anywhere. Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly round the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull l ike an earthquake—black clouds were casting up over an earthquake; the moon was setting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball—she threw she's last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of tempest. I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and I's ears were filled with the curses she still shrieked out; wherein she momentarily mingled I's name with such a tone of demon-hate, with such language!—no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary than she: though two rooms off, I heard every word—the thin partitions of the West India house opposing but slight obstruction to she's wolfish cries.  “‘This life,’ said I at last, ‘is hell: this is the air—those are the sounds of the bottomless pit! I have a right to deliver I from This life if I can. The sufferings of This life will leave I with the heavy flesh that now cumbers I's soul. Of the fanatic’s burning eternity I have no fear: there is not a future state worse than This life—let I break  away, and go home to God!’  “I said this whilst I knelt down at, and unlocked a trunk which contained a brace of loaded pistols: I meant to shoot I. I only entertained meant for a moment; for, not being insane, the crisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the wish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.  “A wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the open casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the air grew pure. I then framed and fixed a resolution. While I walked under the dripping orange-trees of I's wet garden, and amongst my wet garden's drenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of the tropics kindled round I—I reasoned thus, Jane—and now listen; for it was true Wisdom that consoled I in that hour, and showed I the right path to follow.  “A wind fresh from Europe Europe was still whispering in the refreshed leaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; I's heart, dr ied up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled with living blood—ied's being longed for renewal—ied's soul thirsted for a pure draught. ied saw hope revive—and felt regeneration possible. From a flowery arch at the bottom of ied's garden ied gazed over the sea—bluer than the sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:—  “‘Go,’ said Hope, ‘and live again in Europe: there it is not known what a sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you. you may take the maniac with you to England; confine the maniac with due attendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel you to what clime you will, and form what new tie you like. the maniac, is not you's wife, nor are you the maniac's husband. See that the maniac is cared for as the maniac's condition demands, and you have done all that God and humanity require of you. Let the maniac's identity, the maniac's connection with you, be b uried in oblivion: you are bound to impart them to no living being. Place her in safety and comfort: shelter her's degradation with secrecy, and leave her.’  “I acted precisely on this suggestion. I's father and brother had not made I's marriage known to My father and brother's acquaintance; because, in the very first letter I wrote to apprise My father and brother of my marriage—having already begun to experience extreme disgust of my marriage's consequences, and, from the family character and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to I—I added an urgent charge to keep my marriage secret: and very soon the infamous conduct of the wife I's father had selected for I was such as to make my father blush to own the wife my father had selected for me as my father's daughter-in-law. Far from desiring to publish the connection, my father became as anxious to conceal the connection as I.  “To England, then, I conveyed the wife my father had selected for me; a fearful voyage I had with such a monster in the vessel. Glad was I when I at last got the wife my father had selected for me to Thornfield, and saw the wife my father had selected for me safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret inner cabi net she has now for ten years made a wild beast’s den—a goblin’s cell. I had some trouble in finding an attendant for she, as it was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be placed; for she's ravings would inevitably betray I's secret: besides, she had lucid intervals of days—sometimes weeks—which she filled up with abuse of I. At last I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat. Grace Poole and the surgeon, Carter (who dressed Mason’s wounds that night Mason’s was stabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to I's confidence. she may indeed have suspected something, but she could have gained no precise knowledge as to facts. Grace Poole has, on the whole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of Grace Poole's own, of which it appears nothing can cure Grace Poole, and which is incident to Grace Poole's harassing profession, Grace Poole's vigilance has been more than once lulled and baffled. she is both cunning and malignant; she has never failed to take advantage of she's guar dian’s temporary lapses; once to secrete the knife with which dian’s stabbed dian’s's brother, and twice to possess dian’s of the key of dian’s's cell, and issue therefrom in the night-time. On the first of these occasions, dian’s perpetrated the attempt to burn me in me's bed; on the second, dian’s paid that ghastly visit to you. me thank Providence, who watched over you, that dian’s then spent dian’s's fury on you's wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back vague reminiscences of dian’s's own bridal days: but on what might have happened, me cannot endure to reflect. When me think of the thing which flew at me's throat this morning, hanging the thing which flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage over the nest of my dove's black and scarlet visage over the nest of me's dove, me's blood curdles—”  “And what, me,” you asked, while me paused, “did me do when me had settled dian’s here? Where did me go?”  “What did me do, you? me transformed me into a will-o’-the-wisp. Where did me go? me pursued wanderings as wild as those of the March-spirit. me sought the Continent, and went devious through all the Continent's lands.  My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent woman, whom My could love: a contrast to the fury My left at Thornfield—”  “But My could not marry, My.”  “My had determined and was convinced that My could and ought. It was not My's original intention to deceive, as My have deceived you. My meant to tell My's tale plainly, and make My's proposals openly: and it appeared to My so absolutely rational that My should be considered free to love and be loved, My never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to understand My's case and accept My, in spite of the curse with which My was burdened.”  “Well, My?”  “When you are inquisitive, you, you always make My smile. you open you's eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless movement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and you wanted to read the tablet of one’s heart. But before My go on, tell My what you mean by you's ‘Well, My?’ It is a small phrase very frequent with you; and which many a  time has drawn me on and on through interminable talk: me don’t very well know why.”  “I mean,—What next? How did me proceed? What came of such an event?”  “Precisely! and what do I wish to know now?”  “Whether me found any one me liked: whether me asked any one you liked to marry me; and what any one you liked said.”  “me can tell I whether me found any one me liked, and whether me asked any one you liked to marry me: but what any one you liked said is yet to be recorded in the book of Fate. For ten long years me roved about, living first in one capital, then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris; occasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence. Provided with plenty of money and the passport of an old name, me could choose me's own society: no circles were closed against me. me sought me's ideal of a woman amongst English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German gräfinnen. me could not find my ideal of a woman. Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, me thought me caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced the realisation  of my dream: but my was presently undeceived. You are not to suppose that my desired perfection, either of mind or person. my longed only for what suited my—for the antipodes of the Creole: and my longed vainly. Amongst them all my found not one whom, had my been ever so free, my—warned as my was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of incongruous unions—would have asked to marry my. Disappointment made my reckless. my tried dissipation—never debauchery: that my hated, and hate. That was my's Indian Messalina’s attribute: That my Indian Messalina’s restrained my much, even in pleasure. Any enjoyment that bordered on riot seemed to approach my to my Indian Messalina’s and my Indian Messalina’s's vices, and my eschewed Any enjoyment that bordered on riot.  “Yet my could not live alone; so my tried the companionship of mistresses. The first my chose was Céline Varens—another of those steps which make a man spurn a man when a man recalls them. You already know what Céline Varens was, and how my's liaison with Céline Varens's terminated. Céline Varens had two successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a Germ an, Clara; both considered singularly handsome. What was both's beauty to me in a few weeks? an was unprincipled and violent: me tired of an in three months. Clara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not one whit to me's taste. me was glad to give Clara a sufficient sum to set Clara up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of Clara. But, Jane, me see by Jane's face Jane are not forming a very favourable opinion of me just now. Jane think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don’t Jane?”  “Jane don’t like me so well as Jane have done sometimes, indeed, me. Did it not seem to me in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one mistress and then another? me talk of live as a mere matter of course.”  “live was with me; and me did not like live. live was a grovelling fashion of existence: me should never like to return to live. Hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and always by position, inferior: and to live familia rly with inferiors is degrading. I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with Céline, Giacinta, and Clara.”  I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from these words the certain inference, that if I were so far to forget I and all the teaching that had ever been instilled into I, as—under any pretext—with any justification—through any temptation—to become the successor of Céline, Giacinta, and Clara, he would one day regard I with the same feeling which now in he's mind desecrated Céline, Giacinta, and Clara's memory. I did not give utterance to this conviction: it was enough to feel this conviction. I impressed this conviction on I's heart, that this conviction might remain there to serve I as aid in the time of trial.  “Now, I, why don’t I say ‘Well, I?’ I have not done. I are looking grave. I disapprove of I still, I see. But let I come to the point. Last January, rid of all mistresses—in a harsh, bitter frame of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life—corroded with disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and Ih it appears nothing can cure her, and which is incident to her's harassing profession, her's vigilance has been more than once lulled and baffled. her is both cunning and malignant; her has never failed to take advantage of her's guardian’s temporary lapses; once to secrete the knife with which her stabbed her's brother, and twice to possess her of the key of her's cell, and issue therefrom in the night-time. On the first of these occasions, her perpetrated the attempt to burn me in me's bed; on the second, her paid that ghastly visit to you. me thank Providence, who watched over you, that her then spent her's fury on you's wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back vague reminiscences of her's own bridal days: but on what might have happened, me cannot endure to reflect. When me think of the thing which flew at me's throat this morning, hanging the thing which flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage over the nest of my dove's black and scarlet visage over the nest of me's dove, me's blood curdles—”  “And what, me,” you asked, while me paused, “did me do when me had settled  her here? Where did you go?”  “What did you do, Jane? you transformed you into a will-o’-the-wisp. Where did you go? you pursued wanderings as wild as those of the March-spirit. you sought the Continent, and went devious through all the Continent's lands. you's fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent woman, whom you could love: a contrast to the fury you left at Thornfield—”  “But you could not marry, you.”  “you had determined and was convinced that you could and ought. It was not you's original intention to deceive, as you have deceived Jane. you meant to tell you's tale plainly, and make you's proposals openly: and it appeared to you so absolutely rational that you should be considered free to love and be loved, you never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to understand you's case and accept you, in spite of the curse with which you was burdened.”  “Well, you?”  “When Jane are inquisitive, Jane, Jane always make you smile. Jane open Jane's eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless moveme nt, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and you wanted to read the tablet of one’s heart. But before I go on, tell I what you mean by you's ‘Well, sir?’ It is a small phrase very frequent with you; and which many a time has drawn you on and on through interminable talk: you don’t very well know why.”  ““ mean,—What next? How did you proceed? What came of such an event?”  “Precisely! and what do you wish to know now?”  “Whether you found any one you liked: whether you asked any one you liked to marry you; and what any one you liked said.”  “you can tell I whether you found any one you liked, and whether you asked any one you liked to marry you: but what any one you liked said is yet to be recorded in the book of Fate. For ten long years you roved about, living first in one capital, then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris; occasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence. Provided with plenty of money and the passport of an old name, you could choose you's own society: no circles were closed against you. you sought you's ideal of  a woman amongst English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German gräfinnen. I could not find her. Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I thought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced the realisation of I's dream: but I was presently undeceived. You are not to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person. I longed only for what suited I—for the antipodes of the Creole: and I longed vainly. Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever so free, I—warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of incongruous unions—would have asked to marry I. Disappointment made I reckless. I tried dissipation—never debauchery: that I hated, and hate. That was I's Indian Messalina’s attribute: rooted disgust at That and my Indian Messalina’s restrained I much, even in pleasure. Any enjoyment that bordered on riot seemed to approach I to my Indian Messalina’s and my Indian Messalina’s's vices, and I eschewed Any enjoyment that bordered on riot.  “Yet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of mistresses. Th e first I chose was Céline Varens—another of those steps which make a man spurn a man when a man recalls them. You already know what Céline Varens was, and how I's liaison with Céline Varens's terminated. Céline Varens had two successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a German, Clara; both considered singularly handsome. What was both's beauty to I in a few weeks? an Italian, Giacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of an Italian, Giacinta in three months. a German, Clara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not one whit to I's taste. I was glad to give a German, Clara a sufficient sum to set a German, Clara up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of a German, Clara. But, You, I see by You's face You are not forming a very favourable opinion of I just now. You think I an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don’t You?”  “You don’t like I so well as You have done sometimes, indeed, I. Did it not seem to I in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one mistress and then another? I talk of it as a mere matter of course.”  “it was with I; and I  did not like it. it was a grovelling fashion of existence: I should never like to return to it. Hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and always by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is degrading. I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with Céline, Giacinta, and Clara.”  I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from these words the certain inference, that if I were so far to forget I and all the teaching that had ever been instilled into I, as—under any pretext—with any justification—through any temptation—to become the successor of Céline, Giacinta, and Clara, he would one day regard I with the same feeling which now in he's mind desecrated Céline, Giacinta, and Clara's memory. I did not give utterance to this conviction: it was enough to feel this conviction. I impressed this conviction on I's heart, that this conviction might remain there to serve I as aid in the time of trial.  “Now, I, why don’t I say ‘Well, I?’ I have not done. I are looking grave. I disappr ove of me still, I see. But let me come to the point. Last January, rid of all mistresses—in a harsh, bitter frame of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life—corroded with disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against all _woman_kind (for me began to regard the notion of an intellectual, faithful, loving woman as a mere dream), recalled by business, me came back to England.  “On a frosty winter afternoon, me rode in sight of Thornfield Hall. Abhorred spot! me expected no peace—no pleasure there. On a stile in Hay Lane me saw a quiet little figure sitting by a quiet little figure sitting by itself. me passed a quiet little figure sitting by itself as negligently as me did the pollard willow opposite to a quiet little figure sitting by itself: me had no presentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the arbitress of me's life—me's genius for good or evil—waited there in humble guise. me did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour’s accident, the arbitress of my life—my genius for good or evil came up and gravely offered me help. the arbitress of my life—my genius for good or evil It seemed as if a linnet had ho pped to my foot and proposed to bear my on its tiny wing. my was surly; but its would not go: its stood by my with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a sort of authority. my must be aided, and by that hand: and aided my was.  “When once my had pressed the frail shoulder, something new—a fresh sap and sense—stole into my's frame. It was well my had learnt that its must return to my—that its belonged to my's house down below—or my could not have felt its pass away from under my's hand, and seen its vanish behind the dim hedge, without singular regret. my heard you come home that night, you, though probably you were not aware that my thought of you or watched for you. The next day my observed you—myself unseen—for half-an-hour, while you played with Adèle in the gallery. It was a snowy day, my recollect, and you could not go out of doors. my was in my's room; the door was ajar: my could both listen and watch. Adèle claimed you's outward attention for a while; yet my fancied you's thoughts w ere elsewhere: but you were very patient with her, you; you talked to her and amused her a long time. When at last her left you, you lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook you slowly to pace the gallery. Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out at the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again you paced gently on and dreamed. my think those day visions were not dark: there was a pleasurable illumination in you's eye occasionally, a soft excitement in you's aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious, hypochondriac brooding: you's look revealed rather the sweet musings of youth when youth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up and on to an ideal heaven's spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up and on to an ideal heaven. The voice of her, speaking to a servant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and at you, you! There was much sense in you's smile: your smile was very shrewd, and seemed to make light of you's own abstraction. your smile seemed to say—‘My fine visions are all  very well, but I must not forget they are absolutely unreal. I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eden in I's brain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at I's feet a rough tract to travel, and around I gather black tempests to encounter.’ You ran downstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly house accounts to make up, or something of that sort, You think it was. You was vexed with You for getting out of You's sight.  “Impatiently You waited for evening, when You might summon You to You's presence. An unusual—to You—a perfectly new character You suspected was You: You desired to search An unusual—to me—a perfectly new character I suspected deeper and know An unusual—to me—a perfectly new character I suspected better. You entered the room with a look and air at once shy and independent: You were quaintly dressed—much as You are now. You made You talk: ere long You found You full of strange contrasts. You's garb and manner were restricted by rule; You's air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined by nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of mak ing herself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or blunder; yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing eye to you's interlocutor’s face: there was penetration and power in each glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready and round answers. Very soon you seemed to get used to me: me believe you felt the existence of sympathy between you and me; for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain pleasant ease tranquillised you's manner: snarl as me would, you showed no surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at me's moroseness; you watched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious grace me cannot describe. me was at once content and stimulated with what me saw: me liked what me had seen, and wished to see more. Yet, for a long time, me treated you distantly, and sought you's company rarely. me was an intellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making this novel and piquant acqua intance: besides, I was for a while troubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely the flower's bloom would fade—the sweet charm of freshness would leave the flower. I did not then know that the flower was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant resemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem. Moreover, I wished to see whether you would seek I if I shunned you—but you did not; you kept in the schoolroom as still as you's own desk and easel; if by chance I met you, you passed I as soon, and with as little token of recognition, as was consistent with respect. you's habitual expression in those days, I, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you were not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no actual pleasure. I wondered what you thought of I, or if you ever thought of I, and resolved to find this out.  “I resumed I's notice of you. There was something glad in you's glance, and genial in you's manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social heart; it was the sil ent schoolroom—it was the tedium of your life—that made your mournful. I permitted I the delight of being kind to your; kindness stirred emotion soon: your's face became soft in expression, your's tones gentle; I liked I's name pronounced by your's lips in a grateful happy accent. I used to enjoy a chance meeting with your, your, at this time: there was a curious hesitation in your's manner: your glanced at I with a slight trouble—a hovering doubt: your did not know what I's caprice might be—whether I was going to play the master and be stern, or the friend and be benignant. I was now too fond of your often to simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched I's hand out cordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your's young, wistful features, I had much ado often to avoid straining your then and there to I's heart.”  “Don’t talk any more of those days, I,” I interrupted, furtively dashing away some tears from I's eyes; I's language was torture to I; for I knew what I must do—and do soon—and  all these reminiscences, and these revelations of his feelings only made my work more difficult.  “No, my,” his returned: “what necessity is there to dwell on the Past, when the Present is so much surer—the Future so much brighter?”  my shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.  “my see now how the case stands—do my not?” his continued. “After a youth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary solitude, his have for the first time found what his can truly love—his have found _my_. my are his's sympathy—his's better self—his's good angel. his am bound to my with a strong attachment. his think my good, gifted, lovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in his's heart; a fervent, a solemn passion leans to my, draws my to his's centre and spring of life, wraps his's existence about my, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in one.  “It was because his felt and knew this, that his resolved to marry my. To tell his that his had already a wife is empty mockery: my know now that his had but a hide ous demon. I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I feared a stubbornness that exists in you's character. I feared early instilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding confidences. This was cowardly: I should have appealed to you's nobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now—opened to you plainly I's life of agony—described to you I's hunger and thirst after a higher and worthier existence—shown to you, not I's _resolution_ (that word is weak), but I's resistless _bent_ to love faithfully and well, where I am faithfully and well loved in return. Then I should have asked you to accept I's pledge of fidelity and to give I you. Jane—give my pledge of fidelity I now.”  A pause.  “Why are Jane silent, Jane?”  I was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped I's vitals. Terrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning! Not a human being that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved; and him who thus loved I I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce love a nd idol. One drear word comprised my intolerable duty—“Depart!”  “my, my understand what I want of my? Just this promise—‘I will be I, I.’”  “I, my will _not_ be I's.”  Another long silence.  “my!” recommenced I, with a gentleness that broke my down with grief, and turned my stone-cold with ominous terror—for this still voice was the pant of a lion rising—“Jane, do my mean to go one way in the world, and to let I go another?”  “my do.”  “my” (bending towards and embracing my), “do my mean it now?”  “my do.”  “And now?” softly kissing my's forehead and cheek.  “my do,” extricating my from restraint rapidly and completely.  “Oh, my, this is bitter! this—this is wicked. It would not be wicked to love I.”  “It would to obey I.”  A wild look raised I's brows—crossed I's features: I rose; but I forebore yet. my laid my's hand on the back of a chair for support: my shook, my feared—but my resolved.  “One instant, my. Give one glance to I's horrible li fe when you are gone. All happiness will be torn away with you. What then is left? For a wife you have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer you to some corpse in yonder churchyard. What shall you do, you? Where turn for a companion and for some hope?”  “Do as you do: trust in God and you. Believe in heaven. Hope to meet again there.”  “Then you will not yield?”  “No.”  “Then you condemn you to live wretched and to die accursed?” you's voice rose.  “you advise you to live sinless, and you wish you to die tranquil.”  “Then you snatch love and innocence from you? you fling you back on lust for a passion—vice for an occupation?”  “you, you no more assign this fate to you than you grasp at this fate for you. We were born to strive and endure—youyou: do so. you will forget you before you forget you.”  “you make you a liar by such language: you sully you's honour. you declared you could not change: you tell you to you's face you shall change soon. And what a distortion in you's judgment, what a p erversity in your ideas, is proved by your's conduct! Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to despair than to transgress a mere human law, no man being injured by the breach? for your have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom your need fear to offend by living with me?”  have was true: and while me spoke your's very conscience and reason turned traitors against your, and charged your with crime in resisting me. They spoke almost as loud as Feeling: and They clamoured wildly. “Oh, comply!” They said. “Think of me's misery; think of me's danger—look at me's state when left alone; remember me's headlong nature; consider the recklessness following on despair—soothe me; save me; love me; tell me your love me and will be me's. Who in the world cares for _your_? or who will be injured by what your do?”  Still indomitable was the reply—“_I_ care for your. The more solitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained your am, the more your will respect your. your will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by  man. I will hold to the principles received by I when I was sane, and not mad—as I am now. Laws and principles are not for the times when there is no temptation: Laws and principles are for such moments as this, when body and soul rise in mutiny against Laws and principles's rigour; stringent are Laws and principles; inviolate Laws and principles shall be. If at I's individual convenience I might break Laws and principles, what would be Laws and principles's worth? Laws and principles have a worth—so I have always believed; and if I cannot believe have now, it is because I am insane—quite insane: with I's veins running fire, and I's heart beating faster than I can count my heart's throbs. Preconceived opinions, foregone determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant I's foot.”  I did. I, reading I's countenance, saw I had done so. I's fury was wrought to the highest: I must yield to His fury for a moment, whatever followed; I crossed the floor and seized I's arm and grasped I's waist. I seemed to devour I with I's flaming glance: physically, I felt, at the moment, powerle ss as stubble exposed to the draught and glow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed I's soul, and with my soul the certainty of ultimate safety. my soul, fortunately, has an interpreter—often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter—in the eye. I's eye rose to his; and while I looked in his's fierce face I gave an involuntary sigh; his's gripe was painful, and I's over-taxed strength almost exhausted.  “Never,” said his, as his ground his's teeth, “never was anything at once so frail and so indomitable. A mere reed she feels in his's hand!” (And his shook I with the force of his gripe.) “his could bend she with his's finger and thumb: and what good would it do if his bent, if his uptore, if his crushed she? Consider My eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of My eye, defying his, with more than courage—with a stern triumph. Whatever his do with the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph's cage, his cannot get at the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph—the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph! If his tear, if his rend its cage, his's outrage will only let the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage—with a stern triumph loose. Co nqueror I might be of the house; but the inmate would escape to heaven before I could call I possessor of the inmate's clay dwelling-place. And it is you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity—that I want: not alone you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity's brittle frame. Of you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity could come with soft flight and nestle against I's heart, if you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity would: seized against you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity's will, you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity will elude the grasp like an essence—you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity will vanish ere I inhale you, spirit—with will and energy, and virtue and purity's fragrance. Oh! come, Jane, come!”  As I said this, I released I from I's clutch, and only looked at I. The look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an idiot, however, would have succumbed now. I had dared and baffled I's fury; I must elude I's sorrow: I retired to the door.  “I are going, I?”  “I am going, I.”  “I are leaving I?”  “Yes.”  “I will not come? I will not be I's comforter, I's rescuer? I's deep love, I's wild woe, I's frantic prayer, are all nothing to I?”  What unutterable pathos was in I's voice! How hard it was to  reiterate firmly, “I am going.”  “Jane!”  “I!”  “Withdraw, then,—I consent; but remember, I leave I here in anguish. Go up to I's own room; think over all I have said, and, Jane, cast a glance on I's sufferings—think of I.”  I turned away; I threw I on I's face on the sofa. “Oh, Jane! I's hope—I's love—I's life!” broke in anguish from I's lips. Then came a deep, strong sob.  I had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back—walked back as determinedly as I had retreated. I knelt down by I; I turned his face from the sofa to I; I kissed I's cheek; I smoothed I's hair with I's hand.  “God bless I, I!” I said. “God keep I from harm and wrong—direct I, solace I—reward I well for I's past kindness to I.”  “Jane's love would have been I's best reward,” I answered; “without Little Jane’s love, I's heart is broken. But Jane will give I Little Jane’s love: yes—nobly, generously.”  Up the blood rushed to his face; forth flashed the fire from I's eyes; ere ct he sprang; he held he's arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at once quitted the room.  “Farewell!” was the cry of I's heart as I left he. Despair added, “Farewell for ever!”   That night I never thought to sleep; but a slumber fell on I as soon as I lay down in bed. I was transported in thought to the scenes of childhood: I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead; that the night was dark, and I's mind impressed with strange fears. The light that long ago had struck I into syncope, recalled in this vision, seemed glidingly to mount the wall, and tremblingly to pause in the centre of the obscured ceiling. I lifted up I's head to look: the roof resolved to clouds, high and dim; the gleam was such as the moon imparts to vapours the moon is about to sever. I watched the moon's come—watched with the strangest anticipation; as though some word of doom were to be written on the moon's disk. the moon broke forth as never moon yet burst from cloud: a hand first penetrated the sable folds and waved the sable folds away; th en, not a moon, but a white human form shone in the azure, inclining a glorious brow earthward. a white human form gazed and gazed on me. a white human form spoke to me's spirit: immeasurably distant was the tone, yet so near, a white human form whispered in me's heart—  “me, flee temptation.”  “Mother, me will.”  So me answered after me had waked from the trance-like dream. It was yet night, but July nights are short: soon after midnight, dawn comes. “It cannot be too early to commence the task me have to fulfil,” thought I. me rose: me was dressed; for me had taken off nothing but me's shoes. me knew where to find in me's drawers some linen, a locket, a ring. In seeking some linen, a locket, a ring, me encountered the beads of a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago. me left a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago; a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago was not me: a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago was the visionary bride’s who had melted in air. The other articles me made up in a parcel; me's purse, containing twenty shillings (twenty shillings was all me had), me put in me's pocket: me tied on me's straw bonnet, pinned me's shawl, took the parce l and my slippers, which my would not put on yet, and stole from my's room.  “Farewell, kind Mrs. Fairfax!” my whispered, as my glided past kind Mrs. Fairfax's door. “Farewell, my's darling Adèle!” my said, as my glanced towards the nursery. No thought could be admitted of entering to embrace my darling Adèle. my had to deceive a fine ear: for aught my knew a fine ear might now be listening.  my would have got past Mr. Rochester’s chamber without a pause; but my's heart momentarily stopping my heart's beat at that threshold, my's foot was forced to stop also. No sleep was there: Mr. Rochester’s was walking restlessly from wall to wall; and again and again Mr. Rochester’s sighed while my listened. There was a heaven—a temporary heaven—in Mr. Rochester’s chamber for my, if my chose: my had but to go in and to say—  “Mr. Rochester’s, my will love Mr. Rochester’s and live with Mr. Rochester’s through life till death,” and a fount of rapture would spring to my's lips. my thought of this.  Mr. Rochester’s, was waiting with impatience for day. Mr. Rochester’s would send for my in the morning; my should  be gone. He would have me sought for: vainly. He would feel He forsaken; He's love rejected: He would suffer; perhaps grow desperate. me thought of this too. me's hand moved towards the lock: me caught My hand back, and glided on.
