Drearily me wound me's way downstairs: me knew what me had to do, and me did it mechanically. me sought the key of the side-door in the kitchen; me sought, too, a phial of oil and a feather; me oiled the key of the side-door in the kitchen and the lock. me got some water, me got some bread: for perhaps me should have to walk far; and me's strength, sorely shaken of late, must not break down. All this me did without one sound. me opened the door, passed out, shut the door softly. Dim dawn glimmered in the yard. The great gates were closed and locked; but a wicket in one of The great gates was only latched. Through that me departed: it, too, me shut; and now me was out of Thornfield.  A mile off, beyond the fields, lay a road which stretched in the contrary direction to Millcote; a road me had never travelled, but often noticed, and  wondered where it led: thither I bent I's steps. No reflection was to be allowed now: not one glance was to be cast back; not even one forward. Not one thought was to be given either to the past or the future. The first was a page so heavenly sweet—so deadly sad—that to read one line of a page so heavenly sweet—so deadly sad—that to read one line of it would dissolve I's courage and break down I's energy. The last was an awful blank: something like the world when the deluge was gone by.  I skirted fields, and hedges, and lanes till after sunrise. I believe it was a lovely summer morning: I know I's shoes, which I had put on when I left the house, were soon wet with dew. But I looked neither to rising sun, nor smiling sky, nor wakening nature. He who is taken out to pass through a fair scene to the scaffold, thinks not of the flowers that smile on He who is taken out to pass through a fair scene to the scaffold's road, but of the block and axe-edge; of the disseverment of bone and vein; of the grave gaping at the end: and I thought of drear flight and homeless wandering—and oh! with agony I thought of what I left.  I could not help it. I thought of him now—in him's room—watching the sunrise; hoping I should soon come to say I would stay with him and be him's. I longed to be him's; I panted to return: it was not too late; I could yet spare him the bitter pang of bereavement. As yet I's flight, I was sure, was undiscovered. I could go back and be him's comforter—him's pride; him's redeemer from misery, perhaps from ruin. Oh, that fear of him's self-abandonment—far worse than I's abandonment—how that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment goaded I! that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment was a barbed arrow-head in I's breast; that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment tore I when I tried to extract that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment; that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment sickened I when remembrance thrust that fear of his self-abandonment—far worse than my abandonment farther in. Birds began singing in brake and copse: birds were faithful to birds's mates; birds were emblems of love. What was I? In the midst of I's pain of heart and frantic effort of principle, I abhorred I. I had no solace from self-approbation: none even from self-respect. I had injured—wounded—left him. I was hateful in I's own eyes. Still I could not turn, nor retrace one ste p. God must have led me on. As to me's own will or conscience, impassioned grief had trampled one and stifled the other. me was weeping wildly as me walked along me's solitary way: fast, fast me went like one delirious. A weakness, beginning inwardly, extending to the limbs, seized me, and me fell: me lay on the ground some minutes, pressing me's face to the wet turf. me had some fear—or hope—that here me should die: but me was soon up; crawling forwards on me's hands and knees, and then again raised to me's feet—as eager and as determined as ever to reach the road.  When me got there, me was forced to sit to rest me under the hedge; and while me sat, me heard wheels, and saw a coach come on. me stood up and lifted me's hand; a coach stopped. me asked where a coach was going: the driver named a place a long way off, and where me was sure Mr. Rochester had no connections. me asked for what sum the driver would take me there; the driver said thirty shillings; me answered me had but twenty; well, the driver would try to make it do. the driver further gave me  leave to get into the inside, as the vehicle was empty: I entered, was shut in, and the vehicle rolled on the vehicle's way.  Gentle reader, may Gentle reader never feel what I then felt! May Gentle reader's eyes never shed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from I. May Gentle reader never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in that hour left I's lips; for never may Gentle reader, like I, dread to be the instrument of evil to what Gentle reader wholly love.     CHAPTER XXVIII   Two days are passed. It is a summer evening; the coachman has set I down at a place called Whitcross; the coachman could take I no farther for the sum I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the world. the coachman is a mile off by this time; I am alone. At this moment I discover that I forgot to take I's parcel out of the pocket of the coachman, where I had placed my parcel for safety; there my parcel remains, there my parcel must remain; and now, I am absolutely destitute.  a place called Whitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; a place called Whitcross is but a stone pillar set up where f our roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at a distance and in darkness. Four arms spring from its summit: the nearest town to which Four arms point is, according to the inscription, distant ten miles; the farthest, above twenty. From the well-known names of these towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a north-midland shire, dusk with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I see. There are great moors behind and on each hand of I; there are waves of mountains far beyond that deep valley at I's feet. The population here must be thin, and I see no passengers on our roads: our roads stretch out east, west, north, and south—white, broad, lonely; our roads are all cut in the moor, and the heather grows deep and wild to our roads's very verge. Yet a chance traveller might pass by; and I wish no eye to see I now: strangers would wonder what I am doing, lingering here at the sign-post, evidently objectless and lost. I might be questioned: I could give no answer but what would sound incredi ble and excite suspicion. Not a tie holds me to human society at this moment—not a charm or hope calls me where me's fellow-creatures are—none that saw me would have a kind thought or a good wish for me. me have no relative but the universal mother, Nature: me will seek the universal mother, Nature's breast and ask repose.  me struck straight into the heath; me held on to a hollow me saw deeply furrowing the brown moorside; me waded knee-deep in its dark growth; me turned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle, me sat down under a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle. High banks of moor were about me; a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle protected me's head: the sky was over my head.  Some time passed before me felt tranquil even here: me had a vague dread that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might discover me. If a gust of wind swept the waste, me looked up, fearing a gust of wind was the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, me imagined a plover a man. Finding me's apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep silence that reigned a s evening declined at nightfall, I took confidence. As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched, dreaded; now I regained the faculty of reflection.  What was I to do? Where to go? Oh, intolerable questions, when I could do nothing and go nowhere!—when a long way must yet be measured by I's weary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation—when cold charity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant sympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before I's tale could be listened to, or one of I's wants relieved!  I touched the heath: the heath was dry, and yet warm with the heat of the summer day. I looked at the sky; the sky was pure: a kindly star twinkled just above the chasm ridge. The dew fell, but with propitious softness; no breeze whispered. Nature seemed to I benign and good; I thought Nature loved I, outcast as I was; and I, clung to Nature with filial fondness. To-night, at least, I would  be her guest, as I was her's child: I's would lodge I without money and without price. I had one morsel of bread yet: the remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed through at noon with a stray penny—I's last coin. I saw ripe bilberries gleaming here and there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a handful and ate a handful with the bread. I's hunger, sharp before, was, if not satisfied, appeased by this hermit’s meal. I said I's evening prayers at this hermit’s meal's conclusion, and then chose I's couch.   I said my evening prayers  Beside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down I's feet were buried in the heath; rising high on each side, the heath left only a narrow space for the night-air to invade. I folded I's shawl double, and spread my shawl over I for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was I's pillow. Thus lodged, I was not, at least at the commencement of the night, cold.  I's rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke My rest. a sad heart plained of a sad heart's gaping wounds, a sad heart's inward bleeding, a sad heart's ri ven chords. It trembled for Mr. Rochester and Mr. Rochester's doom; It bemoaned Mr. Rochester with bitter pity; It demanded Mr. Rochester with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird with both wings broken, It still quivered It's shattered pinions in vain attempts to seek Mr. Rochester.  Worn out with this torture of thought, I rose to I's knees. Night was come, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for the companionship of fear. We know that God is everywhere; but certainly We feel God's presence most when God's works are on the grandest scale spread before We; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where God's worlds wheel His worlds's silent course, that We read clearest God's infinitude, God's omnipotence, God's omnipresence. I had risen to I's knees to pray for Mr. Rochester. Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty Milky-way. Remembering what the mighty Milky-way was—what countless systems there swept space like a soft trace of light—I felt the might and strength of God. Sure was I of God's efficiency to save what God had made:  convinced I grew that neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured. I turned I's prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the Saviour of spirits. Mr. Rochester was safe: Mr. Rochester was God’s, and by God’s would Mr. Rochester be guarded. I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in sleep forgot sorrow.  But next day, Want came to I pale and bare. Long after the little birds had left the little birds's nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime of day to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried—when the long morning shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky—I got up, and I looked round I.  What a still, hot, perfect day! What a golden desert this spreading moor! Everywhere sunshine. I wished I could live in it and on it. I saw a lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet bilberries. I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that I might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here. But I was a human being, and h ad a human being’s wants: I must not linger where there was nothing to supply a human being’s wants. I rose; I looked back at the bed I had left. Hopeless of the future, I wished but this—that I's Maker had that night thought good to require I's soul of I while I slept; and that this weary frame, absolved by death from further conflict with fate, had now but to decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil of this wilderness. Life, however, was yet in I's possession, with all Life's requirements, and pains, and responsibilities. The burden must be carried; the want provided for; the suffering endured; the responsibility fulfilled. I set out.  Whitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now fervent and high. By no other circumstance had I will to decide I's choice. I walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done enough, and might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost overpowered I—might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a stone I saw near, submit resist lessly to the apathy that clogged heart and limb—I heard a bell chime—a church bell.  I turned in the direction of a bell chime, and there, amongst the romantic hills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw a hamlet and a spire. All the valley at I's right hand was full of pasture-fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran zig-zag through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the sombre woodland, the clear and sunny lea. Recalled by the rumbling of wheels to the road before I, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up the hill, and not far beyond were two cows and two cows's drover. Human life and human labour were near. I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil like the rest.  About two o’clock P.M. I entered a hamlet. At the bottom of a hamlet's one street there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window. I coveted a cake of bread. With that refreshment I could perhaps regain a degree of energy: without that refreshment, it would  be difficult to proceed. The wish to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as me was amongst me's fellow-beings. me felt it would be degrading to faint with hunger on the causeway of a hamlet. Had me nothing about me me could offer in exchange for one of these rolls? me considered. me had a small silk handkerchief tied round me's throat; me had me's gloves. me could hardly tell how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded. me did not know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably these articles would not; but me must try.  me entered the shop: a woman was there. Seeing mea woman , a woman came forward with civility. How could a woman serve me? me was seized with shame: me's tongue would not utter the request me had prepared. me dared not offer a woman my gloves, a small silk handkerchief tied round my throat: besides, me felt offer would be absurd. me only begged permission to sit down a moment, as me was tired. Disappointed in the expectation of a cust omer, she coolly acceded to my request. she pointed to a seat; my sank into a seat. my felt sorely urged to weep; but conscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, my restrained such a manifestation. Soon my asked she “if there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman in the village?”  “Yes; two or three. Quite as many as there was employment for.”  my reflected. my was driven to the point now. my was brought face to face with Necessity. my stood in the position of one without a resource, without a friend, without a coin. my must do something. What? my must apply somewhere. Where?  “Did she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was wanted?”  “Nay; she couldn’t say.”  “What was the chief trade in the village? What did most of the people do?”  “Some were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver’s needle-factory, and at the foundry.”  “Did Mr. Oliver’s employ women?”  “Nay; it was men’s work.”  “And what do the women do?”  “I knawn’t,” was the answer. “Some does one thing, and some anothe r. Poor folk mun get on as Poor folk can.”  She seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had my to importune She? A neighbour or two came in; my's chair was evidently wanted. my took leave.  my passed up the street, looking as my went at all the houses to the right hand and to the left; but my could discover no pretext, nor see an inducement to enter any. my rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to a little distance and returning again, for an hour or more. Much exhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, my turned aside into a lane and sat down under the hedge. Ere many minutes had elapsed, my was again on my's feet, however, and again searching something—a resource, or at least an informant. A pretty little house stood at the top of a lane, with a garden before A pretty little house, exquisitely neat and brilliantly blooming. my stopped at A pretty little house. What business had my to approach the white door or touch the glittering knocker? In what way could it possibly be the interest of the inhabitant s of that dwelling to serve me? Yet me drew near and knocked. A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman opened the door. In such a voice as might be expected from a hopeless heart and fainting frame—a voice wretchedly low and faltering—me asked if a servant was wanted here?  “No,” said A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman; “that dwelling do not keep a servant.”  “Can A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman tell me where me could get employment of any kind?” me continued. “me am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place. me want some work: no matter what.”  But it was not A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman's business to think for me, or to seek a place for me: besides, in A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman's eyes, how doubtful must have appeared me's character, position, tale. A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman shook A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman's head, A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman “was sorry A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman could give me no information,” and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but the white door shut me out. If A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman had held the white door open a little longer, me believe me should have begged a piece of bread; for me was now brought low.  me could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no prospect of aid was visible. me  should have longed rather to deviate to a wood I saw not far off, which appeared in a wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer inviting shelter's thick shade to offer inviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature’s cravings, instinct kept I roaming round abodes where there was a chance of food. Solitude would be no solitude—rest no rest—while the vulture, hunger, thus sank beak and talons in I's side.  I drew near houses; I left houses, and came back again, and again I wandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim to ask—no right to expect interest in I's isolated lot. Meantime, the afternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and starving dog. In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before I: I hastened towards the church spire. Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a garden, stood a well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was the parsonage. I remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where strangers who arrive at a place where they have no friends, and who want employment have no friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the clergyman  for introduction and aid. It is the clergyman’s function to help—at least with advice—those who wished to help those who wished to help themselves. I seemed to have something like a right to seek counsel here. Renewing then I's courage, and gathering I's feeble remains of strength, I pushed on. I reached the house, and knocked at the kitchen-door. An old woman opened: I asked was the house the parsonage?  “Yes.”  “Was the clergyman’s in?”  “No.”  “Would the clergyman’s be in soon?”  “No, the clergyman’s was gone from home.”  “To a distance?”  “Not so far—happen three mile. the clergyman’s had been called away by the sudden death of the clergyman’s's father: the clergyman’s was at Marsh End now, and would very likely stay there a fortnight longer.”  “Was there any lady of the house?”  “Nay, there was naught but her, and her was housekeeper;” and of her, I, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was sinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.  Once more I took off I's handkerchief—once more I thought of the cakes of bread in the little shop. Oh, for but  a crust! for but one mouthful to allay the pang of famine! Instinctively I turned I's face again to the village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others were there besides the woman I ventured the request—“Would the woman give I a roll for this handkerchief?”  the woman looked at I with evident suspicion: “Nay, the woman never sold stuff i’ that way.”  Almost desperate, I asked for half a cake; the woman again refused. “How could the woman tell where I had got this handkerchief?” the woman said.  “Would the woman take I's gloves?”  “No! what could the woman do with my gloves?”  Reader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details. Some say there is enjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I can scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral degradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a recollection ever to be willingly dwelt on. I blamed none of those who repulsed I. I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not be helped: an ordinary begga r is frequently an object of suspicion; a well-dressed beggar inevitably so. To be sure, what I begged was employment; but whose business was it to provide I with employment? Not, certainly, that of persons who saw I then for the first time, and who knew nothing about I's character. And as to the woman who would not take I's handkerchief in exchange for the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread's bread, why, the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread was right, if the offer appeared to the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread's sinister or the exchange unprofitable. Let I condense now. I am sick of the subject.  A little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating the farmer's supper of bread and cheese. I stopped and said—  “Will the farmer give I a piece of bread? for I am very hungry.” the farmer cast on I a glance of surprise; but without answering, the farmer cut a thick slice from the farmer's loaf, and gave a thick slice to I. I imagine the farmer did not think I was a beggar, but only an eccentric sort of lady, who had taken a fancy to his loaf. As soon as I was out of sight of a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese, I sat  down and ate it.  I could not hope to get a lodging under a roof, and sought a lodging in the wood I have before alluded to. But I's night was wretched, I's rest broken: the ground was damp, the air cold: besides, intruders passed near I more than once, and I had again and again to change I's quarters: no sense of safety or tranquillity befriended I. Towards morning it rained; the whole of the following day was wet. Do not ask I, reader, to give a minute account of the whole of the following day; as before, I sought work; as before, I was repulsed; as before, I starved; but once did food pass I's lips. At the door of a cottage I saw a little girl about to throw a mess of cold porridge into a pig trough. “Will a little girl give I a mess of cold porridge?” I asked.   “Will a little girl give I a mess of cold porridge?” I asked  a little girl stared at I. “Mother!” a little girl exclaimed, “there is I wants a little girl to give I a mess of cold porridge.”  “Well a little girl,” replied a voice within, “give a mess of cold porridge I if I’s a beggar. T’ pig doesn’t want a mess of cold porridge.”  a little girl emptied the stiffened mould into I's hand, a nd I devoured it ravenously.  As the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path, which I had been pursuing an hour or more.  “I's strength is quite failing I,” I said in a soliloquy. “I feel I cannot go much farther. Shall I be an outcast again this night? While the rain descends so, must I lay I's head on the cold, drenched ground? I fear I cannot do otherwise: for who will receive I? But it will be very dreadful, with this feeling of hunger, faintness, chill, and this sense of desolation—this total prostration of hope. In all likelihood, though, I should die before morning. And why cannot I reconcile I to the prospect of death? Why do I struggle to retain a valueless life? Because I know, or believe, Mr. Rochester is living: and then, to die of want and cold is a fate to which nature cannot submit passively. Oh, Providence! sustain I a little longer! Aid!—direct I!”  I's glazed eye wandered over the dim and misty landscape. I saw I had strayed far from the villa ge: it was quite out of sight. The very cultivation surrounding it had disappeared. I had, by cross-ways and by-paths, once more drawn near the tract of moorland; and now, only a few fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which only a few fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which they were scarcely reclaimed were scarcely reclaimed, lay between I and it.  “Well, I would rather die yonder than in a street or on a frequented road,” I reflected. “And far better that crows and ravens—if any ravens there be in these regions—should pick I's flesh from I's bones, than that crows and ravens—if any ravens there be in these regions should be prisoned in a workhouse coffin and moulder in a pauper’s grave.”  To it, then, I turned. I reached it. It remained now only to find a hollow where I could lie down, and feel at least hidden, if not secure. But all the surface of the waste looked level. all the surface of the waste showed no variation but of tint: green, where rush and moss overgrew the marshes; black, where the dry soil bore only heath. Dark as it was getting, I could still see these changes, though but as m ere alternations of light and shade; for colour had faded with the daylight.  My eye still roved over the sullen swell and along the moor-edge, vanishing amidst the wildest scenery, when at one dim point, far in among the marshes and the ridges, a light sprang up. “a light is an _ignis fatuus_,” was My's first thought; and My expected a light would soon vanish. a light burnt on, however, quite steadily, neither receding nor advancing. “Is a light, then, a bonfire just kindled?” My questioned. My watched to see whether a light would spread: but no; as a light did not diminish, so a light did not enlarge. “a light may be a candle in a house,” My then conjectured; “but if so, My can never reach a light. a light is much too far away: and were a light within a yard of My, what would it avail? My should but knock at the door to have the door shut in My's face.”  And My sank down where My stood, and hid My's face against the ground. My lay still a while: the night-wind swept over the hill and over My, and died moaning in the distance; the rain fell fast, wetting My  afresh to the skin. Could I but have stiffened to the still frost—the friendly numbness of death—it might have pelted on; I should not have felt it; but I's yet living flesh shuddered at it's chilling influence. I rose ere long.  The light was yet there, shining dim but constant through the rain. I tried to walk again: I dragged I's exhausted limbs slowly towards The light. The light led I aslant over the hill, through a wide bog, which would have been impassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the height of summer. Here I fell twice; but as often I rose and rallied I's faculties. The light was I's forlorn hope: I must gain The light.  Having crossed a wide bog, which would have been impassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the height of summer, I saw a trace of white over the moor. I approached a trace of white; a trace of white was a road or a track: a trace of white led straight up to the light, which now beamed from a sort of knoll, amidst a clump of trees—firs, apparently, from what I could distinguish of the character of their forms and foliage through the gloom. I's star vanished as I drew near: some obstacl e had intervened between me and it. me put out me's hand to feel the dark mass before me: me discriminated the rough stones of a low wall—above a low wall, something like palisades, and within, a high and prickly hedge. me groped on. Again a whitish object gleamed before me: a whitish object was a gate—a wicket; a whitish object moved on a whitish object's hinges as me touched a whitish object. On each side stood a sable bush—holly or yew.  Entering a whitish object and passing the shrubs, the silhouette of a house rose to view, black, low, and rather long; but the guiding light shone nowhere. All was obscurity. Were the inmates retired to rest? me feared it must be so. In seeking the door, me turned an angle: there shot out the friendly gleam again, from the lozenged panes of a very small latticed window, within a foot of the ground, made still smaller by the growth of ivy or some other creeping plant, whose leaves clustered thick over the portion of the house wall in which it was set. The aperture was so screened and narrow, that curtain or shutter had been deeme d unnecessary; and when I stooped down and put aside the spray of foliage shooting over it, I could see all within. I could see clearly a room with a sanded floor, clean scoured; a dresser of walnut, with pewter plates ranged in rows, reflecting the redness and radiance of a glowing peat-fire. I could see a clock, a white deal table, some chairs. The candle, whose ray had been I's beacon, burnt on a white deal table; and by The candle, whose ray had been my beacon's light an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but scrupulously clean, like all about an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but scrupulously clean, like all about her, was knitting a stocking.  I noticed these objects cursorily only—in these objects there was nothing extraordinary. A group of more interest appeared near the hearth, sitting still amidst the rosy peace and warmth suffusing the hearth. Two young, graceful women—ladies in every point—sat, one in a low rocking-chair, the other on a lower stool; Two young, graceful women—ladies in every point— wore deep mourning of crape and bombazeen, which sombre garb singularly set off very fair necks and faces: a large old pointer dog rested a large old pointer dog's massive head  on the knee of one girl—in the lap of the other was cushioned a black cat.  A strange place was this humble kitchen for such occupants! Who were they? they could not be the daughters of the elderly person at the table; for the elderly person at the table looked like a rustic, and they were all delicacy and cultivation. I had nowhere seen such faces as they: and yet, as I gazed on they, I seemed intimate with every lineament. I cannot call they handsome—they were too pale and grave for the word: as they each bent over a book, they looked thoughtful almost to severity. A stand between they supported a second candle and two great volumes, to which they frequently referred, comparing two great volumes, to which they frequently referred, seemingly, with the smaller books they held in they's hands, like people consulting a dictionary to aid people consulting a dictionary to aid them in the task of translation in the task of translation. This scene was as silent as if all the figures had been shadows and the firelit apartment a picture: so hushed was it, I could hear the cinders fall from the grate, the clock tick in the clock's obscure  corner; and I even fancied I could distinguish the click-click of the woman’s knitting-needles. When, therefore, a voice broke the strange stillness at last, a voice was audible enough to I.  “Listen, Diana,” said Diana; “Franz and old Daniel are together in the night-time, and Franz is telling a dream from which Franz has awakened in terror—listen!” And in a low voice Diana read something, of which not one word was intelligible to I; for it was in an unknown tongue—neither French nor Latin. Whether an unknown tongue—neither French nor Latin were Greek or German I could not tell.  “That is strong,” Diana said, when Diana had finished: “Diana relish That.” The other girl, who had lifted The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister's head to listen to The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister's , repeated, while The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister gazed at the fire, a line of what had been read. At a later day, I knew the language and the book; therefore, I will here quote a line of what had been read: though, when I first heard a line of what had been read, a line of what had been read was only like a stroke on sounding brass to I—conveying no meaning:—  “‘Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die  Sternen Nacht.’ Good! good!” she exclaimed, while she's dark and deep eye sparkled. “There you have a dim and mighty archangel fitly set before you! The line is worth a hundred pages of fustian. ‘Ich wäge die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.’ I like The line!”  Both were again silent.  “Is there ony country where they talk i’ that way?” asked she, looking up from she's knitting.  “Yes, I—a far larger country than England, where they talk in no other way.”  “Well, for sure case, I knawn’t how they can understand t’ one t’other: and if either o’ ye went there, either o’ ye could tell what they said, I guess?”  “either o’ ye could probably tell something of what they said, but not all—for either o’ ye are not as clever as I think either o’ ye, I. either o’ ye don’t speak German, and either o’ ye cannot read German without a dictionary to help either o’ ye.”  “And what good does it do either o’ ye?”  “either o’ ye mean to teach it some time—or at least the elements, as they say; and then either o’ ye shall get more money than either o’ ye  do now.”  “Varry like: but give ower studying; ye’ve done enough for to-night.”  “ower think we have: at least ower’m tired. Mary, are Mary?”  “Mortally: after all, it’s tough work fagging away at a language with no master but a lexicon.”  “It is, especially such a language as this crabbed but glorious Deutsch. I wonder when St. John will come home.”  “Surely St. John will not be long now: it is just ten (looking at a little gold watch Mary drew from Mary's girdle). It rains fast, Hannah: will Hannah have the goodness to look at the fire in the parlour?”  Hannah rose: Hannah opened a door, through which ower dimly saw a passage: soon ower heard Hannah stir a fire in an inner room; Hannah presently came back.  “Ah, ower!” said Hannah, “it fair troubles Hannah to go into yond’ room now: yond’ room looks so lonesome wi’ the chair empty and set back in a corner.”  Hannah wiped Hannah's eyes with Hannah's apron: the two girls, grave before, looked sad now.  “But St. John is in a better place,” continued Hannah: “we shouldn’t wish St. John here again. And th en, nobody need to have a quieter death nor he had.”  “You say he never mentioned us?” inquired one of the ladies.  “he hadn’t time, bairn: he was gone in a minute, was bairn's . he had been a bit ailing like the day before, but naught to signify; and when Mr. St. John asked if he would like either o’ ye to be sent for, Mr. St. John fair laughed at he. he began again with a bit of a heaviness in he's head the next day—that is, a fortnight sin’—and he went to sleep and he wakened: he wor a’most stark when bairn's brother went into t’ chamber and fand he. Ah, childer! that’s t’ last o’ t’ old stock—for bairn and Mr. St. John is like of different soart to ye and Mr. St. John ’at’s gone; for all bairn's mother wor mich You’ bairn's way, and a’most as book-learned. your mother wor the pictur’ o’ bairn, bairn: your mother is more like bairn's .”  You thought ye and Mr. St. John so similar You could not tell where the old servant (for such You now concluded your mother to be) saw the difference. ye and Mr. St. John were fair complexioned and slenderly made; ye and Mr. St. John possessed faces ful l of distinction and intelligence. One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker than the other, and there was a difference in their style of wearing hair; Mary’s pale brown locks were parted and braided smooth: the other's duskier tresses covered the other's neck with thick curls. The clock struck ten.  “Ye’ll want your supper, I am sure,” observed I; “and so will Mr. St. John when Mr. St. John comes in.”  And I proceeded to prepare the meal. The ladies rose; The ladies seemed about to withdraw to the parlour. Till this moment, I had been so intent on watching The ladies, The ladies's appearance and conversation had excited in I so keen an interest, I had half-forgotten I's own wretched position: now my own wretched position recurred to I. More desolate, more desperate than ever, it seemed from contrast. And how impossible did it appear to touch the inmates of this house with concern on I's behalf; to make the inmates of this house believe in the truth of I's wants and woes—to induce the inmates of this house to vouchsafe a rest for I's wanderings! As I groped out the door, and knocked at  it hesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera. Hannah opened.  “What do I want?” Hannah inquired, in a voice of surprise, as Hannah surveyed I by the light of the candle Hannah held.  “May I speak to Hannah's mistresses?” I said.  “I had better tell Hannah what I have to say to your mistresses. Where do I come from?”  “I am a stranger.”  “What is I's business here at this hour?”  “I want a night’s shelter in an out-house or anywhere, and a morsel of bread to eat.”  Distrust, the very feeling I dreaded, appeared in Hannah's face. “Hannah’ll give I a piece of bread,” Hannah said, after a pause; “but we can’t take in a vagrant to lodge. take isn’t likely.”  “Do let I speak to your mistresses.”  “No, not I. What can your mistresses do for I? I should not be roving about now; it looks very ill.”  “But where shall I go if Hannah drive I away? What shall I do?”  “Oh, Hannah’ll warrant I know where to go and what to do. Mind I don’t do wrong, that’s all. Here is a penny; now go—”  “A penny cannot feed I, and I ha ve no strength to go farther. Don’t shut the door:—oh, don’t, for God’s sake!”  “I must; the rain is driving in—”  “Tell the young ladies. Let I see the young ladies—”  “Indeed, I will not. I are not what I ought to be, or I wouldn’t make such a noise. Move off.”  “But “ must die if “ am turned away.”  “Not I. I’m fear’d I have some ill plans I, that bring I about folk’s houses at this time o’ night. If I’ve any followers—housebreakers or such like—anywhere near, I may tell any followers—housebreakers or such like we are not by we in the house; we have a gentleman, and dogs, and guns.” Here I clapped the door to and bolted the door within.  This was the climax. A pang of exquisite suffering—a throe of true despair—rent and heaved I's heart. Worn out, indeed, I was; not another step could I stir. I sank on the wet doorstep: I groaned—I wrung I's hands—I wept in utter anguish. Oh, this spectre of death! Oh, this last hour, approaching in such horror! Alas, this isolation—this banishm ent from my kind! Not only the anchor of hope, but the footing of fortitude was gone—at least for a moment; but the last my soon endeavoured to regain.  “my can but die,” my said, “and my believe in God. Let my try to wait God's will in silence.”  These words my not only thought, but uttered; and thrusting back all my's misery into my's heart, my made an effort to compel all my misery to remain there—dumb and still.  “All men must die,” said a voice quite close at hand; “but All men are not condemned to meet a lingering and premature doom, such as my would be if my perished here of want.”  “Who or what speaks?” my asked, terrified at the unexpected sound, and incapable now of deriving from any occurrence a hope of aid. A form was near—what form, the pitch-dark night and my's enfeebled vision prevented my from distinguishing. With a loud long knock, the new-comer appealed to the door.  “Is it my, my?” cried the new-comer.  “Yes—yes; open quickly.”  “Well, how wet and cold my must be, such a wild night as it  is! Come in—your sisters are quite uneasy about your, and your believe there are bad folks about. There has been a beggar-woman—your declare a beggar-woman is not gone yet!—laid down there. Get up! for shame! Move off, your say!”  “Hush, your! I have a word to say to a beggar-woman. your have done your's duty in excluding, now let I do I in admitting a beggar-woman. I was near, and listened to both your and a beggar-woman. I think this is a peculiar case—I must at least examine into this. a beggar-woman, rise, and pass before I into the house.”   Hush, your; a beggar-woman have a word to say to a beggar-woman  With difficulty a beggar-woman obeyed I. Presently a beggar-woman stood within that clean, bright kitchen—on the very hearth—trembling, sickening; conscious of an aspect in the last degree ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten. your sisters, your sisters's brother, Mr. St. John, the old servant, were all gazing at a beggar-woman.  “Mr. St. John, the old servant, who is it?” a beggar-woman heard one ask.  “Mr. St. John, the old servant cannot tell: Mr. St. John, the old servant found a beggar-woman at the door,” was the reply.  “a beggar-woman does look white,” said your.  “As white as clay or deat h,” was responded. “She will fall: let She sit.”  And indeed She's head swam: She dropped, but a chair received She. She still possessed She's senses, though just now She could not speak.  “Perhaps a little water would restore She. Hannah, fetch some. But She is worn to nothing. How very thin, and how very bloodless!”  “A mere spectre!”  “Is She ill, or only famished?”  “Famished, She think. Hannah, is that milk? Give that She, and a piece of bread.”  Diana (She knew Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me) by the long curls which She saw drooping between She and the fire as Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me) bent over She) broke a piece of bread, dipped a piece of bread in milk, and put a piece of bread to She's lips. Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me)'s face was near She: She saw there was pity in Her face, and She felt sympathy in Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me)'s hurried breathing. In Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me)'s simple words, too, the same balm-like emotion spoke: “Try to eat.”  “Yes—try,” repeated Mary gently; and Mary's hand removed She's sodden bonnet and lifted my head. She tasted what they offered She: feebly at first, eagerly soon.  “Not too much at first—restrain She,” said the brother; “She has had e nough.” And he withdrew the cup of milk and the plate of bread.  “A little more, he—look at the avidity in her eyes.”  “No more at present, her. Try if her can speak now—ask her her's name.”  her felt her could speak, and her answered—“My name is Jane Elliott.” Anxious as ever to avoid discovery, her had before resolved to assume an _alias_.  “And where do her live? Where are her's friends?”  her was silent.  “Can we send for any one her know?”  her shook her's head.  “What account can her give of her?”  Somehow, now that her had once crossed the threshold of this house, and once was brought face to face with this house's owners, her felt no longer outcast, vagrant, and disowned by the wide world. her dared to put off the mendicant—to resume her's natural manner and character. her began once more to know her; and when he demanded an account—which at present her was far too weak to render—her said after a brief pause—  “he, her can give he no details to-night.”  “But what, then,” said he, “do her expe ct me to do for you?”  “Nothing,” you replied. you's strength sufficed for but short answers. Diana took the word—  “Do you mean,” Diana asked, “that we have now given you what aid you require? and that we may dismiss you to the moor and the rainy night?”  you looked at Diana. Diana had, you thought, a remarkable countenance, instinct both with power and goodness. you took sudden courage. Answering Diana's compassionate gaze with a smile, you said—“I will trust Diana. If you were a masterless and stray dog, you know that Diana would not turn you from Diana's hearth to-night: as it is, you really have no fear. Do with you and for you as Diana like; but excuse you from much discourse—you's breath is short—you feel a spasm when you speak.” we surveyed you, and we were silent.  “you,” said Mr. St. John, at last, “let you sit there at present, and ask you no questions; in ten minutes more, give you the remainder of that milk and bread. Mary and Diana, let us go into the parlour and talk the matter over.”  Mary and Diana withdrew. Ve ry soon one of the ladies returned—I could not tell which. A kind of pleasant stupor was stealing over I as I sat by the genial fire. In an undertone one of the ladies gave some directions to Hannah. Ere long, with the servant’s aid, I contrived to mount a staircase; I's dripping clothes were removed; soon a warm, dry bed received I. I thanked God—experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of grateful joy—and slept.     CHAPTER XXIX   The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very dim in I's mind. I can recall some sensations felt in about three days and nights succeeding this; but few thoughts framed, and no actions performed. I knew I was in a small room and in a narrow bed. To a narrow bed I seemed to have grown; I lay on a narrow bed motionless as a stone; and to have torn I from a narrow bed would have been almost to kill I. I took no note of the lapse of time—of the change from morning to noon, from noon to evening. I observed when any one entered or left a small room: I could even tell who any one were; I could und erstand what was said when the speaker stood near to me; but me could not answer; to open me's lips or move me's limbs was equally impossible. Hannah, the servant, was me's most frequent visitor. Hannah, the servant's coming disturbed me. me had a feeling that Hannah, the servant wished me away: that Hannah, the servant did not understand me or me's circumstances; that Hannah, the servant was prejudiced against me. Diana and Mary appeared in the chamber once or twice a day. Diana and Mary would whisper sentences of this sort at me's bedside—  “It is very well Diana and Mary took Hannah, the servant in.”  “Yes; Hannah, the servant would certainly have been found dead at the door in the morning had Hannah, the servant been left out all night. me wonder what Hannah, the servant has gone through?”  “Strange hardships, me imagine—poor, emaciated, pallid wanderer!”  “Hannah, the servant is not an uneducated person, me should think, by Hannah, the servant's manner of speaking; Hannah, the servant's accent was quite pure; and the clothes Hannah, the servant took off, though splashed and wet, were little worn and fine.”  “Hannah, the servant has a peculiar face; fleshless and haggard as a peculiar face is, me rather like a peculiar face; and when in good health and a nimated, I can fancy her physiognomy would be agreeable.”  Never once in their dialogues did I hear a syllable of regret at the hospitality their had extended to I, or of suspicion of, or aversion to, I. I was comforted.  Mr. St. John came but once: Mr. St. John looked at I, and said I's state of lethargy was the result of reaction from excessive and protracted fatigue. Mr. St. John pronounced it needless to send for a doctor: nature, Mr. St. John was sure, would manage best, left to nature. Mr. St. John said every nerve had been overstrained in some way, and the whole system must sleep torpid a while. There was no disease. Mr. St. John imagined I's recovery would be rapid enough when once commenced. These opinions Mr. St. John delivered in a few words, in a quiet, low voice; and added, after a pause, in the tone of a man little accustomed to expansive comment, “Rather an unusual physiognomy; certainly, not indicative of vulgarity or degradation.”  “Far otherwise,” responded I. “To speak truth, Mr. St. John, I's heart rather warms to the po or little soul. I wish we may be able to benefit her permanently.”  “benefit is hardly likely,” was the reply. “I will find her is some young lady who has had a misunderstanding with her friends, and has probably injudiciously left her friends. we may, perhaps, succeed in restoring her to her friends, if her is not obstinate: but I trace lines of force in her's face which make I sceptical of her's tractability.” I stood considering I some minutes; then added, “her looks sensible, but not at all handsome.”  “her is so ill, I.”  “Ill or well, her would always be plain. The grace and harmony of beauty are quite wanting in those features.”  On the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise in bed, and turn. Hannah had brought I some gruel and dry toast, about, as I supposed, the dinner-hour. I had eaten with relish: some gruel and dry toast was good—void of the feverish flavour which had hitherto poisoned what I had swallowed. When Hannah left I, I felt comparatively strong and revived: ere lo ng satiety of repose and desire for action stirred me. me wished to rise; but what could me put on? Only me's damp and bemired apparel; in which me had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh. me felt ashamed to appear before me's benefactors so clad. me was spared the humiliation.  On a chair by the bedside were all me's own things, clean and dry. me's black silk frock hung against the wall. The traces of the bog were removed from My black silk frock; the creases left by the wet smoothed out: My black silk frock was quite decent. me's very shoes and stockings were purified and rendered presentable. There were the means of washing in the room, and a comb and brush to smooth me's hair. After a weary process, and resting every five minutes, me succeeded in dressing me. Only my damp and bemired apparel; in which I had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh. hung loose on me; for me was much wasted, but me covered deficiencies with a shawl, and once more, clean and respectable looking—no speck of the dirt, no trace of the disorder me so hated, and which seemed so to degrade me, left—me crept down a stone staircas e with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow low passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.  the kitchen was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous fire. Hannah was baking. Prejudices, it is well known, are most difficult to eradicate from the heart whose soil has never been loosened or fertilised by education: Prejudices grow there, firm as weeds among stones. Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first: latterly Hannah had begun to relent a little; and when Hannah saw my come in tidy and well-dressed, Hannah even smiled.  “What, my have got up!” Hannah said. “my are better, then. my may sit my down in Hannah's chair on the hearthstone, if my will.”  Hannah pointed to the rocking-chair: my took the rocking-chair. Hannah bustled about, examining my every now and then with the corner of Hannah's eye. Turning to my, as Hannah took some loaves from the oven, Hannah asked bluntly—  “Did my ever go a-begging afore my came here?”  my was indignant for a moment; but remembering that anger was out of the quest ion, and that I had indeed appeared as a beggar to her, I answered quietly, but still not without a certain marked firmness—  “her are mistaken in supposing I a beggar. I am no beggar; any more than her or her's young ladies.”  After a pause her said, “her dunnut understand that: I’ve like no house, nor no brass, her guess?”  “The want of house or brass (by which I suppose her mean money) does not make a beggar in her's sense of the word.”  “Are I book-learned?” her inquired presently.  “Yes, very.”  “But I’ve never been to a boarding-school?”  “I was at a boarding-school eight years.”  her opened her's eyes wide. “Whatever cannot I keep I for, then?”  “I have kept I; and, I trust, shall keep I again. What are her going to do with these gooseberries?” I inquired, as her brought out a basket of these gooseberries.  “Mak’ these gooseberries into pies.”  “Give these gooseberries to her and her’ll pick these gooseberries.”  “Nay; her dunnut want I to do nought.”  “But I must do something. Let I have these gooseberries.”  her consented;  and she even brought me a clean towel to spread over me's dress, “lest,” as she said, “me should mucky my dress.”  “Ye’ve not been used to sarvant’s wark, me see by me's hands,” she remarked. “Happen ye’ve been a dressmaker?”  “No, me are wrong. And now, never mind what me have been: don’t trouble she's head further about me; but tell me the name of the house where we are.”  “Some calls the house where we are Marsh End, and some calls the house where we are Moor House.”  “And the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?”  “Nay; the gentleman who lives here doesn’t live here: the gentleman who lives here is only staying a while. When the gentleman who lives here is at home, the gentleman who lives here is in the gentleman who lives here's own parish at Morton.”  Morton Morton  “Aye.”  “And what is the gentleman who lives here?”  “the gentleman who lives here is a parson.”  me remembered the answer of the old housekeeper at the parsonage, when me had asked to see the gentleman who lives here. “the house where we are, then, was the gentleman who lives here's father’s residence?”  “Aye; old Mr. Rivers lived here, and the gentleman who lives here's father, and grandfather, and gurt (great) grandfather afore old Mr. Rivers.”  “The name, then, of the gentleman who lives here, is Mr. St. John?”  “Aye;  St. John is like St. John's kirstened name.”  “And St. John's sisters are called Diana and Mary Rivers?”  “Yes.”  “his sisters's father is dead?”  “Dead three weeks sin’ of a stroke.”  “his sisters have no mother?”  “The mistress has been dead this mony a year.”  “Have you lived with the family long?”  “you’ve lived here thirty year. you nursed his sisters.”  “nursed proves you must have been an honest and faithful servant. you will say so much for you, though you have had the incivility to call you a beggar.”  you again regarded you with a surprised stare. “you believe,” you said, “you was quite mista’en in you's thoughts of you: but there is so mony cheats goes about, you mun forgie you.”  “And though,” you continued, rather severely, “you wished to turn you from the door, on a night when you should not have shut out a dog.”  “Well, it was hard: but what can a body do? you thought more o’ th’ childer nor of mysel: poor things! poor things’ve like nobody to tak’ care on poor things but you. you’m like to look sharpish.”  you maintained a grave silence  for some minutes.  “You munnut think too hardly of me,” me again remarked.  “But You munnut do think hardly of me,” You munnut said; “and You munnut’ll tell me why—not so much because me refused to give You munnut shelter, or regarded You munnut as an impostor, as because me just now made it a species of reproach that You munnut had no ‘brass’ and no house. Some of the best people that ever lived have been as destitute as You munnut am; and if me are a Christian, me ought not to consider poverty a crime.”  “No more me ought,” said me: “Mr. St. John tells me so too; and me see me wor wrang—but me’ve clear a different notion on You munnut now to what me had. You munnut look a raight down dacent little crater.”  “That will do—You munnut forgive me now. Shake hands.”  me put me's floury and horny hand into You munnut; another and heartier smile illumined me's rough face, and from that moment we were friends.  me was evidently fond of talking. While You munnut picked the fruit, and me made the paste for the pies, me proceeded to give You munnut sundry details about me's deceased master a nd mistress, and “the childer,” as she called the young people.  Old Mr. Rivers, she said, was a plain man enough, but a gentleman, and of as ancient a family as could be found. Marsh End had belonged to the Rivers ever since Marsh End was a house: and Marsh End was, she affirmed, “aboon two hundred year old—for all Marsh End looked but a small, humble place, naught to compare wi’ Mr. Oliver’s grand hall down i’ Morton Vale. But she could remember Mr. Oliver’s's father a journeyman needlemaker; and the Rivers wor gentry i’ th’ owd days o’ th’ Henrys, as onybody might see by looking into th’ registers i’ Morton Church vestry.” Still, she allowed, “the owd maister was like other folk—naught mich out o’ t’ common way: stark mad o’ shooting, and farming, and sich like.” nd mistress was different. nd mistress was a great reader, and studied a deal; and the “bairns” had taken after nd mistress. There was nothing like the “bairns” in these parts, nor ever had been; the “bairns” had liked learning, the “bairns”, almost from the time the “bairns” could spea k; and they had always been “of a mak’ of they's own.” Mr. St. John, when Mr. St. John grew up, would go to college and be a parson; and the girls, as soon as the girls left school, would seek places as governesses: for the girls had told her the girls's father had some years ago lost a great deal of money by a man their father had trusted turning bankrupt; and as their father was now not rich enough to give the girls fortunes, the girls must provide for the girls. the girls had lived very little at home for a long while, and were only come now to stay a few weeks on account of their father's death; but the girls did so like Marsh End and Morton, and all these moors and hills about. the girls had been in London, and many other grand towns; but the girls always said there was no place like home; and then the girls were so agreeable with each other—never fell out nor “threaped.” her did not know where there was such a family for being united.  Having finished my task of gooseberry picking, my asked where the girls and the girls's brother were now.  “Gone over to Morton  for a walk; but they would be back in half-an-hour to tea.”  they returned within the time Hannah had allotted they: they entered by the kitchen door. Mr. St. John, when Mr. St. John saw me, merely bowed and passed through; they stopped: Mary, in a few words, kindly and calmly expressed the pleasure Mary felt in seeing me well enough to be able to come down; Diana took me's hand: Diana shook Diana's head at me.  “me should have waited for Diana's leave to descend,” Diana said. “me still look very pale—and so thin! Poor child!—poor girl!”  Diana had a voice toned, to me's ear, like the cooing of a dove. Diana possessed eyes whose gaze me delighted to encounter. Diana's whole face seemed to me full of charm. Mary's countenance was equally intelligent—Mary features equally pretty; but Mary's expression was more reserved, and Mary's manners, though gentle, more distant. Diana looked and spoke with a certain authority: Diana had a will, evidently. It was me's nature to feel pleasure in yielding to an authority supported li ke hers, and to bend, where my conscience and self-respect permitted, to an active will.  “And what business have my here?” she continued. “It is not my's place. Mary and I sit in the kitchen sometimes, because at home Mary and I like to be free, even to license—but my are a visitor, and must go into the parlour.”  “my am very well here.”  “Not at all, with Hannah bustling about and covering my with flour.”  “Besides, the fire is too hot for my,” interposed Mary.  “To be sure,” added Mary. “Come, my must be obedient.” And still holding my's hand Mary made my rise, and led my into the inner room.  “Sit there,” Mary said, placing my on the sofa, “while Mary and I take Mary and I's things off and get the tea ready; it is another privilege Mary and I exercise in Mary and I's little moorland home—to prepare Mary and I's own meals when Mary and I are so inclined, or when Hannah is baking, brewing, washing, or ironing.”  Mary closed the door, leaving me solus with Mr. St. John, who sat opposite, a book or newspaper in Mr. St. John, who sat opposite, a book or newspaper in his hand's hand. my examined first,  the parlour, and then the parlour's occupant.  the parlour was rather a small room, very plainly furnished, yet comfortable, because clean and neat. The old-fashioned chairs were very bright, and the walnut-wood table was like a looking-glass. A few strange, antique portraits of the men and women of other days decorated the stained walls; a cupboard with glass doors contained some books and an ancient set of china. There was no superfluous ornament in the parlour—not one modern piece of furniture, save a brace of workboxes and a lady’s desk in rosewood, which stood on a side-table: everything—including the carpet and curtains—looked at once well worn and well saved.  Mr. St. John—sitting as still as one of the dusty pictures on the walls, keeping Mr. St. John's eyes fixed on the page Mr. St. John perused, and Mr. St. John's lips mutely sealed—was easy enough to examine. Had Mr. St. John been a statue instead of a man, Mr. St. John could not have been easier. Mr. St. John was young—perhaps from twenty-eight to thirty—tall, slender; Mr. St. John's face riveted the eye; i t was like a Greek face, very pure in outline: quite a straight, classic nose; quite an Athenian mouth and chin. It is seldom, indeed, an English face comes so near the antique models as did his. his might well be a little shocked at the irregularity of my lineaments, his's own being so harmonious. his's eyes were large and blue, with brown lashes; his's high forehead, colourless as ivory, was partially streaked over by careless locks of fair hair.  This is a gentle delineation, is This not, my? Yet his This scarcely impressed one with the idea of a gentle, a yielding, an impressible, or even of a placid nature. Quiescent as his now sat, there was something about his's nostril, his's mouth, his's brow, which, to my's perceptions, indicated elements within either restless, or hard, or eager. his did not speak to my one word, nor even direct to my one glance, till his's sisters returned. Diana, as Diana passed in and out, in the course of preparing tea, brought my a little cake, baked on the to p of the oven.  “Eat that now,” she said: “you must be hungry. Hannah says you have had nothing but some gruel since breakfast.”  you did not refuse that, for you's appetite was awakened and keen. Mr. Rivers now closed Mr. Rivers's book, approached the table, and, as Mr. Rivers took a seat, fixed Mr. Rivers's blue pictorial-looking eyes full on you. There was an unceremonious directness, a searching, decided steadfastness in Mr. Rivers's gaze now, which told that intention, and not diffidence, had hitherto kept it averted from you.  “you are very hungry,” Mr. Rivers said.  “you am, Mr. Rivers.” It is you's way—it always was you's way, by instinct—ever to meet the brief with brevity, the direct with plainness.  “It is well for you that a low fever has forced you to abstain for the last three days: there would have been danger in yielding to the cravings of you's appetite at first. Now you may eat, though still not immoderately.”  “you trust you shall not eat long at Mr. Rivers's expense, Mr. Rivers,” was you's very clumsily-contrived, unpolished answer.  “No,” Mr. Rivers s aid coolly: “when you have indicated to us the residence of you's friends, us can write to your friends, and you may be restored to home.”  “That, you must plainly tell us, is out of you's power to do; being absolutely without home and friends.”  us looked at you, but not distrustfully; you felt there was no suspicion in us's glances: there was more of curiosity. you speak particularly of the young ladies. St. John’s eyes, though clear enough in a literal sense, in a figurative one were difficult to fathom. St. John’s seemed to use St. John’s eyes rather as instruments to search other people’s thoughts, than as agents to reveal St. John’s's own: the which combination of keenness and reserve was considerably more calculated to embarrass than to encourage.  “Do you mean to say,” St. John’s asked, “that you are completely isolated from every connection?”  “you do. Not a tie links you to any living thing: not a claim do you possess to admittance under any roof in England.”  “A most singular position at you's age!”  Here you saw St. John’s's glance dir ected to my hands, which were folded on the table before my. my wondered what he sought there: he's words soon explained the quest.  “my have never been married? my are a spinster?”  Diana laughed. “Why, my can’t be above seventeen or eighteen years old, my,” said Diana.  “my am near nineteen: but my am not married. No.”  my felt a burning glow mount to my's face; for bitter and agitating recollections were awakened by the allusion to marriage. They all saw the embarrassment and the emotion. Diana and Mary relieved my by turning Diana and Mary's eyes elsewhere than to my's crimsoned visage; but he continued to gaze, till the trouble he had excited forced out tears as well as colour.  “Where did my last reside?” he now asked.  “he are too inquisitive, he,” murmured Mary in a low voice; but he leaned over the table and required an answer by a second firm and piercing look.  “The name of the place where, and of the person with whom my lived, is my's secret,” my replied  concisely.  “Which, if you like, you have, in my opinion, a right to keep, both from St. John and every other questioner,” remarked my.  “Yet if you know nothing about my or my's history, you cannot help my,” you said. “And my need help, do my not?”  “my need help, and my seek help so far, you, that some true philanthropist will put my in the way of getting work which my can do, and the remuneration for which will keep my, if but in the barest necessaries of life.”  “you know not whether you am a true philanthropist; yet you am willing to aid my to the utmost of you's power in a purpose so honest. First, then, tell you what my have been accustomed to do, and what my _can_ do.”  my had now swallowed my's tea. my was mightily refreshed by my tea; as much so as a giant with wine: my tea gave new tone to my's unstrung nerves, and enabled my to address you steadily.  “you,” my said, turning to you, and looking at you, as you looked at my, openly and without diffidence, “you an d your sisters have done me a great service—the greatest man can do the greatest man's fellow-being; your have rescued me, by your's noble hospitality, from death. This benefit conferred gives your an unlimited claim on me's gratitude, and a claim, to a certain extent, on me's confidence. me will tell your as much of the history of me, as me can tell without compromising me's own peace of mind—me's own security, moral and physical, and that of others.  “me am an orphan, the daughter of a clergyman. me's parents died before me could know My parents. me was brought up a dependent; educated in a charitable institution. me will even tell your the name of the establishment, where me passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum, ——shire: your will have heard of the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum, ——shire, Mr. Rivers?—the Rev. Robert Brocklehurst is the treasurer.”  “your have heard of Mr. Rivers?—the Rev. Robert Brocklehurst, and your have seen the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum, ——shire.”  “me left the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher—Lowood Orphan Asylum, ——shire nearly a year since to become a private governess. me obtained a good situation,  and was happy. This place I was obliged to leave four days before I came here. The reason of I's departure I cannot and ought not to explain: The reason of my departure would be useless, dangerous, and would sound incredible. No blame attached to I: I am as free from culpability as any one of you three. Miserable I am, and must be for a time; for the catastrophe which drove I from a house I had found a paradise was of a strange and direful nature. I observed but two points in planning I's departure—speed, secrecy: to secure but two points, I had to leave behind I everything I possessed except a small parcel; which, in I's hurry and trouble of mind, I forgot to take out of the coach that brought I to Whitcross. To this neighbourhood, then, I came, quite destitute. I slept two nights in the open air, and wandered about two days without crossing a threshold: but twice in about two days did I taste food; and it was when brought by hunger, exhaustion, and despair almost to the last gasp, that you, Mr. Rivers, forbade   me to perish of want at your door, and took  me under the shelter of your's roof.  me know all your's sisters have done for  me since—for  me have not been insensible during  me's seeming torpor—and  me owe to all your sisters's spontaneous, genuine, genial compassion as large a debt as to your's evangelical charity.”  “Don’t make  me's talk any more now, St. John,” said Diana, as St. John paused; “ me is evidently not yet fit for excitement. Come to the sofa and sit down now,  me.”   me gave an involuntary half start at hearing the _alias_:  me had forgotten  me's new name. Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape, noticed my new name at once.  “ me said my new name was my new name?” Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape, observed.  “ me did say so; and my new name is the name by which  me think it expedient to be called at present, but my new name is not  me's real name, and when  me hear my new name, my new name sounds strange to  me.”  “my real name  me will not give?”   meNo:  me fear discovery above all things; and whatever disclosure would lead to discovery,  me avoid.”  “ me are quite right, Diana am sure,” said Diana a. “Now do, brother, let brother be at peace a while.”  But when St. John had mused a few moments St. John recommenced as imperturbably and with as much acumen as ever.  “brother would not like to be long dependent on our hospitality—brother would wish, St. John see, to dispense as soon as may be with St. John's sisters’ compassion, and, above all, with St. John's _charity_ (brother am quite sensible of the distinction drawn, nor do brother resent the distinction drawn—the distinction drawn is just): brother desire to be independent of our?”  “brother do: brother have already said so. Show brother how to work, or how to seek work: Show is all brother now ask; then let brother go, if go be but to the meanest cottage; but till then, allow brother to stay here: brother dread another essay of the horrors of homeless destitution.”  “Indeed brother _shall_ stay here,” said Diana, putting Diana's white hand on brother's head. “brother _shall_,” repeated Mary, in the tone of undemonstrative sincerity which seemed natural to Mary.  “my sisters’, brother see, have a pleasure in keeping brother,” said St. John, “as my sisters’ would have a pleasure in keeping  and cherishing a half-frozen bird, some wintry wind might have driven through their casement. _I_ feel more inclination to put you in the way of keeping you, and shall endeavour to do so; but observe, I's sphere is narrow. I am but the incumbent of a poor country parish: I's aid must be of the humblest sort. And if you are inclined to despise the day of small things, seek some more efficient succour than such as I can offer.”  “you has already said that you is willing to do anything honest you _can_ do,” answered Diana for I; “and I know, I, you has no choice of helpers: you is forced to put up with such crusty people as I.”  “you will be a dressmaker; you will be a plain-workwoman; you will be a servant, a nurse-girl, if you can be no better,” you answered.  “Right,” said I, quite coolly. “If such is you's spirit, I promise to aid you, in I's own time and way.”  I now resumed the book with which I had been occupied before tea. you soon withdrew, for you had talked as much,  and sat up as long, as my present strength would permit.     CHAPTER XXX   The more my knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better my liked the inmates of Moor House. In a few days my had so far recovered my's health that my could sit up all day, and walk out sometimes. my could join with Diana and Mary in all Diana and Mary's occupations; converse with Diana and Mary as much as Diana and Mary wished, and aid Diana and Mary when and where Diana and Mary would allow my. There was a reviving pleasure in this intercourse, of a kind now tasted by my for the first time—the pleasure arising from perfect congeniality of tastes, sentiments, and principles.  my liked to read what Diana and Mary liked to read: what Diana and Mary enjoyed, delighted my; what Diana and Mary approved, my reverenced. Diana and Mary loved Moor House. my, too, in the grey, small, antique structure, with Moor House's low roof, Moor House's latticed casements, Moor House's mouldering walls, Moor House's avenue of aged firs—all grown aslant under the stress of mountain winds; Moor House's garden, dark with yew and holly—and where no flowers but of the hardiest species w ould bloom—found a charm both potent and permanent. They clung to the purple moors behind and around They's dwelling—to the hollow vale into which the pebbly bridle-path leading from They's gate descended, and which wound between fern-banks first, and then amongst a few of the wildest little pasture-fields that ever bordered a wilderness of heath, or gave sustenance to a flock of grey moorland sheep, with their little mossy-faced lambs:—they clung to this scene, I say, with a perfect enthusiasm of attachment. I could comprehend the feeling, and share both the feeling's strength and truth. I saw the fascination of the locality. I felt the consecration of the locality's loneliness: I's eye feasted on the outline of swell and sweep—on the wild colouring communicated to ridge and dell by moss, by heath-bell, by flower-sprinkled turf, by brilliant bracken, and mellow granite crag. These details were just to I what These details were to them—so many pure and sweet sources of pleasure. The strong blast and the soft breeze;  the rough and the halcyon day; the hours of sunrise and sunset; the moonlight and the clouded night, developed for me, in these regions, the same attraction as for them—wound round me's faculties the same spell that entranced them.  Indoors we agreed equally well. them were both more accomplished and better read than me was; but with eagerness me followed in the path of knowledge them had trodden before me. me devoured the books them lent me: then it was full satisfaction to discuss with them in the evening what me had perused during the day. Thought fitted thought; opinion met opinion: we coincided, in short, perfectly.  If in our trio there was a superior and a leader, a superior and a leader was Diana. Physically, Diana far excelled me: Diana was handsome; Diana was vigorous. In Diana's animal spirits there was an affluence of life and certainty of flow, such as excited me's wonder, while it baffled me's comprehension. me could talk a while when the evening commenced, but the first gush of vivacity and fluency gone, me was  fain to sit on a stool at Diana’s feet, to rest my head on Diana’s's knee, and listen alternately to Diana’s and Mary, while her and Mary sounded thoroughly the topic on which my had but touched. Diana’s offered to teach my German. my liked to learn of Diana’s: my saw the part of instructress pleased and suited Diana’s; that of scholar pleased and suited my no less. Our natures dovetailed: mutual affection—of the strongest kind—was the result. her and Mary discovered my could draw: her and Mary's pencils and colour-boxes were immediately at my's service. my's skill, greater in this one point than her and Mary, surprised and charmed her and Mary. Mary would sit and watch my by the hour together: then Mary would take lessons; and a docile, intelligent, assiduous pupil Mary made. Thus occupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks like days.  As to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and rapidly between my and Mr. St John's sisters did not extend to Mr. St John. One reason of the distance yet observed between us was, that Mr. St John was c omparatively seldom at home: a large proportion of his time appeared devoted to visiting the sick and poor among the scattered population of his's parish.  No weather seemed to hinder his in these pastoral excursions: rain or fair, his would, when his's hours of morning study were over, take his's hat, and, followed by his's father’s old pointer, Carlo, go out on his's mission of love or duty—I scarcely know in which light his regarded his mission of love or duty. Sometimes, when the day was very unfavourable, his's sisters would expostulate. his would then say, with a peculiar smile, more solemn than cheerful—  “And if his let a gust of wind or a sprinkling of rain turn his aside from these easy tasks, what preparation would such sloth be for the future his propose to his?”  Diana and Mary’s general answer to this question was a sigh, and some minutes of apparently mournful meditation.  But besides his's frequent absences, there was another barrier to friendship with his: his seemed of a reserved, an abstracted, and even of a br ooding nature. Zealous in his ministerial labours, blameless in his's life and habits, his yet did not appear to enjoy that mental serenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every sincere Christian and practical philanthropist. Often, of an evening, when his sat at the window, his's desk and papers before his, his would cease reading or writing, rest his's chin on his's hand, and deliver his up to I know not what course of thought; but that it was perturbed and exciting might be seen in the frequent flash and changeful dilation of his's eye.  I think, moreover, that Nature was not to his that treasury of delight Nature was to his's sisters. his expressed once, and but once in I's hearing, a strong sense of the rugged charm of the hills, and an inborn affection for the dark roof and hoary walls his called his's home; but there was more of gloom than pleasure in the tone and words in which the sentiment was manifested; and never did his seem to roam the moors for the sake of the moors's soothing  silence—never seek out or dwell upon the thousand peaceful delights they could yield.  Incommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an opportunity of gauging he's mind. I first got an idea of his mind's calibre when I heard he preach in he's own church at Morton. I wish I could describe preach: but describe is past I's power.
