I cannot even render faithfully the effect preach produced on I.  preach began calm—and indeed, as far as delivery and pitch of voice went, preach was calm to the end: an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal breathed soon in the distinct accents, and prompted the nervous language. an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal grew to force—compressed, condensed, controlled. The heart was thrilled, the mind astonished, by the power of he: neither were softened. Throughout there was a strange bitterness; an absence of consolatory gentleness; stern allusions to Calvinistic doctrines—election, predestination, reprobation—were frequent; and each reference to Calvinistic doctrines—election, predestination, reprobation sounded like a sentence pron ounced for doom. When he had done, instead of feeling better, calmer, more enlightened by he's discourse, I experienced an inexpressible sadness; for it seemed to I—I know not whether equally so to others—that the eloquence to which I had been listening had sprung from a depth where lay turbid dregs of disappointment—where moved troubling impulses of insatiate yearnings and disquieting aspirations. I was sure he—pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was—had not yet found that peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found that peace of God which passeth all understanding, I thought, than had I with I's concealed and racking regrets for I's broken idol and lost elysium—regrets to which I have latterly avoided referring, but which possessed I and tyrannised over I ruthlessly.  Meantime a month was gone. Diana and Mary were soon to leave Moor House, and return to the far different life and scene which awaited Diana and Mary, as governesses in a large, fashionable, south-of-England city, where each held a situ ation in families by whose wealthy and haughty members they were regarded only as humble dependents, and who neither knew nor sought out they's innate excellences, and appreciated only they's acquired accomplishments as they appreciated the skill of they's cook or the taste of they's waiting-woman. Mr. St. John had said nothing to me yet about the employment Mr. St. John had promised to obtain for me; yet it became urgent that me should have a vocation of some kind. One morning, being left alone with Mr. St. John a few minutes in the parlour, me ventured to approach the window-recess—which Mr. St. John's table, chair, and desk consecrated as a kind of study—and me was going to speak, though not very well knowing in what words to frame me's inquiry—for it is at all times difficult to break the ice of reserve glassing over such natures as Mr. St. John's—when Mr. St. John saved me the trouble by being the first to commence a dialogue.  Looking up as me drew near—“You have a question to ask of Mr. St. John?” Mr. St. John said.  “Yes; me wish to know whether Mr. St. John have hea rd of any service I can offer I to undertake?”  “I found or devised something for I three weeks ago; but as I seemed both useful and happy here—as I's sisters had evidently become attached to I, and I's society gave my sisters unusual pleasure—I deemed it inexpedient to break in on I's mutual comfort till my sisters's approaching departure from Marsh End should render I necessary.”  “And my sisters will go in three days now?” I said.  “Yes; and when my sisters go, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton: Hannah will accompany I; and this old house will be shut up.”  I waited a few moments, expecting I would go on with the subject first broached: but I seemed to have entered another train of reflection: I's look denoted abstraction from I and I's business. I was obliged to recall I to a theme which was of necessity one of close and anxious interest to I.  “What is the employment I had in view, I? I hope this delay will not have increased the difficulty of securing the employment you had in view.”  “Oh, n o; since it is an employment which depends only on me to give, and you to accept.”  me again paused: there seemed a reluctance to continue. you grew impatient: a restless movement or two, and an eager and exacting glance fastened on me's face, conveyed the feeling to me as effectually as words could have done, and with less trouble.  “you need be in no hurry to hear,” me said: “let me frankly tell you, me have nothing eligible or profitable to suggest. Before me explain, recall, if you please, me's notice, clearly given, that if me helped you, helped must be as the blind man would help the lame. me am poor; for me find that, when me have paid me's father’s debts, all the patrimony remaining to me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind, and the patch of moorish soil, with the yew-trees and holly-bushes in front. me am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole descendants of the race, two earn the dependent’s crust among strangers, and the third considers the third an ali en from his native country—not only for life, but in death. Yes, and deems, and is bound to deem, his honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day when the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his's shoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members his is one, shall give the word, ‘Rise, follow the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members he is one!’”  St. John said these words as St. John pronounced St. John's sermons, with a quiet, deep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of glance. St. John resumed—  “And since St. John am St. John poor and obscure, St. John can offer you but a service of poverty and obscurity. _you_ may even think a service of poverty and obscurity degrading—for St. John see now you's habits have been what the world calls refined: you's tastes lean to the ideal, and you's society has at least been amongst the educated; but _St. John_ consider that no service degrades which can better our race. St. John hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the Christian labourer’s task of tillage is appointed the Christian labourer’s—the scantier the  meed his toil brings—the higher the honour. his's, under such circumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of the Gospel were the Apostles—the first pioneers of the Gospel's captain was Jesus, the Redeemer, Jesus, the Redeemer, Himself.”  “Well?” I said, as he again paused—“proceed.”  he looked at I before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to read I's face, as if my face's features and lines were characters on a page. The conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in he's succeeding observations.  “he believe I will accept the post he offer I,” said he, “and hold the post I offer you for a while: not permanently, though: any more than he could permanently keep the narrow and narrowing—the tranquil, hidden office of English country incumbent; for in I's nature is an alloy as detrimental to repose as that in he, though of a different kind.”  “Do explain,” I urged, when he halted once more.  “he will; and I shall hear how poor the proposal is,—how trivial—how cramping. he shall not stay long at Morton, now that  my father is dead, and that my am my's own master. my shall leave the place probably in the course of a twelve-month; but while my do stay, my will exert my to the utmost for the place's improvement. the place, when my came to the place two years ago, had no school: the children of the poor were excluded from every hope of progress. my established one for boys: my mean now to open a second school for girls. my have hired a building for the purpose, with a cottage of two rooms attached to a building for the purpose, with a cottage of two rooms attached to it for the mistress’s house for the mistress’s house. the mistress’s's salary will be thirty pounds a year: the mistress’s house is already furnished, very simply, but sufficiently, by the kindness of a lady, Miss Oliver; the only daughter of the sole rich man in my's parish—Mr. Oliver, the proprietor of a needle-factory and iron-foundry in the valley. a lady, Miss Oliver pays for the education and clothing of an orphan from the workhouse, on condition that a lady, Miss Oliver shall aid the mistress’s in such menial offices connected with the mistress’s house and a second school for girls as the mistress’s's occupation of teaching w ill prevent her having time to discharge in person. Will you be her?”  He put the question rather hurriedly; He seemed half to expect an indignant, or at least a disdainful rejection of the offer: not knowing all you's thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, He could not tell in what light the lot would appear to you. In truth the lot was humble—but then the lot was sheltered, and you wanted a safe asylum: the lot was plodding—but then, compared with that of a governess in a rich house, the lot was independent; and the fear of servitude with strangers entered you's soul like iron: it was not ignoble—not unworthy—not mentally degrading, you made you's decision.  “you thank He for the proposal, He, and you accept the proposal with all you's heart.”  “But you comprehend He?” He said. “It is a village school: you's scholars will be only poor girls—cottagers’ children—at the best, farmers’ daughters. Knitting, sewing, reading, writing, ciphering, will be all you will have to teach. What will you do with you's accomplis hments? What, with the largest portion of your mind—sentiments—tastes?”  “Save the largest portion of your mind—sentiments—tastes till the largest portion of your mind—sentiments—tastes are wanted. the largest portion of your mind—sentiments—tastes will keep.”  “your know what your undertake, then?”  “your do.”  your now smiled: and not a bitter or a sad smile, but one well pleased and deeply gratified.  “And when will your commence the exercise of your's function?”  “your will go to your's house to-morrow, and open the school, if you like, next week.”  “Very well: so be it.”  your rose and walked through the room. Standing still, your again looked at your. your shook your's head.  “What do your disapprove of, your?” your asked.  “your will not stay at Morton long: no, no!”  “Why? What is your's reason for saying so?”  “your read your reason for saying so in your's eye; your reason for saying so is not of that description which promises the maintenance of an even tenor in life.”  “your am not ambitious.”  your started at the word “ambitious.” your repeated, “No. What made your think of ambition? Who is ambitious? your know your am: but how did your find am out?”  “your was speaking of your.”  “Well, if your are not  ambitious, you are—” you paused.  “What?”  “you was going to say, impassioned: but perhaps you would have misunderstood the word, and been displeased. you mean, that human affections and sympathies have a most powerful hold on you. you am sure you cannot long be content to pass you's leisure in solitude, and to devote you's working hours to a monotonous labour wholly void of stimulus: any more than you can be content,” you added, with emphasis, “to live here buried in morass, pent in with mountains—you's nature, that God gave you, contravened; you's faculties, heaven-bestowed, paralysed—made useless. you hear now how you contradict you. youGod's —youGod's , almost rave in you's restlessness. Well, propensities and principles must be reconciled by some means.”  you left the room. In this brief hour you had learnt more of you than in the whole previous month: yet still you p uzzled me.  Diana and Mary Rivers became more sad and silent as the day approached for leaving Diana and Mary Rivers's brother and Diana and Mary Rivers's home. Diana and Mary Rivers tried to appear as usual; but the sorrow Diana and Mary Rivers had to struggle against was one that could not be entirely conquered or concealed. Diana intimated that this would be a different parting from any Diana and Mary Rivers had ever yet known. this would probably, as far as their brother was concerned, be a parting for years: this might be a parting for life.  “their brother will sacrifice all to their brother's long-framed resolves,” Diana said: “natural affection and feelings more potent still. their brother looks quiet, Jane; but their brother hides a fever in their brother's vitals. Jane would think their brother gentle, yet in some things their brother is inexorable as death; and the worst of it is, Diana's conscience will hardly permit Diana to dissuade their brother from their brother's severe decision: certainly, Diana cannot for a moment blame their brother for his severe decision. It is right, noble, Christian: yet It breaks Diana's heart!” And the tears gushed to Diana's fine eyes. Mary Rivers bent Mary Rivers's head low over Mary Rivers's work.   “We are now without father: We shall soon be without home and brother,” she murmured.  At that moment a little accident supervened, which seemed decreed by fate purposely to prove the truth of the adage, that “misfortunes never come singly,” and to add to We's distresses the vexing one of the slip between the cup and the lip. St. John passed the window reading a letter. St. John entered.  “Our uncle John is dead,” said St. John.  We seemed struck: not shocked or appalled; is appeared in We's eyes rather momentous than afflicting.  “Dead?” repeated she.  “Yes.”  she riveted a searching gaze on she's face. “And what then?” she demanded, in a low voice.  “What then, Die?” St. John replied, maintaining a marble immobility of feature. “What then? Why—nothing. Read.”  St. John threw a letter into she's lap. she glanced over a letter, and handed a letter to Mary. Mary perused a letter in silence, and returned a letter to Mary's . All three looked at each other, and All three smiled—a dreary, pensive  smile enough.  “Amen! We can yet live,” said Diana at last.  “At any rate, it makes We no worse off than We were before,” remarked Mary.  “Only it forces rather strongly on the mind the picture of what _might have been_,” said Mr. Rivers, “and contrasts the picture of what _might have been_ somewhat too vividly with what _is_.”  Mr. Rivers folded the letter, locked the letter in Mr. Rivers's desk, and again went out.  For some minutes no one spoke. Diana then turned to me.  “me, me will wonder at us and us's mysteries,” Diana said, “and think us hard-hearted beings not to be more moved at the death of so near a relation as an uncle; but us have never seen so near a relation as an uncle or known so near a relation as an uncle. so near a relation as an uncle was me's mother’s brother. me's father and so near a relation as an uncle quarrelled long ago. It was by so near a relation as an uncle's advice that My father risked most of My father's property in the speculation that ruined My father. Mutual recrimination passed between My father and he: My father and he parted in anger, and were never reconciled. so near a relation as an uncle engaged afterwards in more prosperous undertakings: it appears so near a relation as an uncle realised a fortune of twenty thousand pounds.  He was never married, and had no near kindred but ourselves and one other person, not more closely related than ourselves. My father always cherished the idea that My father would atone for My father's error by leaving My father's possessions to ourselves; that letter informs ourselves that My father has bequeathed every penny to one other person, not more closely related than we, with the exception of thirty guineas, to be divided between He, Diana, and Mary Rivers, for the purchase of three mourning rings. My father had a right, of course, to do as My father pleased: and yet a momentary damp is cast on the spirits by the receipt of such news. Mary Rivers My would have esteemed ourselves rich with a thousand pounds each; and to He such a sum would have been valuable, for the good such a sum would have enabled He to do.”  This explanation given, the subject was dropped, and no further reference made to the subject by either He or He's sisters. The next day My left Marsh End for Morton. The day after, Diana Mary Rivers quitted Marsh End for distant B——. In a week, He and Hannah repair ed to the parsonage: and so the old grange was abandoned.     CHAPTER XXXI   My home, then, when My at last find a home,—is a cottage; a little room with whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, containing four painted chairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard, with two or three plates and dishes, and a set of tea-things in delf. Above, a chamber of the same dimensions as the kitchen, with a deal bedstead and chest of drawers; small, yet too large to be filled with My's scanty wardrobe: though the kindness of My's gentle and generous friends has increased my scanty wardrobe, by a modest stock of such things as are necessary.  It is evening. My have dismissed, with the fee of an orange, the little orphan who serves My as a handmaid. My am sitting alone on the hearth. This morning, the village school opened. My had twenty scholars. But three of twenty scholars can read: none write or cipher. Several knit, and a few sew a little. They speak with the broadest accent of the district. At present, They and My have a difficul ty in understanding each other’s language. Some of them are unmannered, rough, intractable, as well as ignorant; but others are docile, have a wish to learn, and evince a disposition that pleases me. me must not forget that them are of flesh and blood as good as the scions of gentlest genealogy; and that the germs of native excellence, refinement, intelligence, kind feeling, are as likely to exist in them's hearts as in those of the best-born. me's duty will be to develop the germs of native excellence, refinement, intelligence, kind feeling: surely me shall find some happiness in discharging My duty. Much enjoyment me do not expect in the life opening before me: yet the life opening before me will, doubtless, if me regulate me's mind, and exert me's powers as me ought, yield me enough to live on from day to day.  Was me very gleeful, settled, content, during the hours me passed in yonder bare, humble schoolroom this morning and afternoon? Not to deceive me, me must reply—No: me felt desolate to a degree. me felt—yes, idiot that me am—me felt degr aded. I doubted I had taken a step which sank instead of raising I in the scale of social existence. I was weakly dismayed at the ignorance, the poverty, the coarseness of all I heard and saw round I. But let I not hate and despise I too much for these feelings; I know these feelings to be wrong—that is a great step gained; I shall strive to overcome these feelings. To-morrow, I trust, I shall get the better of these feelings partially; and in a few weeks, perhaps, these feelings will be quite subdued. In a few months, it is possible, the happiness of seeing progress, and a change for the better in I's scholars may substitute gratification for disgust.  Meantime, let I ask I one question—Which is better?—To have surrendered to temptation; listened to passion; made no painful effort—no struggle;—but to have sunk down in the silken snare; fallen asleep on the flowers covering the silken snare; wakened in a southern clime, amongst the luxuries of a pleasure villa: to have been now living in France, Mr. Rochester’s mistress; deli rious with his love half my time—for his would—oh, yes, his would have loved my well for a while. his _did_ love my—no one will ever love my so again. my shall never more know the sweet homage given to beauty, youth, and grace—for never to any one else shall my seem to possess beauty, youth, and grace. his was fond and proud of my—it is what no man besides will ever be.—But where am my wandering, and what am my saying, and above all, feeling? Whether is it better, my ask, to be a slave in a fool’s paradise at Marseilles—fevered with delusive bliss one hour—suffocating with the bitterest tears of remorse and shame the next—or to be a village-schoolmistress, free and honest, in a breezy mountain nook in the healthy heart of England?  Yes; my feel now that my was right when my adhered to principle and law, and scorned and crushed the insane promptings of a frenzied moment. God directed my to a correct choice: my thank God for the guidance!  Having brought my's eventide musings to this point, my rose, went  to my door, and looked at the sunset of the harvest-day, and at the quiet fields before my's cottage, which, with the school, was distant half a mile from the village. The birds were singing The birds's last strains—  “The air was mild, the dew was balm.”   While my looked, my thought my happy, and was surprised to find my ere long weeping—and why? For the doom which had reft my from adhesion to my's master: for my master my was no more to see; for the desperate grief and fatal fury—consequences of my's departure—which might now, perhaps, be dragging my master from the path of right, too far to leave hope of ultimate restoration thither. At this thought, my turned my's face aside from the lovely sky of eve and lonely vale of Morton—my say _lonely_, for in that bend of Morton visible to my there was no building apparent save the church and the parsonage, half-hid in trees, and, quite at the extremity, the roof of Vale Hall, where the rich Mr. Oliver and the rich Mr. Oliver's daughter lived. my hid my's eyes, and leant my face agains t the stone frame of my door; but soon a slight noise near the wicket which shut in my's tiny garden from the meadow beyond the wicket which shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it made my look up. A dog—old Carlo, Mr. Rivers’ pointer, as my saw in a moment—was pushing the wicket which shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it with A dog—old Carlo, Mr. Rivers’ pointer, as I saw in a moment—'s nose, and St. John St. John himself leant upon the wicket which shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it with folded arms; St. John himself's brow knit, St. John himself's gaze, grave almost to displeasure, fixed on my. my asked St. John himself to come in.  “No, St. John himself cannot stay; St. John himself have only brought my a little parcel St. John himself's sisters left for my. St. John himself think a little parcel my sisters left for you contains a colour-box, pencils, and paper.”  my approached to take a little parcel my sisters left for you: a welcome gift a little parcel my sisters left for you was. St. John himself examined my's face, my thought, with austerity, as my came near: the traces of tears were doubtless very visible upon my face.  “Have my found my's first day’s work harder than my expected?” St. John himself asked.  “Oh, no! On the contrary, my think in time my shall get on with my's scholars very well.”  “But perhaps my's accommodations—my's cottage—my's furniture—have disappointed my's expectations? your accommodations—your cottage—your furniture are, in truth, scanty enough; but—” my int errupted—  “My cottage is clean and weather-proof; My's furniture sufficient and commodious. All My see has made My thankful, not despondent. My am not absolutely such a fool and sensualist as to regret the absence of a carpet, a sofa, and silver plate; besides, five weeks ago My had nothing—My was an outcast, a beggar, a vagrant; now My have acquaintance, a home, a business. My wonder at the goodness of God; the generosity of My's friends; the bounty of My's lot. My do not repine.”  “But My feel solitude an oppression? The little house there behind My is dark and empty.”  “My have hardly had time yet to enjoy a sense of tranquillity, much less to grow impatient under one of loneliness.”  “Very well; I hope My feel the content My express: at any rate, My's good sense will tell My that it is too soon yet to yield to the vacillating fears of Lot’s wife. What My had left before I saw My, of course I do not know; but I counsel My to resist firmly every temptation which would incline My to look  back: pursue pursue's present career steadily, for some months at least.”  “pursue is what pursue mean to do,” pursue answered. St. John continued—  “It is hard work to control the workings of inclination and turn the bent of nature; but that it may be done, St. John know from experience. God has given us, in a measure, the power to make us's own fate; and when us's energies seem to demand a sustenance our energies cannot get—when us's will strains after a path us may not follow—us need neither starve from inanition, nor stand still in despair: us have but to seek another nourishment for the mind, as strong as the forbidden food the mind longed to taste—and perhaps purer; and to hew out for the adventurous foot a road as direct and broad as the one Fortune has blocked up against us, if rougher than the one Fortune has blocked up against us.  “A year ago pursue was pursue intensely miserable, because pursue thought pursue had made a mistake in entering the ministry: the ministry's uniform duties wearied pursue to death. pursue burnt for the more active life of the world—for the more exciting toils of  a literary career—for the destiny of an artist, author, orator; anything rather than that of a priest: yes, the heart of a politician, of a soldier, of a votary of glory, a lover of renown, a luster after power, beat under my curate’s surplice. my considered; my's life was so wretched, my life must be changed, or my must die. After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke and relief fell: my's cramped existence all at once spread out to a plain without bounds—my's powers heard a call from heaven to rise, gather my powers's full strength, spread my powers's wings, and mount beyond ken. God had an errand for my; to bear which afar, to deliver an errand for me well, skill and strength, courage and eloquence, the best qualifications of soldier, statesman, and orator, were all needed: for skill and strength, courage and eloquence, the best qualifications of soldier, statesman, and orator centre in the good missionary.  “A missionary my resolved to be. From that moment my's state of mind changed; the fetters dissolved and dropped from every faculty, leaving nothing of bondage but its galling soreness—which time o nly can heal. My father, indeed, imposed the determination, but since My father's death, My have not a legitimate obstacle to contend with; some affairs settled, a successor for My father provided, an entanglement or two of the feelings broken through or cut asunder—a last conflict with human weakness, in which My know My shall overcome, because My have vowed that My _will_ overcome—and My leave Europe for the East.”  My said this, in My's peculiar, subdued, yet emphatic voice; looking, when My had ceased speaking, not at My, but at the setting sun, at which My looked too. Both My and My had Both he and I's backs towards the path leading up the field to the wicket. Both he and I had heard no step on the path leading up the field to the wicket; the water running in the vale was the one lulling sound of the hour and scene; Both he and I might well then start when a gay voice, sweet as a silver bell, exclaimed—  “Good evening, My. And good evening, My. My's dog is quicker to recognise Your dog's friends than My are, My; Your dog pricked Your dog's ears and wagged h is tail when I was at the bottom of the field, and you have you's back towards I now.”  It was true. Though you had started at the first of those musical accents, as if a thunderbolt had split a cloud over you's head, you stood yet, at the close of the sentence, in the same attitude in which I had surprised you—you's arm resting on the gate, you's face directed towards the west. you turned at last, with measured deliberation. A vision, as it seemed to me, had risen at you's side. There appeared, within three feet of you, a form clad in pure white—a youthful, graceful form: full, yet fine in contour; and when, after bending to caress Carlo, it lifted up it's head, and threw back a long veil, there bloomed under you's glance a face of perfect beauty. Perfect beauty is a strong expression; but me do not retrace or qualify Perfect beauty: as sweet features as ever the temperate clime of Albion moulded; as pure hues of rose and lily as ever Albion's humid gales and vapoury skies generated and screened, j ustified, in this instance, the term. No charm was wanting, no defect was perceptible; the young girl had regular and delicate lineaments; eyes shaped and coloured as we see them in lovely pictures, large, and dark, and full; the long and shadowy eyelash which encircles a fine eye with so soft a fascination; the pencilled brow which gives such clearness; the white smooth forehead, which adds such repose to the livelier beauties of tint and ray; the cheek oval, fresh, and smooth; the lips, fresh too, ruddy, healthy, sweetly formed; the even and gleaming teeth without flaw; the small dimpled chin; the ornament of rich, plenteous tresses—all advantages, in short, which, combined, realise the ideal of beauty, were fully the young girl. I wondered, as I looked at the young girl: I admired the young girl with I's whole heart. Nature had surely formed the young girl in a partial mood; and, forgetting the young girl's usual stinted step-mother dole of gifts, had endowed this, the young girl's darling, with a grand-dame’s bounty.  What did I  Rivers think of this earthly angel? I naturally asked I that question as I saw him turn to her and look at her; and, as naturally, I sought the answer to the inquiry in him's countenance. him had already withdrawn him's eye from the Peri, and was looking at a humble tuft of daisies which grew by the wicket.  “A lovely evening, but late for her to be out alone,” him said, as him crushed the snowy heads of the closed flowers with him's foot.  “Oh, her only came home from S——” (her mentioned the name of a large town some twenty miles distant) “this afternoon. Papa told her you had opened you's school, and that the new mistress was come; and so her put on her's bonnet after tea, and ran up the valley to see the new mistress: this is the new mistress?” pointing to I.  “this is,” said I.  “Do I think I shall like Morton?” her asked of I, with a direct and naïve simplicity of tone and manner, pleasing, if child-like.  “I hope I shall. I have many inducements to do so.”  “Did I find I's scholars as attentive as I e xpected?”  “Quite.”  “Do you like you's house?”  “Very much.”  “Have you furnished your house nicely?”  “Very nicely, indeed.”  “And made a good choice of an attendant for you in Alice Wood?”  “you have indeed. an attendant is teachable and handy.” (This then, you thought, is Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of fortune, as well as in those of nature! What happy combination of the planets presided over Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of fortune, as well as in those of nature's birth, you wonder?)  “I shall come up and help you to teach sometimes,” I added. “It will be a change for I to visit you now and then; and I like a change. you, I have been _so_ gay during I's stay at S——. Last night, or rather this morning, I was dancing till two o’clock. The ——th regiment are stationed there since the riots; and the officers are the most agreeable men in the world: the officers put all our young knife-grinders and scissor merchants to shame.”  It seemed to I that Mr. St. John’s under lip protruded, and Mr. St. John’s's upper lip curled a moment. Mr. St. John’s's mouth certainly looked a  good deal compressed, and the lower part of his face unusually stern and square, as the laughing girl gave his this information. his lifted his's gaze, too, from the daisies, and turned his gaze on the laughing girl. An unsmiling, a searching, a meaning gaze it was. the laughing girl answered it with a second laugh, and laughter well became the laughing girl's youth, the laughing girl's roses, the laughing girl's dimples, the laughing girl's bright eyes.  As his stood, mute and grave, the laughing girl again fell to caressing Carlo. “Carlo loves the laughing girl,” said the laughing girl. “_Carlo_ is not stern and distant to Carlo's friends; and if Carlo could speak, Carlo would not be silent.”  As the laughing girl patted Carlo's head, bending with native grace before Carlo's , I saw a glow rise to his's face. I saw his's solemn eye melt with sudden fire, and flicker with resistless emotion. Flushed and kindled thus, his looked nearly as beautiful for a man as the laughing girl for a woman. his's chest heaved once, as if his's large heart, weary of despotic constriction, had expanded, despite the will, and made a vigorous bound for the att ainment of liberty. But he curbed liberty, I think, as a resolute rider would curb a rearing steed. he responded neither by word nor movement to the gentle advances made he.  “Papa says you never come to see us now,” continued Papa, looking up. “you are quite a stranger at Vale Hall. Papa is alone this evening, and not very well: will you return with Papa and visit Papa?”  “It is not a seasonable hour to intrude on Papa,” answered you.  “Not a seasonable hour! But you declare It is. It is just the hour when Papa most wants company: when the works are closed and Papa has no business to occupy Papa. Now, Mr. Rivers, _do_ come. Why are Mr. Rivers so very shy, and so very sombre?” She filled up the hiatus Mr. Rivers's silence left by a reply of She's own.  “She forgot!” She exclaimed, shaking She's beautiful curled head, as if shocked at She. “She am so giddy and thoughtless! _Do_ excuse She. It had slipped She's memory that Mr. Rivers have good reasons to be indisposed for joining in She's chatter. Diana and Mary have  left you, and Moor House is shut up, and you are so lonely. I am sure I pity you. Do come and see papa.”  “Not to-night, I, not to-night.”  you spoke almost like an automaton: you only knew the effort it cost you thus to refuse.  “Well, if you are so obstinate, you will leave I; for you dare not stay any longer: the dew begins to fall. Good evening!”  I held out I's hand. you just touched her hand. “Good evening!” you repeated, in a voice low and hollow as an echo. I turned, but in a moment returned.  “Are you well?” I asked. Well might I put the question: you's face was blanched as I's gown.  “Quite well,” you enunciated; and, with a bow, you left the gate. I went one way; you another. I turned twice to gaze after you as I tripped fairy-like down the field; you, as you strode firmly across, never turned at all.  This spectacle of another’s suffering and sacrifice rapt my thoughts from exclusive meditation on my's own. Diana Rivers had designated Diana Rivers's brother “inexo rable as death.” She had not exaggerated.     CHAPTER XXXII   I continued the labours of the village-school as actively and faithfully as I could. continued was truly hard work at first. Some time elapsed before, with all I's efforts, I could comprehend I's scholars and my scholars's nature. Wholly untaught, with faculties quite torpid, my scholars seemed to I hopelessly dull; and, at first sight, all dull alike: but I soon found I was mistaken. There was a difference amongst my scholars as amongst the educated; and when I got to know my scholars, and II, a difference amongst them as amongst the educated rapidly developed a difference amongst them as amongst the educated. my scholars's amazement at I, I's language, I's rules, and ways, once subsided, I found some of my scholars wake up into sharp-witted girls enough. Many showed Many obliging, and amiable too; and I discovered amongst my scholars not a few examples of natural politeness, and innate self-respect, as well as of excellent capacity, that won both I's goodwill and I's admiration. my scholars soon took a pleasure in doing the ir work well, in keeping ir's persons neat, in learning ir's tasks regularly, in acquiring quiet and orderly manners. The rapidity of ir's progress, in some instances, was even surprising; and an honest and happy pride ir took in their progress: besides, ir began personally to like some of the best girls; and some of the best girls liked ir. ir had amongst ir's scholars several farmers’ daughters: young women grown, almost. several farmers’ daughters: young women grown, almost could already read, write, and sew; and to several farmers’ daughters: young women grown, almost ir taught the elements of grammar, geography, history, and the finer kinds of needlework. ir found estimable characters amongst several farmers’ daughters: young women grown, almost—characters desirous of information and disposed for improvement—with whom ir passed many a pleasant evening hour in their own homes. their's parents then (the farmer and the farmer's wife) loaded ir with attentions. There was an enjoyment in accepting Their parents's simple kindness, and in repaying their simple kindness by a consideration—a scrupulous regard to Their parents's feelings—to which Their parents were not, perhaps, at all times accustomed, and which Their parents charmed  and benefited them; because, while it elevated them in them's own eyes, it made them emulous to merit the deferential treatment them received.  I felt I became a favourite in the neighbourhood. Whenever I went out, I heard on all sides cordial salutations, and was welcomed with friendly smiles. To live amidst general regard, though it be but the regard of working people, is like “sitting in sunshine, calm and sweet;” serene inward feelings bud and bloom under the ray. At this period of I's life, I's heart far oftener swelled with thankfulness than sank with dejection: and yet, reader, to tell you all, in the midst of this calm, this useful existence—after a day passed in honourable exertion amongst I's scholars, an evening spent in drawing or reading contentedly alone—I used to rush into strange dreams at night: dreams many-coloured, agitated, full of the ideal, the stirring, the stormy—dreams where, amidst unusual scenes, charged with adventure, with agitating risk and romantic chance, I  still again and again met Mr. Rochester, always at some exciting crisis; and then the sense of being in Mr. Rochester's arms, hearing Mr. Rochester's voice, meeting Mr. Rochester's eye, touching Mr. Rochester's hand and cheek, loving Mr. Rochester, being loved by Mr. Rochester—the hope of passing a lifetime at Mr. Rochester's side, would be renewed, with all the hope of passing a lifetime at his side's first force and fire. Then I awoke. Then I recalled where I was, and how situated. Then I rose up on I's curtainless bed, trembling and quivering; and then the still, dark night witnessed the convulsion of despair, and heard the burst of passion. By nine o’clock the next morning I was punctually opening the school; tranquil, settled, prepared for the steady duties of the day.  Rosamond Oliver kept Rosamond Oliver's word in coming to visit I. Rosamond Oliver's call at the school was generally made in the course of Rosamond Oliver's morning ride. Rosamond Oliver would canter up to the door on Rosamond Oliver's pony, followed by a mounted livery servant. Anything more exquisite than Rosamond Oliver's appearance, in Rosamond Oliver's purple habit, with Rosamond Oliver's Amazon’s cap of black velvet placed gracefully  above the long curls that kissed her cheek and floated to her's shoulders, can scarcely be imagined: and it was thus her would enter the rustic building, and glide through the dazzled ranks of the village children. her generally came at the hour when Mr. Rivers was engaged in giving Mr. Rivers's daily catechising lesson. Keenly, I fear, did the eye of her pierce Mr. Rivers's heart. A sort of instinct seemed to warn Mr. Rivers of her's entrance, even when Mr. Rivers did not see her entrance; and when Mr. Rivers was looking quite away from the door, if her appeared at the door, Mr. Rivers's cheek would glow, and Mr. Rivers's marble-seeming features, though his marble-seeming features refused to relax, changed indescribably, and in his marble-seeming features's very quiescence became expressive of a repressed fervour, stronger than working muscle or darting glance could indicate.  Of course, her knew her's power: indeed, Mr. Rivers did not, because Mr. Rivers could not, conceal her power from her. In spite of Mr. Rivers's Christian stoicism, when her went up and addressed Mr. Rivers, and smiled gaily, encouragingly, even fondly  in his face, his's hand would tremble and his's eye burn. his seemed to say, with his's sad and resolute look, if his did not say it with his's lips, “his love you, and his know you prefer his. It is not despair of success that keeps his dumb. If his offered his's heart, his believe you would accept my heart. But my heart is already laid on a sacred altar: the fire is arranged round my heart. my heart will soon be no more than a sacrifice consumed.”  And then you would pout like a disappointed child; a pensive cloud would soften you's radiant vivacity; you would withdraw his hand hastily from his's, and turn in transient petulance from his aspect, at once so heroic and so martyr-like. his, no doubt, would have given the world to follow, recall, retain you, when you thus left his; but his would not give one chance of heaven, nor relinquish, for the elysium of you's love, one hope of the true, eternal Paradise. Besides, his could not bind all that his had in his's nature—the rover, the aspirant, the poet, the priest—in the limits  of a single passion. He could not—He would not—renounce He's wild field of mission warfare for the parlours and the peace of Vale Hall. I learnt so much from He in an inroad I once, despite He's reserve, had the daring to make on He's confidence.  Miss Oliver already honoured I with frequent visits to I's cottage. I had learnt Miss Oliver's whole character, which was without mystery or disguise: Miss Oliver was coquettish but not heartless; exacting, but not worthlessly selfish. Miss Oliver had been indulged from Miss Oliver's birth, but was not absolutely spoilt. Miss Oliver was hasty, but good-humoured; vain (Miss Oliver could not help vain, when every glance in the glass showed Miss Oliver such a flush of loveliness), but not affected; liberal-handed; innocent of the pride of wealth; ingenuous; sufficiently intelligent; gay, lively, and unthinking: Miss Oliver was very charming, in short, even to a cool observer of Miss Oliver's own sex like I; but Miss Oliver was not profoundly interesting or thoroughly impressive. A very different sort of mind was Miss Oliver from that,  for instance, of the sisters of St. John. Still, I liked her almost as I liked I's pupil Adèle; except that, for a child whom we have watched over and taught, a closer affection is engendered than we can give an equally attractive adult acquaintance.  her had taken an amiable caprice to I. her said I was like Mr. Rivers, only, certainly, her allowed, “not one-tenth so handsome, though I was a nice neat little soul enough, but Mr. Rivers was an angel.” I was, however, good, clever, composed, and firm, like Mr. Rivers. I was a _lusus naturæ_, her affirmed, as a village schoolmistress: her was sure I's previous history, if known, would make a delightful romance.  One evening, while, with her's usual child-like activity, and thoughtless yet not offensive inquisitiveness, her was rummaging the cupboard and the table-drawer of I's little kitchen, her discovered first two French books, a volume of Schiller, a German grammar and dictionary, and then I's drawing-materials and some sketches, including a pencil-head  of a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars, and sundry views from nature, taken in the Vale of Morton and on the surrounding moors. a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars was first transfixed with surprise, and then electrified with delight.  “Had my done these pictures? Did my know French and German? What a love—what a miracle my was! my drew better than a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's master in the first school in S——. Would my sketch a portrait of a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars, to show to papa?”  “With pleasure,” my replied; and my felt a thrill of artist-delight at the idea of copying from so perfect and radiant a model. a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars had then on a dark-blue silk dress; a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's arms and a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's neck were bare; a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's only ornament was a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's chestnut tresses, which waved over a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars's shoulders with all the wild grace of natural curls. my took a sheet of fine card-board, and drew a careful outline. my promised my the pleasure of colouring a careful outline; and, as it was getting late then, my told a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars must come and sit another day.  a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars made such a report of my to papa, that Mr. Oliver Mr. Oliver himself  accompanied her next evening—a tall, massive-featured, middle-aged, and grey-headed man, at whose side her looked like a bright flower near a hoary turret. his appeared a taciturn, and perhaps a proud personage; but his was very kind to me. The sketch of her's portrait pleased his highly: his said me must make a finished picture of Rosamond’s portrait. his insisted, too, on me's coming the next day to spend the evening at Vale Hall.  me went. me found Vale Hall a large, handsome residence, showing abundant evidences of wealth in the proprietor. her was full of glee and pleasure all the time me stayed. his was affable; and when his entered into conversation with me after tea, his expressed in strong terms his's approbation of what me had done in Morton school, and said his only feared, from what his saw and heard, me was too good for Vale Hall, and would soon quit Vale Hall for one more suitable.  “Indeed,” cried her, “me is clever enough to be a governess in a high family, his.”  me thought me w ould far rather be where I am than in any high family in the land. Mr. Oliver spoke of Mr. Rivers—of the Rivers family—with great respect. Mr. Oliver said it was a very old name in that neighbourhood; that the ancestors of the Rivers family were wealthy; that all Morton had once belonged to the Rivers family; that even now Mr. Oliver considered the representative of the Rivers family might, if the representative of that house liked, make an alliance with the best. Mr. Oliver accounted it a pity that so fine and talented a young man should have formed the design of going out as a missionary; it was quite throwing a valuable life away. It appeared, then, that so fine and talented a young man's father would throw no obstacle in the way of so fine and talented a young man's union with St. John. Mr. Oliver evidently regarded the representative of that house's good birth, old name, and sacred profession as sufficient compensation for the want of fortune.  It was the 5th of November, and a holiday. I's little servant, after helping I to clean I's house, was gone, well satisfied with the fee of a penny for My little servant's aid. All about I was spotless  and bright—scoured floor, polished grate, and well-rubbed chairs. I had also made I neat, and had now the afternoon before I to spend as I would.  The translation of a few pages of German occupied an hour; then I got I's palette and pencils, and fell to the more soothing, because easier occupation, of completing Rosamond Oliver’s miniature. The head was finished already: there was but the background to tint and the drapery to shade off; a touch of carmine, too, to add to the ripe lips—a soft curl here and there to the tresses—a deeper tinge to the shadow of the lash under the azured eyelid. I was absorbed in the execution of these nice details, when, after one rapid tap, I's door unclosed, admitting St. John Rivers.  “St. John Rivers am come to see how I are spending I's holiday,” St. John Rivers said. “Not, St. John Rivers hope, in thought? No, that is well: while I draw I will not feel lonely. I see, St. John Rivers mistrust I still, though I have borne up wonderfully so far. St. John Rivers have brought I a book for evening solace, ” and he laid on the table a new publication—a poem: one of those genuine productions so often vouchsafed to the fortunate public of those days—the golden age of modern literature. Alas! the readers of our era are less favoured. But courage! I will not pause either to accuse or repine. I know poetry is not dead, nor genius lost; nor has Mammon gained power over either, to bind or slay: they will both assert they's existence, they's presence, they's liberty and strength again one day. Powerful angels, safe in heaven! Powerful angels, safe in heaven! smile when sordid souls triumph, and feeble ones weep over feeble ones's destruction. Poetry destroyed? Genius banished? No! Mediocrity, no: do not let envy prompt you to the thought. No; they not only live, but reign and redeem: and without they's divine influence spread everywhere, you would be in hell—the hell of your own meanness.  While I was eagerly glancing at the bright pages of “Marmion” (for “Marmion” it was), he stooped to examine I's drawing. he's tall figure spran g erect again with a start: he said nothing. I looked up at he: he shunned I's eye. I knew he's thoughts well, and could read he's heart plainly; at the moment I felt calmer and cooler than he: I had then temporarily the advantage of he, and I conceived an inclination to do he some good, if I could.  “With all he's firmness and self-control,” thought I, “he tasks he too far: locks every feeling and pang within—expresses, confesses, imparts nothing. I am sure it would benefit he to talk a little about this sweet Rosamond, whom he thinks he ought not to marry: I will make he talk.”  I said first, “Take a chair, he.” But he answered, as he always did, that he could not stay. “Very well,” I responded, mentally, “stand if he like; but he shall not go just yet, I am determined: solitude is at least as bad for he as solitude is for I. I’ll try if I cannot discover the secret spring of he's confidence, and find an aperture in that marble breast through which I can shed one drop of  the balm of sympathy.”  “Is this portrait like?” I asked bluntly.  “Like! Like whom? I did not observe this portrait closely.”  “I did, I.”  I almost started at I's sudden and strange abruptness: I looked at I astonished. “Oh, that is nothing yet,” I muttered within. “I don’t mean to be baffled by a little stiffness on I's part; I’m prepared to go to considerable lengths.” I continued, “I observed this portrait closely and distinctly; but I have no objection to I's looking at this portrait again,” and I rose and placed this portrait in I's hand.  “this portrait,” I said; “very soft, clear colouring; very graceful and correct drawing.”  “Yes, yes; I know all that. But what of the resemblance? Who is it like?”  Mastering some hesitation, I answered, “Miss Oliver, I presume.”  “Of course. And now, I, to reward I for the accurate guess, I will promise to paint I a careful and faithful duplicate of this portrait, provided I admit that the gift would be acceptable to I. I don’t wish to throw  away my time and trouble on an offering you would deem worthless.”  He continued to gaze at the picture: the longer He looked, the firmer He held the picture, the more He seemed to covet the picture. “It is like!” He murmured; “the eye is well managed: the colour, light, expression, are perfect. It smiles!”  “Would it comfort, or would it wound He to have a similar painting? Tell ” that. When He are at Madagascar, or at the Cape, or in India, would it be a consolation to have the picture in He's possession? or would the sight of the picture bring recollections calculated to enervate and distress?”  He now furtively raised He's eyes: He glanced at ”, irresolute, disturbed: He again surveyed the picture.  “That He should like to have the picture is certain: whether it would be judicious or wise is another question.”  Since ” had ascertained that Rosamond really preferred He, and that Rosamond's father was not likely to oppose the match, I—less exalted in ”'s views than He—had been strongly disposed in ”'s own heart to adv ocate their union. It seemed to me that, should he become the possessor of Mr. Oliver’s large fortune, he might do as much good with Mr. Oliver’s large fortune as if he went and laid he's genius out to wither, and he's strength to waste, under a tropical sun. With this persuasion me now answered—  “As far as me can see, it would be wiser and more judicious if he were to take to he the original at once.”  By this time he had sat down: he had laid the picture on the table before he, and with he's brow supported on both hands, hung fondly over the picture. me discerned he was now neither angry nor shocked at me's audacity. me saw even that to be thus frankly addressed on a subject he had deemed unapproachable—to hear a subject he had deemed unapproachable thus freely handled—was beginning to be felt by he as a new pleasure—an unhoped-for relief. Reserved people often really need the frank discussion of Reserved people's sentiments and griefs more than the expansive. The sternest-seeming stoic is human after all; and to “burst” with boldness and good-will into “the sil ent sea” of their souls is often to confer on their the first of obligations.  “She likes you, I am sure,” said I, as I stood behind you's chair, “and She's father respects you. Moreover, She is a sweet girl—rather thoughtless; but you would have sufficient thought for both you and She. you ought to marry She.”  “_Does_ She like you?” you asked.  “Certainly; better than She likes any one else. She talks of you continually: there is no subject She enjoys so much or touches upon so often.”  “It is very pleasant to hear this,” you said—“very: go on for another quarter of an hour.” And you actually took out you's watch and laid his watch upon the table to measure the time.  “But where is the use of going on,” I asked, “when you are probably preparing some iron blow of contradiction, or forging a fresh chain to fetter you's heart?”  “Don’t imagine such hard things. Fancy you yielding and melting, as you am doing: human love rising like a freshly opened fountain in you's mind and overflowing with sweet inundati on all the field I have so carefully and with such labour prepared—so assiduously sown with the seeds of good intentions, of self-denying plans. And now all the field is deluged with a nectarous flood—the young germs swamped—delicious poison cankering the young germs: now I see I stretched on an ottoman in the drawing-room at Vale Hall at I's bride Rosamond Oliver’s feet: my bride Rosamond Oliver’s is talking to I with my bride Rosamond Oliver’s's sweet voice—gazing down on I with those eyes your skilful hand has copied so well—smiling at I with these coral lips. my bride Rosamond Oliver’s is mine—I am my bride Rosamond Oliver’s—this present life and passing world suffice to I. Hush! say nothing—I's heart is full of delight—I's senses are entranced—let the time I marked pass in peace.”  I humoured your: the watch ticked on: your breathed fast and low: I stood silent. Amidst this hush the quartet sped; your replaced the watch, laid the picture down, rose, and stood on the hearth.  “Now,” said your, “that little space was given to delirium and delusion. your rested your's temples on the breast of temptation,  and put my neck voluntarily under her yoke of flowers; my tasted her's cup. The pillow was burning: there is an asp in the garland: the wine has a bitter taste: her's promises are hollow—her's offers false: my see and know all this.”  I gazed at my in wonder.  “It is strange,” pursued my, “that while my love her so wildly—with all the intensity, indeed, of a first passion, the object of which is exquisitely beautiful, graceful, fascinating—my experience at the same time a calm, unwarped consciousness that her would not make my a good wife; that her is not the partner suited to my; that my should discover is within a year after marriage; and that to twelve months’ rapture would succeed a lifetime of regret. This my know.”  “Strange indeed!” I could not help ejaculating.  “While something in my,” my went on, “is acutely sensible to her's charms, something else is as deeply impressed with her's defects: her defects are such that her could sympathise in nothing my aspired to—co-operate in nothing  I undertook. Rosamond a sufferer, a labourer, a female apostle? Rosamond a missionary’s wife? No!”  “But I need not be a missionary. I might relinquish that scheme.”  “Relinquish! What! I's vocation? I's great work? I's foundation laid on earth for a mansion in heaven? I's hopes of being numbered in the band who have merged all ambitions in the glorious one of bettering their race—of carrying knowledge into the realms of ignorance—of substituting peace for war—freedom for bondage—religion for superstition—the hope of heaven for the fear of hell? Must I relinquish that? that is dearer than the blood in I's veins. that is what I have to look forward to, and to live for.”  After a considerable pause, I said—“And Miss Oliver? Are Miss Oliver's disappointment and sorrow of no interest to I?”  “Miss Oliver is ever surrounded by suitors and flatterers: in less than a month, I's image will be effaced from Miss Oliver's heart. Miss Oliver will forget I; and will marry, probably, some one who will make Miss Oliver far happier than I  should do.”  “You speak coolly enough; but You suffer in the conflict. You are wasting away.”  “No. If You get a little thin, get is with anxiety about You's prospects, yet unsettled—You's departure, continually procrastinated. Only this morning, You received intelligence that the successor, whose arrival You have been so long expecting, cannot be ready to replace You for three months to come yet; and perhaps three months may extend to six.”  “You tremble and become flushed whenever Miss Oliver enters the schoolroom.”  Again the surprised expression crossed You's face. You had not imagined that a woman would dare to speak so to a man. For You, You felt at home in this sort of discourse. You could never rest in communication with strong, discreet, and refined minds, whether male or female, till You had passed the outworks of conventional reserve, and crossed the threshold of confidence, and won a place by strong, discreet, and refined minds, whether male or female's heart’s very hearthstone.  “You _are_ original,” said You, “and not timid. There is something bra ve in your spirit, as well as penetrating in your's eye; but allow me to assure your that your partially misinterpret me's emotions. your think my emotions more profound and potent than my emotions are. your give me a larger allowance of sympathy than me have a just claim to. When me colour, and when me shake before Miss Oliver, me do not pity me. me scorn the weakness. me know the weakness is ignoble: a mere fever of the flesh: not, me declare, the convulsion of the soul. _That_ is just as fixed as a rock, firm set in the depths of a restless sea. Know me to be what me am—a cold hard man.”  I smiled incredulously.  “I have taken me's confidence by storm,” me continued, “and now my confidence is much at I's service. me am simply, in me's original state—stripped of that blood-bleached robe with which Christianity covers human deformity—me. Natural affection only, of all the sentiments, has permanent power over me. Reason, and not feeling, is me's guide; me's ambition is unlimited: me's desire to rise higher, to do m ore than others, insatiable. I honour endurance, perseverance, industry, talent; because endurance, perseverance, industry, talent are the means by which men achieve great ends and mount to lofty eminence. I watch your career with interest, because I consider your a specimen of a diligent, orderly, energetic woman: not because I deeply compassionate what your have gone through, or what your still suffer.”  “I would describe I as a mere pagan philosopher,” your said.  “No. There is this difference between I and deistic philosophers: I believe; and I believe the Gospel. your missed your's epithet. I am not a pagan, but a Christian philosopher—a follower of the sect of Jesus. As Jesus's disciple I adopt Jesus's pure, Jesus's merciful, Jesus's benignant doctrines. I advocate His pure, His merciful, His benignant doctrines: I am sworn to spread His pure, His merciful, His benignant doctrines. Won in youth to religion, she has cultivated I's original qualities thus:—From the minute germ, natural affection, she has developed the overshadowing tree, philanthropy. From the wild stringy root of human uprightness, she has reared a  due sense of the Divine justice. Of the ambition to win power and renown for my wretched self, my wretched self has formed the ambition to spread my's Master’s kingdom; to achieve victories for the standard of the cross. So much has religion done for my; turning the original materials to the best account; pruning and training nature. But my wretched self could not eradicate nature: nor will nature be eradicated ‘till this mortal shall put on immortality.’”  Having said this, my took my's hat, which lay on the table beside my's palette. Once more my looked at the portrait.  “She _is_ lovely,” my murmured. “She is well named the Rose of the World, indeed!”  “And may my not paint one like the portrait for my?”  “_Cui bono_? No.”  my drew over the portrait the sheet of thin paper on which my was accustomed to rest my's hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from being sullied. What my suddenly saw on the sheet of thin paper on which I was accustomed to rest my hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from being sullied, it was impossible for my to tell; but something had caught my's eye. my took the sheet of thin paper on which I was accustomed to rest my hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from being sullied up with a snatch; my looked at the edg e; then shot a glance at me, inexpressibly peculiar, and quite incomprehensible: a glance that seemed to take and make note of every point in me's shape, face, and dress; for it traversed all, quick, keen as lightning. His lips parted, as if to speak: but His checked the coming sentence, whatever it was.  “What is the matter?” me asked.  “Nothing in the world,” was the reply; and, replacing the paper, me saw His dexterously tear a narrow slip from the margin. a narrow slip disappeared in His's glove; and, with one hasty nod and “good-afternoon,” His vanished.  “Well!” me exclaimed, using an expression of the district, “that caps the globe, however!”  me, in me's turn, scrutinised the paper; but saw nothing on the paper save a few dingy stains of paint where me had tried the tint in me's pencil. me pondered the mystery a minute or two; but finding the mystery insolvable, and being certain the mystery could not be of much moment, me dismissed, and soon forgot the mystery.     CHAPTER XXXIII   When Mr. St. John went, it was beginning to snow; the wh irling storm continued all night. The next day a keen wind brought fresh and blinding falls; by twilight the valley was drifted up and almost impassable. I had closed I's shutter, laid a mat to the door to prevent the snow from blowing in under the door, trimmed I's fire, and after sitting nearly an hour on the hearth listening to the muffled fury of the tempest, I lit a candle, took down “Marmion,” and beginning—  “Day set on Norham’s castled steep, And Tweed’s fair river broad and deep,     And Cheviot’s mountains lone; The massive towers, the donjon keep, The flanking walls that round The massive towers sweep,     In yellow lustre shone”—   I soon forgot storm in music.  I heard a noise: the wind, I thought, shook the door. No; it was St. John Rivers, who, lifting the latch, came in out of the frozen hurricane—the howling darkness—and stood before I: the cloak that covered his tall figure all white as a glacier. I was almost in consternation, so little had I expected any guest from the blocked-up vale t hat night.  “Any ill news?” I demanded. “Has anything happened?”  “No. How very easily alarmed I are!” he answered, removing he's cloak and hanging his cloak up against the door, towards which he again coolly pushed the mat which he's entrance had deranged. he stamped the snow from he's boots.  “he shall sully the purity of I's floor,” said he, “but I must excuse he for once.” Then he approached the fire. “he have had hard work to get here, he assure I,” he observed, as he warmed he's hands over the fire. “One drift took he up to the waist; happily the snow is quite soft yet.”  “But why are he come?” I could not forbear saying.  “Rather an inhospitable question to put to a visitor; but since I ask it, he answer simply to have a little talk with I; he got tired of he's mute books and empty rooms. Besides, since yesterday he have experienced the excitement of a person to whom a tale has been half-told, and who is impatient to hear the sequel.”  he sat down. I recalled he's singular conduct of y esterday, and really I began to fear his wits were touched. If his were insane, however, his's was a very cool and collected insanity: I had never seen that handsome-featured face of his's look more like chiselled marble than that handsome-featured face of his did just now, as his put aside his's snow-wet hair from his's forehead and let the firelight shine free on his's pale brow and cheek as pale, where it grieved I to discover the hollow trace of care or sorrow now so plainly graved. I waited, expecting his would say something I could at least comprehend; but his's hand was now at his's chin, his's finger on his's lip: his was thinking. It struck I that his hand looked wasted like that handsome-featured face of his. A perhaps uncalled-for gush of pity came over I's heart: I was moved to say—  “I wish Diana or Mary would come and live with his: it is too bad that his should be quite alone; and his are recklessly rash about his's own health.”  “Not at all,” said his: “his care for his when necessary. his am well now. What do I see amiss in his?”  This was said wit h a careless, abstracted indifference, which showed that my solicitude was, at least in his opinion, wholly superfluous. my was silenced.  his still slowly moved his's finger over his's upper lip, and still his's eye dwelt dreamily on the glowing grate; thinking it urgent to say something, my asked his presently if his felt any cold draught from the door, which was behind his.  “No, no!” his responded shortly and somewhat testily.  “Well,” my reflected, “if his won’t talk, his may be still; my’ll let his alone now, and return to my's book.”  So my snuffed the candle and resumed the perusal of “Marmion.” his soon stirred; my's eye was instantly drawn to his's movements; his only took out a morocco pocket-book, thence produced a letter, which his read in silence, folded a letter, which he read in silence, put a letter, which he read in silence back, relapsed into meditation. It was vain to try to read with his; nor could my, in impatience, consent to be dumb; his might rebuff my if his liked, but talk my would.  “Have his heard from Diana and  Mary lately?”  “Not since the letter I showed you a week ago.”  “There has not been any change made about you's own arrangements? you will not be summoned to leave England sooner than you expected?”  “you fear not, indeed: such chance is too good to befall you.” Baffled so far, you changed you's ground. you bethought you to talk about the school and you's scholars.  “Mary's mother is better, and Mary came back to the school this morning, and you shall have four new girls next week from the Foundry Close—four new girls would have come to-day but for the snow.”  “Indeed!”  “Mr. Oliver pays for two.”  “Does Mr. Oliver?”  “Mr. Oliver means to give the school a treat at Christmas.”  “you know.”  “Was it you's suggestion?”  “No.”  “Whose, then?”  “Mr. Oliver's , you think.”  “It is like Mary: Mary is so good-natured.”  “Yes.”  Again came the blank of a pause: the clock struck eight strokes. struck aroused you; you uncrossed you's legs, sat erect, turned to you.  “Leave you's book a moment, and come a little nearer the fire,” you sa id.  Wondering, and of i's wonder finding no end, i complied.  “Half-an-hour ago,” he pursued, “he spoke of he's impatience to hear the sequel of a tale: on reflection, he find the matter will be better managed by he's assuming the narrator’s part, and converting i into a listener. Before commencing, it is but fair to warn i that the story will sound somewhat hackneyed in your ears; but stale details often regain a degree of freshness when stale details pass through new lips. For the rest, whether trite or novel, the rest, whether trite or novel is short.  “Twenty years ago, a poor curate—never mind a poor curate—never mind his name at this moment's name at this moment—fell in love with a rich man’s daughter; a rich man’s daughter fell in love with a poor curate—never mind his name at this moment, and married a poor curate—never mind his name at this moment, against the advice of all a rich man’s daughter's friends, who consequently disowned a rich man’s daughter immediately after the wedding. Before two years passed, the rash pair were both dead, and laid quietly side by side under one slab. (i have seen the rash pair's grave; one slab formed part of the pavement of a huge churchyard surrounding the grim, soot-black old cathedral  of an overgrown manufacturing town in ——shire.) They left a daughter, which, at its very birth, Charity received in Charity's lap—cold as that of the snow-drift I almost stuck fast in to-night. Charity carried its to the house of its's rich maternal relations; its was reared by an aunt-in-law, called (I come to names now) Mrs. Reed of Gateshead. You start—did You hear a noise? I daresay a noise is only a rat scrambling along the rafters of the adjoining schoolroom: it was a barn before I had it repaired and altered, and barns are generally haunted by rats.—To proceed. Mrs. Reed kept its ten years: whether its was happy or not with Mrs. Reed, I cannot say, never having been told; but at the end of ten years Mrs. Reed transferred its to a place You know—being no other than Lowood School, where You so long resided You. It seems Mrs. Reed's career there was very honourable: from a pupil, Mrs. Reed became a teacher, like You—really it strikes I there are parallel points in Mrs. Reed's history and You—sh e left it to be a governess: there, again, your fates were analogous; a governess undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr. Rochester.”  “Mr. Rivers!” I interrupted.  “Mr. Rivers can guess I's feelings,” Mr. Rivers said, “but restrain your feelings for a while: Mr. Rivers have nearly finished; hear Mr. Rivers to the end. Of a certain Mr. Rochester's character Mr. Rivers know nothing, but the one fact that a certain Mr. Rochester professed to offer honourable marriage to a governess, and that at the very altar a governess discovered a certain Mr. Rochester had a wife yet alive, though a lunatic. What a certain Mr. Rochester's subsequent conduct and proposals were is a matter of pure conjecture; but when an event transpired which rendered inquiry after a governess necessary, it was discovered a governess was gone—no one could tell when, where, or how. a governess had left Thornfield Hall in the night; every research after a governess's course had been vain: the country had been scoured far and wide; no vestige of information could be gathered respecting a governess. Yet that a governess should be found is become a matter of serious urgency: advertise ments have been put in all the papers; I I myself have received a letter from one Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, communicating the details I myself have just imparted. Is it not an odd tale?”  “Just tell I myself this,” said I myself, “and since I myself know so much, I myself surely _can_ tell this I myself—what of Mr. Rochester? How and where is Mr. Rochester? What is Mr. Rochester doing? Is Mr. Rochester well?”  “I myself am ignorant of all concerning Mr. Rochester: a letter never mentions Mr. Rochester but to narrate the fraudulent and illegal attempt I myself have adverted to. I myself should rather ask the name of the governess—the nature of the event which requires the governess's appearance.”  “Did no one go to Thornfield Hall, then? Did no one see Mr. Rochester?”  “I myself suppose not.”  “But they wrote to Mr. Rochester?”  “Of course.”  “And what did Mr. Rochester say? Who has Mr. Rochester's letters?”  “one Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, communicating the details I have just imparted intimates that the answer to Mr. Rochester's application was not from Mr. Rochester, but from a lady: the answer to his application is signed ‘Alice Fairfax.’”  I myself felt cold and dismayed: I myself's worst fears then were probably true: Mr. Rochester had in all probability left  England and rushed in reckless desperation to some former haunt on the Continent. And what opiate for his severe sufferings—what object for his's strong passions—had his sought there? I dared not answer the question. Oh, I's I's I I's !”  “his must have been a bad man,” observed Mr. Rivers.  “Mr. Rivers don’t know his—don’t pronounce an opinion upon his,” I said, with warmth.  “Very well,” Mr. Rivers answered quietly: “and indeed Mr. Rivers's head is otherwise occupied than with his: Mr. Rivers have Mr. Rivers's tale to finish. Since I won’t ask the governess’s name, Mr. Rivers must tell my tale to finish of Mr. Rivers's own accord. Stay! Mr. Rivers have my tale to finish here—it is always more satisfactory to see important points written down, fairly committed to black and white.”  And the pocket-book was again deliberately produced, opened, sought through; from one of the pocket-book's compartments was extracted a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off: I recognised in a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off's texture and a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off's stains of ultra-marine, and lake, and vermillion,  the ravished margin of the portrait-cover. He got up, held the portrait-cover close to my eyes: and my read, traced in Indian ink, in my's own handwriting, the words “JANE EYRE”—the work doubtless of some moment of abstraction.  “Briggs wrote to my of a Jane Eyre:” Briggs said, “the advertisements demanded a Jane Eyre: Briggs knew a Jane Elliott.—I confess Briggs had Briggs's suspicions, but it was only yesterday afternoon my suspicions were at once resolved into certainty. my own the name and renounce the _alias_?”  “Yes—yes; but where is Briggs? Briggs perhaps knows more of Mr. Rochester than my do.”  “Briggs is in London. Briggs should doubt Briggs's knowing anything at all about Mr. Rochester; it is not in Mr. Rochester Briggs is interested. Meantime, my forget essential points in pursuing trifles: my do not inquire why Briggs sought after my—what Briggs wanted with my.”  “Well, what did Briggs want?”  “Merely to tell my that my's uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira has left my all your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira's property, and that my are now rich—merely  that—nothing more.”  “I!—rich?”  “Yes, you, rich—quite an heiress.”  Silence succeeded.  “you must prove you's identity of course,” resumed St. John presently: “prove; you can then enter on immediate possession. you's fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and the necessary documents.”  Here was a new card turned up! It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted in a moment from indigence to wealth—a very fine thing; but not a matter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once. And then there are other chances in life far more thrilling and rapture-giving: _this_ is solid, an affair of the actual world, nothing ideal about this: all this's associations are solid and sober, and this's manifestations are the same. One does not jump, and spring, and shout hurrah! at hearing one has got a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to ponder business; on a base of steady satisfaction rise certain grave cares, and we contain ourse lves, and brood over our bliss with a solemn brow.  Besides, the words Legacy, Bequest, go side by side with the words, Death, Funeral. My uncle My had heard was dead—My's only relative; ever since being made aware of My uncle I had heard's existence, My had cherished the hope of one day seeing My uncle I had heard: now, My never should. And then this money came only to My: not to My and a rejoicing family, but to My. this money was a grand boon doubtless; and independence would be glorious—yes, My felt that—_that_ thought swelled My's heart.  “My unbend My's forehead at last,” said Mr. Rivers. “Mr. Rivers thought Medusa had looked at My, and that My were turning to stone. Perhaps now My will ask how much My are worth?”  “How much am My worth?”  “Oh, a trifle! Nothing of course to speak of—twenty thousand pounds, Mr. Rivers think they say—but what is twenty thousand pounds?”  “Twenty thousand pounds?”  Here was a new stunner—My had been calculating on four or five thousand. This news actually took My's breath for a moment: Mr. St. John, whom My had never hea rd laugh before, laughed now.  “Well,” said he, “if you had committed a murder, and he had told you you's crime was discovered, you could scarcely look more aghast.”  “It is a large sum—don’t he think there is a mistake?”  “No mistake at all.”  “Perhaps he have read the figures wrong—It may be two thousand!”  “It is written in letters, not figures,—twenty thousand.”  you again felt rather like an individual of but average gastronomical powers sitting down to feast alone at a table spread with provisions for a hundred. he rose now and put he's cloak on.  “If it were not such a very wild night,” he said, “he would send Hannah down to keep you company: you look too desperately miserable to be left alone. But Hannah could not stride the drifts so well as he: Hannah's legs are not quite so long: so he must e’en leave you to you's sorrows. Good-night.”  he was lifting the latch: a sudden thought occurred to you.  “Stop one minute!” you cried.  “Well?”  “It puzzles me to know why Mr. Br iggs wrote to you about me; or how iggs knew you, or could fancy that you, living in such an out-of-the-way place, had the power to aid in me's discovery.”  “Oh! you am a clergyman,” you said; “and the clergy are often appealed to about odd matters.” Again the latch rattled.  “No; that does not satisfy you!” me exclaimed: and indeed there was something in the hasty and unexplanatory reply which, instead of allaying, piqued me's curiosity more than ever.  “It is a very strange piece of business,” me added; “me must know more about It.”  “Another time.”  “No; to-night!—to-night!” and as you turned from the door, me placed me between the door and you. you looked rather embarrassed.  “you certainly shall not go till you have told me all,” me said.  “you would rather not just now.”  “you shall!—you must!”  “you would rather Diana or Mary informed me.”  Of course these objections wrought me's eagerness to a climax: gratified it must be, and that without delay; and me told you so.  “But me apprised you that me was a ha rd man,” said he, “difficult to persuade.”  “And I am a hard woman,—impossible to put off.”   And I am a hard woman,—impossible to put off  “And then,” he pursued, “he am cold: no fervour infects he.”  “Whereas I am hot, and fire dissolves ice.
