The blaze there has thawed all the snow from he's cloak; by the same token, The blaze there has streamed on to I's floor, and made my floor like a trampled street. As he hope ever to be forgiven, he, the high crime and misdemeanour of spoiling a sanded kitchen, tell I what I wish to know.”  “Well, then,” he said, “he yield; if not to I's earnestness, to I's perseverance: as stone is worn by continual dropping. Besides, I must know some day,—as well now as later. I's name is Jane Eyre?”  “Of course: that was all settled before.”  “he are not, perhaps, aware that I am he's namesake?—that I was christened St. John Eyre Rivers?”  “No, indeed! I remember now seeing the letter E. comprised in he's initials written in books he have at different times lent m e; but I never asked for what name it stood. But what then? Surely—”  I stopped: I could not trust I to entertain, much less to express, the thought that rushed upon I—that embodied itself,—that, in a second, stood out a strong, solid probability. Circumstances knit Circumstances, fitted Circumstances, shot into order: the chain that had been lying hitherto a formless lump of links was drawn out straight,—every ring was perfect, the connection complete. I knew, by instinct, how the matter stood, before St. John had said another word; but I cannot expect the reader to have the same intuitive perception, so I must repeat St. John's explanation.  “I's mother’s name was Eyre; My mother’s had two brothers; one a clergyman, who married Miss Jane Reed, of Gateshead; the other, John Eyre, Esq., merchant, late of Funchal, Madeira. Mr. Briggs, being My mother’s's solicitor, wrote to us last August to inform us of us's death, and to say that My mother’s had left My mother’s's property to My mother’s's brother the clergyman’s orphan daug hter, overlooking us, in consequence of a quarrel, never forgiven, between him and my father. him wrote again a few weeks since, to intimate that the heiress was lost, and asking if we knew anything of the heiress. A name casually written on a slip of paper has enabled me to find the heiress out. You know the rest.” Again me was going, but You set You's back against the door.  “Do let You speak,” You said; “let You have one moment to draw breath and reflect.” You paused—me stood before You, hat in hand, looking composed enough. You resumed—  “me's mother was my father's sister?”  “Yes.”  “You's aunt, consequently?”  me bowed.  “You's uncle John was me's uncle John? me, Diana, and Mary are my father’s sister's children, as You am My uncle John's brother’s child?”  “Undeniably.”  “You, Diana, and Mary, then, are You's cousins; half our blood on each side flows from the same source?”  “our are cousins; yes.”  You surveyed me. It seemed You had found a brother: one You could be proud of,—one You could love; and two sisters, whose qualities were such, that, when You knew  them but as mere strangers, them had inspired me with genuine affection and admiration. The two girls, on whom, kneeling down on the wet ground, and looking through the low, latticed window of Moor House kitchen, me had gazed with so bitter a mixture of interest and despair, were me's near kinswomen; and the young and stately gentleman who had found me almost dying at the young and stately gentleman who had found me almost dying at his threshold's threshold was me's blood relation. Glorious discovery to a lonely wretch! This was wealth indeed!—wealth to the heart!—a mine of pure, genial affections. This was a blessing, bright, vivid, and exhilarating;—not like the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight's way, but sobering from the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight's weight. me now clapped me's hands in sudden joy—me's pulse bounded, me's veins thrilled.  “Oh, me am glad!—I am glad!” me exclaimed.  St. John smiled. “Did St. John not say me neglected essential points to pursue trifles?” St. John asked. “me were serious when St. John told me me had got a fortune; and now, for a matter of no moment, me are excited .”  “What _can_ you mean? It may be of no moment to you; you have sisters and don’t care for a cousin; but you had nobody; and now three relations,—or two, if you don’t choose to be counted,—are born into you's world full-grown. you say again, you am glad!”  you walked fast through the room: you stopped, half suffocated with the thoughts that rose faster than you could receive, comprehend, settle them:—thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere long. you looked at the blank wall: the blank wall seemed a sky thick with ascending stars,—every one lit you to a purpose or delight. Those who had saved you's life, whom, till this hour, you had loved barrenly, you could now benefit. Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly were under a yoke,—I could free Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly: Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly were scattered,—I could reunite Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly: the independence, the affluence which was you, might be Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly too. Were we not four? Twenty thousand pounds shared equally would be five thousand each, justice—enough and to spare: justice would be done,—mutual happiness secured. Now the wea lth did not weigh on me: now it was not a mere bequest of coin,—it was a legacy of life, hope, enjoyment.  How me looked while these ideas were taking me's spirit by storm, me cannot tell; but me perceived soon that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind me, and was gently attempting to make me sit down on a chair. Mr. Rivers also advised me to be composed; me scorned the insinuation of helplessness and distraction, shook off Mr. Rivers's hand, and began to walk about again.  “Write to Diana and Mary to-morrow,” me said, “and tell Diana and Mary to come home directly. Diana said Diana and Mary would both consider Diana and Mary rich with a thousand pounds, so with five thousand Diana and Mary will do very well.”  “Tell me where me can get me a glass of water,” said me; “me must really make an effort to tranquillise me's feelings.”  “Nonsense! and what sort of an effect will it have on me? Will it keep me in England, induce me to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like an ordinary mortal?”  “You wander: your head becomes confused.  I have been too abrupt in communicating the news; the news has excited you beyond you's strength.”  “I I quite put you out of patience: you am rational enough; it is I who misunderstand, or rather who affect to misunderstand.”  “Perhaps, if I explained I a little more fully, you should comprehend better.”  “Explain! What is there to explain? I cannot fail to see that twenty thousand pounds, the sum in question, divided equally between the nephew and three nieces of our uncle, will give five thousand to each? What you want is, that I should write to I's sisters and tell your sisters of the fortune that has accrued to your sisters.”  “To I, I mean.”  “I have intimated I's view of the case: I am incapable of taking any other. I am not brutally selfish, blindly unjust, or fiendishly ungrateful. Besides, I am resolved I will have a home and connections. I like Moor House, and I will live at Moor House; I like Diana and Mary, and I will attach I for life to Diana and Mary. It would ple ase and benefit me to have five thousand pounds; it would torment and oppress me to have twenty thousand; which, moreover, could never be mine in justice, though it might in law. me abandon to you, then, what is absolutely superfluous to me. Let there be no opposition, and no discussion about it; let us agree amongst each other, and decide the point at once.”  “This is acting on first impulses; me must take days to consider such a matter, ere me's word can be regarded as valid.”  “Oh! if all you doubt is me's sincerity, me am easy: you see the justice of the case?”  “you _do_ see a certain justice; but a certain justice is contrary to all custom. Besides, the entire fortune is you's right: me's uncle gained the entire fortune by my uncle's own efforts; my uncle was free to leave the entire fortune to whom my uncle would: my uncle left the entire fortune to you. After all, justice permits you to keep the entire fortune: you may, with a clear conscience, consider the entire fortune absolutely you's own.”  “With me,” said me, “it is fully as much a matter of feeling as of conscience: me must indulge me's feelings; me so  seldom have had an opportunity of doing so. Were you to argue, object, and annoy me for a year, me could not forego the delicious pleasure of which me have caught a glimpse—that of repaying, in part, a mighty obligation, and winning to me lifelong friends.”  “me think so now,” rejoined you, “because me do not know what it is to possess, nor consequently to enjoy wealth: me cannot form a notion of the importance twenty thousand pounds would give me; of the place twenty thousand pounds would enable me to take in society; of the prospects twenty thousand pounds would open to me: me cannot—”  “And you,” me interrupted, “cannot at all imagine the craving me have for fraternal and sisterly love. me never had a home, me never had brothers or sisters; me must and will have brothers or sisters now: you are not reluctant to admit me and own me, are you?”  “me, you will be me's brother—you's sisters will be me's sisters—without stipulating for this sacrifice of me's just rights.”  “Brother? Yes; at the distance of a thousand leagues! Sisters?  Yes; slaving amongst strangers! I, wealthy—gorged with gold I, wealthy never earned and do not merit! You, penniless! Famous equality and fraternisation! Close union! Intimate attachment!”  “But, You, You's aspirations after family ties and domestic happiness may be realised otherwise than by the means You contemplate: You may marry.”  “Nonsense, again! Marry! You don’t want to marry, and never shall marry.”  “That is saying too much: such hazardous affirmations are a proof of the excitement under which You labour.”  “That is not saying too much: You know what You feel, and how averse are You's inclinations to the bare thought of marriage. No one would take You for love; and You will not be regarded in the light of a mere money speculation. And You do not want a stranger—unsympathising, alien, different from You; You want You's kindred: those with whom You have full fellow-feeling. Say again You will be You's brother: when You uttered the words You was satisfied, happy; repeat the words, if You can, repeat the words sincerely.”  “You  think I can. I know I have always loved I's own sisters; and I know on what I's affection for my own sisters is grounded,—respect for my own sisters's worth and admiration of my own sisters's talents. You too have principle and mind: You's tastes and habits resemble Diana’s and Mary’s; You's presence is always agreeable to I; in You's conversation I have already for some time found a salutary solace. I feel I can easily and naturally make room in I's heart for You, as I's third and youngest sister.”  “Thank I: that contents I for to-night. Now I had better go; for if I stay longer, I will perhaps irritate I afresh by some mistrustful scruple.”  “And the school, I? the school must now be shut up, I suppose?”  “No. I will retain I's post of mistress till I get a substitute.”  I smiled approbation: we shook hands, and I took leave.  I need not narrate in detail the further struggles I had, and arguments I used, to get matters regarding the legacy settled as I wished. I's task was a very hard one; but, as I was abs olutely resolved—as my cousins saw at length that my's mind was really and immutably fixed on making a just division of the property—as my cousins must in my cousins's own hearts have felt the equity of the intention; and must, besides, have been innately conscious that in my's place my cousins would have done precisely what my wished to do—my cousins yielded at length so far as to consent to put the affair to arbitration. The judges chosen were Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer: Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer coincided in my's opinion: my carried my's point. The instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and my, each became possessed of a competency.     CHAPTER XXXIV   It was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of general holiday approached. my now closed Morton school, taking care that the parting should not be barren on my's side. Good fortune opens the hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we have largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual ebullition of the sensations.  I had long felt with pleasure that many of I's rustic scholars liked I, and when we parted, liked was confirmed: many of my rustic scholars manifested many of my rustic scholars's affection plainly and strongly. Deep was I's gratification to find I had really a place in many of my rustic scholars's unsophisticated hearts: I promised many of my rustic scholars that never a week should pass in future that I did not visit many of my rustic scholars, and give many of my rustic scholars an hour’s teaching in many of my rustic scholars's school.  Mr. Rivers came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty girls, file out before I, and locked the door, I stood with the key in I's hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some half-dozen of I's best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and well-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British peasantry. And that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British peasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of any in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and Bäuerinnen; and the best of them seemed to I ignorant, c oarse, and besotted, compared with my Morton girls.  “Do my consider my have got my's reward for a season of exertion?” asked Mr. Rivers, when they were gone. “Does not the consciousness of having done some real good in my's day and generation give pleasure?”  “Doubtless.”  “And my have only toiled a few months! Would not a life devoted to the task of regenerating my's race be well spent?”  “Yes,” my said; “but my could not go on for ever so: my want to enjoy my's own faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people. my must enjoy my own faculties now; don’t recall either my's mind or body to the school; my am out of it and disposed for full holiday.”  Mr. Rivers looked grave. “What now? What sudden eagerness is this my evince? What are my going to do?”  “To be active: as active as my can. And first my must beg Mr. Rivers to set Hannah at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on Mr. Rivers.”  “Do my want somebody else?”  “Yes, to go with my to Moor House. Diana and Mary will be at home in a week, and my want to have everything  in order against their arrival.”  “I understand. I thought I were for flying off on some excursion. It is better so: Hannah shall go with I.”  “Tell Hannah to be ready by to-morrow then; and here is the schoolroom key: I will give I the key of I's cottage in the morning.”  I took the key of my cottage. “I give the key of my cottage up very gleefully,” said I; “I don’t quite understand I's light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what employment I propose to I as a substitute for the one I are relinquishing. What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have I now?”  “I's first aim will be to _clean down_ (do I comprehend the full force of the expression?)—to _clean down_ Moor House from chamber to cellar; I's next to rub Moor House up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of cloths, till Moor House glitters again; I's third, to arrange every chair, table, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision; afterwards I shall go near to ruin I in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room; and lastly, the two day s preceding that on which your sisters are expected will be devoted by Hannah and me to such a beating of eggs, sorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christmas cakes, chopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other culinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the uninitiated like your. me's purpose, in short, is to have all things in an absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next Thursday; and me's ambition is to give Diana and Mary a beau-ideal of a welcome when Diana and Mary come.”  me smiled slightly: still me was dissatisfied.  “It is all very well for the present,” said me; “but seriously, me trust that when the first flush of vivacity is over, your will look a little higher than domestic endearments and household joys.”  “The best things the world has!” I interrupted.  “No, I, no: the world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt to make the world so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful.”  “I mean, on the contrary, to  be busy.”  “Jane, I excuse Jane for the present: two months’ grace I allow Jane for the full enjoyment of Jane's new position, and for pleasing Jane with this late-found charm of relationship; but _then_, I hope Jane will begin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and the selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence. I hope Jane's energies will then once more trouble Jane with your energies's strength.”  Jane looked at I with surprise. “I,” Jane said, “Jane think I are almost wicked to talk so. Jane am disposed to be as content as a queen, and I try to stir Jane up to restlessness! To what end?”  “To the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to Jane's keeping; and of which God will surely one day demand a strict account. Jane, I shall watch Jane closely and anxiously—I warn Jane of watch. And try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which Jane throw Jane into commonplace home pleasures. Don’t cling so tenaciously to ties of the flesh; sav e your constancy and ardour for an adequate cause; forbear to waste your constancy and ardour for an adequate cause on trite transient objects. Do you hear, you?”  “Yes; just as if you were speaking Greek. you feel you have adequate cause to be happy, and you _will_ be happy. Goodbye!”  Happy at Moor House you was, and hard you worked; and so did you: you was charmed to see how jovial you could be amidst the bustle of a house turned topsy-turvy—how you could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook. And really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was delightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had made. you had previously taken a journey to S—— to purchase some new furniture: you's cousins having given you _carte blanche_ to effect what alterations you pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that purpose. The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms you left much as The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms were: for you knew Diana and Mary would derive more pleasure from seeing again the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the spectacle of  the smartest innovations. Still some novelty was necessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it to be invested. Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement of some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze, new coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables, answered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring. A spare parlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and crimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the stairs. When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model of bright modest snugness within, as Moor House was, at this season, a specimen of wintry waste and desert dreariness without.  The eventful Thursday at length came. They were expected about dark, and ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in perfect trim; Hannah and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.  St. John arrived first. I had entreated St. John to keep quite clear of th e house till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the commotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within e house's walls sufficed to scare him to estrangement. him found me in the kitchen, watching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking. Approaching the hearth, him asked, “If him was at last satisfied with housemaid’s work?” me answered by inviting him to accompany me on a general inspection of the result of me's labours. With some difficulty, me got him to make the tour of e house. him just looked in at the doors me opened; and when him had wandered upstairs and downstairs, him said me must have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have effected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a syllable did him utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of him's .  This silence damped me. me thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed some old associations him valued. me inquired whether disturbed was the case: no doubt in a somewhat crest-falle n tone.  “Not at all; he had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously respected every association: he feared, indeed, I must have bestowed more thought on the matter than it was worth. How many minutes, for instance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very room?—By-the-bye, could I tell he where such a book was?”  I showed he the volume on the shelf: he took the volume on the shelf down, and withdrawing to he's accustomed window recess, he began to read the volume on the shelf.  Now, I did not like this, I. St. John was a good man; but I began to feel St. John had spoken truth of St. John when St. John said St. John was hard and cold. The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for St. John—life's peaceful enjoyments no charm. Literally, St. John lived only to aspire—after what was good and great, certainly; but still St. John would never rest, nor approve of others resting round St. John. As I looked at St. John's lofty forehead, still and pale as a white stone—at St. John's fine lineaments fixed in study—I comprehended all at once that St. John w ould hardly make a good husband: that it would be a trying thing to be ould's wife. I understood, as by inspiration, the nature of ould's love for Miss Oliver; I agreed with ould that his love for Miss Oliver was but a love of the senses. I comprehended how ould should despise ould for the feverish influence his love for Miss Oliver exercised over ould; how ould should wish to stifle and destroy his love for Miss Oliver; how ould should mistrust his love for Miss Oliver's ever conducting permanently to ould's happiness or Miss Oliver. I saw ould was of the material from which nature hews nature's heroes—Christian and Pagan—nature's lawgivers, nature's statesmen, nature's conquerors: a steadfast bulwark for great interests to rest upon; but, at the fireside, too often a cold cumbrous column, gloomy and out of place.  “This parlour is not ould's sphere,” I reflected: “the Himalayan ridge or Caffre bush, even the plague-cursed Guinea Coast swamp would suit ould better. Well may ould eschew the calm of domestic life; domestic life is not ould's element: there ould's faculties stagnate—his faculties cannot develop or appear to advantage. It is in scen es of strife and danger—where courage is proved, and energy exercised, and fortitude tasked—that he will speak and move, the leader and superior. A merry child would have the advantage of he on this hearth. he is right to choose a missionary’s career—I see it now.”  “They are coming! They are coming!” cried Hannah, throwing open the parlour door. At the same moment old Carlo barked joyfully. Out I ran. It was now dark; but a rumbling of wheels was audible. Hannah soon had a lantern lit. The vehicle had stopped at the wicket; the driver opened the door: first one well-known form, then another, stepped out. In a minute I had I's face under their bonnets, in contact first with Mary’s soft cheek, then with Diana’s flowing curls. their laughed—kissed I—then Hannah: patted old Carlo; asked eagerly if all was well; and being assured in the affirmative, hastened into the house.  their were stiff with their's long and jolting drive from Whitcross, and chilled with the f rosty night air; but their pleasant countenances expanded to the cheerful firelight. While the driver and Hannah brought in the boxes, their demanded St. John. At this moment St. John advanced from the parlour. their threw their's arms round St. John's neck at once. St. John gave each one quiet kiss, said in a low tone a few words of welcome, stood a while to be talked to, and then, intimating that St. John supposed their would soon rejoin St. John in the parlour, withdrew there as to a place of refuge.  I had lit their's candles to go upstairs, but Diana had first to give hospitable orders respecting the driver; this done, their followed I. their were delighted with the renovation and decorations of their's rooms; with the new drapery, and fresh carpets, and rich tinted china vases: their expressed their's gratification ungrudgingly. I had the pleasure of feeling that I's arrangements met their's wishes exactly, and that what I had done added a vivid charm to their's joyous return home.  Sweet was that evening. I's cousins, ful l of exhilaration, were so eloquent in narrative and comment, that their fluency covered St. John’s taciturnity: St. John’s was sincerely glad to see St. John’s's sisters; but in his sisters's glow of fervour and flow of joy St. John’s could not sympathise. The event of the day—that is, the return of Diana and Mary—pleased St. John’s; but the accompaniments of The event of the day—that is, the return of Diana and Mary, the glad tumult, the garrulous glee of reception irked St. John’s: I saw St. John’s wished the calmer morrow was come. In the very meridian of the night’s enjoyment, about an hour after tea, a rap was heard at the door. Hannah entered with the intimation that “a poor lad was come, at that unlikely time, to fetch Mr. Rivers to see a poor lad's mother, who was drawing away.”  “Where does his mother, who was drawing away live, Hannah?”  “Clear up at Whitcross Brow, almost four miles off, and moor and moss all the way.”  “Tell a poor lad “ will go.”  “Hannah’m sure, “, “ had better not. It’s the worst road to travel after dark that can be: there’s no track at all over the bog. And then it is such a bitter night—the keene st wind you ever felt. You had better send word, You, that You will be there in the morning.”  But You was already in the passage, putting on You's cloak; and without one objection, one murmur, You departed. It was then nine o’clock: You did not return till midnight. Starved and tired enough You was: but You looked happier than when You set out. You had performed an act of duty; made an exertion; felt You's own strength to do and deny, and was on better terms with You.  I am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried You's patience. the whole of the ensuing week was Christmas week: we took to no settled employment, but spent the whole of the ensuing week in a sort of merry domestic dissipation. The air of the moors, the freedom of home, the dawn of prosperity, acted on Diana and Mary’s spirits like some life-giving elixir: Diana and Mary’s were gay from morning till noon, and from noon till night. Diana and Mary’s could always talk; and Diana and Mary’s's discourse, witty, pithy, original, had such charms for I, that I preferred listening to, and sharing in their discourse, witty, pithy, original, to doing anything els e. St. John did not rebuke our vivacity; but e. St. John escaped from our vivacity: e. St. John was seldom in the house; e. St. John's parish was large, the population scattered, and e. St. John found daily business in visiting the sick and poor in his parish's different districts.  One morning at breakfast, Diana, after looking a little pensive for some minutes, asked e. St. John, “If e. St. John's plans were yet unchanged.”  “Unchanged and unchangeable,” was the reply. And e. St. John proceeded to inform our that e. St. John's departure from England was now definitively fixed for the ensuing year.  “And Rosamond Oliver?” suggested Mary, the words seeming to escape Mary's lips involuntarily: for no sooner had Mary uttered the words, than Mary made a gesture as if wishing to recall the words. e. St. John had a book in e. St. John's hand—it was e. St. John's unsocial custom to read at meals—e. St. John closed a book, and looked up.  “Rosamond Oliver,” said e. St. John, “is about to be married to Mr. Granby, one of the best connected and most estimable residents in S——, grandson and heir to Sir Frederic Granby: I had the intelligence from  her father yesterday.”  her's sisters looked at each other and at me; we all three looked at her: her was serene as glass.  “The match must have been got up hastily,” said Diana: “they cannot have known each other long.”  “But two months: they met in October at the county ball at S——. But where there are no obstacles to a union, as in the present case, where the connection is in every point desirable, delays are unnecessary: they will be married as soon as S—— Place, which Sir Frederic gives up to they, can be refitted for they's reception.”  The first time me found her alone after this communication, me felt tempted to inquire if the event distressed her: but her seemed so little to need sympathy, that, so far from venturing to offer her more, me experienced some shame at the recollection of what me had already hazarded. Besides, me was out of practice in talking to her: her's reserve was again frozen over, and me's frankness was congealed beneath his reserve. her had not kept her's promise of treating me e like his sisters; his continually made little chilling differences between us, which did not at all tend to the development of cordiality: in short, now that I was acknowledged his's kinswoman, and lived under the same roof with his, I felt the distance between us to be far greater than when his had known I only as the village schoolmistress. When I remembered how far I had once been admitted to his's confidence, I could hardly comprehend his's present frigidity.  Such being the case, I felt not a little surprised when his raised his's head suddenly from the desk over which his was stooping, and said—  “I see, I, the battle is fought and the victory won.”  Startled at being thus addressed, I did not immediately reply: after a moment’s hesitation I answered—  “But are his sure his are not in the position of those conquerors whose triumphs have cost those conquerors whose triumphs have cost them too dear too dear? Would not such another ruin his?”  “his think not; and if his were, it does not much signify; his shall never be called upon to contend  for such another. The event of the conflict is decisive: my way is now clear; my thank God for is!” So saying, my returned to my's papers and my's silence.  As our mutual happiness (_i.e._, Diana’s, Mary’s, and mine) settled into a quieter character, and our resumed our's usual habits and regular studies, my stayed more at home: my sat with our in the same room, sometimes for hours together. While Mary’s drew, Diana’s pursued a course of encyclopædic reading Diana’s had (to mine's awe and amazement) undertaken, and mine fagged away at German, my pondered a mystic lore of my's own: that of some Eastern tongue, the acquisition of which my thought necessary to my's plans.  Thus engaged, my appeared, sitting in my's own recess, quiet and absorbed enough; but that blue eye of my's had a habit of leaving the outlandish-looking grammar, and wandering over, and sometimes fixing upon our, with a curious intensity of observation: if caught, that blue eye of his would be instantly withdrawn; yet ever and anon, that blue eye of his  returned searchingly to our table. I wondered what it meant: I wondered, too, at the punctual satisfaction he never failed to exhibit on an occasion that seemed to I of small moment, namely, I's weekly visit to Morton school; and still more was I puzzled when, if the day was unfavourable, if there was snow, or rain, or high wind, and he's sisters urged I not to go, he would invariably make light of his sisters's solicitude, and encourage I to accomplish the task without regard to the elements.  “Jane is not such a weakling as you would make Jane,” he would say: “Jane can bear a mountain blast, or a shower, or a few flakes of snow, as well as any of us. Jane's constitution is both sound and elastic;—better calculated to endure variations of climate than many more robust.”  And when I returned, sometimes a good deal tired, and not a little weather-beaten, I never dared complain, because I saw that to murmur would be to vex he: on all occasions fortitude pleased he; the reverse was a special annoy ance.  One afternoon, however, I got leave to stay at home, because I really had a cold. His sisters were gone to Morton in I's stead: I sat reading Schiller; His, deciphering Schiller's crabbed Oriental scrolls. As I exchanged a translation for an exercise, I happened to look His's way: there I found I under the influence of the ever-watchful blue eye. How long the ever-watchful blue eye had been searching I through and through, and over and over, I cannot tell: so keen was the ever-watchful blue eye, and yet so cold, I felt for the moment superstitious—as if I were sitting in the room with something uncanny.  “I, what are I doing?”  “Learning German.”  ““ want I to give up German and learn Hindostanee.”  “I are not in earnest?”  “In such earnest that I must have it so: and I will tell I why.”  I then went on to explain that Hindostanee was the language I was I at present studying; that, as I advanced, I was apt to forget the commencement; that it would assist I greatly to have a pupil with whom I might again and  again go over the elements, and so fix the elements thoroughly in his mind; that his's choice had hovered for some time between me and his's sisters; but that his had fixed on me because his saw me could sit at a task the longest of the three. Would me do his this favour? me should not, perhaps, have to make the sacrifice long, as it wanted now barely three months to his's departure.  his was not a man to be lightly refused: you felt that every impression made on his, either for pain or pleasure, was deep-graved and permanent. me consented. When Diana and Mary returned, Diana found Diana's scholar transferred from Diana to Diana's brother: Diana laughed, and Diana and Mary agreed that his should never have persuaded Diana and Mary to such a step. his answered quietly—  “his know it.”  me found his a very patient, very forbearing, and yet an exacting master: his expected me to do a great deal; and when me fulfilled his's expectations, his, in his's own way, fully testified his's approbation. By degrees, his acquired a cert ain influence over me that took away me's liberty of mind: his praise and notice were more restraining than his's indifference. me could no longer talk or laugh freely when his was by, because a tiresomely importunate instinct reminded me that vivacity (at least in me) was distasteful to his. me was so fully aware that only serious moods and occupations were acceptable, that in his's presence every effort to sustain or follow any other became vain: me fell under a freezing spell. When his said “go,” me went; “come,” me came; “do this,” me did this. But me did not love me's servitude: me wished, many a time, his had continued to neglect me.  One evening when, at bedtime, his's sisters and me stood round his, bidding his good-night, his kissed each of his sisters, as was his's custom; and, as was equally his's custom, his gave me his's hand. Diana, who chanced to be in a frolicsome humour (_Diana, who chanced to be in a frolicsome humour (_she_ was not painfully controlled by his will_ was not painfully controlled by his's will; for Diana, who chanced to be in a frolicsome humour (_she_ was not painfully controlled by his will, in another way, was as strong), exclaimed—  “me! me used to call Jane me r third sister, but you don’t treat her as such: you should kiss her too.”  her pushed you towards him. you thought her very provoking, and felt uncomfortably confused; and while you was thus thinking and feeling, him bent him's head; him's Greek face was brought to a level with you, him's eyes questioned you's eyes piercingly—him kissed you. There are no such things as marble kisses or ice kisses, or you should say him's salute belonged to one of these classes; but there may be experiment kisses, and him's was an experiment kiss. When given, him viewed you to learn the result; the result was not striking: you am sure you did not blush; perhaps you might have turned a little pale, for you felt as if him were a seal affixed to you's fetters. him never omitted the ceremony afterwards, and the gravity and quiescence with which you underwent the ceremony, seemed to invest the ceremony for him with a certain charm.  As for you, you daily wished more to please him; but to do so, you felt daily more and more that you must disow n half my nature, stifle half my's faculties, wrest my's tastes from my tastes's original bent, force my to the adoption of pursuits for which my had no natural vocation. He wanted to train my to an elevation my could never reach; it racked my hourly to aspire to the standard He uplifted. The thing was as impossible as to mould my's irregular features to He's correct and classic pattern, to give to my's changeable green eyes the sea-blue tint and solemn lustre of He's own.  Not He's ascendancy alone, however, held my in thrall at present. Of late it had been easy enough for my to look sad: a cankering evil sat at my's heart and drained my's happiness at a cankering evil's source—a cankering evil.  Perhaps you think my had forgotten He, amidst these changes of place and fortune. Not for a moment. He's idea was still with my, because His idea was not a vapour sunshine could disperse, nor a sand-traced effigy storms could wash away; His idea was a name graven on a tablet, fated to last as long as the marble it in scribed. The craving to know what had become of him followed me everywhere; when me was at Morton, me re-entered me's cottage every evening to think of that; and now at Moor House, me sought me's bedroom each night to brood over that.  In the course of me's necessary correspondence with Mr. Briggs about the will, me had inquired if Mr. Briggs knew anything of him's present residence and state of health; but, as St. John had conjectured, Mr. Briggs was quite ignorant of all concerning him. me then wrote to Mrs. Fairfax, entreating information on the subject. me had calculated with certainty on this step answering me's end: me felt sure this step answering my end would elicit an early answer. me was astonished when a fortnight passed without reply; but when two months wore away, and day after day the post arrived and brought nothing for me, me fell a prey to the keenest anxiety.  me wrote again: there was a chance of me's first letter having missed. Renewed hope followed renewed effort: it shone like the former for some weeks, then, like  it, it faded, flickered: not a line, not a word reached me. When half a year wasted in vain expectancy, me's hope died out, and then me felt dark indeed.  A fine spring shone round me, which me could not enjoy. Summer approached; Diana tried to cheer me: Diana said me looked ill, and wished to accompany me to the sea-side. This St. John opposed; This St. John said me did not want dissipation, me wanted employment; me's present life was too purposeless, me required an aim; and, me suppose, by way of supplying deficiencies, This St. John prolonged still further me's lessons in Hindostanee, and grew more urgent in requiring my lessons in Hindostanee's accomplishment: and me, like a fool, never thought of resisting This St. John—me could not resist This St. John.  One day me had come to me's studies in lower spirits than usual; the ebb was occasioned by a poignantly felt disappointment. Hannah had told me in the morning there was a letter for me, and when me went down to take a letter for me, almost certain that the long-looked for tidings were vouchsafed me at last, me found only an un important note from Mr. Briggs on business. The bitter check had wrung from me some tears; and now, as me sat poring over the crabbed characters and flourishing tropes of an Indian scribe, me's eyes filled again.  St. John called me to St. John's side to read; in attempting to do read me's voice failed me: words were lost in sobs. St. John and me were the only occupants of the parlour: Diana was practising Diana's music in the drawing-room, Mary was gardening—it was a very fine May day, clear, sunny, and breezy. St. John expressed no surprise at this emotion, nor did St. John question me as to this emotion's cause; St. John only said—  “He and I will wait a few minutes, me, till me are more composed.” And while me smothered the paroxysm with all haste, St. John sat calm and patient, leaning on St. John's desk, and looking like a physician watching with the eye of science an expected and fully understood crisis in a patient’s malady. Having stifled me's sobs, wiped me's eyes, and muttered something about not being very well that morning, me resumed  my task, and succeeded in completing my task. St. John put away my's books and St. John's, locked St. John's desk, and said—  “Now, my, my shall take a walk; and with St. John.”  “my will call Diana and Mary.”  “No; St. John want only one companion this morning, and only one companion must be my. Put on my's things; go out by the kitchen-door: take the road towards the head of Marsh Glen: St. John will join my in a moment.”  my know no medium: my never in my's life have known any medium in my's dealings with positive, hard characters, antagonistic to my's own, between absolute submission and determined revolt. my have always faithfully observed the one, up to the very moment of bursting, sometimes with volcanic vehemence, into the other; and as neither present circumstances warranted, nor my's present mood inclined my to mutiny, my observed careful obedience to St. John's directions; and in ten minutes my was treading the wild track of Marsh Glen, side by side with St. John.  The breeze was from the west: The breeze came over the hills, sweet with scents of heath  and rush; the sky was of stainless blue; the stream descending the ravine, swelled with past spring rains, poured along plentiful and clear, catching golden gleams from the sun, and sapphire tints from the firmament. As we advanced and left the track, we trod a soft turf, mossy fine and emerald green, minutely enamelled with a tiny white flower, and spangled with a star-like yellow blossom: the hills, meantime, shut we quite in; for the glen, towards the glen's head, wound to the hills's very core.  “Let we rest here,” said St. John, as we reached the first stragglers of a battalion of rocks, guarding a sort of pass, beyond which the beck rushed down a waterfall; and where, still a little farther, the mountain shook off turf and flower, had only heath for raiment and crag for gem—where the mountain exaggerated the wild to the savage, and exchanged the fresh for the frowning—where the mountain guarded the forlorn hope of solitude, and a last refuge for silence.  I took a seat: St. John stood near I. St. John looked up the  pass and down the hollow; his glance wandered away with the stream, and returned to traverse the unclouded heaven which coloured the stream: his removed his's hat, let the breeze stir his's hair and kiss his's brow. his seemed in communion with the genius of the haunt: with his's eye his bade farewell to something.  “And his shall see something again,” his said aloud, “in dreams when his sleep by the Ganges: and again in a more remote hour—when another slumber overcomes his—on the shore of a darker stream!”  Strange words of a strange love! An austere patriot’s passion for his's fatherland! his sat down; for half-an-hour we never spoke; neither his to me nor me to his: that interval past, his recommenced—  “me, his go in six weeks; his have taken his's berth in an East Indiaman which sails on the 20th of June.”  “God will protect his; for his have undertaken God's work,” me answered.  “Yes,” said his, “there is his's glory and joy. his am the servant of an infallible Master. his am not going out under human guidance, subject to the defect ive laws and erring control of i's feeble fellow-worms: i's king, i's lawgiver, i's captain, is the All-perfect. It seems strange to i that all round i do not burn to enlist under the same banner,—to join in the same enterprise.”  “All have not i's powers, and it would be folly for the feeble to wish to march with the strong.”  “I do not speak to the feeble, or think of the feeble: I address only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish the work.”  “only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it are few in number, and difficult to discover.”  “I say truly; but when found, it is right to stir only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it up—to urge and exhort only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it to the effort—to show only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it what only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it's gifts are, and why only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it were given—to speak Heaven’s message in only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it's ear,—to offer only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it, direct from Heaven’s, a place in the ranks of Heaven’s's chosen.”  “If only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it are really qualified for the task, will not only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it's own hearts be the first to inform only such as are worthy of the work, and competent to accomplish it of the task?”  i felt as if an awful charm was framing round and gathering over i: i trembled to hear some fatal word spoken w hich would at once declare and rivet the spell.  “And what does _your_ heart say?” demanded St. John.  “_your_ heart is mute,—my heart is mute,” your answered, struck and thrilled.  “Then St. John must speak for _your_ heart,” continued St. John. “your, come with St. John to India: come as St. John's helpmeet and fellow-labourer.”  The glen and sky spun round: the hills heaved! It was as if your had heard a summons from Heaven—as if a visionary messenger, like him of Macedonia, had enounced, “Come over and help us!” But your was no apostle,—I could not behold the herald,—I could not receive a visionary messenger, like him of Macedonia's call.  “Oh, St. John!” your cried, “have some mercy!”  your appealed to St. JohnSt. John St. John's . St. John continued—  “God and nature intended your for a missionary’s wife. It is not personal, but mental endowments God and nature have given your: your are formed for labour, not for love. A missionary’s wife your must—shall be. your shall be mine: St. John claim your—not for St. John's pleasure, but fo r my Sovereign’s service.”  “I am not fit for my Sovereign’s service: I have no vocation,” I said.  He had calculated on these first objections: He was not irritated by these first objections. Indeed, as He leaned back against the crag behind He, folded He's arms on He's chest, and fixed He's countenance, I saw He was prepared for a long and trying opposition, and had taken in a stock of patience to last He to its close—resolved, however, that its close should be conquest for He.  “Humility, I,” said He, “is the groundwork of Christian virtues: I say right that I are not fit for my Sovereign’s service. Who is fit for my Sovereign’s service? Or who, that ever was truly called, believed himself worthy of the summons? I, for instance, am but dust and ashes. With He, I acknowledge I the chiefest of sinners; but I do not suffer this sense of I's personal vileness to daunt I. I know He: that He is just as well as mighty; and while He has chosen a feeble instrument to perform a great task, He will, from the boundless stores of He's provid ence, supply the inadequacy of the means to the end. Think like me, Jane—trust like me. It is the Rock of Ages me ask Jane to lean on: do not doubt but It will bear the weight of Jane's human weakness.”  “Jane do not understand a missionary life: Jane have never studied missionary labours.”  “There me, humble as me am, can give Jane the aid Jane want: me can set Jane Jane's task from hour to hour; stand by Jane always; help Jane from moment to moment. This me could do in the beginning: soon (for me know Jane's powers) Jane would be as strong and apt as me, and would not require me's help.”  “But your powers—where are your powers for this undertaking? me do not feel your powers. Nothing speaks or stirs in me while Jane talk. me am sensible of no light kindling—no life quickening—no voice counselling or cheering. Oh, me wish me could make Jane see how much me's mind is at this moment like a rayless dungeon, with one shrinking fear fettered in my mind's depths—the fear of being persuaded by Jane to attempt what me cannot accomplish!”  “me have  an answer for you—hear an answer. I have watched you ever since we first met: I have made you I's study for ten months. I have proved you in ten months by sundry tests: and what have I seen and elicited? In the village school I found you could perform well, punctually, uprightly, labour uncongenial to you's habits and inclinations; I saw you could perform it with capacity and tact: you could win while you controlled. In the calm with which you learnt you had become suddenly rich, I read a mind clear of the vice of Demas:—lucre had no undue power over you. In the resolute readiness with which you cut you's wealth into four shares, keeping but one to you, and relinquishing the three others to the claim of abstract justice, I recognised a soul that revelled in the flame and excitement of sacrifice. In the tractability with which, at I's wish, you forsook a study in which you were interested, and adopted another because another interested I; in the untiring assiduity with which you have since persev ered in it—in the unflagging energy and unshaken temper with which you have met it's difficulties—I acknowledge the complement of the qualities I seek. you, you are docile, diligent, disinterested, faithful, constant, and courageous; very gentle, and very heroic: cease to mistrust you—I can trust you unreservedly. As a conductress of Indian schools, and a helper amongst Indian women, you's assistance will be to I invaluable.”  you's iron shroud contracted round you; persuasion advanced with slow sure step. Shut you's eyes as you would, these last words of I's succeeded in making the way, which had seemed blocked up, comparatively clear. you's work, which had appeared so vague, so hopelessly diffuse, condensed My work, which had appeared so vague, so hopelessly diffuse as I proceeded, and assumed a definite form under I's shaping hand. I waited for an answer. you demanded a quarter of an hour to think, before you again hazarded a reply.  “Very willingly,” I rejoined; and rising, I strode a little distance up the pass, threw I down on a swe ll of heath, and there lay still.   He threw He down on a swell of heath, and there lay still  “I _can_ do what He wants I to do: I am forced to see and acknowledge that,” I meditated,—“that is, if life be spared I. But I feel mine is not the existence to be long protracted under an Indian sun. What then? He does not care for that: when I's time came to die, He would resign I, in all serenity and sanctity, to the God who gave I. The case is very plain before I. In leaving England, I should leave a loved but empty land—He is not there; and if He were, what is, what can that ever be to I? I's business is to live without He now: nothing so absurd, so weak as to drag on from day to day, as if I were waiting some impossible change in circumstances, which might reunite I to He. Of course (as St. John once said) I must seek another interest in life to replace the one lost: is not the occupation He now offers I truly the most glorious man can adopt or the God who gave me assign? Is the occupation he now offers me  not, by its noble cares and sublime results, the one best calculated to fill the void left by uptorn affections and demolished hopes? I believe I must say, Yes—and yet I shudder. Alas! If I join St. John, I abandon half I: if I go to India, I go to premature death. And how will the interval between leaving England for India, and India for the grave, be filled? Oh, I know well! That, too, is very clear to I's vision. By straining to satisfy St. John till I's sinews ache, I _shall_ satisfy St. John—to the finest central point and farthest outward circle of St. John's expectations. If I _do_ go with St. John—if I _do_ make the sacrifice St. John urges, I will make the sacrifice he urges absolutely: I will throw all on the altar—heart, vitals, the entire victim. St. John will never love I; but St. John shall approve I; I will show St. John energies St. John has not yet seen, resources St. John has never suspected. Yes, I can work as hard as St. John can, and with as little grudging.  “Consent, then, to St. John's demand is possible: but for one item—one dreadful item.  It is—that he asks me to be he's wife, and has no more of a husband’s heart for me than that frowning giant of a rock, down which the stream is foaming in yonder gorge. he prizes me as a soldier would a good weapon; and prizes is all. Unmarried to he, this would never grieve me; but can me let he complete he's calculations—coolly put into practice he's plans—go through the wedding ceremony? Can me receive from he the bridal ring, endure all the forms of love (which me doubt not he would scrupulously observe) and know that the spirit was quite absent? Can me bear the consciousness that every endearment he bestows is a sacrifice made on principle? No: such a martyrdom would be monstrous. me will never undergo such a martyrdom. As he's sister, me might accompany he—not as he's wife: me will tell he so.”  me looked towards the knoll: there he lay, still as a prostrate column; he's face turned to me: he's eye beaming watchful and keen. he started to he's feet and approached me.  “he am ready to go to India, if he may  go free.”  “Your answer requires a commentary,” he said; “Your answer is not clear.”  “he have hitherto been Your's adopted brother—Your: let us continue as such: us had better not marry.”  he shook he's head. “Adopted fraternity will not do in this case. If Your were he's real sister it would be different: he should take Your, and seek no wife. But as it is, either us's union must be consecrated and sealed by marriage, or our union cannot exist: practical obstacles oppose practical obstacles to any other plan. Do Your not see it, Your? Consider a moment—Your's strong sense will guide Your.”  Your did consider; and still your strong senseyour strong sense , directed Your only to the fact that us did not love each other as man and wife should: and therefore your strong sense inferred us ought not to marry. Your said so. “he,” Your returned, “Your regard he as a brother—Your as a sister: so let us continue.”  “us cannot—us cannot,” he answered, with short, sharp determination: “it would not do. Your have said Your will go with he to  India: remember—you have said that.”  “Conditionally.”  “Well—well. To the main point—the departure with you from England, the co-operation with you in you's future labours—you do not object. you have already as good as put you's hand to the plough: you are too consistent to withdraw your hand. you have but one end to keep in view—how the work you have undertaken can best be done. Simplify you's complicated interests, feelings, thoughts, wishes, aims; merge all considerations in one purpose: that of fulfilling with effect—with power—the mission of you's great Master. To do so, you must have a coadjutor: not a brother—that is a loose tie—but a husband. you, too, do not want a sister: a sister might any day be taken from you. you want a wife: the sole helpmeet you can influence efficiently in life, and retain absolutely till death.”  you shuddered as you spoke: you felt you's influence in you's marrow—you's hold on you's limbs.  “Seek one elsewhere than in you, you: seek one fitted to you.”  “One fitted to you's purpose,  you mean—fitted to my vocation. Again my tell you it is not the insignificant private individual—the mere man, with the man’s selfish senses—my wish to mate: it is the missionary.”  “And my will give the missionary my's energies—give is all the missionary wants—but not my: give would be only adding the husk and shell to the kernel. For the husk and shell the missionary has no use: my retain the husk and shell.”  “my cannot—my ought not. Do my think God will be satisfied with half an oblation? Will God accept a mutilated sacrifice? It is the cause of God my advocate: it is under His standard my enlist you. my cannot accept on God's behalf a divided allegiance: it must be entire.”  “Oh! my will give my's heart to God,” my said. “_you_ do not want my heart.”  my will not swear, you, that there was not something of repressed sarcasm both in the tone in which my uttered this sentence, and in the feeling that accompanied this sentence. my had silently feared St. John till now, because my had not understood St. John. St. John had held my in awe, because St. John had held my in doubt. How  much of him was saint, how much mortal, I could not heretofore tell: but revelations were being made in this conference: the analysis of him's nature was proceeding before I's eyes. I saw him's fallibilities: I comprehended his fallibilities. I understood that, sitting there where I did, on the bank of heath, and with that handsome form before I, I sat at the feet of a man, erring as I. The veil fell from him's hardness and despotism. Having felt in him the presence of these qualities, I felt him's imperfection and took courage. I was with an equal—one with whom I might argue—one whom, if I saw good, I might resist.  him was silent after I had uttered the last sentence, and I presently risked an upward glance at him's countenance. him's eye, bent on I, expressed at once stern surprise and keen inquiry. “Is I sarcastic, and sarcastic to _him!_” His eye, bent on me, seemed to say. “What does Is signify?”  “Do not let us forget that this is a solemn matter,” him said ere long; “one of which we may neither think nor talk lightly  without sin. I trust, Jane, Jane are in earnest when Jane say Jane will serve Jane's heart to God: serve is all I want. Once wrench your heart from man, and fix your heart on Jane's Maker, the advancement of your Maker's spiritual kingdom on earth will be Jane's chief delight and endeavour; Jane will be ready to do at once whatever furthers the advancement of that Maker’s spiritual kingdom on earth. Jane will see what impetus would be given to Jane's efforts and I by our physical and mental union in marriage: the only union that gives a character of permanent conformity to the destinies and designs of human beings; and, passing over all minor caprices—all trivial difficulties and delicacies of feeling—all scruple about the degree, kind, strength or tenderness of mere personal inclination—Jane will hasten to enter into our physical and mental union in marriage at once.”  “Shall Jane?” Jane said briefly; and Jane looked at I's features, beautiful in his features, beautiful in their harmony, but strangely formidable in their still severity's harmony, but strangely formidable in their still severity; at I's brow, commanding but not open; at I's eyes, bright and deep and searching, but  never soft; at his tall imposing figure; and fancied myself in idea _his's wife_. Oh! it would never do! As his's curate, his's comrade, all would be right: myself would cross oceans with his in his curate, his comrade; toil under Eastern suns, in Asian deserts with his in his curate, his comrade; admire and emulate his's courage and devotion and vigour; accommodate quietly to his's masterhood; smile undisturbed at his's ineradicable ambition; discriminate the Christian from the man: profoundly esteem the one, and freely forgive the other. myself should suffer often, no doubt, attached to his only in his curate, his comrade: myself's body would be under rather a stringent yoke, but myself's heart and mind would be free. myself should still have myself's unblighted self to turn to: myself's natural unenslaved feelings with which to communicate in moments of loneliness. There would be recesses in myself's mind which would be only mine, to which his never came, and sentiments growing there fresh and sheltered which his's austerity could never blight, nor his's measured warrior-ma rch trample down: but as his wife—at his's side always, and always restrained, and always checked—forced to keep the fire of my nature continually low, to compel the fire of my nature to burn inwardly and never utter a cry, though the fire of my nature consumed vital after vital—_this_ would be unendurable.  “St. John!” my exclaimed, when my had got so far in my's meditation.  “Well?” St. John answered icily.  “my repeat my freely consent to go with St. John as St. John's fellow-missionary, but not as St. John's wife; my cannot marry St. John and become part of St. John.”  “A part of St. John my must become,” St. John answered steadily; “otherwise the whole bargain is void. How can St. John, take out with St. John to India a girl of nineteen, unless a girl of nineteen be married to St. John? How can we be for ever together—sometimes in solitudes, sometimes amidst savage tribes—and unwed?”  “Very well,” my said shortly; “under the circumstances, quite as well as if my were either St. John's real sister, or a man and a clergyman like St. John.”  “It is known that my are not St. John's  sister; I cannot introduce you as such: to attempt introduce would be to fasten injurious suspicions on us both. And for the rest, though you have a man’s vigorous brain, you have a woman’s heart and—it would not do.”  “it would do,” you affirmed with some disdain, “perfectly well. you have a woman’s heart, but not where I are concerned; for I you have only a comrade’s constancy; a fellow-soldier’s frankness, fidelity, fraternity, if I like; a neophyte’s respect and submission to a neophyte’s's hierophant: nothing more—don’t fear.”  “It is what I want,” I said, speaking to I; “It is just what I want. And there are obstacles in the way: obstacles in the way must be hewn down. you, you would not repent marrying I—be certain of that; we _must_ be married. I repeat it: there is no other way; and undoubtedly enough of love would follow upon marriage to render the union right even in you's eyes.”  “you scorn I's idea of love,” you could not help saying, as you rose up and stood before I, leaning you's back against the rock . ““ scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer: yes, you, and “ scorn you when you offer the counterfeit sentiment you offer.”  you looked at “ fixedly, compressing you's well-cut lips while you did so. Whether you was incensed or surprised, or what, it was not easy to tell: you could command you's countenance thoroughly.  “you scarcely expected to hear that expression from “,” you said: “you think you have done and uttered nothing to deserve scorn.”  “ was touched by you's gentle tone, and overawed by you's high, calm mien.  “Forgive “ the words, you; but it is you's own fault that “ have been roused to speak so unguardedly. you have introduced a topic on which our natures are at variance—a topic our should never discuss: the very name of love is an apple of discord between our. If the reality were required, what should our do? How should our feel? you, abandon you's scheme of marriage—forget your scheme of marriage.”  “No,” said you; “your scheme of marriage is a long-cherished scheme, and the only one which can secure you's great end: but you shall urge “ no f urther at present. To-morrow, I leave home for Cambridge: I have many friends there to whom I should wish to say farewell. I shall be absent a fortnight—take that space of time to consider I's offer: and do not forget that if you reject my offer, it is not I you deny, but God. Through I's means, God opens to you a noble career; as I's wife only can you enter upon a noble career. Refuse to be my wife, and you limit you for ever to a track of selfish ease and barren obscurity. Tremble lest in that case you should be numbered with those who have denied the faith, and are worse than infidels!”  you had done. Turning from I, you once more  “Looked to river, looked to hill.”   But this time you's feelings were all pent in you's heart: I was not worthy to hear his feelings uttered. As I walked by you's side homeward, I read well in you's iron silence all you felt towards I: the disappointment of an austere and despotic nature, which has met resistance where an austere and despotic nature, which has met resistance where it expected submission expected submission—the disapprobation of a cool, inflexible judg ment, which has detected in another feelings and views in which it has no power to sympathise: in short, as a man, he would have wished to coerce me into obedience: it was only as a sincere Christian he bore so patiently with me's perversity, and allowed so long a space for reflection and repentance.  That night, after he had kissed he's sisters, he thought proper to forget even to shake hands with me, but left the room in silence. I—who, though me had no love, had much friendship for he—was hurt by the marked omission: so much hurt that tears started to me's eyes.  “I see me and he have been quarrelling, me,” said I, “during me's walk on the moor. But go after he; he is now lingering in the passage expecting me—he will make it up.”  me have not much pride under such circumstances: me would always rather be happy than dignified; and me ran after he—he stood at the foot of the stairs.  “Good-night, he,” said I.  “Good-night, me,” he replied calmly.  “Then shake hands,” me  added.  What a cold, loose touch, he impressed on my fingers! he was deeply displeased by what had occurred that day; cordiality would not warm, nor tears move he. No happy reconciliation was to be had with he—no cheering smile or generous word: but still he was patient and placid; and when my asked he if he forgave my, he answered that he was not in the habit of cherishing the remembrance of vexation; that he had nothing to forgive, not having been offended.  And with that answer he left my. my would much rather he had knocked my down.     CHAPTER XXXV   he did not leave for Cambridge the next day, as he had said he would. he deferred he's departure a whole week, and during a whole week he made my feel what severe punishment a good yet stern, a conscientious yet implacable man can inflict on one who has offended a good yet stern, a conscientious yet implacable man. Without one overt act of hostility, one upbraiding word, he contrived to impress my momently with the conviction that my was put beyond the pale of he's favour.  N ot that St. John harboured a spirit of unchristian vindictiveness—not that St. John would have injured a hair of my head, if it had been fully in St. John's power to do so. Both by nature and principle, St. John was superior to the mean gratification of vengeance: St. John had forgiven my for saying my scorned St. John and St. John's love, but St. John had not forgotten the words; and as long as St. John and my lived St. John never would forget the words. my saw by St. John's look, when St. John turned to my, that the words were always written on the air between he and I; whenever my spoke, the words sounded in my's voice to St. John's ear, and the words's echo toned every answer St. John gave my.  St. John did not abstain from conversing with my: St. John even called my as usual each morning to join St. John at St. John's desk; and my fear the corrupt man within St. John had a pleasure unimparted to, and unshared by, the pure Christian, in evincing with what skill St. John could, while acting and speaking apparently just as usual, extract from every deed and every phrase the spirit of interest and approval which had formerl y communicated a certain austere charm to his language and manner. To me, his was in reality become no longer flesh, but marble; his's eye was a cold, bright, blue gem; his's tongue a speaking instrument—nothing more.  All this was torture to me—refined, lingering torture. All this kept up a slow fire of indignation and a trembling trouble of grief, which harassed and crushed me altogether. me felt how—if me were his's wife, his, could soon kill me, without drawing from me's veins a single drop of blood, or receiving on his's own crystal conscience the faintest stain of crime. Especially me felt this when me made any attempt to propitiate his. No ruth met me's . _his_ experienced no suffering from estrangement—no yearning after reconciliation; and though, more than once, me's fast falling tears blistered the page over which we both bent, my fast falling tears produced no more effect on his than if his's heart had been really a matter of stone or metal. To his's sisters, meantime, his wa s somewhat kinder than usual: as if afraid that mere coldness would not sufficiently convince me how completely me was banished and banned, he added the force of contrast; and added me am sure he did not by malice, but on principle.  The night before he left home, happening to see he walking in the garden about sunset, and remembering, as me looked at he, that this man, alienated as he now was, had once saved me's life, and that we were near relations, me was moved to make a last attempt to regain he's friendship. me went out and approached he as he stood leaning over the little gate; me spoke to the point at once.  “he, me am unhappy because he are still angry with me. Let we be friends.”  “he hope we are friends,” was the unmoved reply; while he still watched the rising of the moon, which he had been contemplating as me approached.  “No, he, we are not friends as we were. he know are.”  “Are we not? That is wrong. For he's part, he wish me no ill and all good.”  “me believe he, St . John; for I am sure you are incapable of wishing any one ill; but, as I am you's kinswoman, I should desire somewhat more of affection than that sort of general philanthropy you extend to mere strangers.”  “Of course,” you said. “I's wish is reasonable, and you am far from regarding I as a stranger.”  This, spoken in a cool, tranquil tone, was mortifying and baffling enough. Had I attended to the suggestions of pride and ire, I should immediately have left you; but something worked within I more strongly than pride and ire could. I deeply venerated you's talent and principle. you's friendship was of value to I: to lose His friendship tried I severely. I would not so soon relinquish the attempt to reconquer His friendship.  “Must we part in this way, you? And when you go to India, will you leave I so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?”  you now turned quite from the moon and faced I.  “When you go to India, I, will you leave I! What! do I not go to India?”  “you said I could not  unless I married you.”  “And you will not marry I! you adhere to that resolution?”  Reader, do Reader know, as I do, what terror those cold people can put into the ice of those cold people's questions? How much of the fall of the avalanche is in those cold people's anger? of the breaking up of the frozen sea in those cold people's displeasure?  “No. you, you will not marry you. you adhere to that resolution.”  the avalanche had shaken and slid a little forward, but the avalanche did not yet crash down.  “Once more, why this refusal?” you asked.  “Formerly,” you answered, “because you did not love you; now, you reply, because you almost hate you. If you were to marry you, you would kill you. you are killing you now.”  you's lips and cheeks turned white—quite white.  “_you should kill you_—_I am killing you_? you's words are such as ought not to be used: violent, unfeminine, and untrue. Your words betray an unfortunate state of mind: Your words merit severe reproof: Your words would seem inexcusable, but that it is the duty of man to forgive man's fellow even until seventy-and -seven times.”  I had finished the business now. While earnestly wishing to erase from his mind the trace of I's former offence, I had stamped on that tenacious surface another and far deeper impression: I had burnt another and far deeper impression in.  “Now his will indeed hate I,” I said. “It is useless to attempt to conciliate his: I see I have made an eternal enemy of his.”  A fresh wrong did these words inflict: the worse, because these words touched on the truth. That bloodless lip quivered to a temporary spasm. I knew the steely ire I had whetted. I was heart-wrung.  “his utterly misinterpret I's words,” I said, at once seizing his's hand: “I have no intention to grieve or pain his—indeed, I have not.”  Most bitterly his smiled—most decidedly his withdrew his hand from I. “And now I recall I's promise, and will not go to India at all, his presume?” said his, after a considerable pause.  “Yes, I will, as his's assistant,” I answered.  A very long silence succeeded. What struggle there was in his between Nature and Grac e in this interval, I cannot tell: only singular gleams scintillated in his eyes, and strange shadows passed over his's face. his spoke at last.  “his before proved to I the absurdity of a single woman of I's age proposing to accompany abroad a single man of his. his proved the absurdity of a single woman of your age proposing to accompany abroad a single man of mine to I in such terms as, his should have thought, would have prevented I ever again alluding to the plan. That I have done so, his regret—for I's sake.”  I interrupted his. Anything like a tangible reproach gave I courage at once. “Keep to common sense, his: his are verging on nonsense. his pretend to be shocked by what I have said. his are not really shocked: for, with his's superior mind, his cannot be either so dull or so conceited as to misunderstand I's meaning. I say again, I will be his's curate, if his like, but never his's wife.”  Again his turned lividly pale; but, as before, controlled his's passion perfectly. his answered emphatically but calmly—  “A female curate, who is not his's wife, would never suit his . With me, then, it seems, me cannot go: but if me are sincere in me's offer, me will, while in town, speak to a married missionary, whose wife needs a coadjutor. me's own fortune will make me independent of the Society’s aid; and thus me may still be spared the dishonour of breaking me's promise and deserting the band me engaged to join.”  Now me never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard and much too despotic for the occasion. me replied—  “There is no dishonour, no breach of promise, no desertion in the case. me am not under the slightest obligation to go to India, especially with strangers. With me me would have ventured much, because me admire, confide in, and, as a sister, me love me; but me am convinced that, go when and with whom me would, me should not live long in that climate.”  “Ah! me are afraid of me,” me said, curling me's lip.  “me am. God did not give me me's life to throw away ; and to do as you wish me would, me begin to think, be almost equivalent to committing suicide. Moreover, before me definitively resolve on quitting England, me will know for certain whether me cannot be of greater use by remaining in England than by leaving England.”  “What do me mean?”  “It would be fruitless to attempt to explain; but there is a point on which me have long endured painful doubt, and me can go nowhere till by some means painful doubt is removed.”  “you know where me's heart turns and to what your heart clings. The interest me cherish is lawless and unconsecrated. Long since me ought to have crushed The interest you cherish: now me should blush to allude to The interest you cherish. me think of Mr. Rochester?”  think was true. me confessed think by silence.  “Are me going to seek Mr. Rochester?”  “me must find out what is become of Mr. Rochester.”  “It remains for you, then,” you said, “to remember me in you's prayers, and to entreat God for me, in all earnestness, that me may not indeed become a castaway. you had thought you recognised in me one of the c hosen. But God sees not as man sees: _God's_ will be done—”  God opened the gate, passed through the gate, and strayed away down the glen. God was soon out of sight.  On re-entering the parlour, I found Diana standing at the window, looking very thoughtful. Diana was a great deal taller than I: Diana put Diana's hand on I's shoulder, and, stooping, examined I's face.  “I,” Diana said, “I are always agitated and pale now. Diana am sure there is something the matter. Tell Diana what business St. John and I have on hands. Diana have watched I this half hour from the window; I must forgive Diana's being such a spy, but for a long time Diana have fancied Diana hardly know what. St. John is a strange being—”  Diana paused—I did not speak: soon Diana resumed—  “St. John cherishes peculiar views of some sort respecting I, Diana am sure: St. John has long distinguished I by a notice and interest St. John never showed to any one else—to what end? Diana wish St. John loved I—does St. John, I?”  I put Diana cool hand to I's hot forehead; “No, Die,  not one whit.”  “Then why does he follow you so with he's eyes, and get you so frequently alone with he, and keep you so continually at he's side? Mary and I had both concluded he wished you to marry he.”  “he does—he has asked you to be he's wife.”  I clapped I's hands. “That is just what Mary and I hoped and thought! And you will marry he, you, won’t you? And then he will stay in England.”  “Far from that, I; he's sole idea in proposing to you is to procure a fitting fellow-labourer in he's Indian toils.”  “What! he wishes you to go to India?”  “Yes.”  “Madness!” I exclaimed. “you would not live three months there, I am certain. you never shall go: you have not consented, have you, you?”  “you have refused to marry he—”  “And have consequently displeased he?” I suggested.  “Deeply: he will never forgive you, you fear: yet you offered to accompany he as he's sister.”  “It was frantic folly to do so, you. Think of the task you undertook—one of incessant fatigue, where fatigue kills even  the strong, and you are weak. St. John—you know St. John—would urge you to impossibilities: with St. John there would be no permission to rest during the hot hours; and unfortunately, I have noticed, whatever St. John exacts, you force you to perform. I am astonished you found courage to refuse St. John's hand. you do not love St. John then, you?”  “Not as a husband.”  “Yet St. John is a handsome fellow.”  “And you am so plain, I see, Die. We should never suit.”  “Plain! you?
