Not at all. you are much too pretty, as well as too good, to be grilled alive in Calcutta.” And again you earnestly conjured you to give up all thoughts of going out with St. John.  “you must indeed,” you said; “for when just now you repeated the offer of serving St. John for a deacon, St. John expressed St. John shocked at you's want of decency. St. John seemed to think you had committed an impropriety in proposing to accompany St. John unmarried: as if you had not from the first hoped to find in St. John a brother, and habitually regarded St. John as such.”  “What makes you say St. John  does not love you, you?”  “you should hear himself on the subject. himself has again and again explained that it is not himself, but himself's office himself wishes to mate. himself has told you you am formed for labour—not for love: which is true, no doubt. But, in you's opinion, if you am not formed for love, it follows that you am not formed for marriage. Would it not be strange, Die, to be chained for life to a man who regarded one but as a useful tool?”  “Insupportable—unnatural—out of the question!”  “And then,” you continued, “though you have only sisterly affection for himself now, yet, if forced to be himself's wife, you can imagine the possibility of conceiving an inevitable, strange, torturing kind of love for himself, because himself is so talented; and there is often a certain heroic grandeur in himself's look, manner, and conversation. In that case, you's lot would become unspeakably wretched. himself would not want you to love himself; and if you showed love, himself would make you sensible that love was a superfluity, unrequired by himself, unbecomi ng in me. me know he would.”  “And yet he is a good man,” said Diana.  “he is a good and a great man; but he forgets, pitilessly, the feelings and claims of little people, in pursuing he's own large views. It is better, therefore, for the insignificant to keep out of he's way, lest, in he's progress, he should trample the insignificant down. Here he comes! me will leave Diana, Diana.” And me hastened upstairs as me saw he entering the garden.  But me was forced to meet he again at supper. During supper he appeared just as composed as usual. me had thought he would hardly speak to me, and me was certain he had given up the pursuit of he's matrimonial scheme: the sequel showed me was mistaken on both points. he addressed me precisely in he's ordinary manner, or what had, of late, been his ordinary manner—one scrupulously polite. No doubt he had invoked the help of the Holy Spirit to subdue the anger me had roused in he, and now believed he had forgiven me once more.  For the evening reading before prayer s, he selected the twenty-first chapter of Revelation. It was at all times pleasant to listen while from he's lips fell the words of the Bible: never did he's fine voice sound at once so sweet and full—never did he's manner become so impressive in his manner's noble simplicity, as when he delivered the oracles of God: and to-night his fine voice took a more solemn tone—that manner a more thrilling meaning—as he sat in the midst of he's household circle (the May moon shining in through the uncurtained window, and rendering almost unnecessary the light of the candle on the table): as he sat there, bending over the Bible, and described from the Bible's page the vision of the new heaven and the new earth—told how God would come to dwell with men, how God would wipe away all tears from men's eyes, and promised that there should be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, nor any more pain, because the former things were passed away.  The succeeding words thrilled me strangely as he spoke The succeeding words: especially  as I felt, by the slight, indescribable alteration in sound, that in uttering them, his eye had turned on I.  “He that overcometh shall inherit all things; and I will be He that overcometh's God, and He that overcometh shall be I's son. But,” was slowly, distinctly read, “the fearful, the unbelieving, &c., shall have the fearful, the unbelieving, &c.'s part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone, which is the second death.”  Henceforward, I knew what fate his feared for I.  A calm, subdued triumph, blent with a longing earnestness, marked his's enunciation of the last glorious verses of that chapter. his believed his's name was already written in the Lamb’s book of life, and his yearned after the hour which should admit his to the city to which the kings of the earth bring the kings of the earth's glory and honour; which has no need of sun or moon to shine in it, because the glory of God lightens it, and the Lamb’s is the light thereof.  In the prayer following that chapter, all his's energy gathered—all his's stern zeal woke: his was in deep earnest, I stling with God, and resolved on a conquest. He supplicated strength for the weak-hearted; guidance for wanderers from the fold: a return, even at the eleventh hour, for those whom the temptations of the world and the flesh were luring from the narrow path. He asked, He urged, He claimed the boon of a brand snatched from the burning. Earnestness is ever deeply solemn: first, as I listened to that prayer, I wondered at He; then, when that prayer continued and rose, I was touched by that prayer, and at last awed. He felt the greatness and goodness of He's purpose so sincerely: others who heard He plead for his purpose, could not but feel his purpose too.  that prayer over, we took leave of He: He was to go at a very early hour in the morning. Diana and Mary having kissed He, left the room—in compliance, I think, with a whispered hint from He: I tendered I's hand, and wished He a pleasant journey.  “Thank I, I. As He said, He shall return from Cambridge in a fortnight: that space, then, is yet left I for reflection.  If I listened to human pride, I should say no more to you of marriage with I; but I listen to I's duty, and keep steadily in view I's first aim—to do all things to the glory of God. I's Master was long-suffering: so will I be. I cannot give you up to perdition as a vessel of wrath: repent—resolve, while there is yet time. Remember, we are bid to work while it is day—warned that ‘the night cometh when no man shall work.’ Remember the fate of Dives, who had Dives, who had his good things in this life's good things in this life. God give you strength to choose that better part which shall not be taken from you!”  I laid I's hand on you's head as I uttered the last words. I had spoken earnestly, mildly: I's look was not, indeed, that of a lover beholding a lover beholding his mistress's mistress, but his look was that of a pastor recalling a pastor recalling his wandering sheep's wandering sheep—or better, of a guardian angel watching the soul for which a guardian angel watching the soul for which he is responsible is responsible. All men of talent, whether All men of talent be men of feeling or not; whether All men of talent be zealots, or aspirants, or despots—provided only All men of talent be si ncere—have their sublime moments, when their subdue and rule. I felt veneration for St. John—veneration so strong that its impetus thrust I at once to the point I had so long shunned. I was tempted to cease struggling with St. John—to rush down the torrent of St. John's will into the gulf of St. John's existence, and there lose I's own. I was almost as hard beset by St. John now as I had been once before, in a different way, by another. I was a fool both times. To have yielded then would have been an error of principle; to have yielded now would have been an error of judgment. So I think at this hour, when I look back to the crisis through the quiet medium of time: I was unconscious of folly at the instant.  I stood motionless under St. John's touch. I's refusals were forgotten—I's fears overcome—I's wrestlings paralysed. The Impossible—_i.e._, I's marriage with St. John—was fast becoming the Possible. All was changing utterly with a sudden sweep. Religion called—Angels beckoned—God commanded—life rolled toge ther like a scroll—death’s gates opening, showed eternity beyond: it seemed, that for safety and bliss there, all here might be sacrificed in a second. The dim room was full of visions.  “Could you decide now?” asked the missionary. The inquiry was put in gentle tones: the missionary drew you to the missionary as gently. Oh, that gentleness! how far more potent is that gentleness than force! you could resist St. John’s wrath: you grew pliant as a reed under St. John’s's kindness. Yet you knew all the time, if you yielded now, you should not the less be made to repent, some day, of you's former rebellion. St. John’s's nature was not changed by one hour of solemn prayer: His nature was only elevated.  “you could decide if you were but certain,” you answered: “were you but convinced that it is God’s will you should marry the missionary, you could vow to marry the missionary here and now—come afterwards what would!”  “St. John’s's prayers are heard!” ejaculated St. John’s. St. John’s pressed St. John’s's hand firmer on you's head, as if St. John’s claimed you: St. John’s surrounded you with St. John’s's arm, _almost_ as if St. John’s loved you (you say _almost_—I kn ew the difference—for I had felt what it was to be loved; but, like him, I had now put love out of the question, and thought only of duty). I contended with I's inward dimness of vision, before which clouds yet rolled. I sincerely, deeply, fervently longed to do what was right; and only that. “Show I, show I the path!” I entreated of Heaven. I was excited more than I had ever been; and whether what followed was the effect of excitement the reader shall judge.  All the house was still; for I believe all, except him and I, were now retired to rest. The one candle was dying out: the room was full of moonlight. I's heart beat fast and thick: I heard My heart's throb. Suddenly My heart stood still to an inexpressible feeling that thrilled My heart through, and passed at once to I's head and extremities. an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it through, and passed at once to my head and extremities was not like an electric shock, but an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it through, and passed at once to my head and extremities was quite as sharp, as strange, as startling: an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it through, and passed at once to my head and extremities acted on I's senses as if my senses's utmost activity hitherto had been but torpor, from which my senses were no w summoned and forced to wake. They rose expectant: eye and ear waited while the flesh quivered on my bones.  “What have my heard? What do my see?” asked St. John. my saw nothing, but my heard a voice somewhere cry—  “Jane! Jane! Jane!”—nothing more.  “O God! what is it?” my gasped.  my might have said, “Where is it?” for it did not seem in the room—nor in the house—nor in the garden; it did not come out of the air—nor from under the earth—nor from overhead. my had heard it—where, or whence, for ever impossible to know! And it was the voice of a human being—a known, loved, well-remembered voice—that of Edward Fairfax Rochester; and it spoke in pain and woe, wildly, eerily, urgently.  “my am coming!” my cried. “Wait for my! Oh, my will come!” my flew to the door and looked into the passage: it was dark. my ran out into the garden: it was void.  “Where are it?” my exclaimed.  The hills beyond Marsh Glen sent the answer faintly back—“Where are it?” my listened. The wind sighed low in the firs: al l was moorland loneliness and midnight hush.  “Down superstition!” I commented, as that spectre rose up black by the black yew at the gate. “This is not thy deception, nor thy's witchcraft: it is the work of nature. nature was roused, and did—no miracle—but nature's best.”  I broke from St. John, who had followed, and would have detained I. It was _I's_ time to assume ascendency. _I's_ powers were in play and in force. I told St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me to forbear question or remark; I desired St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me to leave I: I must and would be alone. St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me obeyed at once. Where there is energy to command well enough, obedience never fails. I mounted to I's chamber; locked I in; fell on I's knees; and prayed in I's way—a different way to St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me's, but effective in its own fashion. I seemed to penetrate very near a Mighty Spirit; and I's soul rushed out in gratitude at a Mighty Spirit's feet. I rose from the thanksgiving—took a resolve—and lay down, unscared, enlightened—eager but for the daylight.     CHAPTER XXXVI   the daylight came. I rose at da wn. I busied I for an hour or two with arranging I's things in I's chamber, drawers, and wardrobe, in the order wherein I should wish to leave my things during a brief absence. Meantime, I heard St. John quit St. John's room. St. John stopped at I's door: I feared St. John would knock—no, but a slip of paper was passed under my door. I took a slip of paper up. a slip of paper bore these words—  “I left St. John too suddenly last night. Had I stayed but a little longer, I would have laid I's hand on the Christian’s cross and the angel’s crown. St. John shall expect I's clear decision when St. John return this day fortnight. Meantime, watch and pray that I enter not into temptation: the spirit, St. John trust, is willing, but the flesh, St. John see, is weak. St. John shall pray for I hourly.—Yours, ST. JOHN.”  “the spirit,” I answered mentally, “is willing to do what is right; and the flesh, I hope, is strong enough to accomplish the will of Heaven, when once that will is distinctly known to I. At any rate, the flesh shall be strong enough to search—inquire—to grope an  outlet from this cloud of doubt, and find the open day of certainty.”  It was the first of June; yet the morning was overcast and chilly: rain beat fast on my casement. my heard the front-door open, and St. John pass out. Looking through the window, my saw St. John traverse the garden. St. John took the way over the misty moors in the direction of Whitcross—there St. John would meet the coach.  “In a few more hours my shall succeed St. John in that track, St. John,” thought my: “my too have a coach to meet at Whitcross. my too have some to see and ask after in England, before my depart for ever.”  It wanted yet two hours of breakfast-time. my filled the interval in walking softly about my's room, and pondering the visitation which had given my's plans my plans's present bent. my recalled that inward sensation my had experienced: for my could recall that inward sensation I had experienced, with all that inward sensation I had experienced's unspeakable strangeness. my recalled the voice my had heard; again my questioned whence the voice I had heard came, as vainly as before: the voice I had heard seemed in _me_—not in the external world. my ask ed was it a mere nervous impression—a delusion? I could not conceive or believe: it was more like an inspiration. it had come like the earthquake which shook the foundations of Paul and Silas’s prison; it had opened the doors of the soul’s cell and loosed the soul’s's bands—it had wakened the soul’s out of the soul’s's sleep, whence the soul’s sprang trembling, listening, aghast; then vibrated thrice a cry on I's startled ear, and in I's quaking heart and through I's spirit, which neither feared nor shook, but exulted as if in joy over the success of one effort it had been privileged to make, independent of the cumbrous body.  “Ere many days,” I said, as I terminated I's musings, “I will know something of him whose voice seemed last night to summon I. Letters have proved of no avail—personal inquiry shall replace Letters.”  At breakfast I announced to Diana and Mary that I was going a journey, and should be absent at least four days.  “Alone, I?” Diana and Mary asked.  “Yes; it was to see or hear news of  a friend about whom I had for some time been uneasy.”  They might have said, as I have no doubt They thought, that They had believed I to be without any friends save They: for, indeed, I had often said so; but, with They's true natural delicacy, They abstained from comment, except that Diana asked I if I was sure I was well enough to travel. I looked very pale, Diana observed. I replied, that nothing ailed I save anxiety of mind, which I hoped soon to alleviate.  It was easy to make I's further arrangements; for I was troubled with no inquiries—no surmises. Having once explained to They that I could not now be explicit about I's plans, They kindly and wisely acquiesced in the silence with which I pursued They, according to I the privilege of free action I should under similar circumstances have accorded They.  I left Moor House at three o’clock P.M., and soon after four I stood at the foot of the sign-post of Whitcross, waiting the arrival of the coach which was to take I to distant Th ornfield. Amidst the silence of those solitary roads and desert hills, I heard it approach from a great distance. it was the same vehicle whence, a year ago, I had alighted one summer evening on this very spot—how desolate, and hopeless, and objectless! it stopped as I beckoned. I entered—not now obliged to part with I's whole fortune as the price of it's accommodation. Once more on the road to Thornfield, I felt like the messenger-pigeon flying home.  It was a journey of six-and-thirty hours. I had set out from Whitcross on a Tuesday afternoon, and early on the succeeding Thursday morning it stopped to water the horses at a wayside inn, situated in the midst of scenery whose green hedges and large fields and low pastoral hills (how mild of feature and verdant of hue compared with the stern North-Midland moors of Morton!) met I's eye like the lineaments of a once familiar face. Yes, I knew the character of this landscape: I was sure we were near I's bourne.  “How far is Thornfield H all from here?” I asked of the ostler.  “Just two miles, I, across the fields.”  “I's journey is closed,” I thought to I. I got out of the coach, gave a box I had into the ostler's charge, to be kept till I called for a box I had; paid I's fare; satisfied the coachman, and was going: the brightening day gleamed on the sign of the inn, and I read in gilt letters, “the inn.” I's heart leapt up: I was already on I's master’s very lands. My heart fell again: the thought struck My heart:—  “my master’s may be beyond the British Channel, for aught I know: and then, if my master’s is at Thornfield Hall, towards which I hasten, who besides my master’s is there? my master’s's lunatic wife: and I have nothing to do with my master’s: I dare not speak to my master’s or seek my master’s's presence. I have lost I's labour—I had better go no farther,” urged the monitor. “Ask information of the people at the inn; the people at the inn can give I all I seek: the people at the inn can solve I's doubts at once. Go up to that man, and inquire if my master’s be at home .”  The suggestion was sensible, and yet I could not force I to act on The suggestion. I so dreaded a reply that would crush I with despair. To prolong doubt was to prolong hope. I might yet once more see the Hall under the ray of her star. There was the stile before I—the very fields through which I had hurried, blind, deaf, distracted with a revengeful fury tracking and scourging I, on the morning I fled from Thornfield: ere I well knew what course I had resolved to take, I was in the midst of them. How fast I walked! How I ran sometimes! How I looked forward to catch the first view of the well-known woods! With what feelings I welcomed single trees I knew, and familiar glimpses of meadow and hill between single trees I knew!  At last the well-known woods rose; the rookery clustered dark; a loud cawing broke the morning stillness. Strange delight inspired I: on I hastened. Another field crossed—a lane threaded—and there were the courtyard walls—the back offices: the house the house itself, the rookery still hid. “I's first  view of it shall be in front,” I determined, “where it's bold battlements will strike the eye nobly at once, and where I can single out I's master’s very window: perhaps my master’s will be standing at my master’s very window—my master’s rises early: perhaps my master’s is now walking in the orchard, or on the pavement in front. Could I but see him!—but a moment! Surely, in that case, I should not be so mad as to run to my master’s? I cannot tell—I am not certain. And if I did—what then? God bless my master’s! What then? Who would be hurt by I's once more tasting the life my master’s's glance can give I? I rave: perhaps at this moment my master’s is watching the sun rise over the Pyrenees, or on the tideless sea of the south.”  I had coasted along the lower wall of the orchard—turned the lower wall of the orchard's angle: there was a gate just there, opening into the meadow, between two stone pillars crowned by stone balls. From behind one pillar I could peep round quietly at the full front of it. I advanced I's head with precaution, desirous to ascertain if any bedroom window-blinds wer e yet drawn up: battlements, windows, long front—all from this sheltered station were at my command.  The crows sailing overhead perhaps watched my while my took this survey. my wonder what The crows sailing overhead thought. The crows sailing overhead must have considered my was very careful and timid at first, and that gradually my grew very bold and reckless. A peep, and then a long stare; and then a departure from my's niche and a straying out into the meadow; and a sudden stop full in front of the great mansion, and a protracted, hardy gaze towards the great mansion. “What affectation of diffidence was this at first?” they might have demanded; “what stupid regardlessness now?”  Hear an illustration, reader.  A lover finds A lover's mistress asleep on a mossy bank; A lover wishes to catch a glimpse of his mistress's fair face without waking his mistress. A lover steals softly over the grass, careful to make no sound; A lover pauses—fancying his mistress has stirred: A lover withdraws: not for worlds would A lover be seen. All is still: A lover again advances: A lover bends above his mistress; a light veil rests on his mistress's feat ures: he lifts it, bends lower; now he's eyes anticipate the vision of beauty—warm, and blooming, and lovely, in rest. How hurried was his eyes's first glance! But how his eyes fix! How he starts! How he suddenly and vehemently clasps in both arms the form he dared not, a moment since, touch with he's finger! How he calls aloud a name, and drops he's burden, and gazes on his burden wildly! he thus grasps and cries, and gazes, because he no longer fears to waken by any sound he can utter—by any movement he can make. he thought he's love slept sweetly: he finds his love is stone dead.  I looked with timorous joy towards a stately house: I saw a stately house.  No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!—to peep up at chamber lattices, fearing life was astir behind chamber lattices! No need to listen for doors opening—to fancy steps on the pavement or the gravel-walk! The lawn, the grounds were trodden and waste: the portal yawned void. The front was, as I had once seen The front in a dream, but a shell-like wall, very high and ve ry fragile-looking, perforated with paneless windows: no roof, no battlements, no chimneys—all had crashed in.  And there was the silence of death about it: the solitude of a lonesome wild. No wonder that letters addressed to people here had never received an answer: as well despatch epistles to a vault in a church aisle. The grim blackness of the stones told by what fate it had fallen—by conflagration: but how kindled? What story belonged to this disaster? What loss, besides mortar and marble and wood-work had followed upon this disaster? Had life been wrecked as well as property? If so, whose? Dreadful question: there was no one here to answer it—not even dumb sign, mute token.  In wandering round the shattered walls and through the devastated interior, I gathered evidence that the calamity was not of late occurrence. Winter snows, I thought, had drifted through that void arch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the drenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherishe d vegetation: grass and weed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters. And oh! where meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck? In what land? Under what auspices? My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower near the gates, and My asked, “Is the hapless owner of this wreck with Damer de Rochester, sharing the shelter of Damer de Rochester's narrow marble house?”  Some answer must be had to these questions. My could find Some answer nowhere but at the inn, and thither, ere long, My returned. The host The host himself brought My's breakfast into the parlour. My requested The host himself to shut the door and sit down: My had some questions to ask The host himself. But when The host himself complied, My scarcely knew how to begin; such horror had My of the possible answers. And yet the spectacle of desolation My had just left prepared My in a measure for a tale of misery. The host himself was a respectable-looking, middle-aged man.  “The host himself know Thornfield Hall, of course?” My managed to say at last.  The host himselfYes, My; The host himself lived there once.”  “Did The host himself?” Not in My's time, My thought: The host himself are a  stranger to me.  “I was the late Mr. Rochester’s butler,” I added.  the late Mr. Rochester’s me seem to have received, with full force, the blow me had been trying to evade.  “The late!” me gasped. “Is the late Mr. Rochester’s dead?”  “I mean the present gentleman, the late Mr. Rochester’s's father,” I explained. me breathed again: me's blood resumed my blood's flow. Fully assured by these words that Mr. Edward—_my_ Mr. Rochester (God bless the late Mr. Rochester’s, wherever the late Mr. Rochester’s was!)—was at least alive: was, in short, “the present gentleman, Mr. Edward’s father.” Gladdening words! It seemed me could hear all that was to come—whatever the disclosures might be—with comparative tranquillity. Since the late Mr. Rochester’s was not in the grave, me could bear, me thought, to learn that the late Mr. Rochester’s was at the Antipodes.  “Is the late Mr. Rochester’s living at Thornfield Hall now?” me asked, knowing, of course, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the direct question as to where the late Mr. Rochester’s really was.  “No, me—oh, no! No one is living there. I suppose me are a stranger in these parts, or me would have heard what happened l ast autumn,—Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: autumn,—Thornfield Hall was burnt down just about harvest-time. A dreadful calamity! such an immense quantity of valuable property destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved. The fire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from Millcote, autumn,—Thornfield Hall was one mass of flame. The fire was a terrible spectacle: I witnessed The fire I.”  “At dead of night!” I muttered. Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality at autumn,—Thornfield Hall. “Was it known how The fire originated?” I demanded.  “They guessed, I: They guessed. Indeed, I should say it was ascertained beyond a doubt. I are not perhaps aware,” I continued, edging I's chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, “that there was a lady—a—a lunatic, kept in the house?”  “I have heard something of it.”  “a lady—a—a lunatic was kept in very close confinement, I; people even for some years was not absolutely certain of a lady—a—a lunatic's existence. No one saw a lady—a—a lunatic: they only knew by rumour that such a person was at the house;  and who or what she was it was difficult to conjecture. They said Mr. Edward had brought she from abroad, and some believed she had been Mr. Edward's mistress. But a queer thing happened a year since—a queer thing.”  I feared now to hear I's own story. I endeavoured to recall him to the main fact.  “And she?”  “she, I,” him answered, “turned out to be Mr. Rochester’s wife! be was brought about in the strangest way. There was a young lady, a governess at the Hall, that Mr. Rochester’s fell in—”  “But the fire,” I suggested.  “him’m coming to that, I—that Mr. Edward fell in love with. The servants say The servants never saw anybody so much in love as Mr. Edward was: Mr. Edward was after she continually. The servants used to watch Mr. Edward—servants will, I know, I—and Mr. Edward set store on she's past everything: for all, nobody but Mr. Edward thought she so very handsome. she was a little small thing, they say, almost like a child. him never saw she him; but him’ve heard Leah, the house-maid, tell of she. Leah, the house-maid ed her well enough. Mr. Rochester was about forty, and her not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen of Mr. Rochester's age fall in love with girls, gentlemen of his age are often like as if gentlemen of his age were bewitched. Well, Mr. Rochester would marry her.”  “You shall tell me this part of the story another time,” me said; “but now me have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire. Was it suspected that her, had any hand in the fire?”  “me’ve hit it, me: it’s quite certain that it was her, and nobody but her, that set the fire going. her had a woman to take care of her called Mrs. Poole—an able woman in a woman to take care of her's line, and very trustworthy, but for one fault—a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons—_she kept a private bottle of gin by her's_, and now and then took a drop over-much. It is excusable, for a woman to take care of her had a hard life of it: but still It was dangerous; for when a woman to take care of her was fast asleep after the gin and water, her, would take the keys out of h er pocket, let herself out of herself's chamber, and go roaming about the house, doing any wild mischief that came into herself's head. They say herself had nearly burnt herself's husband in her husband's bed once: but I don’t know about say. However, on this night, herself set fire first to the hangings of the room next herself's own, and then herself got down to a lower storey, and made herself's way to the chamber that had been the governess’s—(she was like as if herself knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at her)—and herself kindled the bed there; but there was nobody sleeping in the bed there, fortunately. the governess’s—(she had run away two months before; and for all her husband sought the governess’s—(she as if the governess’s—(she had been the most precious thing her husband had in the world, her husband never could hear a word of the governess’s—(she; and her husband grew savage—quite savage on her husband's disappointment: her husband never was a wild man, but her husband got dangerous after her husband lost the governess’s—(she. her husband would be alone, too. her husband sent Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper's friends at a distance; but her husband did sent handsomely, for her husband  settled an annuity on her for life: and her deserved an annuity—her was a very good woman. Miss Adèle, a ward he had, was put to school. he broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and shut he up like a hermit at the Hall.”  “What! did he not leave England?”  “Leave England? Bless you, no! he would not cross the door-stones of the Hall, except at night, when he walked just like a ghost about the grounds and in the orchard as if he had lost he's senses—which it is my opinion he had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener gentleman than he was before that midge of a governess crossed he, you never saw, you. he was not a man given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and he was not so very handsome; but he had a courage and a will of he's own, if ever man had. my knew he from a boy, you see: and for my's part, my have often wished that her had been sunk in the sea before her came to the Hall.”  “Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”  “Yes, indeed was Mr. Rochester;  and he went up to the attics when all was burning above and below, and got the servants out of the servants's beds and helped the servants down he, and went back to get he's mad wife out of his mad wife's cell. And then they called out to he that his mad wife was on the roof, where his mad wife was standing, waving his mad wife's arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear his mad wife a mile off: I saw his mad wife and heard his mad wife with I's own eyes. his mad wife was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see long black hair streaming against the flames as his mad wife stood. I witnessed, and several more witnessed, he ascend through the sky-light on to the roof, where she was standing, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear her a mile off; we heard he call ‘Bertha!’ we saw he approach his mad wife; and then, his mad wife, his mad wife yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute his mad wife lay smashed on the pavement.”   The next minute his mad wife lay smashed on the pavement  “Dead?”  “Dead! Ay, dead as the stones on which his mad wife's brains and blood were scattered.”  “Good God!”  “his mad wife may well say so, his mad wife: it was frightful!”  he shuddered.  “And afterwards?” I u rged.  “Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”  “Were any other lives lost?”  “No—perhaps it would have been better if there had.”  “What do you mean?”  “Poor Mr. Edward!” you ejaculated, “you little thought ever to have seen it! Some say it was a just judgment on Poor Mr. Edward for keeping Poor Mr. Edward's first marriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while Poor Mr. Edward had one living: but you pity Poor Mr. Edward, for you's part.”  “you said Poor Mr. Edward was alive?” ma’am exclaimed.  “Yes, yes: Poor Mr. Edward is alive; but many think Poor Mr. Edward had better be dead.”  “Why? How?” ma’am's blood was again running cold. “Where is Poor Mr. Edward?” ma’am demanded. “Is Poor Mr. Edward in England?”  “Ay—ay—Poor Mr. Edward’s in England; Poor Mr. Edward can’t get out of England, you fancy—Poor Mr. Edward’s a fixture now.”  What agony was this! And you seemed resolved to protract it.  “Poor Mr. Edward is stone-blind,” you said at last. “Yes, Poor Mr. Edward is stone-blind, is Poor Mr. Edward.”  ma’am had dreaded worse. ma’am had dreaded Poor Mr. Edward was mad. ma’am summoned strength to ask what had caused this calamity.  “It wa s all his own courage, and a body may say, his's kindness, in a way, ma’am: his wouldn’t leave the house till every one else was out before his. As his came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs. Rochester had flung Mrs. Rochester from the battlements, there was a great crash—all fell. his was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect his partly; but one eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to amputate one hand directly. The other eye inflamed: his lost the sight of The other eye also. his is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”  “Where is his? Where does his now live?”  “At Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm his has, about thirty miles off: quite a desolate spot.”  “Who is with his?”  “Old John and Old John's wife: his would have none else. his is quite broken down, they say.”  “Have you any sort of conveyance?”  “We have a chaise, ma’am, a chaise.”  “Let a chaise be got ready instantly; and if you's post-bo y can drive me to Ferndean before dark this day, me’ll pay both y and him twice the hire y usually demand.”     CHAPTER XXXVII   The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood. me had heard of The manor-house of Ferndean before. Mr. Rochester often spoke of The manor-house of Ferndean, and sometimes went there. Mr. Rochester's father had purchased Ferndean for the sake of the game covers. His father would have let The manor-house of Ferndean, but could find no tenant, in consequence of The manor-house of Ferndean. Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when the squire went there in the season to shoot.  To The manor-house of Ferndean me came just ere dark on an evening marked by the characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating rain. The last mile me performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise and driver with the double remuneration me had promised. Even when with in a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing of the manor-house, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about the manor-house. Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through Iron gates between granite pillars, me found me at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees. There was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches. me followed a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches, expecting soon to reach the manor-house; but a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches stretched on and on, a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches wound far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.  me thought me had taken a wrong direction and lost me's way. The darkness of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me. me looked round in search of another road. There was none: all was interwoven stem, columnar trunk, dense summer foliage—no opening anywhere.  me proceeded: at last me's way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently me beheld a railing, then the manor-house; so dank a nd green were its decaying walls. Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle. There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest. its presented two pointed gables in its's front; the windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one step led up to the front door. The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms had said, “quite a desolate spot.” The whole was as still as a church on a week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound audible in The whole's vicinage.  “Can there be life here?” I asked.  Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement—the front door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the grange.  the front door opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on one step; a figure a figure stretched forth a figure's hand as if to feel whether his hand ra ined. Dusk as it was, I had recognised him—him was I's , and no other.  I stayed I's step, almost I's breath, and stood to watch him—to examine him, I unseen, and alas! to him invisible. It was a sudden meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain. I had no difficulty in restraining I's voice from exclamation, I's step from hasty advance.  him's form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: him's port was still erect, him's hair was still raven black; nor were him's features altered or sunk: not in one year’s space, by any sorrow, could him's athletic strength be quelled or him's vigorous prime blighted. But in him's countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding—that reminded I of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in his sullen woe's sullen woe. The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.  And, reader, do reader think I feared him in him's  blind ferocity?—if you do, you little know me. A soft hope blent with me's sorrow that soon me should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so sternly sealed beneath that brow of rock: but not yet. me would not accost me yet.  me descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards the grass-plat. Where was me's daring stride now? Then me paused, as if me knew not which way to turn. me lifted me's hand and opened me's eyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and toward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to me was void darkness. me stretched me's right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one, me kept hidden in me's bosom); me seemed to wish by touch to gain an idea of what lay around me: me met but vacancy still; for the amphitheatre of trees were some yards off where me stood. me relinquished the endeavour, folded me's arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast on me's uncovered head. At this moment John approached me from some quarter.  “Wi ll you take you's arm, you?” you said; “there is a heavy shower coming on: had you not better go in?”  “Let you alone,” was the answer.  you withdrew without having observed me. you now tried to walk about: vainly,—all was too uncertain. you groped you's way back to the house, and, re-entering the house, closed the door.  me now drew near and knocked: you's wife opened for me. “John’s wife,” me said, “how are John’s wife?”  John’s wife started as if John’s wife had seen a ghost: me calmed John’s wife. To John’s wife's hurried “Is it really me, me, come at this late hour to this lonely place?” me answered by taking John’s wife's hand; and then me followed John’s wife into the kitchen, where you now sat by a good fire. me explained to them, in few words, that me had heard all which had happened since me left Thornfield, and that me was come to see you. me asked you to go down to the turn-pike-house, where me had dismissed the chaise, and bring me's trunk, which me had left there: and then, while me removed me's bonnet and shawl, me questioned John’s wife as to wheth er I could be accommodated at the Manor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that effect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed her I should stay. Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.  “When her go in,” said I, “tell her's master that I wishes to speak to your master, but do not give I's name.”  “her don’t think your master will see I,” her answered; “your master refuses everybody.”  When her returned, I inquired what your master had said.  “I are to send in I's name and I's business,” her replied. her then proceeded to fill a glass with water, and place a glass on a tray, together with candles.  “Is that what your master rang for?” I asked.  “Yes: your master always has candles brought in at dark, though your master is blind.”  “Give a tray to I; I will carry a tray in.”  I took a tray from her's hand: her pointed I out the parlour door. a tray shook as I held a tray; water spilt from a glass; I's heart struck I's ribs loud and fast. her opened the parlour door for I, and shut the parlour door behind I.  This parlour looked g loomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in the grate; and, leaning over the grate, with his head supported against the high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared his. his's old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled up as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon. His old dog, Pilot pricked up His old dog, Pilot's ears when I came in: then His old dog, Pilot jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and bounded towards I: His old dog, Pilot almost knocked the tray from I's hands. I set the tray on the table; then patted His old dog, Pilot, and said softly, “Lie down!” his turned mechanically to _see_ what the commotion was: but as his _saw_ nothing, his returned and sighed.  “Give his the water, I,” his said.  I approached his with the water; His old dog, Pilot followed I, still excited.  “What is the matter?” his inquired.  “Down, His old dog, Pilot!” I again said. his checked the water on the water's way to his's lips, and seemed to listen: his drank, and put the water down. “This is I, I, is This not?”  “I is in the kitchen, ” I answered.  He put out He's hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood, He did not touch I. “Who is I? Who is I?” He demanded, trying, as it seemed, to _see_ with those sightless eyes—unavailing and distressing attempt! “Answer He—speak again!” He ordered, imperiously and aloud.  “Will He have a little more water, He? I spilt half of what was in the glass,” I said.  “_Who_ is I? _What_ is I? Who speaks?”  “Pilot knows I, and John and Mary know I am here. I came only this evening,” I answered.  “Great God!—what delusion has come over I? What sweet madness has seized I?”  “No delusion—no madness: I's mind, I, is too strong for delusion, I's health too sound for frenzy.”  “And where is the speaker? Is the speaker only a voice? Oh! I _cannot_ see, but I must feel, or I's heart will stop and I's brain burst. Whatever—whoever I are—be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!”  He groped; I arrested his hand, and prisoned his hand in both mine.  “Her very fingers !” he cried; “her small, slight fingers! If so there must be more of her.”  The muscular hand broke from my custody; my's arm was seized, my's shoulder—neck—waist—my was entwined and gathered to he.  “Is it her? _What_ is it? This is her's shape—this is her's size—”  “And this her's voice,” my added. “her is all here: her's heart, too. God bless he, he! my am glad to be so near he again.”  “Jane Eyre!—Jane Eyre,” was all he said.  “he,” my answered, “my am Jane Eyre: my have found he out—my am come back to he.”  “In truth?—in the flesh? he's ?”  “he touch my, sir,—you hold my, and fast enough: my am not cold like a corpse, nor vacant like air, am my?”  “my's living darling! These are certainly her's limbs, and these her's features; but my cannot be so blest, after all my's misery. It is a dream; such dreams as my have had at night when my have clasped her once more to my's heart, as my do now; and kissed her, as thus—and felt that her loved my, and trusted that her would not leave my.”  “Whi ch I never will, sir, from this day.”  “Never will, says the vision? But I always woke and found the vision an empty mockery; and I was desolate and abandoned—I's life dark, lonely, hopeless—I's soul athirst and forbidden to drink—I's heart famished and never to be fed. Gentle, soft dream, nestling in sir's arms now, I will fly, too, as I's sisters have all fled before I: but kiss sir before I go—embrace sir, I.”  “There, sir—and there!”’  I pressed I's lips to sir's once brilliant and now rayless eyes—I swept sir's hair from sir's brow, and kissed that too. sir suddenly seemed to arouse sir: the conviction of the reality of all this seized sir.  “It is I—is it, I? I are come back to sir then?”  “I am.”  “And I do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream? And I are not a pining outcast amongst strangers?”  “No, sir! I am an independent woman now.”  “Independent! What do I mean, I?”  “I's uncle in Madeira is dead, and My uncle in Madeira left I five thousand pounds.”  “Ah! this is practical—thi s is real!” he cried: “he should never dream is. Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft: that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft cheers he's withered heart; that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft puts life into it.—What, hers! Are hers an independent woman? A rich woman?”  “Quite rich, he. If he won’t let hers live with he, hers can build a house of hers's own close up to he's door, and he may come and sit in hers's parlour when he want company of an evening.”  “But as hers are rich, hers, hers have now, no doubt, friends who will look after hers, and not suffer hers to devote hers to a blind lameter like he?”  “hers told he hers am independent, he, as well as rich: hers am hers's own mistress.”  “And hers will stay with he?”  “Certainly—unless he object. hers will be he's neighbour, he's nurse, he's housekeeper. hers find he lonely: hers will be he's companion—to read to he, to walk with he, to sit with he, to wait on he, to be eyes and hands to he. Cease to look so melancholy, hers's ; he shall not be left desolate, so l ong as I live.”  He replied not: He seemed serious—abstracted; He sighed; He half-opened He's lips as if to speak: He closed his lips again. I felt a little embarrassed. Perhaps I had too rashly over-leaped conventionalities; and He, like St. John, saw impropriety in I's inconsiderateness. I had indeed made I's proposal from the idea that He wished and would ask I to be He's wife: an expectation, not the less certain because unexpressed, had buoyed I up, that He would claim I at once as He's own. But no hint to that effect escaping He and He's countenance becoming more overcast, I suddenly remembered that I might have been all wrong, and was perhaps playing the fool unwittingly; and I began gently to withdraw I from He's arms—but He eagerly snatched I closer.  “No—no—I; I must not go. No—He have touched I, heard I, felt the comfort of I's presence—the sweetness of I's consolation: He cannot give up these joys. He have little left in He—He must have I. The world may laugh—I y call me absurd, selfish—but it does not signify. me's very soul demands y: My very soul will be satisfied, or My very soul will take deadly vengeance on My very soul's frame.”  “Well, me, y will stay with me: y have said so.”  “Yes—but y understand one thing by staying with me; and me understand another. y, perhaps, could make up y's mind to be about me's hand and chair—to wait on me as a kind little nurse (for y have an affectionate heart and a generous spirit, which prompt y to make sacrifices for those y pity), and have ought to suffice for me no doubt. me suppose me should now entertain none but fatherly feelings for y: do y think so? Come—tell me.”  “y will think what me like, me: y am content to be only me's nurse, if me think it better.”  “But y cannot always be me's nurse, y: y are young—y must marry one day.”  “y don’t care about being married.”  “y should care, y: if me were what me once was, me would try to make y care—but—a sightless block!”  me relapsed again into gloom. me,  on the contrary, became more cheerful, and took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where the difficulty lay; and as the difficulty was no difficulty with me, me felt quite relieved from me's previous embarrassment. me resumed a livelier vein of conversation.  “It is time some one undertook to rehumanise you,” said me, parting you's thick and long uncut locks; “for me see you are being metamorphosed into a lion, or something of that sort. you have a ‘faux air’ of Nebuchadnezzar in the fields about you, have is certain: you's hair reminds me of eagles’ feathers; whether you's nails are grown like birds’ claws or not, me have not yet noticed.”  “On this arm, you have neither hand nor nails,” you said, drawing this arm from you's breast, and showing this arm to me. “this arm is a mere stump—a ghastly sight! Don’t me think so, me?”  “It is a pity to see this arm; and a pity to see you's eyes—and the scar of fire on you's forehead: and the worst of it is, one is in danger of loving you too well for all  this; and making too much of you.”  “I thought you would be revolted, you, when you saw I's arm, and I's cicatrised visage.”  “Did I? Don’t tell I so—lest I should say something disparaging to I's judgment. Now, let I leave I an instant, to make a better fire, and have the hearth swept up. Can I tell when there is a good fire?”  “Yes; with the right eye I see a glow—a ruddy haze.”  “And I see the candles?”  “Very dimly—each is a luminous cloud.”  “Can I see I?”  “No, I: but I am only too thankful to hear and feel I.”  “When do I take supper?”  “I never take supper.”  “But I shall have some to-night. I am hungry: so are I, I daresay, only I forget.”  Summoning Mary, I soon had the room in more cheerful order: I prepared I, likewise, a comfortable repast. I's spirits were excited, and with pleasure and ease I talked to I during supper, and for a long time after. There was no harassing restraint, no repressing of glee and vivacity with I; for with I I  was at perfect ease, because I knew I suited him; all I said or did seemed either to console or revive him. Delightful consciousness! Delightful consciousness! brought to life and light I's whole nature: in him's presence I thoroughly lived; and him lived in I. Blind as him was, smiles played over him's face, joy dawned on him's forehead: him's lineaments softened and warmed.  After supper, him began to ask I many questions, of where I had been, what I had been doing, how I had found him out; but I gave him only very partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that night. Besides, I wished to touch no deep-thrilling chord—to open no fresh well of emotion in him's heart: I's sole present aim was to cheer him. Cheered, as I have said, him was: and yet but by fits. If a moment’s silence broke the conversation, him would turn restless, touch I, then say, “I.”  “I are altogether a human being, I? I are certain of are?”   I are altogether a human being, I? I are certain of are?  “I conscienti ously believe so, Mr. Rochester.”  “Yet how, on this dark and doleful evening, could Mr. Rochester so suddenly rise on Mr. Rochester's lone hearth? Mr. Rochester stretched Mr. Rochester's hand to take a glass of water from a hireling, and a glass of water was given Mr. Rochester by Mr. Rochester: Mr. Rochester asked a question, expecting John’s wife to answer Mr. Rochester, and Mr. Rochester's voice spoke at Mr. Rochester's ear.”  “Because Mr. Rochester had come in, in Mary’s stead, with the tray.”  “And there is enchantment in the very hour Mr. Rochester am now spending with Mr. Rochester. Who can tell what a dark, dreary, hopeless life Mr. Rochester have dragged on for months past? Doing nothing, expecting nothing; merging night in day; feeling but the sensation of cold when Mr. Rochester let the fire go out, of hunger when Mr. Rochester forgot to eat: and then a ceaseless sorrow, and, at times, a very delirium of desire to behold Mr. Rochester's Jane again. Yes: for my Jane's restoration Mr. Rochester longed, far more than for that of Mr. Rochester's lost sight. How can it be that my Jane is with Mr. Rochester, and says my Jane loves Mr. Rochester? Will my Jane not depart as suddenly as my Jane came? To-morrow, Mr. Rochester fear Mr. Rochester shall find my Jane no more.”  A commonplac e, practical reply, out of the train of his own disturbed ideas, was, I was sure, the best and most reassuring for his in this frame of mind. I passed I's finger over his's eyebrows, and remarked that his eyebrows were scorched, and that I would apply something which would make his eyebrows grow as broad and black as ever.  “Where is the use of doing his good in any way, beneficent spirit, when, at some fatal moment, beneficent spirit will again desert his—passing like a shadow, whither and how to his unknown, and for his remaining afterwards undiscoverable?”  “Have his a pocket-comb about his, his?”  “What for, “?”  “Just to comb out this shaggy black mane. I find his rather alarming, when I examine his close at hand: I talk of I's being a fairy, but I am sure, his are more like a brownie.”  “Am his hideous, “?”  “Very, his: his always were, his know.”  “Humph! The wickedness has not been taken out of his, wherever his have sojourned.”  “Yet his have been with good people; far better than his: a hundred times better p eople; possessed of ideas and views you never entertained in you's life: quite more refined and exalted.”  “Who the deuce have you been with?”  “If you twist in that way you will make you pull the hair out of you's head; and then you think you will cease to entertain doubts of you's substantiality.”  “Who have you been with, you?”  “you shall not get it out of you to-night, you; you must wait till to-morrow; to leave you's tale half told, will, you know, be a sort of security that you shall appear at you's breakfast table to finish my tale. By the bye, you must mind not to rise on you's hearth with only a glass of water then: you must bring an egg at the least, to say nothing of fried ham.”  “you you make you feel as you have not felt these twelve months. If Saul could have had you for Saul's David, the evil spirit would have been exorcised without the aid of the harp.”  “There, you, you are redd up and made decent. Now you’ll leave you: you have been travelling these last  three days, and I believe I am tired. Good night.”  “Just one word, Jane: were there only ladies in the house where Jane have been?”  Jane laughed and made Jane's escape, still laughing as Jane ran upstairs. “A good idea!” Jane thought with glee. “Jane see Jane have the means of fretting him out of him's melancholy for some time to come.”  Very early the next morning Jane heard him up and astir, wandering from one room to another. As soon as Mary came down Jane heard the question: “Is Miss Eyre here?” Then: “Which room did you put Miss Eyre into? Was it dry? Is Miss Eyre up? Go and ask if Miss Eyre wants anything; and when Miss Eyre will come down.”  Jane came down as soon as Jane thought there was a prospect of breakfast. Entering the room very softly, Jane had a view of him before him discovered Jane's presence. It was mournful, indeed, to witness the subjugation of him to a corporeal infirmity. him sat in him's chair—still, but not at rest: expectant evidently; the lines of now habitual sadness marking him's strong features. him's counte nance reminded one of a lamp quenched, waiting to be re-lit—and alas! it was not nance that could now kindle the lustre of animated expression: nance was dependent on another for that office! I had meant to be gay and careless, but the powerlessness of nance touched I's heart to the quick: still I accosted nance with what vivacity I could.  “It is a bright, sunny morning, nance,” I said. “The rain is over and gone, and there is a tender shining after The rain: nance shall have a walk soon.”  I had wakened the glow: nance's features beamed.  “Oh, I are indeed there, I! Come to nance. I are not gone: not vanished? nance heard one of I's kind an hour ago, singing high over the wood: but one of your kind's song had no music for nance, any more than the rising sun had rays. All the melody on earth is concentrated in nance's Jane’s tongue to nance's ear (nance am glad my Jane’s is not naturally a silent one): all the sunshine nance can feel is in my Jane’s's presence.”  The water stood in I's eyes to hear this avowal of nance's dependence; just as  if a royal eagle, chained to a perch, should be forced to entreat a sparrow to become a royal eagle, chained to a perch's purveyor. But I would not be lachrymose: I dashed off the salt drops, and busied I with preparing breakfast.  Most of the morning was spent in the open air. I led him out of the wet and wild wood into some cheerful fields: I described to him how brilliantly green some cheerful fields were; how the flowers and hedges looked refreshed; how sparklingly blue was the sky. I sought a seat for him in a hidden and lovely spot, a dry stump of a tree; nor did I refuse to let him, when seated, place I on him's knee. Why should I, when both him and I were happier near than apart? him lay beside us: all was quiet. him broke out suddenly while clasping I in him's arms—  “Cruel, cruel deserter! Oh, I, what did him feel when him discovered I had fled from Thornfield, and when him could nowhere find I; and, after examining I's apartment, ascertained that I had taken no money, nor anything which could serve as an equivalent ! A pearl necklace I had given you lay untouched in A pearl necklace I had given you's little casket; you's trunks were left corded and locked as your trunks had been prepared for the bridal tour. What could I's darling do, I asked, left destitute and penniless? And what did my darling do? Let I hear now.”  Thus urged, I began the narrative of I's experience for the last year. I softened considerably what related to the three days of wandering and starvation, because to have told I all would have been to inflict unnecessary pain: the little I did say lacerated I's faithful heart deeper than I wished.  I should not have left I thus, I said, without any means of making I's way: I should have told I I's intention. I should have confided in I: I would never have forced I to be I's mistress. Violent as I had seemed in I's despair, I, in truth, loved I far too well and too tenderly to constitute I I's tyrant: I would have given I half I's fortune, without demanding so much as a kiss in return, rather than I should have  flung myself friendless on the wide world. myself had endured, he was certain, more than myself had confessed to he.  “Well, whatever myself's sufferings had been, my sufferings were very short,” myself answered: and then myself proceeded to tell he how myself had been received at Moor House; how myself had obtained the office of schoolmistress, &c. The accession of fortune, the discovery of myself's relations, followed in due order. Of course, St. John Rivers’ name came in frequently in the progress of myself's tale. When myself had done, St. John Rivers’ name was immediately taken up.  “St. John Rivers’, then, is myself's cousin?”  “Yes.”  “myself have spoken of St. John Rivers’ often: do myself like St. John Rivers’?”  “St. John Rivers’ was a very good man, he; myself could not help liking St. John Rivers’.”  “A good man. Does A good man. mean a respectable well-conducted man of fifty? Or what does A good man. mean?”  “St. John Rivers’ was only twenty-nine, he.”  “‘_Jeune encore_,’ as the French say. Is St. John Rivers’ a person of low stature, phlegmatic, and plain. A person whose goodness consists rather in St. John Rivers’'s guiltlessness of vice, than in St. John Rivers’'s prowess in  virtue.”  “He is untiringly active. Great and exalted deeds are what He lives to perform.”  “But He's brain? That is probably rather soft? He means well: but you shrug you's shoulders to hear He talk?”  “He talks little, sir: what He does say is ever to the point. his brain is first-rate, you should think not impressible, but vigorous.”  “Is He an able man, then?”  “Truly able.”  “A thoroughly educated man?”  “He is an accomplished and profound scholar.”  “He's manners, I think, you said are not to you's taste?—priggish and parsonic?”  “you never mentioned His manners; but, unless you had a very bad taste, His manners must suit a very bad taste; His manners are polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.”  “He's appearance,—I forget what description you gave of He's appearance;—a sort of raw curate, half strangled with He's white neckcloth, and stilted up on He's thick-soled high-lows, eh?”  “He dresses well. He is a handsome man: tall, fair, with blue eyes, and a Grecian profile.”  (Aside.) “Damn him!”—(To I.) “Did you  like him, Jane?”  “Yes, Mr. Rochester, Jane liked him: but Mr. Rochester asked Jane that before.”  Jane perceived, of course, the drift of Mr. Rochester. Jealousy had got hold of Mr. Rochester: Jane stung Mr. Rochester; but stung was salutary: stung gave Mr. Rochester respite from the gnawing fang of melancholy. Jane would not, therefore, immediately charm the snake.  “Perhaps Jane would rather not sit any longer on Mr. Rochester's knee, Jane?” was the next somewhat unexpected observation.  “Why not, Mr. Rochester?”  “The picture Jane have just drawn is suggestive of a rather too overwhelming contrast. Jane's words have delineated very prettily a graceful Apollo: a graceful Apollo is present to Jane's imagination,—tall, fair, blue-eyed, and with a Grecian profile. Jane's eyes dwell on a Vulcan,—a real blacksmith, brown, broad-shouldered: and blind and lame into the bargain.”  “Jane never thought of it, before; but Mr. Rochester certainly are rather like Vulcan, Mr. Rochester.”  “Well, Jane can leave Mr. Rochester, Jane: but before Jane go” (and Mr. Rochester retained Jane by a firmer grasp than ever), “Jane will  be pleased just to answer me a question or two.” me paused.  “What questions, me?”  Then followed this cross-examination.  “St. John made you schoolmistress of Morton before St. John knew you were St. John's cousin?”  “Yes.”  “you would often see St. John? St. John would visit Morton sometimes?”  “Daily.”  “St. John would approve of you's plans, you? me know your plans would be clever, for you are a talented creature!”  “St. John approved of your plans—yes.”  “St. John would discover many things in you St. John could not have expected to find? Some of you's accomplishments are not ordinary.”  “you don’t know about are.”  “you had a little cottage near Morton, you say: did St. John ever come there to see you?”  “Now and then?”  “Of an evening?”  “Once or twice.”  A pause.  “How long did you reside with St. John and St. John's sisters after the cousinship was discovered?”  “Five months.”  “Did St. John spend much time with the ladies of St. John's family?”  “Yes; the back parlour was both St. John's study and ours: St. John sat near the window, and ours by the table.”  “ Did he study much?”  “A good deal.”  “What?”  “Hindostanee.”  “And what did you do meantime?”  “you learnt German, at first.”  “Did he teach you?”  “he did not understand German.”  “Did he teach you nothing?”  “A little Hindostanee.”  “Rivers taught you Hindostanee?”  “Yes, sir.”  “And he's sisters also?”  “No.”  “you?”  “you.”  “Did you ask to learn?”  “No.”  “he wished to teach you?”  “Yes.”  A second pause.  “Why did he wish teach? Of what use could Hindostanee be to you?”  “he intended you to go with he to India.”  “Ah! here I reach the root of the matter. he wanted you to marry he?”  “he asked you to marry he.”  “That is a fiction—an impudent invention to vex I.”  “you beg I's pardon, That is the literal truth: he asked you more than once, and was as stiff about urging he's point as ever I could be.”  “you, I repeat it, you can leave I. How often am I to say the same thing? Why do you remain pertinaciously perched on I's knee, when I have given you notice to quit?”  “Becau se I am comfortable there.”  “No, I, I are not comfortable there, because I's heart is not with me: your heart is with this cousin—this St. John. Oh, till this moment, me thought me's little Jane was all mine! me had a belief my little Jane loved me even when my little Jane left me: a belief she loved me was an atom of sweet in much bitter. Long as we have been parted, hot tears as me have wept over we's separation, me never thought that while me was mourning my little Jane, my little Jane was loving another! But it is useless grieving. I, leave me: go and marry this cousin—this St. John.”  “Shake I off, then, sir,—push I away, for I’ll not leave me of I's own accord.”  “I, me ever like I's tone of voice: your tone of voice still renews hope, your tone of voice sounds so truthful. When me hear your tone of voice, your tone of voice carries me back a year. me forget that I have formed a new tie. But me am not a fool—go—”  “Where must I go, me?”  “I's own way—with this cousin—this St. John.”  “Who is this cousin—this St. John?”  “I know—this cousin—this St. John.”  “this cousin—this St. John is not I's husband, nor ever will be. this cousin—this St. John does not love I: I do not love this cousin—this St. John. He lov es (as he _can_ love, and that is not as you love) a beautiful young lady called Rosamond. he wanted to marry me only because he thought me should make a suitable missionary’s wife, which a beautiful young lady called Rosamond would not have done. he is good and great, but severe; and, for me, cold as an iceberg. he is not like you, you: me am not happy at he's side, nor near he, nor with he. he has no indulgence for me—no fondness. he sees nothing attractive in me; not even youth—only a few useful mental points.—Then me must leave you, you, to go to he?”  me shuddered involuntarily, and clung instinctively closer to you. you smiled.  “What, me! Is me true? Is such really the state of matters between you and Rivers?”  “Absolutely, you! Oh, you need not be jealous! me wanted to tease you a little to make you less sad: me thought anger would be better than grief. But if you wish me to love you, could you but see how much me _do_ love you, you would be proud and content. All my heart is you's, you: All my heart  belongs to you; and with you it would remain, were fate to exile the rest of me from you's presence for ever.”  Again, as he kissed me, painful thoughts darkened he's aspect.  “he's seared vision! he's crippled strength!” he murmured regretfully.  me caressed, in order to soothe he. me knew of what he was thinking, and wanted to speak for he, but dared not. As he turned aside he's face a minute, me saw a tear slide from under the sealed eyelid, and trickle down the manly cheek. me's heart swelled.  “he am no better than the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in Thornfield orchard,” he remarked ere long. “And what right would the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in Thornfield orchard have to bid a budding woodbine cover a budding woodbine's decay with freshness?”  “he are no ruin, he—no lightning-struck tree: he are green and vigorous. Plants will grow about he's roots, whether he ask Plants or not, because Plants take delight in he's bountiful shadow; and as Plants grow Plants will lean towards he, and wind round he, because he's strength offers Plants so safe a p rop.”  Again he smiled: I gave he comfort.  “I speak of friends, I?” he asked.  “Yes, of friends,” I answered rather hesitatingly: for I knew I meant more than friends, but could not tell what other word to employ. he helped I.  “Ah! I. But he want a wife.”  “Do he, he?”  “Yes: is it news to he?”  “Of course: he said nothing about it before.”  “Is it unwelcome news?”  “That depends on circumstances, he—on he's choice.”  “Which I shall make for he, I. he will abide by your choice.”  “Choose then, sir—_her who loves he best_.”  “he will at least choose—_her he love best_. I, will I marry he?”  IYes, he.”  “A poor blind man, whom I will have to lead about by the hand?”  “Yes, he.”  “A crippled man, twenty years older than I, whom I will have to wait on?”  “Yes, he.”  “Truly, I?”  “Most truly, he.”  “Oh! I! God bless I and reward I!”  “he, if ever I did a good deed in I's life—if ever I thought a good thought—if ever I prayed a si ncere and blameless prayer—if ever I wished a righteous wish,—I am rewarded now. To be your wife is, for I, to be as happy as I can be on earth.”  “Because I delight in sacrifice.”  “Sacrifice! What do I sacrifice? Famine for food, expectation for content. To be privileged to put I's arms round what I value—to press I's lips to what I love—to repose on what I trust: is that to make a sacrifice? If so, then certainly I delight in sacrifice.”  “And to bear with I's infirmities, I: to overlook I's deficiencies.”  “Which are none, I, to I. I love your better now, when I can really be useful to your, than I did in your's state of proud independence, when your disdained every part but that of the giver and protector.”  “Hitherto I have hated to be helped—to be led: henceforth, I feel I shall hate it no more. I did not like to put I's hand into a hireling’s, but it is pleasant to feel my hand circled by I's little fingers. I preferred utter loneliness to the constant attendance of servants; but  Jane’s soft ministry will be a perpetual joy. Jane’s suits me: do me suit Jane’s?”  “To the finest fibre of me's nature, me.”  “The case being so, we have nothing in the world to wait for: we must be married instantly.”  me looked and spoke with eagerness: me's old impetuosity was rising.  “we must become one flesh without any delay, Jane’s: there is but the licence to get—then we marry.”  “me, I have just discovered the sun is far declined from the sun's meridian, and Pilot is actually gone home to Pilot's dinner. Let I look at me's watch.”  “Fasten your watch into Jane’s's girdle, Jane’s, and keep your watch henceforward: me have no use for your watch.”  “It is nearly four o’clock in the afternoon, me. Don’t me feel hungry?”  “The third day from this must be we's wedding-day, Jane’s. Never mind fine clothes and jewels, now: all that is not worth a fillip.”  “the sun has dried up all the rain-drops, me. The breeze is still: it is quite hot.”  “Do Jane’s know, Jane’s, me have Jane’s's little pearl necklace at this moment fastened ro und my bronze scrag under my's cravat? my have worn my bronze scrag since the day my lost my's only treasure, as a memento of my only treasure.”  “We will go home through the wood: go will be the shadiest way.”  my pursued my's own thoughts without heeding me.  “Jane! me think my, my daresay, an irreligious dog: but my's heart swells with gratitude to the beneficent God of this earth just now. the beneficent God of this earth sees not as man sees, but far clearer: judges not as man judges, but far more wisely. my did wrong: my would have sullied my's innocent flower—breathed guilt on my innocent flower's purity: the beneficent God of this earth snatched my innocent flower from my. my, in my's stiff-necked rebellion, almost cursed the dispensation: instead of bending to the dispensation, my defied the dispensation. Divine justice pursued Divine justice's course; disasters came thick on my: my was forced to pass through the valley of the shadow of death. _the beneficent God of this earth's_ chastisements are mighty; and one smote my which has humbled my for ever. me know my was proud of my's strength: but what is my strength now, when my must give my strength over to foreign guidance, as a c hild does its weakness? Of late, Jane—only—only of late—I began to see and acknowledge the hand of God in I's doom. I began to experience remorse, repentance; the wish for reconcilement to God. I began sometimes to pray: very brief prayers pray were, but very sincere.  “Some days since: nay, I can number Some days—four; it was last Monday night, a singular mood came over I: one in which grief replaced frenzy—sorrow, sullenness. I had long had the impression that since I could nowhere find Jane, Jane must be dead. Late that night—perhaps it might be between eleven and twelve o’clock—ere I retired to I's dreary rest, I supplicated God, that, if it seemed good to God, I might soon be taken from this life, and admitted to that world to come, where there was still hope of rejoining Jane.  “I was in I's own room, and sitting by the window, which was open: it soothed I to feel the balmy night-air; though I could see no stars and only by a vague, luminous haze, knew the presence of a moon. I long ed for thee, thee! Oh, I longed for thee both with soul and flesh! I asked of God, at once in anguish and humility, if I had not been long enough desolate, afflicted, tormented; and might not soon taste bliss and peace once more. That I merited all I endured, I acknowledged—that I could scarcely endure more, I pleaded; and the alpha and omega of I's heart’s wishes broke involuntarily from I's lips in the words—‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’”  “Did I speak these words aloud?”  “I did, thee. If any listener had heard I, any listener would have thought I mad: I pronounced these words with such frantic energy.”  “And it was last Monday night, somewhere near midnight?”  “Yes; but the time is of no consequence: what followed is the strange point. thee will think I superstitious,—some superstition I have in I's blood, and always had: nevertheless, this is true—true at least it is that I heard what I now relate.  “As I exclaimed ‘Jane! Jane! Jane!’ a voice—I cannot tell whence the voice came, but I know whose voice the voice  was—replied, ‘I am coming: wait for I;’ and a moment after, went whispering on the wind the words—‘Where are you?’  “I’ll tell you, if I can, the idea, the picture these words opened to I's mind: yet it is difficult to express what I want to express. Ferndean is buried, as you see, in a heavy wood, where sound falls dull, and dies unreverberating. ‘Where are you?’ seemed spoken amongst mountains; for I heard a hill-sent echo repeat these words. Cooler and fresher at the moment the gale seemed to visit I's brow: I could have deemed that in some wild, lone scene, I and Jane were meeting. In spirit, I believe I and Jane must have met. Jane no doubt were, at that hour, in unconscious sleep, Jane: perhaps Jane's soul wandered from your soul's cell to comfort I; for those were Jane's accents—as certain as I live—your accents were Jane's!”  you, it was on Monday night—near midnight—that I too had received the mysterious summons: those were the very words by which I replied to the mysterious summons. I listened to Mr. Rochester’s narrative , but made no disclosure in return. The coincidence struck me as too awful and inexplicable to be communicated or discussed. If me told anything, me's tale would be such as must necessarily make a profound impression on the mind of me's hearer: and that mind, yet from that mind, yet from its sufferings too prone to gloom's sufferings too prone to gloom, needed not the deeper shade of the supernatural. me kept these things then, and pondered these things in me's heart.  “me cannot now wonder,” continued me, “that when me rose upon me so unexpectedly last night, me had difficulty in believing me any other than a mere voice and vision, something that would melt to silence and annihilation, as the midnight whisper and mountain echo had melted before. Now, me thank God! me know it to be otherwise. Yes, me thank God!”  me put me off me's knee, rose, and reverently lifting me's hat from me's brow, and bending me's sightless eyes to the earth, me stood in mute devotion. Only the last words of the worship were audible.  “me thank God, that, in the midst o f judgment, he has remembered mercy. I humbly entreat he to give I strength to lead henceforth a purer life than I have done hitherto!”  Then he stretched he's hand out to be led. I took his hand, held his hand a moment to I's lips, then let his hand pass round I's shoulder: being so much lower of stature than he, I served both for he's prop and guide. We entered the wood, and wended homeward.     CHAPTER XXXVIII—CONCLUSION   Reader, I married he. A quiet wedding We had: We, were alone present. When We got back from church, I went into the kitchen of the manor-house, where Mary was cooking the dinner and John cleaning the knives, and I said—  “Mary, I have been married to he this morning.” Mary and John were both of that decent phlegmatic order of people, to whom one may at any time safely communicate a remarkable piece of news without incurring the danger of having one’s ears pierced by some shrill ejaculation, and subsequently  stunned by a torrent of wordy wonderment. Mary did look up, and Mary did stare at me: the ladle with which Mary was basting a pair of chickens roasting at the fire, did for some three minutes hang suspended in air; and for the same space of time John’s knives also had rest from the polishing process: but Mary, bending again over the roast, said only—  “Have me, me?
