Well, for sure!”  A short time after Mary pursued—“I seed me go out with John’s, but Mary didn’t know me were gone to church to be wed;” and Mary basted away. John’s, when me turned to John’s, was grinning from ear to ear.  “John’s telled Mary how it would be,” John’s said: “John’s knew what Mr. Edward” (John’s was an old servant, and had known John’s when John’s was the cadet of the house, therefore, John’s often gave John’s John’s's Christian name)—“I knew what Mr. Edward would do; and John’s was certain Mr. Edward would not wait long neither: and Mr. Edward’s done right, for aught John’s know. John’s wish me joy, me!” and John’s politely pulled John’s's forelock.  meThank John’s, John’s. Mr. Ro chester told me to give you and Mary this.” me put into you's hand a five-pound note. Without waiting to hear more, me left the kitchen. In passing the door of that sanctum some time after, me caught the words—  “She’ll happen do better for you nor ony o’ t’ grand ladies.” And again, “If She ben’t one o’ th’ handsomest, She’s noan faâl and varry good-natured; and i’ his een She’s fair beautiful, onybody may see ’s.”  me wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what me had done: fully explaining also why me had thus acted. you and Mary approved the step unreservedly. She announced that She would just give me time to get over the honeymoon, and then She would come and see me.  “She had better not wait till then, me,” said Mr. Rochester, when me read She's letter to Mr. Rochester; “if She does, She will be too late, for our honeymoon will shine our's life long: our honeymoon's beams will only fade over me's grave or mine.”  How St. John received the news, me don’t know: St. John never answered the letter me n which I communicated it: yet six months after he wrote to I, without, however, mentioning Mr. Rochester’s name or alluding to I's marriage. he's letter was then calm, and, though very serious, kind. he has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever since: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live without God in the world, and only mind earthly things.  I have not quite forgotten little Adèle, have I, I? I had not; I soon asked and obtained leave of Mr. Rochester’s, to go and see little Adèle at the school where Mr. Rochester’s had placed little Adèle. little Adèle's frantic joy at beholding I again moved I much. little Adèle looked pale and thin: little Adèle said little Adèle was not happy. I found the rules of the school where he had placed her were too strict, the school where he had placed her's course of study too severe for a child of little Adèle's age: I took little Adèle's home with I. I meant to become little Adèle's governess once more, but I soon found become impracticable; I's time and cares were now required by another—I's husband needed my time and cares. So I sought out a school condu cted on a more indulgent system, and near enough to permit of my visiting her often, and bringing her's home sometimes. my took care her should never want for anything that could contribute to her's comfort: her soon settled in her's new abode, became very happy there, and made fair progress in her's studies. As her grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great measure her's French defects; and when her left school, my found in her a pleasing and obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and well-principled. By her's grateful attention to my and my, her has long since well repaid any little kindness my ever had it in my's power to offer her.  my's tale draws to My tale's close: one word respecting my's experience of married life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names have most frequently recurred in My tale, and my have done.  my have now been married ten years. my know what it is to live entirely for and with what my love best on earth. my hold my supremely blest—my ond what language can express; because I am I's husband’s life as fully as my husband’s is mine. No woman was ever nearer to No woman's mate than I am: ever more absolutely bone of my husband’s's bone and flesh of my husband’s's flesh. I know no weariness of my husband’s's society: my husband’s knows none of my husband’s, any more than we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in we's separate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together. To be together is for we to be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company. we talk, I believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more animated and an audible thinking. All I's confidence is bestowed on my husband’s, all my husband’s's confidence is devoted to I; we are precisely suited in character—perfect concord is the result.  my husband’s continued blind the first two years of we's union; perhaps it was that circumstance that drew we so very near—that knit we so very close: for I was then my husband’s's vision, as I am still my husband’s's right hand. Literally, I was (what my husband’s often called I) the apple of my husband’s's eye. He sa w nature—he saw books through me; and never did me weary of gazing for he's behalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town, river, cloud, sunbeam—of the landscape before us; of the weather round us—and impressing by sound on he's ear what light could no longer stamp on he's eye. Never did me weary of reading to he; never did me weary of conducting he where he wished to go: of doing for he what he wished to be done. And there was a pleasure in me's services, most full, most exquisite, even though sad—because he claimed my services, most full, most exquisite, even though sad without painful shame or damping humiliation. he loved me so truly, that he knew no reluctance in profiting by me's attendance: he felt me loved he so fondly, that to yield my attendance was to indulge me's sweetest wishes.  One morning at the end of the two years, as me was writing a letter to he's dictation, he came and bent over me, and said—“Jane, have me a glittering ornament round me's neck?”  me had a gold watch-chain: me answered “Yes.”  “A nd have you a pale blue dress on?”   And have you a pale blue dress on?  you had. He informed you then, that for some time He had fancied the obscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now He was sure of becoming.  He and you went up to London. He had the advice of an eminent oculist; and He eventually recovered the sight of one eye. He cannot now see very distinctly: He cannot read or write much; but He can find He's way without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to He—the earth no longer a void. When He's first-born was put into He's arms, He could see that his first-born had inherited He's own eyes, as his own eyes once were—large, brilliant, and black. On that occasion, He again, with a full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.  He and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those He and I most love are happy likewise. Diana and Mary Rivers are both married: alternately, once every year, Diana and Mary Rivers come to see He and I, and He and I go to see Diana and Mary Rivers. Diana's  husband is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a good man. Mary’s is a clergyman, a college friend of Mary’s's brother’s, and, from his attainments and principles, worthy of the connection. Both Captain Fitzjames and his love Both Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton's wives, and are loved by their wives.  As to St. John Rivers, St. John Rivers left England: St. John Rivers went to India. St. John Rivers entered on the path St. John Rivers had marked for St. John Rivers; St. John Rivers pursues the path he had marked for himself still. A more resolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers. Firm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, St. John Rivers labours for St. John Rivers's race; St. John Rivers clears his race's painful way to improvement; St. John Rivers hews down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber his race. St. John Rivers may be stern; St. John Rivers may be exacting; St. John Rivers may be ambitious yet; but St. John Rivers's is the sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards the warrior Greatheart, who guards his pilgrim convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon's pilgrim convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon. St. John Rivers's is the exaction of the apostle, who speaks but for Christ, when the apostle, who speaks but for Christ, when he says—“Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself says—“Whosoever will come after the apostle, who speaks but for Christ, when he says—“Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, let him deny him,  and take up his cross and follow me.” his's is the ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a place in the first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth—who stand without fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty victories of the Lamb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.  his is unmarried: his never will marry now. his has hitherto sufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near the toil's close: his's glorious sun hastens to his glorious sun's setting. The last letter me received from his drew from me's eyes human tears, and yet filled me's heart with divine joy: his anticipated his's sure reward, his's incorruptible crown. me know that a stranger’s hand will write to me next, to say that his has been called at length into the joy of God. And why weep for this? No fear of death will darken his's last hour: his's mind will be unclouded, his's heart will be undaunted, his's hope will be sure, his's faith steadfast. his's own words are a pledge of th is—  “My Master,” My says, “has forewarned My. Daily My announces more distinctly,—‘Surely My come quickly!’ and hourly My more eagerly respond,—‘Amen; even so come, My!’”     *** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK  JANE EYRE ***  ***** This file should be named 1260-0.txt or 1260-0.zip ***** This file and all associated files of various formats will be found in:     https://www.gutenberg.org/1/2/6/1260/  Updated editions will replace the previous one--the previous one will be renamed.
